Hugo Boss is obviously known for making some of the best suits and fragrances in the world and 'Boss in Motion' is no exception. This is a perfectly sized cologne to travel with, it smells great and was very well designed (reminiscent of the 'Thermal Detonator' from Star Wars).

Wow, this thing is awesome. In the picture there is nothing shown to reference size but the egg is much bigger than I expected. Love the way it looks, the facehugger seems very screen accurate although much smaller but the glowing effect kind of makes this piece overall. If you turn off the lights when the egg is on, the low green glow will remind you exactly of seeing all those xenomorph eggs in Aliens.
The original and still the best, a great classic, vintage style James Bond poster suitable for any man cave.
Pretty good Chewbacca figure, it's not quite screen accurate but it is an older release and basically a classic at this point.

Love this original Terminator T-800 endoskeleton, however it is a bit smaller than I expected for some reason. Looks great in my collection thought and I would recommend it to anyone who is a collector.

Without question Enter the Dragon is the best Bruce Lee movie out there. Things that were exhibited in this film had not been previously demonstrated in any of Lee's other headlining movies, such as quality production design, substantial plot and characters and the use of Bruce Lee's actual voice which led us to finally hearing some of his spiritual insight and now some of his most famous quotes. Enter the Dragon is essentially a kung-fu/spy movie hybrid, looking to have been influenced by James Bond. Even the villain in the movie had James Bond villain traits, the white cat, a removable hand and a mirror room (featured in The Man With the Golden Gun).There are a few scenes where the dialogue is unbelievably corny ("Man, you come right out of a comic book"), and if it wasn't made in the 1970's that might be an issue. It is also not hard to see that there are very few actual martial artists in the film besides Lee. Unlike when you see a Jackie Chan movie where he has his own team of martial artists to help authenticate the fight scenes. It's a shame Lee passed away only days before this films release, it seems someone had just figured out how to capture the essence of his greatness.

I ventured out to build myself a home theater, looking for the best quality products without spending an arm or a leg on anything. I came by Carl's DIY section and after seeing all the good reviews decided to give the screen a shot. Here's the deal on the 'projector screen'. When you think of a projector screen you probably have an idea in mind of the type of material it's going to be. I paid the extra $20 to have the fabric rolled instead of folded, as I did not want to mess with having to get out any creases in the screen. As it turns out the material is very soft and pliable like fabric, opposed to a sturdier canvas like projector screen that I thought it would be, so I probably didn't need to spend the extra $20 after all.The quality of the fabric is good and seems to work well with a projected image. However, if you do not have a plan on exactly what you are going to do with the material, you may find yourself at a crossroads. Carl recommends buying lumber and constructing your own frame for the screen, then stretching the material over the frame, and stapling it to the edges, finally adding Carl's 'contrast boosting border' (very nice marketing phrase) to the edges of the frame. If that seems like an inordinate amount of work to you, there are other options.Since my projector didn't quite fill up the 66x110-inch space at the recommended viewing distance (most people's won't), I had to do something about the excess screen that was effectively washing out the picture. You will definitely need something to line the edges of your screen and ideally it should be black. What I did was first paint the wall I was projecting on black (highly recommended). After putting the fabric on the wall (which you have to be careful when doing so you do not create any ripples in the screen) I then hung a black piece of fabric on the ceiling so the projection would be absorbed rather than bounced off of the white ceiling. Finally I used the same black fabric to outline my screen so the only thing showing was the projected image. Overall, I would suggest this method or a similar one to save yourself excess time and money in the end.

It's rare that a film will exude such raw and powerful emotion that is just as rooted in truth as it is in it's fiction. When The Breakfast Club was released in 1985, teenagers of the era were stunned by the profound revelation of hearing and seeing problems that they actually experienced.In one way or another anyone could relate to one or more of the 5 archetypes and be emotionally invested in what they had to say. It isn't particularly surprising that over 25 years later many of these core issues remain the same in the life of the American adolescent.Each actor helped contribute their piece to this seminal film, but perhaps none better than Ally Sheedy's character, the basket case. The young actors connected with their characters enough to make them incredibly believable and thus they connected with their audience. The film's eulogy gives it it's fitting and iconic ending.

Beautiful, comedic, inspired, adventurous, insightful and heartfelt, these are just a few of the adjectives that well describe Ben Stiller's  remake of The Secret Life of Walter Mitty. It is honestly one of Ben Stiller's best outings as an actor and probably the best film he's ever directed. One of the most interesting aspects about this movie is simply that you do not know what to expect next.The film is very well rounded and has a general appeal to all who would watch. Many may claim that the film is boring or too slow, unfortunately for them, they just aren't watching close enough. The movie is about Life, literally. The movie is about Life magazine and a 16 year tenured employee who has yet to do much with his. Something that you might not expect from a movie like this is the incredible cinematography (perfectly accented by the blu-ray release). There is much more to Walter Mitty than meets the eye and thats how the movie is too. The Secret Life of Walter Mitty is a very enjoyable watch and I highly recommend it.

I'm the kind of guy that actually gives remakes like these a chance before condemning them, I even went to see the Total Recall remake in theaters. But there were things about this RoboCop remake that I just couldn't get over. First of all, taking the rating down to a PG-13 when remaking an R-rated film is usually a mistake. How could you possibly emulate the essence of the original film, known for it's particular brand of violence, by dropping the rating? On top of that not release an unrated cut?I was a fan of the tech in the 'not-too-distant-future', especially the Omnicorp machines, RoboCop's bike and all the hologram interfaces (even though they didn't do much for the cars but throw hubcaps on em). I was not really a fan of the over-emotional tone throughout the movie, there wasn't really enough run and gun action/violence to balance out all the "I'm a monster" scenes. When I first heard Joel Kinnaman from AMC's 'The Killing' was going to be the new Alex Murphy, I didn't know how I felt about it. After watching the movie and seeing that he basically plays a similar character, I still don't know how I feel about it.Samuel L Jackson's "The Novak Element" bit served as something of a right winged Greek chorus for the film and was mildly amusing. Finally at the end of the movie there is a big action scene, but the CG seemed a little too flimsy for it to feel authentic. Instead RoboCop ends up just looking like Spider-man jumping and flipping around. If you're a die hard fan of the original you probably won't care much for the remake, otherwise it's good for some entertainment.

Days of Future Past is a lot more than just an X-Men movie. It is the union of two X-Men film series', Bryan Singer's X-Men from 2000 and X2 2003 (as well as Brett Ratner's The Last Stand 2006) and Matthew Vaughn's X-Men First Class from 2011, with Singer returning to direct for DoFP. Based off of one of the most popular X-Men graphic novels of the same name, this movie experiments with the idea of time travel.From the second the movie starts we are thrown into an engrossing scene of explosive action. Without giving anything away, DoFP essentially acts as both a sequel to Singer's films and Vaughn's First Class. One of the most interesting aspect about this is that we are able to see original characters from the first X-Men movies as well as new characters from First Class and even more (there are tons of great easter eggs hidden throughout this one).There isn't a lot of over the top action in this X-Men movie like there is in some of the previous installments. Instead a much heavier focus is on the story, which is incredibly deep, and the characters, which are equally as complex. Overall there is a lot to enjoy about this entry if you are a fan of the previous films, it is indeed a contender for the best X-Men movie thus far.

No sweeping score, no dastardly villains and no incredible tension. When Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid was released in 1969, the Western genre of film was already decades old. The world had long since been introduced to John Ford and John Wayne, Sergio Leone and Clint Eastwood, but what they hadn't been introduced to yet, was a movie like this. What you get when you watch this movie is a contemporary American Western classic.With one of the greatest onscreen pairings of Paul Newman and Robert Redford, this movie comes off as fun more than anything else. The music performed by Burt Bacharach and the addition of the song "Raindrops Keep Fallin' on My Head" is a huge change of pace from the grande Elmer Bernstein or whistling Ennio Morricone type scores. Not to say that it is completely devoid of all Western film archetypes. The movie is beautifully shot by Conrad Hall (Cool Hand Luke, The Professionals) and features great American Western terrain and landscapes.I wouldn't necessarily label Butch Cassidy as a Western Comedy, but you can't deny the comedic banter in the film. It's easy to watch, it's enjoyable, it's entertaining and sometimes it's even exciting, what else could you ask for?

Up until this point John Carpenter has directed the likes of Halloween, The Fog, Escape From New York, The Thing and Christine, all of which have a very distinguished John Carpenter signature to them. Starman is more of a melodramatic romantic film with science fiction implications, if you like that sorta thing. Truly nothing like the aforementioned movies, and if thats what you're expecting you will likely be disappointed.

Theatrical Cut Review:Payback is a hard boiled, neo-noir crime thriller with comical and satirical elements, featuring a great Mel Gibson character and a straight up revenge plot. The movie has a very cold and dark feel to it along with a gritty film look that sets the tone for the story.It's filled with lots of great cliche's and archetype characters along with smart mouthed dialogue which helps distinguish it from your run of the mill revenge flick. The story is about a man, Porter, who gets two timed and will now do anything necessary to get back the $70,000 (not $130,000) that should rightfully be his. Payback is entertaining and a must watch for fans of Mel Gibson.

Chinese Connection, or Fist of Fury as it's known, is one of Bruce Lee's few headliner movies. It is definitely better than The Big Boss but not as good as Enter the Dragon. Based on the death of real life Chinese folk hero Huo Yuanjia, fictional character and Yuanjia disciple Chen seeks vengeance for his master.One of the most unfortunate things about both Chinese Connection and The Big Boss is that they suffer from poor filmmaking. If you compare both of these films to the Shaw Brothers kung-fu films of the same time you will recognize major differences in quality favoring the Shaw productions, such as choreography, production design, special effects, cinematography and even score. There's not a lot of fight scenes in the movie but the few that there are have contributed to making Bruce Lee the legend that he became.

The Magnificent Seven is known as the American Western remake of Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai. It is a great all-star ensemble Western with a recognizable story and many familiar faces. In my opinion it is not one of the best Western's ever made and I wouldn't even put it in the top 10.But where else will you see Steve McQueen, Yul Brenner, Charles Bronson, James Coburn and Eli Wallach all in the same place? It's worth pointing out that Charlie Bronson later appeared in Once Upon a Time in the West, Eli Wallach in The Good, The Bad and The Ugly and James Coburn in Fistful of Dynamite, all directed by Sergio Leone.

Is Rumble in the Bronx the greatest Jackie Chan movie ever made? Definitely not. But is it a hell of a lot of fun to watch? Definitely. When you think about your average Jackie Chan flick, one of the first titles that probably comes up is Rumble in the Bronx. When it was filmed Jackie was already 40 years old, but that didn't stop him from pulling out some of the greatest stunt and fight scenes of his career.The plot may not be profound but when Jackie Chan's concerned, it usually doesn't need to be. The action in this movie is constant and probably doesn't go 10 minutes in the 90 minute movie without something cool happening. If you like Jackie Chan movies you will probably enjoy Rumble in the Bronx.

Although Bruce Lee had been in movies and television quite a while before this, The Big Boss was really his breakout movie. The martial arts scenes may not be very good and certainly pale in comparison to some of the Shaw productions of that time, but this movie was more of a segue to Lee's later and significantly better films.There is nothing special about the barely audible dialogue or semi-generic story, but what's more is that there are hardly any Bruce Lee fight scenes for the first 40 mins of the movie. The Big Boss has a raw classic 1970's cinema feel but one of it's biggest problems is that there is no driving force in the movie or interesting or memorable characters outside of Bruce Lee.Unfortunately the production quality of the film is pretty poor, the special effects are weak and it almost just seems like someone grabbed Bruce Lee, a camera and a couple of other guys with mediocre martial arts abilities then decided to make a movie. The dog dodging scene towards the end relies on very amateur trick photography and at this point is just comical. The films most redeeming quality is the final fight scene where, in his vengeance, Bruce Lee holds nothing back.

Desperado was Robert Rodriguez's first movie playing with house money, the result proved that he was indeed a capable filmmaker. Since the $7,000 budget of El Mariachi was financed solely by Rodriguez himself, being able to see what he could do with an incrementally larger budget ($7 million) gave him a chance to show that he wasn't just a one hit wonder.On the outside Desperado may just look like a generic 90's action movie with Mexican flair (it may on the inside a little too), but what it really showed was the potential of a talented filmmaker and ultimately the world that he would create with his Mexican Western trilogy. The nods to movies like Hard Boiled, Fistful of Dollars and various John Carpenter flicks aren't very hard to spot, luckily they became a bit more subtle in his films over time. One of the most notable things to come out of Desperado were the introductions of Antonio Banderas and Salma Hayek to the world, ultimately changing both of their careers forever.

Don't be fooled by the generic title, this movie is anything but generic. As my review title suggests, the film looks to have had a clear influence from the American movie "A History of Violence". The same premise of a man with a history of violence taking on a new identity to escape his past is used in both films.One of the main differences between the films, aside from the obvious setting, is the detective and neo-noir element used in Dragon. Through the amazing cinematography we see a great scope of the world in Southern China, where a story is laid out in front of us, although it may not be exactly what it appears. This not an action movie but rather a well paced and well shot, story driven crime drama with kung-fu inspiration. The fight scenes in the film are intense and have been excellently choreographed.

In The Mechanic (before Death Wish) Charles Bronson solidified his role in the creation of tough guy cinema, which essentially started with his role as The Man With the Harmonica in Once Upon a Time in the West. It is important to note that there is no character dialogue for the first 15 minutes of the movie. This element was basically born in the Spaghetti Western and demonstrated in Sergio Leone's masterpiece The Good, The Bad and The Ugly.Like Death Wish, The Mechanic exhibits many classic features of 1970's cinema. For example, towards the beginning of the film there are many psychedelic qualities that were influenced by the year of the film, 1972. No doubt The Mechanic showcases one of Bronson's best characters and keeps a solid story, but let's be honest, the supporting acts aren't great. Nevertheless, there is something about watching a movie about a hitman who has an appreciation for the arts. Luckily, unlike Death Wish, there were not a slew of sequels for The Mechanic (for obvious reasons).

No matter which side of the political aisle you are on, you have to laugh at this. It really is wonderful. Not only does this book contain several ACTUAL paper dolls to punch out and dress, but it also has three pop-out settings to "play" with  your dolls in. My favorite doll pages are "The First Gentleman" and the "White House Ghosts". This is a clever and funny gift for anyone, and will make a fun conversation piece, no matter how you feel about this woman.

Patrick Ness, as an author, has a voice that is so distinctly his own, that his books are incredibly easy to distinguish from the mass of all the other nearly-identical YA novels out there. And, while I am not always the biggest fan of his books, I AM ALWAYS a fan of his ideas and the unique style in which he hashes them out. Does that make sense? I admire his uniqueness and artistry as an author, though, in general I don't particularly love his books.Until now.The Rest of Us Just Live Here, is, by far, my favorite of his works to date. It manages to capture his unique twist on the world in the most perfectly nuanced way. It manages to be cheeky and clever, while also making fun of itself, and is still totally page-turning and immersive. I truly can't say enough about this book and how utterly unique it is - it's not hilarious, it's not genius, but it IS funny and smart, and unlike any other book you've read, in all the best kind of ways. It's predictable, in a sense, but the familiarity is due to the reverent satire woven throughout the story. It's no wonder everyone is talking about this book right now, don't miss this one!

So far I really like the projector. This is the second projector I’ve owned and there we a couple notable differences:This projector has a great lumen output of 3000 lumens. I could see the image clearly even with the windows open.The replacement bulb cost looks to be less than my current infocus projector… I shopped around a bit and found them for under $200.I also like the foam filter on the air intake. I’m sure it cuts down on noise and reduces dust intake.One thing I wasn’t super fond of was the limited projector location VS screen size ratio. I have a large living room and was hoping to put the projector on one end of the room, the screen on the other. Without reading the manual I set it up as such. I quickly found that as marketed, this is for home use, not a long conference room. When projecting across my long living room, the image was WAY larger than my screen. I tried leveraging both the mechanical adjustment on the top of the unit as well as the digital screen adjustments, but couldn’t get the image small enough. I’d say as a rule of thumb the diagonal size of your image is about the length the projector will need to be away from the screen.I think this is an economical, high performance unit built with maintenance and longevity in mind. More adjustability in the screen size would have been nice, but it’s all there in the marketing material and intended for home use… I think most “theater rooms” are smaller rooms in a basement and this projector would be perfect.Be warned though, like most projectors, this thing put out some serious HEAT. Where ever it is placed, make sure you have good ventilation!

We loved the look of this desk for our son, who is in 2nd grade and needs to have a desk in his room now for home work, and of course, for housing various Lego projects. The size was just right for his needs, and the look is very sleek and adult-looking, so he loves it. However, getting to the finished product was NOT an easy task at all. The directions were not easy to follow, and fairly useless. Once put together it is a good desk for what it is - pressed particle board. It will last him a few years, hopefully.

After being told my my electrical engineer husband to not expect too much from this, as plugging multiple headphones in would result in the loss of sound quality for all, I wasn't expecting too much from this product. But after plugging it in to our laptop and plugging FIVE sets of headphones in, we were ALL surprised that there was no noticeable loss of sound! Hooray! This will be a much-used item for road trips in our future.

I generally make a point to skip books that heavily involve infidelity, but I was interested in the premise of this one, so I made an exception. I was really surprised at how much I liked this book, based on the reviews that I read for it. Honestly, I felt like the main character Marci was NOT as unlikable as many reviewers said she was. I felt like instead of being an anti-hero character, as I had expected, she really was just a regular girl who sort of found herself in a bad situation. The book evoked real emotional responses for me, and I felt like the characters evolved. The little part in the middle where we get a few chapters set tn years in the past was a bit unconventional, but I felt really helped to hash out the characters better and give us a better picture of who they are. I didn't always buy some of the romantic interactions, and we weren't always shown why she makes some of the choices she makes, but this is a first novel, it can't be perfect. It's not exactly a light-hearted, funny read, but it's not as heavy and dreary as I had expected, either (based on other reviews). Over all I really enjoyed the book and the settings and the characters and felt it was a read worth my time. And the thank you note near the end made me laugh out loud :)

I have to admit, I am not really a fan of tic tacs. The fact that they are too hard for my teeth, and have sugar in them means I rarely buy them. But this new flavor - cherry cola - suckered me in. I cannot resist anything cherry cola flavored! They are trying a new layering technique here, which I think really works. When you first put it in your mouth, all you taste is cherry. When you bite into it (and halleluia, they aren't as hard as normal tic tacs!!) you immediately get a tart burst of cola flavor. Because they have kept the two flavors separate, you get a TRUE cherry cola flavor. Honestly, I think it's better than actual cherry cola, in which I often feel like you can't even taste the distinct cherry flavor. These are a winner in my book - i ate the whole box within an hour of opening the package!

I love Annie Chun's seaweed snacks and have been eating them for years. All the flavors are delicious and satisfy a salty craving without many calories. These new crisps are the same seaweed snack but magically fused with a thin rice cracker. The texture is wonderful, and filling, again with fewer calories than chips, so they are a good snack.However, I must say that I was VERY disappointed that these have a blatantly sweet and sugary flavor. First of all, I just don't think it pairs well with the seaweed and rice, and secondly, it's simply unnecessary! These would be fantastic without the sugar, so why add it?? I'd be very interested to try some other flavors and see if they are better and do not have the annoying sugar added, because I very much enjoy this new type of snack!

I got this for my daughter for her third birthday. She absolutely LOVES it! It's about 2/3 as big as her (so, HUGE to a toddler!) and durable but soft and lovable. I was surprised at how well-made it seems, and hope this will bring her lots of cuddles and fun!

I was anxious to receive this product for multiple reasons:* Supply clean power to my router and modem* Extend internet connectivity through power outages* Mobile battery for rechargingAs a networking hobbyist I've invested a fair amount of time into my router configuration (DD-WRT). While I can export my config files, I'd rather be proactive in supplying clean power in an effort to extend device life. This product is marketed to provide constant voltage and frequency (115VAC +- 8%, 60Hz +- 1Hz).Being a hobbyist, I enjoy buying super cheap routers and flashing them with advanced (ie - expensive) software features. Unfortunately cheap routers implies low cost hardware... I figure that if I supply good clean power, I'll get longer life out of it.Along with many others, we've abandoned a traditional land line telephone - relying exclusively on cell phones. The trick is if the power goes out and our cell battery is low, it can induce a complexity in maintaining communication. Additionally, there may be times when the local cell tower also loses power along with the house. If my local ISP / DSL is still up this battery backup will provide about an hour of additional communication (internet based texting / facetime) incase of emergency.I really like the utility of the mobile battery. While the battery is charged in the device, it can also be charged with common USB cable. If you go on an extended trip this flexibility is great! The other cool thing is that when these batteries wear out, they're easily replaced some day.I have confirmed the unit's ability to power a light load in the case of wall power loss (un-plugged). I have not confirmed the exact time span of the battery feeding my modem and router but I'd expect at least 30 minutes...Things that would have been cool:A way to mute the lights.A way to choose light vs sound for power status notifications.Network connectivity telling me status:* power quality in* power quality out* Watts in* Watts out* battery state of charge* battery condition (estimated life)* time and date of last power outage* Estimated time on battery backup (relative to immediate load).So far I'm very happy with it though.

This chemistry kit was enjoyed by my two older kids, ages 7 and 5, quite a bit. I felt that it was rather simplistic for the price, and the directions were overly wordy. Additionally, it's not actually NINE experiments, there are maybe four actual experiments (its been a couple of weeks since we did this, my memory is failing me here) and the rest of the "nine" are simply small twists or suggested idea to explore a little further within the existing experiments. Not a big deal, as what we were able to do was fun and educational for the kids, but felt a bit like a minor rip-off. Still, this kit was great fun for my kids, so it was well worth the time we put into it.

Very nice dress pants for school, special occasion, or church. Durable, which is great for boys! Our pair came with a dark blue belt instead of the khaki colored one shown, which was fine. Nice fit - VERY long, but I can hem them. My boy is slim but not too skinny, and the waist size was fine for him, especially with the adjustable elastic.***EDIT*** Knocking off a couple of stars because after the 2nd wearing (hadn't been washed, though!) the metal pronged tab that helps keep the fly closed came off. I put it back in and tried to bend the prongs again so it would stay, and it popped off again five minutes later! So NOW they have to ALWAYS be worn with a belt OR I have to sew a button hole and button on to them.Honestly, now that I have to do that AND hem them, I'm getting annoyed with these pants. They're just plain khakis that you can get at any Walmart or Target, just because they have a "fancy" name on them doesn't make them ANY better quality.

These are cute, although not terribly sturdy. My son says they are comfortable. The big issue is in getting them ON. They are a BEAR to put on! WHY?? It's a huge struggle, usually involving several family members to get these things on his feet. Once on they fit perfectly!

I ordered what Amazon lists as a size "XL". I am already extremely leery of ordering clothing from Amazon because so much of it is "Asian sizing" which runs 1-2 sizes smaller than US sizing, and their listings rarely reflect this difference. But i checked the size chart for this product, and it seemed like the sizing they listed was accurate to "US sizing". So, I purchased the "XL", which is my normal size. What arrived, however, was very distinctly NOT XL. The tag inside says "L/XL" , which first of all, had I KNOWN that is how these pants were sized I WOULD NOT HAVE ORDERED THEM! Anyone who is a size XL can tell you that ANYTHING listed as "L/XL" NEVER FITS. Amazon, you need to FIX that error in the listing!  So right off the bat I was unsure of these pants. They looked TINY, but i thought maybe they stretch a lot? Then, as I try to pull them up over my calves I realize there's NO WAY these are even a size US Large, let alone the XL they were supposed to be. Honestly, I'm SO MAD. These pants that ARE SUPPOSED TO BE a size US XL are actually more like a US Medium. Which means they are now wholly and utterly useless to me. Lesson learned, if you want cheap Chinese clothes, just buy them at Walmart where you can at least SEE the size of the clothes before you buy them.

After getting this item, I decided to use it in my PC instead of a Playstation… long story. I just formatted it and it ran in my PC – no big deal.Relative to the info above this is my review:Cons:  * For a drive specifically marketed for Playstation usage, I found the accompanying documentation rather weak. If you want to instructions regarding the installation into a Playstation, you’ll need to hit Google, Youtube, or the Seagate web site.  * Packaged as an “OEM drive”. This is fine for the Playstation, but if you want to use in a PC, you’ll need to come up with your own SATA cable and screws.Pros:  * Very slim drive – even among 2.5 drives.  * Seems fast in my desktop (I did not formally benchmark).  * Standard PC mounting holes facilitate usage in places other than Playstation.Overall it's a good drive no matter how you want to use it.

This is by far the nicest knife I own. The handle is beautiful, and while, upon close inspection it seems that the parts of the handle could have been made to be more flush than they are, this fact doesn't seem to irritate the hand when using the knife. So far I have used it for many things and have been pleased at the knife's performance on everything. This is a true treasure in my kitchen.

As someone who tends to be light-handed with makeup, i was leery of trying this blush because I was afraid it would be too dark. But I loved the look the of the color for fall so I went ahead and tried it. I must say that I simply love this. It is easy to apply, you don't even know you're wearing it, and the color is light and natural and warm. It's just beautiful.

This coat is cute and VERY warm. Not weather-proofed, but I can fix that with a can of scotch guard. The ends of the sleeves are awkward and not well made. An extra row of stitching would greatly improve the look there. The main issue with this is THE SIZE. Thankfully I read the reviews and ordered accordingly. So my teeny-tiny 2.5 year old, who normally is a little small for 3T sizes, fits exactly perfectly in the size 4. So be aware, you MUST order a size up or this coat will be useless to you!

This sweater is gorgeous and seems to be well-made. But it is GIGANTIC!! My very slim 5 year old is just now wearing size 6, so i ordered a 6... and it fits like a 7/8! It could easily fit my 8 year old.

This sweater is a beautiful color and quite soft. The neck is super awkward, though, and the whole thing is just gigantic. I'm a solid size 16 and the XL is giant on me. But its really snuggly, so I'll keep it. It also has elbow patches that are super cute.

I often keep a few cans or boxes of tomato soup on hand for those times (in the fall or winter) when I need to whip up a quick dinner. I only used pre-made soups as a base for my own homemade soups when I don't have a lot of time. Throw in some rice, veggies, a little chicken or ground beef, and you have a lovely soup that doesn't taste like it came from a factory. This particular non-homemade soup is about average. It doesn't have any more or less flavor than its non-organic counterparts, and the texture is about the same as well. This really isn't anything fancy. Not great, not bad, it's just.... plain tomato soup. Does anyone actually eat tomato soup JUST plain? I mean isn't that just watered down tomato paste? Anyway, it works great as a base for a semi-homemade soup, but honestly, I don't think it's good for much else.

My second grader is head over heels in love with this book! He is a born reader, always deep into some book or another, so although this is a bit meatier than books he has previously read, he is powering though it. Every day he reads a chapter or two and has LOADS of information to share with me about what he has read. Amazing facts and stories are coming out of his mouth at random times all day long and when I ask him where he learned what he is talking about the answer is always the same: "I learned it from the Bubba Jones book!" This wonderful book is filled full of geography, history, and science, all told in the frame of an engaging novel, and it includes cute illustrations and some handy maps of presumably real places. I can't even tell you how much we are looking forward to many, many more installations in this series and we hope they are published SOON! He cannot wait to explore more National parks with Bubba and Hug-a-Bug!

After several days of using the TP-Link AV1200, I can say I'm quite pleased with their performance.First, let me say that I am not using them in their most commonly intended environment and application. In reading their documentation, they seem designed to provide higher bandwidth and stable connectivity to devices like TVs. They're also MUCH easier to set up than secure WiFI. I think this would perfectly suit the bill for that application.My application scenario:I have a metal out building about 50 yards from my home. I have 220VAC to the building, but not ethernet cable. I fiddled around for over a year with wireless adapters / bridges / gateways, but was never happy with their reliability, security, or performance. I've been aware of these power line bridges for some time, but finally took the leap. I quickly learned a few things.1. The performance is improved by at least of factor of 10x when on the same 110V leg of your 220V breaker.2. There seems to be a performance drop going across multiple sub-panels (but still works!).3. In the few days I've been running them, they seem to handle HIGH ambient temps (130F) without issue (we are in Arizona in the summer!).So far I'm loving them. I'm sort of old school- if the PC is physically static (not a laptop), I vastly prefer a wired ethernet connection. These bridges are 100% transparent to my network - everything just works! I haven't tried WOL packets yet, but so far they totally meet my expectations. For my application - running across 3 subpannels, varying power wire gauges, all sorts of noise, etc -  I can still sustain 7 MB / s file transfers. Less than advertised, but a reasonable 100Mb/s connection in my book - kills my wireless attempts. I can now access my network and web with speed and security.If you're running WiFi to a desktop PC instead of these - you're doing it wrong!

I've long been a fan of Food Should Taste Good products. They are made with quality ingredients and you can trust that what they say you are eating is exactly what you are eating. These black bean chips may be in my top three favorites of theirs. It is not as flavorful as some of their other products, but still has a deep, wholesome, satisfying flavor. My family very much enjoyed these and the bag didn't even last a whole hour between the five of us chowing down on them.

This is a fun and unique read for older elementary school kids (or adults, too!) filled with pictures and interesting information. Any kid who loved planes, cars, any thing mechanical, or inventing will enjoy this book. My son is seven, but reads at a fourth grade level. He found this book a little lengthy at times, but still very much enjoyed it.

Tried this out for several days on my two daughters eczema patches. It seemed to help a little, though not as good as some other lotions we have used before. The main problem with this is that it seems to sting awfully. I put it on my own (non-eczema) dry skin patches and it felt fine. But my girls, who are used to having eczema treated, screamed and screamed whenever I put this on them. That's a very uncharacteristic reaction for both of them. So, regardless of the effectiveness of this cream, I will not continue to use it as it seems to cause pain for my girls.

This is exactly everything that I love in a cereal. High in nutrients (hello protein and fiber!), low in sugar, and tastes AWESOME! I can eat this stuff right out of the bag, but it's not sugary like most granolas. It has such a mild, pleasant taste, fresh and earthy from the oats and pumpkin seeds, nutty from the almonds, slightly sweet from the blueberries, raisins, and cranberries. I could (and plan to!) eat this EVERY day. This is an absolute home run  for breakfast!

First off, if you want to order these during the summer and/or you live in a warm climate, be warned that they will likely NOT be "gummies" when the arrive, but rather, each package will contain one long, sticky gummy that is QUITE difficult to extract from the package. Mine came to me in Arizona in July, BUT I actually grabbed them from my mail carrier at 9:30am, so they weren't on a hot porch all day, and weren't in a hot car for too long; and yet they were still a gelatinous mess that I had to stick int he fridge before I could even attempt to open. This is obviously more a function of Amazon's packaging and the USPS driving around in the heat rather than a reflection on the actual product, but it's something to be aware of.Second thing to be aware of - the FIRST ingredient is corn syrup. I get it, they're gummies, they aren't meant to be TOO terribly healthy. They're meant to pump you full of sugar that you will burn of quickly. But the corn syrup alone made me certain I'd never get these again after this box is finished. I work too hard on my body to be putting that kind of crap into it.The flavor is pleasant, though a little... strange? I guess it's all the electrolyte minerals. But it's an enjoyable little snack after a workout. Each package even contains 2g of protein, so they're not a total loss, nutritionally.Overall, the product really isn't THAT bad. I just feel like there are a lot of other things that are healthier and will replenish me after a workout better than these.

This powder is a nice little tool to help get you through the day. It dissolves almost instantly and has no color or flavor. My favorite way to use this fiber powder and stay hydrated is to chop a strawberry in half, and a slice of lime, put them in my water bottle with one scoop of this powder, and add ice and water. I actually WANT to keep drinking instead of forcing myself to stay hydrated. The fiber gives you a little extra boost so that you're not ravenous. It just takes the edge of your hunger. Do remember though, that each serving is 30 calories. Which might not seem like much, but if you refill and put a scoop in 4 times a day, that's an extra 120 calories! There's a lot you can actually EAT for 120 calories. But I do a scoop one or twice a day and i feel it really helps me get through the day without any extra snacking.

Don't let the cover or the title fool you. This book is a hidden gem! The illustrations are so cute and fresh, very much in the style of the "Adventure Time" cartoons. The story is so funny that my kids (and I) still laughed all the way through the book even on our 10th reading of it. It's just not the kind of story I was expecting and it is pleasantly clever, funny, and sweet. Your family will enjoy this change of pace in childrens books.I will say though, there's a certain word written twice in the book that we don't say in our family - its word to describe flatulence, which I change to "toot" when I read it  ;)  I'm sure that not every family is as sensitive about that word as we are, but just wanted to give the warning. It also doesn't help that my oldest child can READ that word! ha!

These glasses are simply beautiful. Not as "bubbly" as I thought they would be, they are very simple and almost entirely clear and bubble-free, with a smooth band of color at the top. The glass is also not as thick and heavy as I had expected, so while these are 19oz glasses and VERY big (I can just BARELY get my little 5'4" lady hand around them!) they aren't too heavy to hold. These will make a classy and lovely addition to any cabinet.

This file folder is an eye-catcher! Just beautiful. I wish it was sturdier, the plastic is a bit flimsy, and I'm afraid that after it gets stacked with other folders and lugged around a bit that it will end up splitting in various places - time will tell. I also wish it had a little clear pocket on the front for adding an index card, as most file folders have - not a big deal, though. Other than the gorgeous colors this is a no-frills item, but that's fine, it gets the job done.

Absolutely BEAUTIFUL. I crave color in every facet of my life, and this folder definitely brings the COLOR! It comes with an insert that gives it two pockets, which is helpful. It is VERY flexible - which is my only complaint, it's so slick and slippery that it's difficult to stack when you have other folders, and it's not very sturdy to use for writing on or in.  Personally, I wouldn't be able to use this as a PRIMARY, daily use folder, I require a folder with more rigidity. But it's gorgeous and will serve me well for a storage folder.

I read reviews and ordered up a size and I'm glad that I did. I'm normally an 18/20 or 2x, but I ordered a 3x and it fits great. I suppose if you don't have a lot of belly fat and/or don't mind being squeezed in like a sausage, then ordering your regular size would be fine. It's very comfy, and a gorgeous color. The fit is flattering, and I can't wait to break this out at the beach and when kayaking!

We love these bottles! My family uses them for hiking, for sports practice and games, for bike rides, for road trips, and even just for every day use. And what Arizonan wouldn't love showing off their AZ pride? This one is by far our family favorite, and the kids always argue over who gets to use it.

***Will update review in September 2015***Unfortunately these arrived a week too late for our first beach trip of the year to California, and my deadline to write a review for this item is a few weeks before our second trip to the beach. We will be in Hawaii September 2015, so these items will get a much better reviewing after that time.I got these for my husband who is a size 13Wide, and while the fins technically fit on him, they just won't be useable. He could barely get the latch shut, and certainly wouldn't be able to comfortably wear them in the water. I'm sure if you have a 13 Medium or Narrow width or smaller foot these will fit just fine.The snorkel tube looks amazing. I spent a lot of my childhood snorkeling and never had anything like this one! It is supposed to be able to protect you from a big wave filling your tube full of ocean water. I cannot WAIT to see how this works!The mask is very good quality and fits my husband's face well, and also attaches to the mask easily.

As a homeschooling mom, I can tell you that our household goes through a LOT of scissors. Between my three kids, various friends coming over for doing crafts, homeschool group activities, and strength testing "experiments",  I swear we are buying a couple of set of kids scissors every month or so. It's nice to have several months worth of scissors all taken care of at once. These are great for my preschooler, my kindergartener, and my third grader, and stand up well to their wild creativity.

I have long been a fan of Burt's Bees, and always used their sunscreen (and diaper cream, and lotion, etc) for my kids. I'm always trying to find body products that are paraben free, and Burt's Bees is a reliable, trustworthy brand! BUT, in my 8 eight years as a mom (who lives in Arizona) I have never found a good sunscreen face stick that is free of all the chemicals we try to avoid. Until now! I'm so happy to add this to our sunscreen repertoire, and know that my kids are covered, and safe from the sun AND chemicals!

Do you have daughters? Do they LOVE when you brush their nasty, tangled up hair after a day of playing and napping, crafting, eating, and sweating? HAHA! No, of course not.Before we discovered  this bush my daughters would always SCREAM when I told them to bring me their hairbrush. Nope, I promise there was no beating happening, just a loving mom brushing her girls' hair so they looked like someone cares about them. It always started and ended in screaming, with lots of screaming in between. No matter how gentle I was. No matter how much spray-in conditioner I used. No matter how many stories I told about how I hated having my hair brushed as a girl, too.  No matter how many times I threatened to have their hair cut short. NOTHING fixed the hairbrushing screaming fits.UNTIL THIS BRUSH!I am convinced it is made from the bristles of a magical fairy-enchanted animal, or some such. No more crying. No more fighting. Just sweet, well-groomed little girls who no longer look homeless all the time. Thank you WetBrush, you have saved my sanity, and saved my daughters years of therapy as adults.

Now that these little beauties are in every light fixture in our RV we can have more lights on when dry camping! They do make the place feel more industrial and less "homey", but hey, if it means I can see later into the night, or run the AC or furnace once or twice in the night, then it's worth it!
Fit her a bit big, but she can grow into them. They are a bit closer to a "nude" color than pink, but that's fine.

THE BEST. No contest. I have cycled through many favorite hot sauces in my day, but this one is by far the best. I use it in EVERYTHING, and I even lick it off the spoon! It has a great clean balance of flavors with salty, garlic, and spicy, and a crisp freshness to it. I'm so over sriacha, my new favorite is Sambal Oelek!

I have wide feet and a medium arch, my ideal shoe size is a 7.5 wide, but I can often squeeze into a 8 medium. I LIVE in Sanuk yoga mat flip flops ALL DAY, EVERY DAY. I live in Arizona, so this is no exaggeration (I even have them in four colors!). But for my most recent vacation I knew I'd need something a little more substantial. These shoes were purchased before my trip where I knew I would be walking on a lot of rocks at the beach while exploring tidal pools and coral reefs. They were also worn while making a long, steep hike up and down a costal cliff and on asphalt and sidewalk in town. They were a little tight to get on, but once they were on they fit fine - and of course, I want them to be a LITTLE tight so they don't get yanked off by a strong wave! They are pretty cute as far as water shoes go, better looking in person than they are in the listing picture. I wore them all day every day for four days straight of snorkeling, body surfing, and exploring, and never once missed my flip flops. At one point in the afternoon on my first day of wearing them I looked down at my feet and was SURPRISED to see these Speedo watershoes on my feet! They were so comfy and unobtrusive that I absolutely forgot I was wearing them! Now isn't that the best review you can possibly give?!

I was skeptical at first. I have an ancient iphone 4 that's in a slim case. This armband arrived with an insert that says its for an iphone 5. It didn't look like my phone would fit, certainly not with its case on. But after a little stretching it managed to fit into the armband just fine! Fit is nice and adjustable, pretty comfortable as far as armbands go.

My kids and I love this story. The pictures are sweet, the story is filled with instances that hit home for parents and kids alike, and the lessons are good ones. Some of the vocabulary is a bit over the head of the demographic this is aimed at, I wish that the God element wasn't so subtle, and it would be nice if the unconditional love was shown ALONG SIDE healthy discipline. But oh well, no book is perfect. A favorite element of mine is that the bear cubs are all different kinds of bears. My kids were confused by this, but I reminded them about friends of our who have adopted kids. They don't all look the same, but they are all family. Over all a good kids book with a good message and god illustrations. Not exceptional, but solidly good.

This series is my seven year old son's FAVORITE. He talks endlessly about them and has learned so much from them! Of the two released so far, this one is his favorite. He is already saving his money to buy the third when it comes out. He already loved to read before these books, but this is the first time i've seen him read with fervor and passion, and SAVE the last chapter for fear of it all being over. These books have made him a true book-lover.

Bought this for my kids' first trip to the beach, we read it the night before. It's not a short book, but that's okay! Parents, lets read longer books once in a while, we won't die! The story is lacking, but the pictures are what really make this book. There is SO MUCH to see in the illustrations! As I read my kids loved to find the things I was reading about. They giggled endlessly over the funny illustrations. The next day the poured over it in the car to find the things they had missed or revisit favorite finds. It was also cute to have a bit of Australian quirk. Over all a very enjoyable book.

I am normally a size 20W, so, after reading reviews I ordered a 22W and it fits very well. Maybe slightly big, but snug enough to not pop off in waves. I'm glad I ordered a size up.They are far more flattering, in my opinion, than the standard plus-size swim suit bottoms with a too-little skirt over top - those just scream "I'm insecure about my legs! Don't look at them!!". I can say that because just last week I wore a pair of those to the beach. I'm so glad I have these now!The length is good (although I'm a mom, another inch in length would be nice), I love that it has pockets, and I would feel comfortable wearing these at the beach all day, and walking to get lunch, too.My only complaint is that there is a weird insert sewn in that is meant to act as swimsuit bottoms. It doesn't fit as well as the shorts and feels very awkward. I plan to wear these shorts with a one piece suit and a rash guard over top, so I don't need TWO bottoms underneath the shorts. I may cut that section out of the shorts (as a fairly accomplished sewer, I can attest that this is easily done without real damage to the item). The fly is velcro, which some people take issue with, but I think it's just fine. Like I said, I'll have a real suit on underneath, and it's nice to not have to fiddle with ties when you're all wet.So, in all, I recommend these, but keep in mind that nothing is perfect!

I am already a kale chip fan. I have bought many varieties and made many of my own at home. No need to convince me that these are a delicious snack. THIS particular brand and flavor of kale chips, however, while good, is not my favorite.For one, even though it has an oxygen absorber in it, they were not very crisp when I received them. I live in ARIZONA. I can't even imagine how un-crisp these might be if you live in an actual humid climate.Two, the flavor is pretty mild in my opinion. But I tend to like very spicy, super flavorful things. It was a nice, subtle flavor, but don't expect it to taste like doritos. I'd love to try their mango habenero flavor!Three, and this is an issue with ALL kale chips, they are not a frugal snack! Kale is cheap. Nutritional yeast is reasonably priced. I have NO CLUE why these things are always so pricey!That being said, between myself and two of my kids, one entire bag was GONE within five minutes of delivery by the mail man :)

This is a sweet devotional to do nightly with your kids. There is nothing wrong with it, it has cute illustrations, everything is easy to understand, and helpful for starting conversations. But the age range listed is 4-8years old - I have a 2, 4, and 7 year old and I can tell you right now that after only a few days of reading this, most of the contents of this book is old news to my 7 and 4 year olds. They have heard all of this simplistic stuff before and want to hear ACTUAL Bible stories, and read things that are longer than one short paragraph. Of course, it's over the head of my two year old, so I may save it and do it with her in another year when she is three. But my 4 and 7 year olds require a little more substance in their devotions. My 7 year old does some on his own, since he can read, but I still need to find something for the four year old that will help her grow. This book isn't it.
My mom has now ordered these TWICE for my girls and BOTH times they did not come with the purses!! The hats fit fine, but what is being shown and what are being sent do not add up.

No doubt about it, these things are DELICIOUS. Of course, to be delicious AND only 90 calories you know what that means... they are literally two square inches. If you're the kind of person who is fully satisfied after two bites of a small brownie then these are the perfect snack for you. If you are the sort who eats six brownies and then finally forces yourself to stop... then you're going to want several boxes of these... or a pan of actual brownies.

This book was nothing like I expected it to be. Sure, I read the synopsis and had a vague idea, but there was so much more happening in this story than I had anticipated. For starters, this book is HILARIOUS. Not dripping with sweet cheesy romantic buffoonery in the least - but honest, true, authentic humor with some darkness and grit peppered in just to make it authentic. Sure, it has some parts that are a bit hard to believe, but what book doesn't? It also has many, many more f-bombs than most books of this sort usually have - see, I said there's nothing sappy sweet here! And, for me at least, the main character was INCREDIBLY easy to identity with... maybe I need some fake rehab, too?  Anyway, you know it's a good book when you're sad that you've finished it. "Lola Carlyle's 12-Step Romance" is just an absolutely delicious, funny, and wholly enjoyable read!

This curry paste is excellent!! It has a tangy fresh flavor with a slow burn to it. I mixed with some coconut-almond milk and added to stir fried chicken, carrots, peppers, onions, and snap peas, served over Jasmin rice. My husband, who usually is not a fan of my home-cooked curry, exclaimed several times how good it was was, and that it even tasted as good as our local Thai restaurant! I think I will be able to get two or even three more servings out of this container (the first batch I made served 5). Much better than using powdered curry. Will definitely be getting this again in the future!

I really hate to write a bad review. But if an item is truly deserving of it, I feel I have no choice.Let me begin by saying that I am an official "Blender Snob". I worked for over six years in a popular smoothie shop and became quite familiar with what a GOOD blender should be able to do. Currently I own a 1500W Blendtec blender and it is my BABY. I use it daily and love it immensely... but it isn't cheap. I was interested in trying this Nesco blender to see if there was a cheaper alternative that I could recommend to friends, as I am asked often what blender they should buy.Here's a hint. This isn't it.After loading the blender with the standard ingredients for a milkshake and hitting the button marked "smoothie" it quickly became clear that this machine couldn't handle it. There was NOT an excessive amount of ice, and I added more liquid than was necessary just to help lubricate the blending process. After the first round on the "smoothie" setting, not much had happened. I added MORE liquid, loosened up the ice and ice cream in the carafe, and tried it again. THIS TIME the motor REALLY couldn't handle it, and for some reason and continued to run WITHOUT turning itself off. As a result the room filled with stinky plastic-smelling smoke and my counter was covered in black soot under the blender! I dumped the still unblended contents into my Blendtec carafe and had a perfect milkshake in less than 30 seconds.Perhaps I got a faulty product. But, according to my husband who is an electrical engineer who works in the design and manufacturing of machinery, a simple circuit breaker or extra fuse (like the ones provided in Christmas lights) would cost the company between 5 cents to a dollar per machine, and could have prevented the damage that was done to the machine. So, faulty or not, the design is poor.After this incident I did not give up. Then I tried the ice function with just a carafe full of ice. The IDEA of the ice function is great. The execution, not so much.Then I tried blending a normal smoothie, no ice cream, just fruit, juice, and ice. Again, bad results, smoke and soot. To make it fair I also blended an almost identical smoothie in my Blendtec for comparison. The Blendtec smoothie did just fine, the Nesco one was not.The reason why I am giving this, in my experience, TERRIBLE blender two stars instead of one is the carafe. It is well-designed! Nothing out of the ordinary, but it is a quality piece of work, and I love the smaller opening on the lid to allow for adding things mid-blend. I wish my Blendtec lid had that feature! Although I will say that when the lid is firmly in place it is VERY difficult to remove - it usually results in splattering some of the contents all over the counter. Maybe i should take off that second star after all? Naw, I'll play nice. Point is, if you've stuck with me and read the review this far already then you know - i do NOT recommend this blender. AT ALL.

This bag (mine is light grey) has been a delight from the second I opened the Amazon box! I am using it as a transition purse between diaper bag and regular purse, now that my youngest child is two and I don't need to carry so many items any more. Even so, it has great compartments and carries so much more than it looks like it would. I get SO MANY compliments on it and have actually had a couple of friends order the same purse in different colors after seeing me carry it around.If I could possibly drum up a complaint about this beautiful bag it would be that I wish that it had a fun colorful fabric on the inside rather than the silly animal print it has, but I guess some people like that sort of thing.It is beautiful, sleek, well-made, and efficient, what more could you want?

This set has everything that you need to create one project, with all the materials and clear, easy to understand instructions. It's a pretty fun kit that will serve as a great summer craft for a child or even an adult. I do feel that it is a bit misleading in that I was under the impression that SEVERAL projects could be made from this kit. Also, the Amazon listing says it is for kids aged 7-15, but I feel it would be more appropriate for 8 or 9 and older. My seven year old enjoyed it and wanted to complete the project alone, but simply didn't have the patience or precision to do so. A fun kit, just be aware of its limitations before purchasing.

These are good. Sweet, slightly salty, crispy, and delicious. I just wish they had a stronger chocolate flavor - the coating on one side is very thin - and more protein! I just don't get how an ALMOND bar with 130 calories has only 3g of protein. These are good, but not great.

First things first, these Streusel bars taste GREAT. They have a sweet, slightly tart, fresh fruit flavor, paired with a lovely rich, crumbly, crunchy cake base. They also have 5g of fiber, and 2g of protein... BUT DO NOT BE FOOLED. These are dessert. These are NOT healthy by any stretch of the imagination. At 150 calories per bar, these tiny bars (about 1.5 inches square) are nothing but a sweet treat. Which is FINE if you know what you're getting into! These are great and enjoyable with a little added bonus of fiber and protein, just make sure you're eating informed!

It's a rare thing these days for a book to hold my interest long enough for me to finish it without begrudging feelings. Eden West is a book that I looked forward to reading, was intrigued by every page, and gladly finished. There are even some moments of gorgeous and profound prose that I enjoyed reading over a few times. The ending may be a bit vague for some readers' tastes, but I quite enjoy it when an author allows the reader some creative license. So why only three stars? While I enjoyed it all, and the ending didn't bother me, I just felt that the story lacked cohesiveness. There were several elements that I just couldn't grasp the significance of, and felt like they were left a bit undone - not in a creative way, but in an unthoughtful way. I kept thinking that these things had been added for a purpose... and then that purpose really didn't quite reveal itself. Overall, it's a good book that is worth the read, but it lacks some spark and precision  for me.

My kids love this book. The illustrations are funny and have a lot to look at and interpret. The vocabulary of the book is quite advanced which means we have to pause a lot to explain the meanings of words, which is a tad annoying,but not necessarily bad. The moral of the story is a little cloudy and also requires some explaining. But over all it is a fun and enjoyable read for all.

This gum smells and tastes EXACTLY like strawberry Starburst! So good! It does have sugar in it and each stick is 5 calories. Also, the fact that is has sugar in it means it isn't going to actually "freshen" your breath. But for a little something sweet, this gets the job done. My kids love it and so do I!

The information that IS in this book is concise, well-presented, and useful. It has nice illustrations. But that's about all the praise I'm going to give this book.I'm just guessing here, but based on the information (or lack thereof) and maps (I use the term loosely) in this book, I'm going to say that the author only conducted research on and only made research trips to the Grand Canyon, Phoenix, and Tucson. There is a WHOLE LOT more to Arizona than just those three regions. Though, to be honest, I grew up in the Phoenix area, and until I moved away, I thought those were the only noteworthy regions of Arizona, as well.Currently, I am raising my own family at the foot of the Hualapai Mountains. Oh, what's that? You've NEVER HEARD OF THEM? Exactly. No one has. Because NO ONE WRITES ABOUT THEM (for the record, is it a range that encompasses over 1,300 square miles of granite mountains with ponderosa and pinon pines, with its highest peak at an elevation of 8,417 feet, and a rise of over 6,000 feet in elevation from the surrounding desert floor - but this sky island range is not mentioned even ONCE in this book). It is incredibly difficult to find out ANY information on the plants and wildlife that are specific to this unique portion of Arizona. While this area is technically in the Mohave Desert (Mojave if you're a Californian), this specific Northwestern corner of Arizona (South of the Grand Canyon, to the West of the Colorado River and North of Lake Havasu), is quite different than the rest of the Mohave desert, and quite different from the rest of Arizona. The Mohave desert is mentioned, ever-so-briefly, maybe two or three times in this "resource". We are the forgotten stepchild of Arizona. Which is truly sad because this region has so many unique and beautiful features that few people ever see or hear about. Absolutely NONE of which are mentioned in this book, which claims to tell of "The Nature of Arizona" (granted, you'll find no words like "complete" in the title, so the author has a loophole). To be fair, my beef here is not just with THIS author, it is that NO ONE seems to remember this gorgeous corner of Arizona, and NO ONE seems to have written about it!There are so many birds and plants that we come in contact with here that I simply cannot find in any book. Locals have names for them and stories about them, but I'd sure love to have a book that has scientific facts and drawings. For example, my kids and I have tried for months to identify three species of birds that frequent our garden and have been unsuccessful because of the lack of publication on this region. Even talking to friends at Fish and Game has yielded uncertain results.The MOST glaring example of missing information in this book is the absence of the Mohave Green Rattlesnake (Crotalus scutulatus). It is widely said to be the most deadly snake in North America. They are aggressive and have been known to CHASE after people. No joke. They are quite prolific here in Mohave county, and they slither across my property regularly. They can be found from California and Nevada, down through Southern Arizona and pretty far South into Mexico. But is this common and very deadly snake mentioned in this book? Nope.Another terrible over sight: invertebrates. Want to guess how many pages are on invertebrates in this book? TWO. No, not two double-sided pages, JUST TWO. That comes out to exactly SEVEN invertebrates mentioned. Want to guess how many unique species of invertebrates Arizona has? I don't know the exact number, but after living more than 30 years in Arizona I am going to guess that the number is upwards of 10,000 species that are prevalent in the Southwest, and specifically Arizona. Seriously. And it lists only one type of scorpion when I know for a fact that i have seen with my very own eyes at least for different species in Arizona. How about spiders? Just the black widow and the tarantula. No mention of the Arizona Brown Spider (a highly dangerous cousin of the brown recluse, a camel spider (when you see one you will NEED to know what it is!) the huntsman spider, the wolf spider, the list could go on for paragraphs. This lack of highly pertinent information is just plain insultingly negligent.Again, the information that IS presented here is *mostly* fine, and, to my knowledge, pretty accurate. But I'd LOVE to see a new edition that actually talked about the plants, animals, and ecosystem where my family lives. We the people of Mohave County, Arizona are tired of our region being overlooked!  Tell me, have you read this book and noticed basic information missing about YOUR section of Arizona? I'd love to know if this book is cheating the readers out of other pockets of information.

I should have known better. Jonah - the ACTUAL book - has always been my favorite book of the Bible. I am always easily snared by anything to do with Jonah; the Biblical account speaks to me and plight of the human condition, reconciling our free will with a God who has big plans. Anyway, I should have known better. Nothing is as good as the original, right? This book starts off quite well, but like quicksand, you slowly sink in and it becomes a chore to read. And there really aren't a lot of parallels between this story and the actual book of Jonah. I'm not sure what the author was trying to accomplish with this book, but if it was to entertain me or give me some sort of revelation, then it was not a success.

I found this book to be great. It had been years since I fooled with electronics or programming, but this book held my hand through my reintroduction. Entertaining and engaging, this book provided fun and insightful labs to cut my teeth on.I also liked the primer at the beginning of the book explaining the different hardware options, it was very useful.I have since lent this book to a friend and he reports the same opinions of the book. Highly recommended!

LOVE this collapsible bottle! I used it recently on several airplane trips across the country and back and it was awesome. Easy to collapse, easy to fill, easy to clean, clips to my carry on bag, and easily tucks inside empty or full.Two small issues (not bad enough to knock a star off, though!) are that, ONE because it is made of silicone it collects lint and hair and gross stuff like crazy. A quick rinse cleans it off, but after it rolls around in my bag and on the floor of the airplane it's pretty nasty. The second issue... I don't know how to say this without sounding completely dumb... it's tricky to drink out of at times. I swear, I am in my 30's and have a college degree, but if you're not paying attention, this water bottle has a learning curve. More than once I have squirted water on myself when it was full, or lifted the half-full bottle to my mouth only to have it flaccidly flop around and NOT give me any water. Y'all will understand when you get this bottle. But I love it. A new travel staple for me!

This devotional is ALMOST exactly what I had hoped it would be. It is engaging, fun, easy to read (for my 2nd grader), and relevant to my son's life. He LIKES it. He remembers to do it when I have forgotten! It's pretty all-around great.I just wish it had more BIBLE in it.Each day it gives the child ONE verse to read and vaguely talks about that subject. I know this isn't for tweens who are more advanced, but my seven year old can process more complexities than this book offers up, and I'd like him to get a little more actual BIBLE in his devotional. As it stands, most days we still do some Bible study together in addition to this. It's good for us to discuss it together, but I wish THIS book was more of a starting point for us. I wish it would have the kids read a small paragraph from the Bible, explain some of the context, and ask questions that are relevant to that paragraph.I still haven't found the perfect early elementary devotional, but this IS the closest I've found yet.

This is a great little book for summer time activities to keep your child's mind sharp int he long summer weeks between grades. Each day's activities are quick and easy to understand, but impactful. I think each day's pages can be done in under 10-20 minutes, depnding on your child's skill level. It is fairly fun, and not terribly involved, so from a adult's point of view it shouldn't be a problem to get your child involved in this notebook... but of course kids will be kids, don't expect them to BEG to do this each day of their vacation! ha!I am actually a homeschooling parent, and we are using this right now int eh 2nd half of 1st grade as our morning warm-up work. It is excellent at getting my kid's brain working, and doesn't require much help from me.

Love the concept of this power station. It  has everything, including an attached micro USB cable and two USB ports. I love that it not only gives back the outlet you use up, but also another one. Who wouldn't love this?? It is quite literally everything that it claims to be. The plugging in to the USB ports is not as smooth as it would be in your device's manufacturer's charging cube, but that's a minor complaint.However, it should be noted that it's great in theory that the USB charging ports are 2.4 amp, so as to charge your devices faster. But doing this on a regular basis will unnecessarily stress the battery and cause it to wear out much faster. Just be aware, this isn't really the right device for regular habitual use if you care at all about the life of your battery.

I really like Stur products, and appreciate their commitment to healthy, quality ingredients. These coconut water flavors are great! The lime is my favorite by far. They taste great, are easy to use, easy to carry with you, and the bottles are adorable.My only issue is that I REALLY wish they would make a line that DOESN'T have stevia in it. I can't STAND sweet drinks! I keep using this product because I like the flavors, I just wish they weren't sweetened! I LOVE the flavor of "infused" water, when you just let fruits sit in water. That's it, no stevia or sugar, just the essence of the fruit in the water. I have a pitcher that will do this for me,  but I don't want to deal with the clean up that comes with it, and I want to be able to drink that kind of water when I'm not at home. I want to be able to buy a "water enhancer" that will give me that same effect as infused water but without the sweetness. So how about it, Stur? Want to make some of that? I'd buy it from you in bulk!!

THE AVIATOR’S WIFE REVIEWFictional history, if done right, is my favorite read.  Unfortunately, it is very often done poorly, producing books that frustrate and irritate me for their lack of authenticity.  We need to talk about Melanie Benjamin, author of “The Aviator’s Wife.”  And we should speak glowingly and with great admiration.  She always seems to get it right, a tribute to her research, dedication, and resolve.Benjamin, in her book notes, states that she wanted to tell the story of a famous woman who few people really know, who has a hero for a husband whom she supports without question, who is hounded constantly by the press, and who, after an early life of reticence, finally emerges as resilient and outspoken, very much her own woman and deserving of her own accolades.  The author has done that with wonderful style.Charles Lindbergh was the wildly celebrated aviator who made a 1927 solo flight across the Atlantic that secured his place in American history.  Anne Morrow was the shy daughter of a U.S. Ambassador, often overshadowed by her father and her radiant older sister, who inexplicably captured the attention of of the most revered man in America.  Their life together was full of achievement, sporadic happiness, tragedy, secrecy, abandonment, and, finally, revelation.  Not many know of the turmoil between Anne and Charles, or the dysfunction in their family.  Benjamin has researched it, analyzed it, and, with her marvelous writing skills, reimagined the emotional truths behind this remarkable relationship.It’s a political story of an American hero with somewhat treasonous leanings, an anti-Semitic who held unfavorable opinions about the policies of his country during the early years of World War Two.  The aviator’s wife who, at first, wasn’t brave enough separate herself from her husband’s domination, eventually disavowed his beliefs and emerged as perhaps the most fearless and courageous of the two, insisting on honesty and seeking answers about Lindbergh’s double life as he approached death at age 72.It’s also the story of their children.  The eldest, Charles, Jr., was tragically kidnapped and murdered.  The couple’s other five children struggled with personality disorders and the specter of having parents and a family life in disarray.  It is also revealed that Charles fathered seven other children with different partners as he roamed around the world doing his notable work while his family struggled at home without his presence.Historical fiction fans, in search of marvelous writing, must not ignore Melanie Benjamin’s novels.  She has recently released “The Swans of Fifth Avenue,” a penetrating look at Truman Capote.  Her talent is obvious in all her books, and is particularly shining in Aviator’s Wife.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

FLASHMAN AT THE CHARGE REVIEWGeorge MacDonald Fraser (2 April 1925 – 2 January 2008) was a prolific Scottish author who wrote historical novels, nonfiction books, and numerous screenplays.  His notorious Flashman series was based on the antics of the protagonist Tom Brown in “Tom Brown’s School Days,” created by Thomas Hughes in 1857, where a coward and a bully becomes a hero.  The series, “The Flashman Papers,” became a popular sensation, and the bawdy, and often socially incorrect adventures of Harry Flashman, a British soldier during the 19th century, is perhaps Fraser’s best-known works.“Flashman at the Charge,” published in 1973, is the fourth in the 12-book series centers on Flashman’s escapades during the Crimean War, including the famous Charge of the Light Brigade, where Flashman always prevails in spite of trembling fear and loose bowels.  He is not a brave man and tends towards constant self-disparagement, but the circumstances he finds himself in seem to always turn in his favor.  A similar theme forms most of the Flashman storylines, and if it were not for Fraser’s historical knowledge and hilarious writing skills, the Flashman line would probably die the death of monotony.  But, I have always enjoyed the irreverent series, as apparently do many others, and enjoy reading about an anti-hero who prevails in spite of himself.The dialogue is authentic, uproarious, and filled with dry wit.  The battle scenes are intricate and well presented, with heroic antics that are not intended to be noble.  Fraser keeps a close hand on the intended character of Flashman, making his deeds notable, if not fearless.  His boudoir escapades are more amusing than licentious.Yes, I enjoy Harry Flashman.  I think many people associate his tentative approach to life with their own, hoping to achieve much honor without a lot of heroic effort.  If that fits your secret personality, Flashman is your savant.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

STELLA REVIEWThe Holocaust is recent history that is imbedded in the brain of most humans today.  The systematic annihilation of Jews by Nazi Germany from 1941 to 1945 has been documented in every conceivable way, yet what do we really know?  Constant new revelations come forward to shock and repulse us, generating new feelings that add to our personal perspective of an evil time.Enter Stella Kübler-Isaacksohn nee Goldschlag, a German Jewish woman of startling beauty and ambition, with a dogged sense of survival for self and family, who engaged in the heinous activity of exposing Berlin’s underground Jews and revealing them to Gestapo authorities, leading to the imprisonment and deaths of untold numbers of people desperately seeking safety.“Stella” is Peter Wyden’s 1992 biography of his childhood fantasy girl, a German Jew with luminous blonde hair, sparkling white teeth, and a winning, flirtatious personality.  Her shapely bare legs in gym shorts fueled his adolescent dreams.  She was his schoolmate and choir mate, always near but as distant as the farthest star.
