Stella Goldschlag created a lasting imprint on his brain.Wyden and his parents, through good fortune, escaped the early Hitler years.  Stella was trapped in Berlin when the cleansing began and, inexplicably, became a Nazi collaborator, giving up her fellow Jews to the Gestapo leading to some being imprisoned and exterminated in the concentration camps.  When Wyden returned to Germany after the War as part of the United States occupying force, he discovered the horrendous story of his glamorous classmate’s life as a “catcher” of Jews and resolved to uncover her story.  It took forty-six years to generate this book.The Holocaust is a complicated and emotional time in our history.  Countless accounts of all its hideous aspects have been written.  Wyden has done his research and his accounting is factually accurate, at least as accurate as can be determined by the veracity of emotional recollections.  I learned some new facts about the conduct of the purge that made the book worth reading.I struggled, however, with the author’s narration when it came to the actions of Stella.  There was too much ambiguity and too many gaps in her story.  In the end, I found I didn’t really know Stella very well.  I’m not sure Wyden ever did either.  The book was published in 1992 and didn’t contain the information that in 1994 Stella committed suicide by jumping out of the window of her apartment.  One could sense, by Wyden’s final conversations with her that she was emotionally unstable and the ending was not far off.  It appears, however, that Wyden didn’t see it coming.This is a dark read with many flashbacks and characterizations.  It’s interesting, however, and well worth the read to get a fascinating look at a different aspect of the Holocaust.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

TWAIN’S END REVIEWIf Kitty Kelley is called the Queen of Mean for her unauthorized biographies of contemporary celebrities, what should we call Lynn Cullen?  Kelley has earned that label by spearing such luminaries as Frank Sinatra, Oprah Winfrey, Nancy Reagan, the Bush clan, and Jackie Onassis.  Cullen has produced accounts of the lives of Rembrandt’s wife, Cornelia; Edgar Allen Poe’s paramour, Frances Osgood; Juana of Castile, The Mad Queen of Spain; and portraitist Sofonisba Anguissola, lady-in-waiting to Spain’s Queen Elizabeth.  Both Kelley and Cullen have presented impropriety and scandalous behavior in their accounts but Kelley’s work is more “National Enquirer,” while Cullen is more David McCullough using a meticulous historian’s approach.  Her biographies of notable people of the past use a gentler, more scholarly tone.I prefer Cullen’s work.  In her latest book, “Twain’s End,” she reimagines the personal life of America’s most famous and successful writer, Mark Twain (Samuel Clemens), and his strange relationship with his private secretary, Isabel Lyon.  In 1909, after a six-year friendly alliance filled with abiding trust, Twain wrote a 400 plus-page tirade, calling Isabel “a liar, a forger, a thief, a hypocrite, a drunkard, a sneak, a humbug, a traitor, a conspirator, a filthy-minded and salacious slut pining for seduction.”  After years of devoted service, Lyon had evidently p!&$*d Twain off.  He continued to publicly belittle her for a year until his death in 1910.Cullen is a wonderful writer who selects her words carefully, unfurls masterful dialogue, and presents scenes in authentic detail.  The reader is transported into a past era of careful comportment, respectful relationships, and courteous interactions.  Mark Twain was not, however, particular about being socially acceptable and was loud, abusive, and self-absorbed.  His popularity was gained because of his remarkable storytelling ability and his imposing charisma.  Close family members and staffers were more aware of his shortcomings because he was less careful about congeniality when around them.There was a tangled relationship between Twain and Lyon and, in later tears, his business manager, Ralph Ashcroft, whom Lyon eventually married.  Another love triangle between Helen Keller, her teacher Anne Sullivan Macy, and Anne’s husband, John Macy, is chronicled, as well as Twain’s interest in Keller and his well-known propensity for young girls and pretty women.  Cullen has carefully explored this lusty life in discreet language based on Isabel Lyon’s expansive diary, Twain’s writings, his letters, and hundreds of books by or about the legendary writer.Lyon died in 1956 at age 94 in New York City, never having commented on Twain’s allegations against her nor the circumstances that so enraged him.  It’s obvious that Cullen feels a strong empathy for Lyons’ story, although it’s never so stated in “Twains End.”Cullen’s portrayal of Twain somewhat denigrates his persona of a likeable bon vivant.  However, because his works are such excellent examples of writing well done, I’ll continue reading them.  I’ll also read more of Lynn Cullen because her careful explorations of human frailty are non judgmental and beautifully presented, with interesting subject matter.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

BROTHER REVIEWAnia Ahlborn is a well-known writer of horror fiction, and “Brother,” her latest story, continues her streak of horrifying novels that delve deep into the world of nightmarish ugliness.  She’s a resident of Portland, Oregon.  Could that contribute to her weirdness?Deep in the woods of Appalachia there is rumored to be people with malicious minds and horrible life practices.  In “Brother,” we meet the Morrow family that has a penchant for murdering young girls who have wandered into their domain and, if eliminated, will never be missed.  Michael, a nineteen-year-old, adopted some ten years earlier by the family, does not carry the ingrained familial bloodlust exhibited by the other members and is looking for an escape.  His adopted brother isn’t about to let that happen and finds ways to keep Michael involved in the family carnage sprees, even expanding his duties to more and more fiendish chores.The author has had a somewhat unusual childhood herself, spending a lot of time in a cemetery, rearranging flowers to make a more equitable distribution among the graves.  Who knows if this penchant has led to strange thoughts, but Ahlborn certainly has a morbid imagination that she likes to share.  Her book will have strong appeal for those who appreciate ghoulish stories and murderous escapades.  Her writing is exceptional if somewhat disturbing.Who is Ania Ahlborn?  I’ve read quite a few of her blogs and find a thoughtful, intelligent wordsmith who decries those writers who publish work that is not particularly good because of their need for speed.  Their editing is dismal or often nonexistent.  Not so with her releases.  I relish her dedication to good writing and the joy it brings to my ever-searching eyes.That said, I don’t find Ahlborn’s storyline to be easily believed.  I doubt there exists any family with the Morrows’ unmitigated lust for psychopathic behavior involving brutal murder, dismemberment, and cannibalism.  To get away with this behavior for so many years, even in the backwoods of West Virginia, seems illogical.But I’ve always said that a writer gets to fantasize and write about anything without worrying that the words will be scrutinized for credibility.  The only standard to be met is the entertainment of the reader, and there are certainly those who enjoy this type of story.  Strangely enough, I found myself being drawn into this evil environment to the point that I was actually entertained by the bloody behavior.  Hopefully, when I return to my more sedate reading material, I will not have been traumatized.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

Jen Mann, author of “People I Want to Punch in the Throat,” is a piece of work.  Yes, she is opinionated.  Yes, she is self-centered.  Yes, she is profane.  Yes, she would be the wrong person to cross.  And, yes, she is funny.Who are all these people she wants to punch out?  They’re preschool mothers and their obnoxious spawn.  They’re office mates with devious lifestyles.  They’re camp followers and their obsessive drive to get the best for their developing prodigies.  They’re pretentious people, pesky telemarketers, nosy neighbors, overprotective parents, and, well, pretty much anyone who gets crossways with the author’s frame of mind.  If I was her husband, Hubs, I’d wear a spiked dog collar at all times because he is always asking for a throat chop.Here’s the thing about Jen Mann.  Her outlook, while crusty, is hilarious and runs completely parallel with mine.  The annoying people she describes are the same people I run across…irritating and completely unworthy of occupying space in a civilized society.  They don’t have a clue about their idiotic behavior and tend to denigrate those who can’t understand their attitude.  I don’t know if she really confronts them as forcefully as she describes, but I’m sure they get the point she is making.  I suspect she’s also a nicer person than she lets on.She is profane and has a “don’t give a s**t” attitude.  She’s comfortable with that persona and just as at ease if you choose to not read her book because it offends you.  But you will miss a lot of sensible reflections and opinions, and, for sure, will miss a lot of outstanding humor.  There are two things I don’t get because they’re not explained.  How did Hubs get that nickname?  Is he the center of her universe or does everything revolve around him?  Based on her description, I don’t think so.  And what are her children’s real names? Mann says they are worse than Gomer and Adolpha, the names assigned to them in her book.  If so, I’d like to know what they are.This is an entertaining book.  Don’t get turned off by the language that is more humorous than obscene.  Loosen up a little and let some else’s miseries wash over you.  It’s a warm, languid bath that summons up a nice glass of pinot gris.  Under those conditions a grin would seem appropriate.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE GIRL WITH TWO NAMES REVIEW“The Girl with Two Names is an interesting book with a different storyline that wavers between strongly appealing and disconcertingly amateurish.  There’s no doubt that the author, Gerard O’Neill, is talented but he needs to pay more attention to little details such as creating more realistic dialogue and doing a better job of editing.I received a gratis copy of the book from the author and because it’s marked 2nd edition I’m assuming it’s not a pre-publication proof.  That allows me to be critical of the editing that is less than professional and that disturbed my reading cadence.  Just as I was starting to marvel at some great scene setting, along would come double wording, bad grammar, atrocious punctuation, and gaps in the typography that definitely affected my rating of the book.A Japanese rock star, either Yayoi or Yaya, depending on your preference, struggles with an unhappy marriage and the professional demands on her time.  She makes a break for it, escaping to New Zealand, where she gets involved with Bill and other New Zealanders who like their outdoor adventures accented with scraggly life.  She attempts to fit into the environment, struggling with the inconveniences, until her husband finds her and begins a campaign of intimidation and violence as he attempts to win her back.  The later pages of the book are filled with beatings and shootings and shenanigans that threaten her and those unfortunate enough to be around her.  It gets a bit complicated.I didn’t much care for Yayoi, finding her to be weak willed and self absorbed.  The author attempted to present her as an endearing and sweet waif who was searching for her big-girl persona but it didn’t work for me.  I finished the book mostly out of curiosity created by the author’s story.  But, in reality, I didn’t much care about how Yayoi fared in her big adventure.One thing I took from the book was O’Neill’s love for writing.  It was a well-intentioned attempt at getting his words into a book and I applaud that.  Hopefully I don’t discourage his continued efforts at becoming a first-rate author that I’m sure will happen with more experience.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

DARK STAR SAFARI REVIEWPaul Theroux, author of “Dark Star Safari,” is many things to many people but, above all, he is prolific, having written over fifty books of both fiction and nonfiction: he also writes essays and criticisms; edits anthologies; and produces articles for many publications.  Most of his work is produced while rambling around the world in less than luxurious circumstances, so travel writer is also an appropriate title.As a person, he casts an aura of crustiness, sarcastic humor, and a deep feeling for the human condition.  He’s willing to get grungy, sleep in filth, and eat gross things. He’s not shy, somewhat a loner, and fearless in his search for intriguing stories.  He is a glorious writer with a vocabulary that is outer-space huge.  His choice of words is intimidating to most readers who should always include a dictionary at their chair side when starting one of his books.“Dark Star Safari,” written in 2003, is his opus dedicated to the mysteries and lore of Africa.  He deeply studies it in all its wrenching poverty, political turmoil, and volatile temperament and presents its intricate face and scabby underbelly to those with patience and a love for detail.The reader will travel the nearly 5,000 miles from Cairo to Cape Town by ratty bus, nasty cattle truck, bug-infested dugout canoe, clanking train, and derelict boat.  The food is gross, the beds are dirty, the natives are uneasy, and death from bandits is always close at hand. But Theroux, in his unflinching pursuit of reportable events, drags us with him through the dirt, mosquitoes, and bullets.  It seems he knows almost every person in Africa, and those he doesn’t he approaches without trepidation to grill them for information.  Sometimes he hits a nerve but he never reports that he’s been beaten or thrown in jail for his audacious manner.  Hopefully that never comes.“Dark Star Safari” is a lengthy read.  The author is thorough in his reporting, frequently inflicting self-castigation for his wordiness.  I spend a lot of time looking up words because I am curious as to their meaning, only to think why does he not just say it another way so we common folk could understand it.  But, of course, Theroux is not common folk.  He is an intellectual who allows obscure words roll off his pen as a matter of course.  Actually it’s beautiful to see.When you finish this book you will be proud of yourself and feel more knowledgeable.  These are fascinating stories that are beautifully put together.  This is the reason why we read Theroux in the first place.  Whether you want it or not, Africa will become a much more familiar place.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

A BEGINNERS GUIDE TO PARADISE REVIEWIn “A Beginners Guide to Paradise” author Alex Sheshunoff has concocted a stew of silliness, cultural enlightenment, and travel tips that is both entertaining and somewhat disorganized.  We have the story of a dissatisfied American male seeking happiness in faraway places but who has no idea what it is that he wants.  So he leads the reader into his world of thrashing around in the remote areas of Micronesia among the topless and casual natives, trying to find his footing.He hooks up with Sarah, another American and better grounded individual, who takes a firm grip on his restlessness, steers him towards a more productive existence, and eventually becomes a wife and mother whom he credits with making his life “immeasurably more full of wonder and possibility and humor and plain old-fashioned love than I ever knew was possible.”  So we know that his wandering nature ended up in a good place.I find that his writing is complex, full of wit and humor, and amazingly erudite in his observations about cultural complexities and the behavior of the indigenous people of remote Pacific islands.  Sometimes the distance between wacky behavior and cultural dissertation gets too intimate in his writing but that’s the way Sheshunoff operates in both in his thinking and lifestyle.  The humor is rampant in the beginning of the book and seems to give way to more education as the book goes along, but overall it is very engaging.The author’s command of language is very good and his scenic descriptions are outstanding.  One can feel the heat and humidity, the oppressive lushness of the tropics, and the constant presence of the ocean.  This is not a travelogue that is intended to lure tourists to Yap or Anguar or Palau, but it is a realistic look at a place, normally considered a paradise, that requires some acclimatization.Sheshunoff offers some things that can be attained by giving up everything in your life; moving to a South Pacific island, wearing a loin cloth, reading a hundred books, building a bungalow, diapering a baby monkey, and maybe falling in love.  If these come close to matching your goals in life, you should read this book.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

IN A DARK, DARK WOOD REVIEWRuth Ware, English author of “In a Dark, Dark Wood,” has prepared a thriller for readers in her debut novel.Mystery novelist Leonora lives a regimented but content life in London.  She gets up, has coffee, goes for a run, takes a shower, and starts writing.  Apart from having an internal conflict about her name, she’s known as Nora or Lee, depending on who is talking to her, she is content and well settled.  Then an email changes her life by recalling old friends that are not necessarily good friends, and that invites her to a hen weekend for Claire, a childhood friend she hasn’t seen for ten years.Her inclination is to decline but some intense urging by a mutual friend, Nora, changes her mind and she finds herself in a strange house in a remote dark woods with people she’d rather not be hanging around with.  Instability, backstabbing, snarkiness, and sinister behavior give way to terror and murder, eventually making the party a nightmare.  Ware has developed a story with twists that would make Agatha Christie proud, and a reading experience that is spellbinding.  Needless to say, reading it is the only way you’ll learn its secrets.Nora is a control freak and finds herself in circumstances over which she has no control.  That, and the bizarre behavior of each attendee, allows the author to keep the reader unnerved as the story develops.  Dark humor is interspersed at appropriate intervals, but in such a manner as to not destroy the mood.  The structuring is believable, the dialogue crackles, and the stygian landscape makes for a mysterious setting.  Even the author admits to having the weird characters still running through her mind, spoiling her attempts to start a new book.This is a different read for me in that females dominate the story.  The author and the characters, including a gay man, would probably qualify this as chick lit but I was totally immersed in the story and never thought of it that way.  It is simply a great suspense tale that should not be denigrated as having a female slant.  Of course a hen party before a wedding is a feminine tradition, but the acrimony and past associations that are revealed at the gathering are universally human when early years are remembered.This is a wonderful book and an exciting read for mystery fans.  Ware, although personally not a fan of overly sadistic or violent writing, manages to insert just enough carnage to make sure the story keeps its suspenseful grip on the reader.  I recommend “In a Dark, Dark Wood” as a thriller worth reading.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES
Good looking shoes and very comfortable.  Haven't had a breaking-in problem.  I liked the price, as well.
Great to have repair part handy in one bucket.  Would be handier if the lid fit better.
Extension cords are extension cords.  I bought these to get the split that I need for under a couch to table lamps at each end.  Longer ones would have worked but didn't want the tangle.

These sleeves were free so can't complain too much.  The card sleeves take up too much room in my wallet, barely fitting into the slots.  That's probably good because I had to remove some cards I never use.
Fits well between the burners on my Weber Genesis and generates smoke as advertised.  Can't complain.
Seems to be kink-free and flexible and my wife appreciates the light weight.  How it holds up is to be determined.
Smoking chips are pretty much the same.  These are a nice size and fit well in my smoker can.  Good aromatic smoke production.
Very sturdy with no frills.  Gets the job done and its small size is a plus.
A little small but works well.  Great for two of us but need a larger size for groups.  Well made and appears to be durable.
Turns out these gloves are as stiff as a banker's heart.  Not easy to handle the flipper with these on.
I wore this shirt to an Angels game and Mike Trout was eyeballing it.  Tough luck, big fella, you have enough shirts and you're not getting mine.

Put my grill cover on for the first time and was delighted at the fit.  It slipped right on my Weber Genesis #-310 without a struggle.  The extra wide velcro straps fit snuggly under the side tables so no wind will blow its skirts up.  Appears well made from heavy material.  How it will hold up is to be determined but my guess is that the folks at Texas Grill Covers got it right.

THE OREGON TRAIL REVIEWRinker Buck and his younger brother, Nick, both alcoholics with spotty lifestyles, discover their identities in “The Oregon Trail,” spending four months looking at the rear ends of three intrepid mules from a jarring wagon seat.  Whatever their past, they are instant heroes of the indolent for their modern-day adventure.Buck is consumed by fervor to travel 2,000 miles on the famed route that settled the West and he wants to suffer the same discomforts experienced by gritty settlers in the middle 1800s.  He calls it a “crazyass passion.”Under a heavy cloud of pessimism, he consents to having his brother join him.  Nick is an experienced team driver, mechanic, and animal handler who will provide needed expertise to Rink, who is better suited to giving orders and planning daily events.  Rink is instantly installed as Wagon Master and Nick becomes Top Hand. The decision to include Nick is easily big brother’s best.Together they fight equipment breakdowns, sand storms, torrential rains, and runaway mules.  They subsist on huge quantities of chili, without beans.  Heat, grease, and grime surround them.  When route uncertainties plague the Wagon Master, Top Hand just plods along, certain they will get somewhere.Rinker sleeps in the built-in bed in the tarp-covered wagon, while Nick, and his eternally greasy Jack Russell terrier, Olive Oyl, bed under the wagon and in leaky barns, often in manure, without complaint.  This is a four-month long journey and, yes, I said without complaint.We come to love Rink and Nick by the end of the trip. We get even more emotionally involved with three mules; the unpredictable Beck, the unmotivated Bute, and Jake, the gentle giant.  Their individual shortcomings disappear when the hauling begins, and Buck captures their personalities and chronicles how the two men develop great love their long-eared buddies.  The cadence for “calling the team,” urging them to carry on under horrible strain, is lyrical in Buck’s book.This is a great adventure that melds historical information with today’s journey into an unforgettable memoir.  The book is wordy, to be sure, but each one is important to the story.  It all comes together into a highly entertaining read; one you shouldn’t miss.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

IMPOSTERS OF PATRIOTISM REVIEWTed Richardson has presented an outstanding book in his debut writing endeavor, “Imposters of Patriotism.”  He has imagined that our leading patriot, George Washington, was forced to offer a surrender to the British during the Revolutionary War because of the dire conditions that Americans were being forced to endure.  The horrible conditions did actually exist, the British forces were about to overwhelm the colonists, and Washington was desperate to find solutions to the problems he faced.  But there is no evidence Washington ever considered surrendering.  In Richardson’s novel the surrender offer was actually written by Washington, sent via a trusted courier, but not delivered.  Washington believed the undelivered letter was burned per his instructions to the courier who, for whatever reason, disobeyed the order.  The letter disappeared for a couple of hundred years.The story moves to modern times when an antique dealer, Matt Hawkins finds a journal in which the letter is disclosed.  Knowing the impact such an act would have on the legacy of George Washington, Hawkins becomes obsessed with finding the actual letter to allay any concerns that might sully the reputation of the first President of the United States.  He believes the letter should be found and disclosed, being certain that it is an important historical event, and that George Washington’s reputation and the conditions that prompted the offer would overcome any negative public reaction.Unfortunately unscrupulous politicians and their equally nefarious promoters have a different view.  The Republican nominee for President in an approaching election is a direct descendant of Washington, bears his name, and is shamelessly exploiting the father of our country in his campaign.  The tactic has worked and he has steadily risen in the polls.  He also has a hidden hedge fund involving huge amounts of money that he will be able to enhance by presidential edict after he wins the election.  Fearing that Washington will be become a pariah for even considering a surrender and the public fallout will damage his campaign, costing him billions of dollars.  He and his vicious advisors are frantic to make sure the letter disappears into the dark morass of historical secrets.Richardson’s idea is intriguing.  He has done his research and his writing stirs the imagination.  He presents it so well that one has to think it might really have happened.  Of course, the way things have turned out in the real world, we know the delivery was never made--think what our world might be had we not won our war for independence.  The author has combined a realistic historical possibility with a modern detective drama and come up with a very enjoyable and thought-provoking read.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

MADELEINE’S KISS REVIEWMost avid readers that I know can’t really express what it is they like or don’t like about a book.  “Madeleine’s Kiss” by Peter Gilboy first created that indecision in me.  But, in the end, I have decided that the story, although highly unlikely, is a good read and definitely worth my time.The concept is very unusual.  An unmotivated professor of art history is the narrator and tells his story of an infatuated experience with a comely young girl who is operating out of a leaky boat.  This is an unlikely liaison because of the differences in their lifestyle.  Why would an academic man fall so heavily for a flighty and slightly scary backwoods denizen?  He tells us in his narrative that a sexual encounter is not foremost in his mind, but we are left wondering exactly what it is that has ensnared him.  In fact, he tells us more than that.  He lets us in on his own sketchy behavior before his meeting up with Madeleine.The runaway from Appalachia sees things, hears things, and says things that would scare the crap out of a normal person.  Yet the good professor continues to get deeper and deeper into their relationship to the point he is now being prosecuted for her murder.He brings up many questions.  Is he a past abuser of women?  Does his consorting with this disturbed young woman make him a likely suspect in her disappearance?  Are his repeated denials of committing abuse or of having a sexual connection with this girl reliable?  His past history and all the evidence of his escapades with Madeleine (is that really her name?) would seem to indicate that he also operates a boat with holes in it.Peter Gilboy is a former university professor, intelligence officer, truck driver, bartender, and short-order cook.  He drew from his experience in all these ventures in the writing of “Madeleine’s Kiss.”  He has a couple of other novels that are themed the same as “Kiss,” psychological dramas that feature sexual drama and lots of questions about personal behavior.  He is a strong writer, good with grammar, and able to develop his story in such a manner that the reader may feel that he or she has the storyline under control.  But the surprises keep coming and the results usually surprise the smug.I liked this book and will be reading more of Peter Gilboy.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

CIRCLING THE SUN REVIEWPaula McLain is a polite writer who doesn’t dish the dirt on the subjects of her historical novels.  In “The Paris Wife,” her study of the early years of marriage between Ernest Hemingway and his first wife, Hadley Richardson, she was very kind about Hemingway’s personality and behavior, and almost forgot about Richardson’s chronic alcoholism that plagued her in later years.  In my opinion, for some reason, their lifestyle among the “Lost Generation” in Paris was not realistically dealt with.And so it is in “Circling the Sun,” McLain’s historical novel about Beryl Markham, renowned as the first woman horse trainer in Africa, owner of numerous horses that won championships all over The Dark Continent, and first aviatrix to fly the Atlantic Ocean solo East to West.  She could ride and shoot like a man and threw a better spear than most of her male African counterparts.  She could also run faster and leap higher than them.  But the book, written in the first person as though Markham is telling her own story, doesn’t really let us see the other woman who had countless affairs, bedded Prince Henry, son of King George V and Queen Mary, and accepted a trust fund pay-off to stay away from the prince.  She also sponged off her friends when her funds ran low, and was, as Ernest Hemingway described her, ... “to my knowledge very unpleasant and we might even say a high-grade bitch, (but she) can write rings around all of us…” Yes, she was also a writer, although that has also been disputed over the years.Many famous people of that period appear in McLain’s book including a fascinating love triangle involving Karen Blixen, who later wrote “Out of Africa” as Isak Dinesen, her lover Denys Finch Hatten, and Markham.  The author doesn’t describe anger, jealousy, or reprisal to the trio, and only a little betrayal.  In real life, syphilis was in the area but seemingly not a barrier to their shenanigans, and also not reported by McLain.The author also chose to be stingy on details about Markham’s flying skills, how she attained them, and about her voyage across the Atlantic.  Only a small portion at the end of the book even mentions it.  Some have said Markham’s struggle in the darkness of the mid-Atlantic to keep her engines running is the most terrifying flying experience ever described.So McLain soft-pedals the shortcomings and some of the glories of her subjects.  She is actually a first-rate writer who tells a compelling story, describes the beauties of Africa in glorious language, and brings us great heights of entertainment not normally reached by lesser scribes.  Her skills are superb and I don’t seriously question her writing choices.  I suppose it’s not necessary to show the underwear of everyone who gets written about, but when the subjects have gloriously colored and widely discussed unmentionables, it would be nice to get a closer look.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

RENALDO REVIEW“Renaldo” is an intriguing book in which the author, James McCreath, has jammed a lot of stuff, and I don’t mean ‘stuff’ in a demeaning manner.  He has literally packed his book with seemingly disparate events, i.e. romance, terrorism, global soccer, politics, and history.  It all seems overwhelming until you begin reading and the carefully researched topics all fall into place, becoming important to the overall story.The storyline itself is simple.  A talented, affluent Argentian teenager, Renaldo De Seta, saves the life of a wealthy lawyer, Astor Gordero, who wields tremendous influence in all aspects of soccer and politics in Argentina.  As a reward, Renaldo is given a chance to try out for Argentina’s World Cup soccer team.  Renaldo becomes an idol after getting involved in rough-and-tumble team hazing and proving his worth in preliminary matches.  His older brother, Lonfranco De Seta, himself a talented and affable person, slowly descends into a world of dissatisfaction with the government and gets involved with terrorism and murder.And then there are the women, and a delectable bunch they are.  Symca, the most popular singing sexpot in Argentina, and fantasy object of every man, turns Renaldo from a shy and virginal boy into a lustful time bomb.  She is replaced by Englishwoman Mallory, who wants Renaldo on her soccer team and in her bed.  And there’s Celeste, a violent terrorist who knows how to manipulate Lonfranco into her personal instrument of radicalism; a dangerous liaison if there ever was one.It’s a very good story, if somewhat overwritten in spots.  McCreath writes riveting soccer action scenes. At times his dialogue vacillates from flowery to overblown but is very well done in most instances.  I believe he should try to be more consistent in his verbal exchanges.  The ending is somewhat vanilla as compared to the rest of the story.Soccer, unlike some American sports, has staggering international appeal that continues to grow.  Over 240 million players are registered with FIFA worldwide and billions of fans are maniacal in their support.  Its website is recording over 2 billion viewers worldwide, far outdistancing any other sports website.Despite the popular uproar about the sport, very little worthwhile adult soccer fiction has been written.  This becomes an interesting read because McCreath has done the research necessary to bring realism and timeliness to his story.  I found it enjoyable and very informative.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE BAREFOOT LAWYER REVIEWImagine wending your way through your house and yard then down the street to your mailbox in total darkness.  There would be the usual impediments along the way; furniture, doorways, planters, gates, garden hoses, cars, curbs, trashcans.  You could not see them.In “The Barefoot Lawyer,” author Chen Guangcheng describes a much more dangerous passage.  Totally blind since an infant, Chen had to negotiate the backyards of his poor Chinese neighborhood, through gates, over walls, and through goat pens as he made a desperate attempt to escape his captors who were holding him under house arrest.  A civil rights activist in modern China, Chen, after being released from four years in prison, had been subjected to two years of brutal confinement in his tiny house.  He needed to escape and subsequently get his family to safety.It took eight hours to negotiate the first 100 feet.  Along the way, he broke an ankle, sent a herd of goats into a braying frenzy, caused an mentally ill adult to break into a screaming fit for his mother, but somehow escaped detection from some twenty four guards who were specifically deployed to keep an eye on him.  Several days later he turned up at the American embassy in Beijing, dehydrated, hungry, and filthy dirty.Chen’s memoir is an illuminating account of animosity towards China’s system of oppressive government that features brutality, oppression, and total disregard for human dignity.  Today he is an important voice for human rights in China and the amazing story of his flight to freedom will stir the heart and soul of every person who reads this saga.There is much to learn in the book about the oppressive and inhumane policies in China.  It is also a mesmerizing account of the handicap of being blind and the struggle to exist in a world of darkness, misunderstanding, and harassment, every day occurrences for those who cannot see.Another shocker is that after escaping the clutches of a brutal government, Chen found that his safe haven of democracy, freedom, and human rights advocacy was, in fact, a nest of United States officials who were prone to giving in to China’s demands.  In his book Chen is careful to thank the Americans for their shelter, but is still troubled by their condescending partnership with his oppressors.It is difficult to imagine the world of the blind.  In a particularly beautiful passage in the book, Chen, as a young student, is asked to describe a waterfall.  Drawing from images in his mind, he describes it as “a screen of pearly beads,” a depiction that both enthralls his teacher and produces a tirade at the rest of the students who can’t describe something they can actually see.This is a good book that, along with uncovering the treacherous Chinese government, will make you more appreciative of the constant struggles of the blind.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

This is a great little tool, replacing the monstrous full-sized bolt cutter that fills up my tool box.  I realize the cutter isn't going to work on big locks or anything of any size and toughness, but it is perfect for cutting through smaller items.  Haven't had a chance to really give it a meaningful test because of the Vine program's short reporting period, but I have no doubt this item is a winner.

CRUDE CARRIER REVIEWI find nothing about Rex Burns, author of “Crude Carrier,” having experience aboard any type of ship.  He mostly writes detective stories around the Denver area where he lives.  Burns has moved from his normal writing tendencies to the pitching deck, claustrophobic confines of an ocean-going transport vessel, and the complexities of petroleum commerce.  His knowledge and ability to write about on-board life aboard a crude oil ship is a radical change and indicates a devotion to intensive research.Howard Pease (1894-1974) is a legend for his tramp steamer adventures written for young adults in the mid 20th century.  As a young boy I was mesmerized by the sinister confines and intrigue found aboard freighters and still have every book he wrote in my library.  But Pease had much to draw on as he presented his wondrous stories because he lived the life of a crewman on this type of vessel.  I find Burns also has an authentic voice about adventures at sea, despite his lack of background, and I don’t find a false step in his writing.  Perhaps his background as a Marine Captain helped a bit.The details he describes about the workings, procedures, and life aboard a large vessel are enlightening.  His casual allusions about claustrophobia aboard a steel can on surging endless waters are realistic enough to bring shivers to my sensitive core.  My innards do not suffer confinement gladly.  There is also authenticity in his descriptions of the electronics the protagonist must maintain aboard the ship.  Again, I see dedication to research.Critics might point out that getting a job as third officer on a ship of this size with zero maritime experience is an unlikely event.  Also, to have the entire staff of command officers of a large-scale crude oil transport, including the Captain, be heavily involved in criminal activity including murder might be a stretch.  And the disappearance of millions of gallons of crude would likely raise a few more eyebrows than are lifted in the story.  But, as I have said many times, it’s the author’s book and he has license to write anything he feels comfortable with.  I enjoyed the novel and didn’t feel a bit hoodwinked by these developments.His use of a female sidekick is done with respect and careful consideration of the fact that sex does not have to be flaunted in every mystery story.  She is not a superwoman but adds an important element to the story.Burns writes in a terse and brawny style and his depictions are convincing and magnetic.  This is an entertaining and illuminating report on the transportation of crude oil and the corruption surrounding its commerce.  I enjoyed the book and heartily recommend it for an entertaining read.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor f TIN LIZARD TALES

WOLF WINTER REVIEW“Wolf Winter” is set in the dark and endless winter of northern Sweden under a foreboding mountain known as Blackasen.  The year is 1717, times are tough, and the populace is struggling with animus, poverty, and superstition.  When the dismembered body of a man is discovered in the wilderness, many strange theories surface about his demise.  Maija, a local woman, whose daughters find the body, is convinced that a murder has occurred, but her neighbors believe a bear or wolves killed and mauled the man.  And so a long and black tale of conflict begins, a twisting drama of betrayal, superstition, accusation, and sorcery.The author, Cecilia Ekback, has developed an interesting story as she sets Maija to the task of uncovering secrets being held by both the church and prominent leaders of the community.  Unfortunately, a good plot struggles because her storytelling skills come up short.  I was unable to get a strong feel for Maija’s resolve, couldn’t interpret the meaning of her thoughts or those of her witchlike daughter, and couldn’t account for the wicked behavior of church officials.  As the story progressed, these actions became more and more abstract to the point that I lost interest and struggled to finish the book.The expression “Wolf Winter” in Swedish (Vargavinter) refers to an unusually long and severe winter.  It is also used to describe the darkest time of a human’s life; literally taken as the wolves have eaten the sun.  With that sort of essence, this book has wonderfully chilling possibilities.  They don’t materialize, although I desperately wanted them to.  The author presents some great insight into ethnic distrust and superstitious ignorance, but fails to create a stirring story.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE REVIEWAnthony Doerr is a celebrated writer whose first successes were with short stories.  He has added fiction, nonfiction, and memoirs to his repertoire, creating a short but notable list of credits.  The list of prizes he has won is impressive.  “All the Light We Cannot See” won the big one—the Pulitzer.  It is deserving.Two children of the 1940s, a blind French girl and a German boy prodigy, travel separate but converging paths during the last days of the Second World War and meet briefly as Germany nears defeat.  Their story is poignant, filled with individual terrors, and ends with a compassionate encounter amidst the rubble and horror of warThe girl, Marie Laure, blind from the age of six, lives with her father in Paris where he is master of the locks at the Museum of Natural History.  He builds her a scale model of their part of the city so the girl can navigate on her own with her feet and cane.  He hides a diamond of great value deep within it.  When the Germans occupy Paris, father and daughter flee to Saint-Malo on the Brittany coast where she ends up in her great uncle’s six-story narrow house, full of stairways, doors, and murky hidden spaces.  There she remains hidden with her treasure and uncle’s forbidden radio as the war rages around her.In Germany the boy, an orphan, displays a mastery for building and fixing radios, a skill that places him in a military academy noted for its selectivity and brutality where he ultimately becomes an expert tracker of Resistant partisans and their radio traffic.  His activities take him to Russia and eventually to Saint-Malo, where he discovers Marie-Laure living in her own dark world, hiding from the Germans and the war.Doerr is adept at intermingling the many lives that make up the story.  The Germans, French partisans, shopkeepers, scientists, and frightened residents are realistically depicted, their actions detailed. The book is lengthy but is so gloriously written that, aided by the writer’s use of spare language and brief chapters, time passes quickly.  The book has been criticized as being too simplistic, but I applaud the writing style that emphasizes clear narration and lyrical use of words.Factual background adds to the richness of Doerr’s writing.  Thescience of the mind, and matters of the heart are explored in the story but are so seamlessly inserted in the narrative they seem natural and unobtrusive.Doerr’s research into the diverse fields of radio, invertebrates, firearms, precious stones, and flora and fauna shows up in his expert discourses and accounts for the 10 years he needed to get this book written.  He reports that he wrote two additional books during the time he was putting together “All the Light.”I recommend this book as an illuminating look at a writer who is at the top of his game.  The skills of plotting, characterization, wording, and scenic description are on full display, creating a great reading experience.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN REVIEWPaula Hawkins has created a blockbuster in “The Girl on the Train.”  It’s a smash hit that tops every book-selling list.  Yet, when I read it, I wonder why all the adulation?  It’s a good book, somewhat suspenseful, but certainly not the masterpiece that earns such raves.It’s alternately narrated in the first person by three women who drag horribly overloaded baggage.  Rachel, Megan, and Anna and their men revolve around each other through sordid events that seemingly never end.  They exploit each other, betray each other, stalk each other, make love to each other, lie to each other, and then discard each other until they need each other again.  Oh, and there’s a masculine and dusky psychologist who enters the rumble and promptly forsakes the tenets imposed by his profession.  Somewhere in this sordid mix is a murderer, easily detected about halfway through.I find the crazy quilt of relationships too complicated to be believable.  The frame of mind the author assigns to each woman becomes eerily similar and not particularly of a sort to generate much sympathy.  The men seem to be irresolute and too self-involved to be able to handle the ladies and are inclined to be finding comfort in frequent quickies with each other’s mates.Yes, it’s a murder mystery but I can’t call it a thriller.  Without a compassionate feeling for the characters, I’m not terribly interested in their problems or the solutions.  I don‘t detect any aha moments and, with no probing and relentless detectives in the picture, I am ready to roll over and go to sleep.I know there are readers who enjoy simplicity in chill and thrill novels.  Immoral characters abound in novels these days and writers get rich by detailing their wanton ways.  But I need more depth, more realism, and more suspense.  Hawkins has a way with the weather in England.  The gloomy, wet, and picturesque landscape populated by taciturn Britishers who love their dismal pubs is well represented in her descriptive writing.  But a stunning story isn’t present for me.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

IT’S A LONG STORY REVIEWMy image of Willie Nelson goes like this; a grizzled little guy standing at a microphone, singing with a nasally twang and picking the crap out of an old, banged up guitar with a hole in it.  Then, from the backdrop of a wrinkled t-shirt and pigtails comes fascinating music with bewitching phrasing and impeccable rhythm.  When you say “Willie Nelson” to others, they chuckle at the image until the music starts.  Then his quivering voice and nimble fingers become captivating.The correct way to envision Willie is as a wondrous performer and songwriter who doesn’t give a fig about what people think of him, how he lives, or how they see him.  Once the scruffy image disappears, admiration moves in.  Should I be concerned about being critical about Willie’s first impression?  I don’t think so.  It’s been carefully cultivated and embraced, and Willie will be the first to tell you he doesn’t care what you think.“It’s a Long Story” shows that, along with his musicality, he’s also a good writer.  He expresses his feelings about his music and memories clearly and with feeling.  As he puts it, this book is the story of a song picker from Texas who has managed his stormy nights and sun-filled days by “staying close to the music of my heart.”  It’s a song he wants to sing to you, the reader.He is profane, opinionated, and full of spunk but his writing is as lyrical and captivating as his songs and the melodies he wraps around them.  To read him is to hear his musicality.  His words are sometimes hard to digest because of the habits he embraces, but there’s no questioning the intensity of his desire to bring his song to the world, wrinkles and all.His life of carousing, drinking, and smoking weed isn’t relevant to his music or his writing.  It’s all part of being Willie, of getting him to his work, of quieting his world to allow the words and music to flow.Willie surrounds himself with family and friends and exalts in their company.  His cronies in the music world, many with his same attitude about life, are all here and get outed about their habits to some extent.  But the indifference to other people’s opinion about their life style seems universal.  To me that’s okay because I’ve come to the same place myself.This book will be enjoyed by music lovers because of its honesty and because of the prurient details about living a rambling life with no guilt.  Willie’s freewheeling life has brought alternating periods of joy and murkiness but his euphoria about life in general has allowed him to overcome the obstacles.  There are many lessons to learn here for a receptive reader with an open mind.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THINGS THAT MATTER REVIEWIt would be a good idea to have a dictionary handy while reading Dr. Krauthammer’s collection of insightful observations, “Things That Matter.”  The erudite author is clearly dedicated to plain speak but occasionally, like a body tic, he throws in a word that makes me fumble for Webster’s definitions.  Sometimes even that doesn’t help.I’m okay with that because I feel so much more intelligent after I read his material.  I even understand and applaud most of it.  I know.  I’m showing my conservative underwear.  But if you really concentrate on his ideas about civility, political foolishness, scientific and medical wonders, man and God, the Jewish question, terrorism, and life’s oddities, you will find much with which to agree.Along with his common-sense look at all things we encounter, he displays a jovial sense of humor and an appreciation of nonsensical happenings that enlivens his writing.He writes in defense of the F-word.  He makes fun of the American tendency towards arrogance.  He embraces the joy of losing with his devotion to the Washington Nationals.  He considers it a slow news day when the naming of the President’s dog is the leading topic of media conversation.So, you see, he is not all egg headed and solemn.  There’s twisted and whacky material in that splendid brain.Dr. Krauthammer is a magnificent thinker and writer.  It’s one thing to have a mind that can comprehend a myriad of complex issues and quite another to be able to explain them to a normal person.  Many geniuses of the world labor in obscurity because of this shortcoming.  Not so with this wise man and gifted communicator.Charles Krauthammer doesn’t have to go away when you close the book.  He writes a weekly column for a Washington D.C. newspaper that should be a must read if you are a fan.  He’s also a frequent contributor to a major TV network.  He has to be considered a national treasure regardless of your personal political leanings and this book is a tribute to his clearheaded thinking.  Read it as soon as possible.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

The Weber line of barbecues get high ratings.  I like the workmanship of this E-310, it gets high ratings, it's attractive, and it was fairly easy to put together.  It has a misalignment with the burner controls and I can't figure out why.  It all works well and does a fine job at its main function of cooking as long as one doesn't use too high a temperature.  Five stars except for the alignment problem.

There are many of these types of movements out there.  Unfortunately there are too many that are inferior and don't hold up.  The Takane movement gets high ratings for durability and workmanship but the proof is how long the clock keeps working.  I will have a better idea about the value of this particular movement in about ten years.

NOTHING DAUNTED REVIEWThe author of “Nothing Daunted,” Dorothy Wickendon, is the most fortunate of biographers.  She had a treasure trove of letters, news clippings, and family remembrances on which to develop her story.  Historical researchers and writers are ecstatic when finding such abundant material.Her grandmother. Dorothy Woodruff, and close friend of eighty-three years, Rosamond Underwood, will be two of the most likable and adventurous women the reader will ever meet.  In their late twenties, with open spirits and inquisitive minds, the two ladies signed on to be teachers in the remote high country of Colorado.  They knew nothing of being a teacher or of subsisting in a turbulent environment, but overcame all the hurdles with their eager and resolute attitude.The amazing thing about their comments is the absence of complaints or odious remarks about anything or anybody they encounter.  It’s almost Pollyannaish in its reading, yet refreshing and delightful in our contemporary world of distasteful literary efforts.Dorothy’s letters are filled with insight and amusing anecdotes.  I squirmed when reading of the flea infestation found in the straw flooring of Parisian carriages.  And I understand her perplexed look at Matisse paintings.  She was opinionated and set in her ways, but in an agreeable and down-to-earth manner.There are interesting glimpses at Isadora Duncan, Nijinsky, and Agnes de Mille, who, as a thirty-year-old dance instructor, wanted to see a real square dance.  She came to Elkhead, witnessed and joined in the locals’ dance, and ended up in the sagebrush when she was pitched through the door at the end of a “crack the whip” step.  Seven years later she danced the lead in her ballet, “Rodeo,” to Aaron Copeland’s rousing score, crediting her trip to Elkhead as the inspiration.There’s not a disagreeable character in story.  Perhaps the most intriguing is Ferry Carpenter, a local lawyer, who hires the two women and becomes their guardian angel.  He is about their age, kind and solicitous, and I sense a romantic entanglement never acted upon until Ros marries him after the death of her husband many years later.This book is an uplifting look at the goodness in people, not only in Dorothy and Ros, but also in the people they encounter.  That feeling of benevolence is extended to the author as she interviews the expanded group of family members from the early days of Elkhead, Hayden, and Oak Creek.  Wickendon’s gift for language, passion for research, and painstaking construction of complex relationships will fascinate you.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

GREEN DOLPHIN STREET REVIEWI first read “Green Dolphin Street” when I was about fourteen, motivated, no doubt, by the 1947 movie that featured exciting scenes of sailing, New Zealand, earthquakes, tidal waves, wild weather, natives, and swashbuckling adventure.  The fact that it starred Lana Turner and Donna Reed was surely a factor because of their luminous beauty that scratched the libido of a teen aged boy.I remember the read as a good one, although, as I grind through it now, it seems stodgy, overwritten, and full of sermonizing.  That’s normal for Elizabeth Goudge (1900-1984) who was known to be very religious and painstakingly deliberate in her writing.  The story of two siblings, an adventurer fond of drink, a rough-hewn lumber man, a glorious clipper ship with it’s heroic captain, a glorious country filled with cannibals, and romance that borders on sappy is the makeup of Goudge’s story.  My copy is very old with dog-eared pages and a strong mildewy smell.  Possibly that has shaped my opinion.I haven’t found much on Goudge’s background but there has been no indication that she ever visited or researched New Zealand.  That makes for some question as to the authenticity of her setting.  I’m a stickler for authenticity.  She was, however, a prolific writer, and is still highly regarded, a standing that enhances her believability.I recommend this book for romantics who like a touch of adventure, distantly in the style of Bronte or Austen.  Goudge should be admired for her strong characterizations and scenic descriptions.  Some of her writing is beautifully wrought with exhilarating  accounts of weather and ocean.The book is lengthy with small type, making it a drudge to read.  But if historical romance is your primary reading preference, “Green Dolphin Street” might be for you.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

SILENT CREED REVIEWThis is my first reading of Alex Kava and the expertise she shows at plotting a crime story is a strong indicator of why she has so many books published in the genre.  In “Silent Creed” she combines the exploits of expert dog handler, former marine Ryder Creed, with an FBI forensics’ expert, Maggie O’Dell, already an iconic Kava character.  This is their second adventure together and probably more are on the way.Creed is deployed to North Carolina with his dogs to sniff out victims in a monstrous landslide.  There he finds O’Dell, a former colleague (and perhaps more), who is assigned to prowl around in her role as FBI agent because some of the bodies found have been murdered.  Somewhere under all the trees, rocks, and mud is a secret government research lab where clandestine experiments have politicians and military big wigs nervous about what might be discovered in the rubble.  That’s about it for the plot.Of interest is the way Kava lets us follow the dogs, by far the most interesting of all her characters.  They are brave, talented, and lovable.  The humans could be imbued with some of these traits to make them a little more engaging as well.  Creed spends most of his time trying to recuperate from numerous injuries and O’Dell is a hardback with mostly negative feelings towards other people.  The author seems determined to make them either unlikeable or maladroit, although they seem to strike a favorable chord with some readers.Kava’s writing is straightforward and not focused on major thought-bending ruminations on the part of the characters.  The story is clearly written and the plot line well developed.  There are many flashbacks that add some level of confusion, but mostly the book proceeds in an orderly fashion and gets down to business.The author has researched her dog information and is well versed in animal behavior and handling techniques.  This makes for dogs we all can love.The book ends with obvious clues that something more is coming.  As prolific as Kava is, we will, no doubt, see more of the dogs and of her signature characters.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

BACKYARD REVIEWNorman Draper, author of “Backyard,” from what I can learn, is about as eccentric and free-spirited as the characters he brings to life in this delightfully whacky book.  He’s a long time journalist with an impressive list of publications to his credit, none of which we’ve ever heard of.  I suggest that “Backyard” will provide the impetus for a more notable writing career.A small upper mid-west town is populated with a mélange of characters who demonstrate their many quirks with impetuous and outlandish behavior.  The most prominent conduct concerns their interest in gardening where egos, presumptiveness, jealousy, and greed are the byproducts.  When a local nursery introduces a gardening contest with a huge first prize, the horns come out and widespread goring takes place.There is a self-declared expert with a mail-order doctorate in gardening who will stop at nothing to get her hands on the cash.  There is a middle-aged couple who enjoys the beauty and notoriety of their backyard through wine-tinted eyes and over-indulgent spending that threatens their retirement savings.  There’s a garden witch, a quivering sycophant who fawns over garden expertise, and other assorted characters that will all come together in a riotous encounter where a knife, a tomahawk, and a baseball bat become weapons of hilarity.The contest winner and circumstances surrounding the decision shall remain a secret that you can solve by reading the book.Draper’s characterizations are masterfully constructed and I defy the reader to not recognize any of the figures as being family or friends.  Painful or not, these people have been around us many times.Draper does a remarkable job at producing silliness and pomposity as a way of life.  His insight into human frailty is clever and well presented, and his dialogue fits right into the merriment.  This is a great book, ready made for book clubs, and enjoyable reading.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE DINNER REVIEW“The Dinner” is a bewildering book.  It’s full of opinions, odd reactions, pomposity, family communion and dysfunction, and decisions that promote reflective musings.  It’s a disturbing story filled with dark undertones and reminders of parental obsession with the protection of their young.  In some ways it’s a little over the top.The writer, Howard Koch, assaults the reader’s sensitivity as he explores this primeval impulse of protection.  Koch explains that the narrator, Paul, in the process of protecting his child, is hiding something from himself as well.  He is unable to control his emotions and his response to those who displease him is to deal out physical punishment.  That influences his thinking.His brother, Serge, is a pompous egoist who revels in his own importance.  The fact he might be the Netherlands next prime minister weighs heavily on his mind.  There is constant tension between the two brothers, a failed teacher and a political big wig.They decide to have dinner with their wives to discuss the behavior of their two sons who have committed a heinous act.  The meal evolves into an affair of roiling emotions and riotous conflict filled with accusations, missed signals, and differences of opinion.  What is apparent is their boys are pawns in a game of dodging responsibility and covering up embarrassing behavior.Set in an elegant Amsterdam restaurant, the diners combine moments of condescension and accusation, along with bellicose exchanges with the restaurant staff and huffy retreats from the table.  The solutions are explored with obvious disagreement between all parties.  And, to the writer’s credit, he doesn’t impose his idea of what the solution should or will be.  The reader will determine any conclusion.  This might be unsatisfactory to some who like solid endings.This is a book that will promote some thinking in the reader.  Where and how far does the love of our children take us as protectors?  How much does our behavior reflect in our children’s development?  And how far should we let our emotions rule our actions?  My emotions gave this book four stars instead of five.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

MASTERS OF THE GAME REVIEWFinally Joseph Epstein has taken his immense talent and intelligence and directed them to writing something I understand: Sports.  In “Masters of the Game,” Epstein has departed from topics such as the lives of writers, snobbery, ambition, de Tocqueville, and literary education to direct a book of essays at sports, its luminaries, and the happiness of being a spectator.  Ah, the joy.I have had occasion to admire Epstein’s works, especially those I understand.  He is a most intelligent and prolific writer, occasionally controversial, but mentally superior to many writers out there and a marvelous voice on behalf of those who toil at games and those who admire the struggle.In this, his twenty fifth book, he explains that sports is a noble outlet for “violent emotions, regaining adolescence, discovering metaphysical truths”…explaining why television sets glow all night and monstrous stadiums explode with lights and noise all over the world.  And he reminds us of those who play or have played the game, the likes of Thorp, Cobb, Dempsey, and modern idols such as DiMaggio, Jordan, and Ted Williams.  He has intelligent musings on gambling, Jewish athletes, performance enhancement, the effects of money, and even juggling.His erudite introduction is a precursor of the intensity and attraction of the book.  I can’t think of another writer who has as much insight and important things to say about sports.  It’s an extremely intelligent commentary that will leave the reader with a highly inflated IQ.  Sports aficionados won’t want to miss this one.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

SALTWATER COWBOYS REVIEWDayle Furlong, author of “Saltwater Cowboys,” comes from a long line of miners.She is a Canadian, originally from Newfoundland, and begins this story at a time when mining jobs are drying up and the miners, unskilled at anything else, are desperate for any job that can provide for them and their families.The story centers on the struggle of a couple of friends and their families who are forced to the gold mines of northern Alberta after losing their jobs in Newfoundland.  When they arrive, they find themselves outsiders (East coasters are considered “Saltwater Cowboys”) in an atmosphere of resentment.  Jack McCarthy is the more reserved of the two, slightly crippled, and reluctant to protect himself from the slights and bullying they encounter.  Peter Fifield, Jack’s best friend since grade school, is pugnacious and not one who will step back, earning him many lumps and bruises.  They have a pact to always protect each other’s back, a promise that becomes more difficult for Jack to keep when Peter decides to start pilfering gold ore from the mine.The two men’s’ wives are also very different in temperament.  While Peter’s wife enjoys her ill-gotten windfall, Jack’s is distraught with the entire situation and blames him for her declining mental state.  After she loses an unborn baby, Jack sees her as becoming even more disagreeable.  After being swindled, he, in turn, becomes deceitful and unfaithful, eventually caving into the temptation his friend is waving around.There are many wrinkles to Furlong’s story that, in fairness to the author, I shouldn’t disclose.  She has done a great job of capturing the atmosphere of a sorrowful life and dysfunctional families caught up in surreptitious activity.  Personalities change.  Family relationships become strained.  Depression and self-loathing become all enveloping.  It’s a realistic and fascinating appraisal.I recommend Furlong’s book.  It’s carefully crafted and aimed at the heart.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

BAD KARMA REVIEWDwight Holing has the gift of gab and a smart- aleck attitude going for him.  I like the second, not so much the first.  “Bad Karma” is a fun book that could use a little trimming, but I’ve been accused of wordiness in the past and feel somewhat hypocritical.  So I won’t dwell on that pan.The protagonist, Jack McCoul, lives in San Francisco, the book is situated there, and I recognize many of the characters from my days in the glorious city.  Holing has a knack for bringing the city to life and it made the backdrop joyous.  However the people I remember were even more colorful than those portrayed by the author.  It’s probably just as well he backed off a little there because my acquaintances were mostly strung out, somewhat smelly, and not of much interest.McCoul has a shifty friend hanging around who hungers for stuff – things that belong to other people.  When a priceless gold Buddha disappears and the owner, a mega rich tech mogul gets murdered, McCoul and his wife are up to their necks in suspicion.  When the Buddha shows up in friend’s possession, McCoul is forced into a desperate search for the killer as he tries to elude a couple of nasty assassins, plays hide and seek with the police, and tries to clear the bombshell wife of the dead guy, his wife’s best friend, who is also implicated.  Yes, it’s complicated but aren’t all mysteries that amount to anything?Holing does a great job plotting this story.  His characterizations are strong; his scenes of mayhem are realistic; his dialogue is spot on for the environment he presents.  There are a lot of familiar things happening that I’ve read before, but they seem fresh under Holing’s careful writing.It’s good book, full of action and snappy banter.  As I mentioned, some word pruning wouldn’t hurt but I’m light on that criticism because the overall effect is still good and the story moves along without being ponderous.  I believe you’ll enjoy the book.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE WIVES OF LOS ALAMOS REVIEW“The Wives of Los Alamos” is Tarashea Nesbitt’s debut novel and it shines.  Nesbitt, in a unique style, delves into the people and attitudes behind a controversial episode in American history.  She presents insight into a way of life that is hard to imagine.  A secret remote desert location becomes home to six hundred and twenty families with no idea of why they are there. The young scientists and technicians involved in The Project are in the dark as to the purpose of their labors, the covertness of which impacts every inhabitant.  Even what little they do know cannot be shared with the family.Nesbitt, in a daring piece of writing technique, uses narration in the first person plural.  “Before we arrived at Los Alamos as wives and mothers we had been teachers in Seattle, housewives in New Jersey, watercolorists in Nebraska, writers in Des Moines, chemists at Harvard, and one of us had been a dancer in the Chicago ballet.”  As this example shows, the narrator has no individual traits.  We are given widespread examples of who the wives are without getting any individual attributes.  At first I found it somewhat disconcerting.  But the further I read the more I understood the author’s intention; an overall illustration of the environment without the burden of individual complexity.  I liked it.Now, of course, we all know the secret behind Los Alamos.  The husbands and fathers were scientists charged with developing portions of a nuclear weapon, although they were generally not aware of the end product or what was to be done with it.  The wives were allowed to accompany them to the site but had no idea of what was being developed because of the ban on sharing of information.Suddenly, all became clear when the atomic bombs were dropped on Japan. The secrets were no more.  A multitude of feelings surfaced as a result.  “Some of us thought we saved a half a million lives.  Some of thought we, or our husbands, were murderers, that we had helped light a fuse that would destroy the world.”  The author, throughout her book, as demonstrated here, presents both sides and doesn’t comment on the humanity of the product being developed.  The narration simply presents the many different behaviors and attitudes that might exist in a community that made such impact on the world.The author presents ideas on the social life, the jealousy, the flirting and affairs, gossip, and maybe some larceny committed because of the secrecy under which they all operated.  Those who were sacrosanct before the experience found themselves slipping into a life that was a little looser inside the rigid boundaries set upon them.  This slipping of morals, however slight, might be the biggest revelation about of the closeted life at Los Alamos.The author has done some great research and neither praises nor censures the residents.  Their circumstances are carefully laid out, their actions are outlined, the results are analyzed from several viewpoints, and the reader is left to decide whether or not to make judgments.The book is a marvelous chronicle of unsuspecting participants thrust into an alien place and time and how they survive.  At the book’s end, we are given a perspective on how life worked out for the families, both the adults and the children, after returning to a normal existence.  Great book with careful research and superb writing.  I highly recommend it.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

DOUBLE DOWN REVIEWTom Kakonis has been hailed as a successor to Elmore Leonard.  It’s true that his clever and gritty thrillers have some resemblance but I can’t put them in that lofty company just yet.  Leonard’s literary polish and creativeness set a high standard that Kakonis approaches, but this book doesn’t reach that level.The protagonist, Tim Waverly, is a gambler who seems to have a dark cloud hovering over him.  A drug boss warns him that he has two weeks to pay back $300,000 for some drugs he burned or face an untimely death. He manages to finagle his way into a high-stakes poker game with some big shot developers and a rich Arab prince where he hopes he can win enough money to pay the debt.  He realizes that even if he does come out a winner at cards, he will probably still be a target for hit men.  The story has many characters, many twists, and a lot of violence.  How Waverly survives the turmoil provides an ending that you will have to read for yourself.One character, Sigurd Stumpley, almost carries the story with his crude and boorish behavior.  Unfortunately he won’t be around for his own series but Kakonis might try to revive a similar spirit for a change-of- pace personality in his next stories.  A well-done portrait.I had a problem with unevenness in Kakonis’ writing.  One minute he is waxing philosophically with classical citations, the next he is spouting obscenities that would embarrass a longshoreman.  Periods of heavy introspection are interrupted with blasphemous rants about racial groups, fat women, and body functions.  Too much self-examination and deep thinking creates a wordiness that makes the clarity and flow seem murky.  Much of the verbosity could have been pared.Some snappy comebacks and great one-liners, however, kept me in the book.  The author has a great sense of humor that makes the dialogue sparkle in places.  An enjoyable read from an author with talent.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

DEAD FLOAT REVIEWWarren C. Easley is a writer who will give you an exciting read without putting you through a lot of mental gymnastics.  He tells his story in uncomplicated language at a pace you can handle.  “Dead Float, ” his 2014 novel, is the second about Cal Claxton, an everyday kind of guy who gets tangled up in messes he isn’t looking for, doesn’t want, then handles adroitly just because he has to.This story is about a fishing trip, the murder of one of the participants, a rush to judgment, and Claxton’s efforts to get from under the suspicion directed at him.  There are bad guys, good friends, beautiful women, and loyal pets woven together in a pleasantly spun narrative that eschews gory details and salacious sex.  There are great descriptions of the loveliness of Oregon, fishing scenes that make the homebound angler thirst for the river, and realistic dialogue that keeps the reader involved.  What Easley also provides is a well thought out sequence of events that are vividly described and engrossing.  And apparently the writer is a food fan; there are many references to victuals and the eating thereof.This book has just the right number of characters to provide interest, but not so many that the twists get knotted and snarled.  Other that the bad hombres, no one is really disagreeable.  My guess is that Easley has good, solid friends that he can use to sharpen his images.  I liked the book and can recommend it for a great summer read, especially along one of Oregon’s streams while waiting for the hatch to rise.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE ONE THAT GOT AWAY REVIEWIf nothing else about the INS thrills us, we can thank the agency for getting Simon Wood into writing.  It took so long for Wood to get residency clearance when he arrived from the UK he was forced, despite the fact he was dyslexic, to write some dozen books and a hundred short stories just to make a living.He has other interests, of course, but the theme of conflict drives most of his writing.  In “The One That Got Away,” the protagonist is suffering from survivor guilt after being abducted, along with her girlfriend, by a maniac who treats them badly, then kills friend Holly after Zo Sutton frees herself and flees the scene.  A year later she gets involved with a law enforcement investigation of another abduction that resembles her own.  Although still consumed with guilt for abandoning her friend, Sutton get involved, generally makes a nuisance of herself until one of the investigators takes an interest in her obsession with finding the killer.  The madman discovers her existence and wants to get the one that got away.  I won’t go any deeper into the storyline, but suggest you read the book to unravel this inventive story.The important thing is to note is that Wood is a terrific writer who skillfully prepares his plot, realistically constructs his dialogue, and sets the scenes with an adroit command of language that places the reader right in the middle of the happenings.  How he manages that under the spell of dyslexia is perplexing to me who has no problem of that sort but who struggles with language in general.Some of the occurrences in the book are somewhat far fetched but Wood handles that with a casual flap to his writing style that says, “It’s my book, my vision, my idea, so deal with it and move along.”  I like that attitude and applaud Wood for his innovation.  I think you will agree that it’s a good, suspenseful, and entertaining read.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

SUFFER THE CHILDREN REVIEWRobert Earle, after retiring from a twenty-year career as a United States diplomat, is attending to his first love of writing.  He is prolific and talented.  “Suffer the Children” is his take on circumstances that might arise from threats we face from gunmen who target schools.  He uses the December 15, 2012, massacre in a Connecticut elementary school as the basis for this story.An intense and somewhat disoriented retired Army General, Budge Kleeforth, renews his romantic interest in Pru Malvaeux, an earler love affair that ruined both his marriage and his career.  Together with a reclusive genius, they develop a defensive weapon that is intended to disable shooters, not kill them, and protect school children and teachers from the devastating effects of school mass shootings.  He takes his idea to his hometown, in close proximity to the school that was victim to the 2012 massacre, and convinces the anxious community to participate in a pilot program to introduce the non-lethal weapon into the classroom.Earle manages to capture all the drama and controversy such a program would initiate.  There’s indecision on the part of community leaders.  Strong pro and con opinions are voiced.  The gun industry sees a threat to its position on weapons ownership and usage.
