And local teenagers believe they are best able to sort out the threats in their own community.Pru and Budge are eventually separated by conflicting ideas about their own involvement.  Pru sees a threat to her regaining the custody of her children and the ever goatish Budge finds a new love interest that tarnishes his enthusiasm for the program.  In the background the arms interest attempts to buy out the defensive weapon idea.  And, an intriguing side plot develops as a new shooting threat arises from an unexpected source.Earle’s writing is intriguing and uneven by design.  The entire topic of maniacal killing of masses of people, especially children, is going to be controversial and full of disparate feelings.  Earle does a masterful job of capturing that imbalance in the thoughts and actions of his characters.I thought his idea behind a non-lethal weapon being wielded by a teacher to be somewhat unrealistic.  But this is a fictional story with allowances necessary on the part of the reader.  The book is well written, carefully thought out, and thought provoking.  It is well worth reading.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

XJ Kennedy is an icon and his poetry is magnificent, if somewhat obscure.  I suppose that's the criteria for most poetry which is why I'm not a poetry fan.  At least, with Kennedy, I understand most of what he's presenting;  for example, with "Nude Descending a Staircase," looking at the painting while reading the poem is an unforgettable experience.  And, "In a Prominent Bar in Secaucus,"  I've been there and met the lady.  Where does that mind come from?

THINGS THAT MATTER REVIEWIt would be a good idea to have a dictionary handy while reading Dr. Krauthammer’s collection of insightful observations, “Things that Matter.”  The erudite author is clearly dedicated to plain speak but occasionally, like a body tic, he throws in a word that makes me fumble for Webster’s definitions.  Sometimes even that doesn’t help.I’m okay with that because I feel so much more intelligent after I read his material.  I even understand and applaud most of it.  I know.  I’m showing my conservative underwear.  But if you really concentrate on his ideas about civility, political foolishness, scientific and medical wonders, man and God, the Jewish question, terrorism, and life’s oddities, you will find much with which to agree.Along with his common-sense look at all things we encounter, he displays a jovial sense of humor and an appreciation of nonsensical happenings that enlivens his writing.He writes in defense of the F-word.  He makes fun of the American tendency towards arrogance.  He embraces the joy of losing with his devotion to the Washington Nationals.  He considers it a slow news day when the naming of the President’s dog is the leading topic of media conversation.So, you see, he is not all egg headed and solemn.  There’s twisted and whacky material in that splendid brain.Dr. Krauthammer is a magnificent thinker and writer.  It’s one thing to have a mind that can comprehend a myriad of complex issues and quite another to be able to explain them to a normal person.  Many geniuses of the world labor in obscurity because of this shortcoming.  Not so with this wise man and gifted communicator.Charles Krauthammer doesn’t have to go away when you close the book.  He writes a weekly column for a Washington D.C. newspaper that should be a must read if you are a fan.  He’s also a frequent contributor to a major TV network.  He has to be considered a national treasure regardless of your personal political leanings and this book is a tribute to his clearheaded thinking.  Read it as soon as possible.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE STEADY RUNNING OF THE HOUR REVIEWJustin Go’s debut novel, “The Steady Running of the Hour,” is an epic love story including an intense study of the horrors of war and the climbing the world’s highest mountain.  It covers two centuries, mixes many cultures and traditions, is filled with complex characterizations, and travels all over the world.  It’s quite a trip, making for a long but satisfying read.Tristan Campbell learns he might be the heir to a huge estate left by famed mountaineer Ashley Walsingham who died on Mt. Everest in 1924.  After an unsettling meeting with a London law firm that claims to be legally prohibited from searching for heirs, Campbell, using his own rather meager funds, sets out in an attempt to satisfy the odd terms of the will.  There is a time limit, after which he will lose all rights to the inheritance.Some eighty years have passed since Walsingham’s death.  Campbell doesn’t have much family history to draw on so he gets off to a wobbly start. He tends to grasp at straws, causing the legal eagles to shake their heads and tell him he needs more facts.  He also finds a romance along the way that throws up some additional obstacles.  It seems a fool’s quest but he struggles on as time winds down.Go does a wonderful job of keeping all this turmoil under control.  His sense of time and place is well portrayed and his characterizations are nicely constructed.  One doesn’t get too enamored by any of the characters.  It’s all business and the author keeps it that way, not getting too bogged down with internal ruminations.  It’s an agreeable read that’s full of convincing developments.Go has worked hard at constructing this story.  Heavy research is evident, and the storyline is carefully worked out in spite of its complexities.  I was somewhat mystified and left wanting at the end, but that’s just me.  Readers will be able to apply their own interpretation to the way Go terminates his story.  It’s all in the eye of the beholder.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

MANHUNT REVIEWJames L. Swanson, noted Lincoln scholar, has to be considered as a premier writer of narrative non-fiction. “Manhunt: The 12-Day Chase for Lincoln’s Killer” is a masterpiece of a no-nonsense chronicle, crisp and to the point, and as exciting as any fictional detective story.  He has to be placed among the ranks of Larson, Krakauer, Junger, and Winchester.When John Wilkes Booth shot President Abraham Lincoln on the night of April 14, 1865, he set off a manhunt that is unparalleled in American history.  For twelve days he was hunted through the Maryland and Virginia wilderness by droves of frantic searchers desperate to capture the infamous killer of an American hero.Swanson has his information immaculately researched, tightly wound together, and deftly reported in suspenseful prose taking an event we are all familiar with and making it a new-born incident complete with some interesting revelations.Swanson takes us from a dusky little theatre box in Ford’s Theatre to a tobacco barn in rural Virginia, death being the common theme.  He describes the actions of a demented and angry man who sends a lead ball burrowing through Lincoln’s brain.  That’s followed by an intense 12-day chase that ends with a bullet through the neck and spinal cord of the assassin.  In between there’s day-by-day reporting of other assassination attempts by accomplices who fail at their assignments.  Secret locations are uncovered, deceit and incompetence is displayed, and physical hardship is endured. There are cowardly actions, foolish decisions, and extreme loyalty, all brilliantly depicted by the author.A Civil War enthusiast since he was five years old, Swanson’s personal War reference library numbers several thousand books.  He has a vast collection of Lincoln memorabilia, Civil War newspapers, original photographs and posters, trinkets, and medals.  He knows this stuff and can write about it with simplicity and beauty.According to a March 2015 article in “Smithsonian,” Swanson calls himself a “crazed collector who happens to write books.”  He has a swatch of actress Laura Keene’s dress stained with Lincoln’s blood in his collection, and it never left his sight as he wrote about what happened in the Presidential box. He “could see it all and the paragraphs wrote themselves.”This is a must read for history buffs and lovers of true detective stories.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES
I don't wear this version so have no opinion.  However my great grandson has a big smile on his face in his new undies so I have to say they're marvelous.

THE BULLY OF ORDER REVIEWBrian Hart tries to present a memorable story, displays some talent, but, in the end, falls prey to the bane of all authors; the tendency to dig too deep and losing focus.His story about life’s hardships in the late 1880s Pacific Northwest has elements of realism, some great descriptive passages, and formidable characters.  Unfortunately, as it progresses, demented mind reflections, drunken visions, and the disorganized handling of common affairs too often cloud episodes of interest.  It is these departures that turn a grand idea into a stumbling account with a fuzzy storyline.As a Pacific Northwest resident I welcome stories of the area and am appreciative of the many talented writers who recount its wonders.  The hardscrabble conditions of soggy and frigid weather, exploiting the natural bounty of lumber, fish, and glittery minerals, and living an independent, stubborn life make for many adventures that demand chronicling.  Hart does that but unfortunately his story becomes as dreary as the weather and his characters as unlikeable as rain down the neck.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

CLINTON CASH REVIEWPeter Schweizer certainly fits the definition of a muckraker; a reformed-minded journalist whose investigations dip into crooked politicians, unpleasant social issues, and ill-gotten money.  He even heads up an organization that specializes in exposing such malfeasance.  And, although muckraker is an ugly word, it’s not necessarily an offensive moniker.“Clinton Cash” is a bomb-tossing look at a couple of public figures who have long been targets of such investigations.  Bill and Hillary Clinton; the two names stir up a brouhaha of sentiment that is either highly derogatory or prompts breathless admiration.Schweizer’s book, as has been widely reported, is not complimentary but relies on solid information coupled with tireless research.  I’m sure he wears his title with head held high.In a complicated, well-grounded expose, the author delves into the seamy world of politics, bribery, greed, and favoritism.  The Clintons, if one believes what is written, are stars of a world where backs are scratched, huge amounts of money change hands in questionable deals, and powerful people ride the backs of those with immense influence.One of the questions that Schweizer asks repeatedly in his book is why do the Clintons get involved with so many people of ill repute?  He answers it with illustrations of the vast amounts on money the couple have accumulated through the years, particularly when Hillary was Secretary of State and could exert tremendous influence on worldwide decisions.  Bill has been paid millions of dollars to give speeches, mostly complementary, of scabby world leaders and corrupt public works processes, and has received huge donations to the family foundation along with immense speaking fees.  Shortly thereafter, Hillary makes favorable decisions in her official capacity that garner lucrative returns to the cash cows that more than justifying the initial investment.There are some who claim the Clintons could care less about money and influence.  The laughter that follows such declarations is loud and raucous.  Their storybook rise from rags to riches, haunted along the way with shady deeds, is not one of innocence and purity.There has been tremendous research into the premise of the book, all duly noted in the book notes.  The convoluted arrangements are mind-numbing but clearly laid out by the author.  Of course the reader’s political persuasion will dictate the believability.  It is both informative and stomach turningSchuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

PALACE OF TREASON REVIEWJason Matthews is a master at concocting intriguing spy stories.  His new novel, “Palace of Intrigue,” continues the adventures of Dominika Egorova and Nathaniel Nash who were introduced to readers in his Edgar Award winning “Red Sparrow.”  This book is a stand-alone story of current international political events presented in totally believable prose by someone who’s been there.Matthews, a retired CIA officer, with over thirty years of clandestine prowling around the world of international intelligence, knows of what he writes and the authenticity of his stories rings loud and clear.  His writing is crystal clear, his characterizations are right on, his dialogue crackles with reality, and his scenic descriptions are vivid and authentic.This book is not for the faint hearted.  Torture sessions and assassinations are presented in full color and striking detail.  The absolute evil of the villains makes one’s teeth hurt.  And an overabundance of dolts in high places is also carefully documented, giving just the right balance to his characters.In an epicurean touch, the author has included a recipe at the close of each chapter for a regional food treat that appears somewhere in the story.  They appear delicious; red lentil soup, potato pancakes with mushroom sauce, stuffed buns with beets, cold cucumber soup.  Unfortunately, when considered along with the circumstances under which they appeared in the text, I’ll wait awhile before I try them.The spy business is actually very wearisome and mundane except for brief periods of terrifying confrontations and constant expectation of a horrible death.  Matthews is very adept at bringing his reader along for these moments.  I urge you to indulge Jason Mathews, travel with him, and then enjoy the quiet when you return to your safe house.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

CHILDREN OF PARADISE REVIEWFred D’Aguiar in “Children of Paradise” is attempting to tell the story of the Jim Jones commune in Guyana.  In some ways it’s interesting but it mostly falls flat for me because of his attempts to bring poetry to a story that resists poetic musicality.The preacher, as the Jones inspired leader of the commune, performs sermons that mesmerize his followers and induces near catatonic disciples to follow his every command.  The author does a good job of wording the sermons so even the reader can see the overt seduction.  But the reality ends there.There is a gorilla called extraordinary by publicists that should be labeled unbelievable.  The characters wind in and out of a story that is hard to follow and the ending produces confusion and a sense of unfulfillment that renders the story unsettled.  We all know how the Jonestown tragedy really ended, yet the author adds mystery and conjecture to his story making it unfathomable.The author, a native of Guyana, writes beautifully of the attributes of the location.  His prose, however, written in the present tense, is less than intriguing and is sometimes difficult to decipher, perhaps too poetic in its construction.The book is an interesting look at mass hypnotism and the indecency of brainwashing, but stumbles as it tries to establish itself as authentic historical fiction.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE STORY OF LAND AND SEA REVIEWAs intriguing as Katy Simpson Smith’s debut novel “The Story of Land and Sea” might be, I find her personal thoughts and essence even more so.First, about the book.  It’s a turbulent tale, told gently, of the latter days of the American Revolution and the heartbreak of slavery.  The setting is a small town in North Carolina where three generations of family exist in the turmoil of war, abduction, slavery, and strange notions about love.There’s a strong wife and mother, Helen, a ten-year old daughter, Tabitha, the husband and father, John, who loses them both and ventures off in a strange voyage of discovery with the black son of Moll, a slave with strong personal ties to Helen.  Asa, Helen’s father, is the owner of a small plantation who had given Moll to Helen when they were both young girls and who, as later years provides conflicts to his beliefs, cannot bring himself to free Moll, invoking more struggles.  Sounds confusing and is, but Smith manages to present the tangled web in a well thought-out story.As for the author, Katy Simpson Smith, I find her to be a very interesting and talented woman who, in researching the history of mothers in the South, discovered that death during childbirth was very common during the late 1770s and fathers often had to raise daughters on their own.  The specter of their wives’ deaths created more tendencies to sort of mope around more than actually be leaders in the activities of the time.  Women taking initiative is a strong theme in this book.Smith reveals she is always nervous about speaking about people with different experiences than her own but she believes there is the responsibility to do just that.  She wants her research as an historian to create fiction that is factual for the period.As an example of her ingenuity, a wooden marker in an eighteenth-century graveyard in Beauford, North Carolina, inscribed “Little Girl Buried in Rum Keg,” inspired a notable incident in Smith’s novel.There is clarity of language and beatific scene setting in Smith’s writing.  There is also carefully cultivated characterization that allows the reader get vibrations of real human activity instead of being spoon-fed contrived behavior.  That’s refreshing.“Land and Sea” has captured all I expect from great historical fiction.  Captivating times, impeccable research, believable dialogue, and the chance to realistically revisit the glorious past are all here.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE NAKED CONSUMERHaving just read “Dead Wake,” Erik Larson’s latest blockbuster, and having consumed each of his previous novels, I ran across his very first book, a nonfiction account of how companies spy on the consumer.  I was curious as to how Larson would report on my least favorite social activity.  He handled it with remarkable aplomb.Published in 1992, when Larson was a free-lancer living in Baltimore, it’s a book he claims to love, although apparently no one else did.  It is not the booming hit his later novels have become, but I liked it and believe that the consumer, even more put upon now by sleazy marketing than when Larson wrote the book, would find it mesmerizing and should read it.Larson, in his clear and precise reporting, tells us how tax dollars have enabled marketers to find us, zero in on our secret wishes, and persuade us to buy things we don’t need.  We are all on lists that help companies locate us, determine what we are patsies for, and how to make us empty our pocketbooks.  The US Census, as have many other public agencies, although confidentiality is promised, has given immense amounts of information to companies that exist to sort through, quantify, and assemble data into lists that identify every person in our country by name, address, ethnicity, economic wealth, living condition, household makeup, religion, and any other characteristic that’s usable in determining vulnerability to marketing schemes...and to make a great deal of money doing so.This book is complex and mindboggling. To me it is also infuriating.  I’m not some nave dolt who thinks I exist in a vacuum, safe and secure in my cocoon of privacy.  But Larson has opened my eyes to an irritating conspiracy that, while seemingly harmless, is a pervasive intrusion into privacy.  Areas of my personal activity, the value of my home, credit limits on my charge cards, bank account balances, access to my passwords, PIN numbers and, perhaps my preference in underwear are all fair game to these scavengers, information I insist is none of their business.It never entered my mind that a little innocuous viewing window, the scanner at the checkout stand, could also pass on so much information about me. Combined with the frequent shopper card information I willingly passed out in exchange for gasoline savings, money bonuses, and premiums, it itemizes the commodities I purchase, screens, scores, analyzes the results, and digs deep into my existence.  Huge corporations lust for this information.The information here is dated because of when it was written.  I suspect that public infuriation at privacy invasion, manifest in the 1990s, is even greater now. Larson is urging us to recognize that privacy is indeed an unalienable right and that those charged with our protection must do so with dogged resolve.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

BLACK RIVER REVIEWI’ve read many novels this year with top-grade writing and satisfying stories.  S.M. Hulse’s “Black River” is among the best.  This is a debut novel and it’s a magnificent first effort.  I know nothing of Hulse, but I suspect that she will become a more familiar figure in the writing world.The story is not complicated.  The prose is crisp.  The characters are clearly delineated.  Dialogue is masterfully rendered.  And the author keeps introspection simple and unfettered, making the book easy to comprehend.  It is simplistic by the most positive definition.A corrections officer is taken prisoner some twenty years earlier by a sadistic inmate during a Montana prison riot.  The officer is tortured and his hands are horribly crippled, a significant infirmity because of his love for fiddling.  The ensuing years are a struggle as self-pity, thoughts of revenge, and depression disrupt his life and his relationship with a loving wife and his stepson.Now, at age 60, he returns to the prison town of Black River with his wife’s ashes intending to put her at rest and to attend a parole hearing that threatens to set his torturer free.  Hulse makes effective use of telling the story from both the man and his wife’s perspective.  Each is featured throughout the book, a technique that sometimes muddies the storyline, but one that the author handles with great dexterity.The book is filled with magnificent depictions about how the playing of a musical instrument can be so gratifying, how the loss of the skill can be so devastating, how words can never seem to fill an emotional gap, how earlier joy can become sour ashes.  The author displays an insight that far exceeds her youthful experience, a trait that signals great things ahead.I can recommend this rather morose book as an uplifting experience and the opportunity to celebrate a young writer’s talent.  It has moved to the top of my 2015 favorites.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE BOOTLEGGER REVIEWClive Cussler is often called the grandmaster of adventure and, indeed, he has authored over fifty books, many of them bestsellers.  But missteps happen, and “The Bootlegger,” in my opinion, is a stumble.The story is an involved study of the Prohibition era complete with hijackers, bootleggers, crooked cops, Coast Guardsmen on the take, and a private detective agency that defies description for its massive operations.  Throw in New Jersey, Wall Street, Florida, the Bahamas, Cuba, and Nassau, along with government intrigue, foreign secret agents, and weapons from all over the world and a reading stew of massive proportions is formed, much too difficult to divide into understandable portions.Throughout the book I felt like I was looking through small windows at a carousel, never really feeling involved with the whirling diversion inside.  I kept reading hoping that Cussler would throw the doors wide open at some point revealing all the revelry, but it never happened.I know the author can do better, and I’ll keep checking for something akin to the many blockbusters I’ve enjoyed in the past.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

DRIVING THE KING REVIEWThis book has an intriguing premise, a close look at Nat King Cole.  Cole is a musical icon whose life and times have been treated rather skimpily by writers.  Ravi Howard has attempted to change that with a fictional account of Cole and his driver/bodyguard Nat Weary.  As autobiographical fiction, it didn’t work for me.I know a little about Nat King Cole and discovered too many alterations of facts to place much credence to Howard’s story.  Too many holes crop up and too many incidents don’t square with reality.Cole was actually attacked in Birmingham, not Montgomery, and was rescued by the police, not by some courageous friend.  There were three attackers and a fourth who apparently was the getaway driver.  All four went to prison.  Cole was so angered by the attack that he refused to ever perform in the South again.Cole’s actual life was eventful and full of controversy.  He even ran afoul of the NAACP and was called a traitor and narrow-minded for his failure to actively challenge racial discrimination.  Both Thurgood Marshall and Roy Wilkins publicly chastised him for his indifference to racial matters.  He was deeply hurt and eventually joined in boycotts and became active in the civil rights movement.Cole was a womanizer who miraculously maintained good relationships with his ex-wives; in fact his second wife, Maria, was with him throughout his battle with lung cancer until he died in 1965.I mention a couple of events in Cole’s life to point out that Howard could have created a spellbinding story had he included more real Cole moments.Howard’s story is a good one, but suffers from the lack of an intriguing storyline.  Cole appears as a character behind drapery, never really being fully exposed.  This was not enough disclosure for me.  I wanted more Nat King Cole.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

DEAD WAKE REVIEWI consider Erik Larson to be one of our finest writers and have wolfed down each of his books.  I’m sure my reviews reflect this almost cultish devotion and “Dead Wake” certainly fits right in.Larson is obsessive about his research.  That, to me, is the most important quality of any great writer.  Getting mountains of information together and presenting it in an organized and entertaining book is the least writers can do if they expect to have a loyal following.  Even Larson’s end Notes are a joy to read.In “Dead Wake,” Larson follows many trails.  The Lusitania, a magnificent cruise ship, is filled with international passengers of many backgrounds and agendas who settle in for a pleasant voyage across the Atlantic.  It’s early in World War I and there are rumors of German submarines lurking near the English coast looking to sink such a fine prize.  But the travelers and crew ignore direct threats and rely instead on comforting assurance from the British Admiralty as to their safety and head east with little concern; not a wise decision.In the waters around the British Isles there’s a dedicated German U-boat captain, Walther Schwieger, who prowls the seas with orders to attack and sink troop transports that might be carrying personnel deployed to resupply British forces in France.  Larson, with his typical clarity, explains how the luxury liner, captained by William Thomas Turner, gets ensnared in a web of deceit, misinformation, and changes in German intent, that ultimately lead to it being torpedoed by Schwieger’s Unterseeboot 20.In Larson’s inimitable style, he tucks little bits of interesting facts into the pages that add to the reader’s ability to visualize the background, interpret the complicated forces that make up the story, and bring reality to the characters’ behavior and their involvement.  Suspense increases as lapses in protection are magnified by German persistence.We see Turner’s stubborn dedication that overcomes missteps in the early years of his career.  We are almost sympathetic to a U-boot captain who can, without a twinge of remorse, drive a torpedo into a ship filled with humanity but then be unable to watch the traumatic results. We experience an American president’s anguish over the loss of his wife and subsequent infatuation with another woman, the timing of said romance to be unfortunate when he should be exhibiting total attention to the American condition.There are studies of the passengers and their behavior, manner of dress, varied financial circumstances, and purpose.  Life aboard a submarine is detailed. There is glamour, suspense, family loss and triumph, official missteps, and the notorious Room 20, a most important element in this story.This book is another example of Erik Larson’s talent.  Don’t miss it.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

SAVAGE HARVEST REVIEWWhen I read the first ten pages of Carl Hoffman’s epic tale of Michael Rockefeller and his 1961 New Guinea explorations, I wondered where the author was taking it.  It appeared that he had answered the question of what happened to the young adventurer and there was no need to read further.  I was wrong.The author was setting the stage for what has been a perplexing riddle about Rockefeller’s disappearance.  Did he drown after setting out on a desperate swim to escape a watery grave?  Or did he survive the 10-mile swim only to be captured, murdered, and subsequently eaten by savages. Hoffman has attempted, through exhaustive research, interviews of witnesses, and four months living among the natives who allegedly were responsible, to piece together the actual events.The book jacket says Hoffman “finally tells the full, astonishing story.”  I don’t get that impression.  The author has investigated and pieced together a scenario that, at best, can be labeled probable.  It is not definitive and, indeed, has been rejected by the Rockefeller family as not viable and the cause of Michael’s death has been formally labeled as “drowning.”The Asmat, a tribe of warriors with an inscrutable culture of violence, cannibalism, and headhunting, has only recently been declared as free of those traditions.  However, members remain secretive and elusive about past occurrences and admit to giving answers that are evasive. They make things up while maintaining absolute secrecy about actual events.  There is no malice intended.  Rather their intention is to get along with the questioner. Even Hoffman has not been able to turn up any solid facts one way or another, which leads to his best guess as to the actual events.The inability of Hoffman to produce evidence beyond any reasonable doubt could be considered a flaw in his book.  I believe that this failure has been remarkably well handled by Hoffman and he expects the reader to examine the gleaned information and form an opinion as to its veracity, much the same as a jury would when deliberating a trial.What is interesting to me is the total conviction that Asmat hold regarding their culture, practices, taboos, and spiritual beliefs.  They are what they are and they have no interest in or reason to change.  The pressure to change their ways comes from others who don’t share their devotion to a way of life.Hoffman does an excellent job of presenting this culture gap.  There is a certain indifference to other ideas by the Asmat, an innocence that is refreshing.  Their life is hard by our standards, but perfectly acceptable to them, even Elysian.  So, when the tribesmen who know the most about Michael Rockefeller sense a dislike for what was a perfectly normal in their culture, they dodge the issue and insert or omit information more in line with what they sense is acceptable to the outside world, a trait initially developed to get along with strait-laced missionaries.This is a good book that is sometimes perplexing with its many characters with confusing names that have varied relationships and degrees of involvement.  It needs to be read carefully, keeping in mind the difference between our cultures.  You probably won’t like some of the gorier details about how the Asmat live, how they think, and some of their traditional practices.  But hopefully you will come to appreciate their innocent adherence to principle and tradition.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

A HOARSE HALF-HUMAN CHEER REVIEWI hadn’t heard of X.J. Kennedy until I read the blurb for his novel “A Hoarse Half-Human Cheer.”  He has emerged from behind his dozens of books of poetry to write his first adult novel.  It’s a comedic foray into a world of academia that is filled with oblivious administrators, stained Fathers, unschooled war veterans, nervous students, inept mobsters, and a beautiful nymphomaniac who doesn’t give a fig for accepted behavior.  Kennedy was 85 when he published this book in 2014, but don’t stereotype his work as stodgy.An obscure Catholic college in upper New Jersey is down at its heels and struggling.  Forced to admit 4,500 war veterans at the end of World War II to keep its doors open, it also leaves itself vulnerable to mismanagement, an illegal military surplus fraud, Mafia interference, inept faculty hires, and campus deterioration.  In this frazzled world we find struggling students, a priest with a fondness for young boys and the grape, inept Mafia kingpins, a collared basketball coach who is targeted for a violent end, and a beautiful teacher who is more than happy to conduct after class instruction.There is arson, firebombing, exorcism, a brothel raid, a basketball game without players, crumbling buildings, and a graduation with gunplay.  Kennedy loosely weaves it all together and presents glowering prospects with comedic outcomes that will sometimes leave you sputtering with laughter.  The characters, too numerous to categorize, are zany and somewhat out of focus, but that is the way the entire book is structured.  It is fuzzy and frantic but pleasing and fun to read.I’m not ecstatic about the book.  Some of the dialogue seemed contrived and a little dated.  But I enjoyed the overall entertainment of watching inept people flounder in their own follies.  So I recommend it for its diversionary value.  I’m more impressed with F.X. Kennedy’s amazing poetry.  Read his “In a Prominent Bar in Secaucus One Day” for a delightful straight up account of a former beauty accepting her role as a barfly.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

WRECKAGE REVIEWI have mixed emotions about “Wreckage,” Emily Bleeker’s novel about two castaways who return to their former lives after two years on a deserted island.  The writing and scenic portrayals are good.  The premise of the book that somehow the two survivors feel the need to concoct a web of lies about their experiences doesn’t square with what actually happened.  I won’t screw up the book by saying anything other than I didn’t see the need for elaborate lies that would certainly be uncovered.Lillian and Dave are the survivors; four others were there but didn’t come back.  An ill-fated contest prize trip goes awry when the charter plane carrying two winners, a sponsor’s rep, an airline hostess, and the pilot crashes in the sea on the way to a tropical paradise.  There’s a lifeboat scenario, a deserted island refuge, survival efforts, personal conflicts, and the gradual reduction of victims through consequences I won’t reveal.The writing was good but not excellent.  The storyline was well presented, if not totally believable.  The dialogue was somewhat sophomoric and the characters turned out to be rather weak and unlikeable.  I finished the book with luke warm interest because I was just not buying the story.  I suppose I somewhat resemble the repulsive newscaster who was determined to out Lillian and Dave, although I already knew the story but didn’t understand its premise.  Neither do I see the need to ruin everyone’s life by being snarky.Survival stories are always interesting, as are romances that flourish under tropical skies.  I like tales of survival.  Sticky romances; not so much.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

MAÑANA REVIEWThis is not a pretty story but William Hjortsberg has written something that reverberates and makes the reader pay attention.  A hapless, chemically impaired drifter finds himself in bed with a dead hooker.  He also finds his knife in the bloody mess, as well as blood stained hands and an empty memory bank.  As the fog clears he remembers three equally disreputable men and his wife as being somewhere in the vicinity when the nightmare occurred but they are not there now.  “Maňana” is the story of this loser who goes looking for the missing group through the dregs of Mexico, trying to find answers.It’s a first person account of drinking, drugging, and stumbling around in a beat up VW van in search of things he doesn’t want to find, in a world where he’s out of place, in locations where he’s not comfortable, with people who are mean and ugly. Give the author credit.  He manages to make the atmosphere interesting even as he delves into drug use, murder, and wired sex.  His descriptions of captivating Mexican locations, customs, and tradition are artfully enveloped in a gritty environment that both captivates and horrifies.  The writing is clear and crisp even though a baked brain and conflicting emotions screw up the narrator’s mind.The novel is an easy read, the writing is alluring, and there’s a certain amount of empathy that comes across for a stoner who can’t help himself get straight.  I enjoyed the book, although it will fade from my memory much the same as the night of throat cutting departed from the mind of our hero.  It’s entertainment that grabs with an elusive touch, but easily goes away.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

I normally won't write a review for a stinker of a book.  I'm doing so now simply because the "woodsy scent" the author used so often made me "groan," another favorite term high on her usage list.  The odor from this book was not of the forest.

LAST BREATH REVIEWAs I sit reading “Last Breath,” Peter Stark’s engrossing study of life’s last moments during venturesome activities, a sudden thought occurs.  I’ve done several of the activities he writes about, and experienced some of the physiological hardships he discusses.  Not to the extremes he portrays, of course, but I’ve been cold, thirsty, overheated, and even nearly drowned.  I can appreciate that had any of my hardships progressed to the levels of his discussions, I wouldn’t be here right now.  That’s sobering.For this book Stark has conducted immense research and interviewed a vast array of medical specialists.  He has plumbed the depths of normally recalcitrant research labs, reticent scientists, wilderness conference attendees, and adventurers from many disciplines.  With the information he has gathered he dissects hypothermia, drowning, mountain sickness, burial by avalanche, scurvy, heatstroke, falls, predators, the bends, malaria, and dehydration.  To top it off, he includes an essay on his own fear of death.It’s a thought-provoking book that conjures up intense personal feelings about one’s mortality and willingness to take chances.  It illuminates moments of foolishness and bravery, although the bravery most always leads to poor decisions.  Stark knows how to make each experience resonate within the reader like a fire bell.  In my case, introspection leads to disturbing thoughts of the way things could have been had my comfort zone been larger.The author uses a highly effective technique of creating a story leading to each mishap.  He weaves wonderful tales of seemingly innocuous circumstances leading to decisions that illustrate how judgment can bring death to careless adventurers.  A Jeep stuck in the snow prompts the driver to attempt to walk to his destination, a warm and cheery mountain cabin filled with friends.  A kayaker bites off more river than he can swallow.  A hot dogging snow boarder creates an avalanche that traps him in its cold embrace.  A rock climber falls, is seemingly saved by a ledge, but then succumbs in a lonely place from injuries caused by his sudden stop.  A cyclist attempts to blow away her competition by a sprint that ends up with a fatal heatstroke.Every end result benefits from Stark’s careful explanation of the physical possibilities that exist, the actual damage incurred in each scenario, and what the stricken person’s mind envisions as trauma overtakes him or her.  The chattering thought process will carry over to the reader, bringing dismay and a bit of self-study.  I sucked on an orange the entire time I was reading the chapter on scurvy.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE MESSENGER REVIEWIt would appear that Daniel Silva is the apple of the Charbonneau Book Club’s eye.  We read “The English Woman” less than a year ago and “The Messenger” is our new assignment.  It was written about seven years earlier than “Woman” but, with Silva, there’s no worry about staleness seeping in.  He’s always a refreshing read.In this Gabriel Allon adventure the intrepid Jewish spy is assigned to find an elusive al-Qaeda bigwig who is planning an assassination attack on both the Pope and the president of the United States. After already devastating parts of the Vatican and killing hundreds of people with an audacious daytime bombing, the terrorist operative is continuing his rabid campaign against his sworn enemies.  Cloaked in anonymity and possessed of great wealth and power, this dangerous fanatic must be rooted out and eliminated before he strikes, although Allon knows the search will be extremely risky and complicated.  He plans a trap using bait the operative can’t resist.Once again Silva demonstrates incredible knowledge of his subject, this time the complexities of mid Eastern religion terrorist activity, and Roman Catholic convention.  His plotting is intricate and unassailable.  His characterizations are immaculate and their realism resonates with the reader. Event after event keeps unfurling as the author assaults the reader’s mind with inventive and adventurous ideas.Silva employs spotless grammar and writing skills in his books.  One always feels more intelligent after reading him because of the information he unveils and the respect he gives to the reader’s brainpower.  He is a true master at creating the very quintessential adventure novel, entertaining and full of fascinating detail.Silva has a tried and true formula by which he operates.  Allon’s skill is paramount to his stories.  The attractive female agent who faces death with aplomb is always present.  Immensely skilled associates handle details that would befuddle lesser mortals.  But it all works and each new novel is eagerly awaited by his plethora of fans.It’s difficult to rank Silva’s books by which is better.  Each one has it’s own ingenious subject matter.  Some ideas might register better than others, depending on the reader’s interest, but none will disappoint.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

A PEARL IN THE STORM REVIEWTori Murden McClure isn’t interested in having me as an admirer so I won’t say that I am.  I’ll just say that I respect her and the strong person that she is.She has stated that she considers herself an introvert.  I’m not sure about that.  She shows some proclivity to being an extrovert as well.  She is industrious, grasps reality with vigor, and is comfortable with a struggle.  One needs only to read “A Pearl in the Storm” to see those traits, not necessarily associated with being an introvert.Her accomplishments are many.  She is highly educated, president of a university, the first woman to row solo across the Atlantic Ocean, and the first to ski overland to the South Pole.  In her spare time she has climbed mountains over several continents.  So this shy, retiring flower is as far out there as one can get.In “Pearl” McClure takes the reader on two rowing trips on the Atlantic.  The first, in 1998, from west to east, ended when a series of ferocious hurricanes sunk her boat and nearly killed her. The second, about a year later, from east to west was successful after spending 81 days rowing some 3,3000 miles.  A strengthened vessel, better equipment, and maybe a better frame of mind saw her through.  She credits winning battles with herself over what she considered a failure on her first effort, a face to face with Muhammad Ali, and strong moral support from her new husband and faithful friends as providing the catalyst she needed to persevere on the second attempt.McClure’s writing is clear and highly descriptive.  I was with her through every upset, physical battering, and violent weather episode.  I did face plants in the goo and poo splattered around her miniscule cabin.  I also spent unforgettable nights with her looking at billions of stars from the rowing deck.  Physically participating in an adventure is the pinnacle of my reading experiences.  The author took me with her.It’s a great book for lovers of sea stories.  Actually taking this sort of death defying journey speaks to the courage of McClure.  Continuing with another after the disastrous results, physical damage, and traumatic upset of the first reaches new levels of perseverance.  There are not many of us daring enough to attempt it.Okay, I’m going to say it.  I admire Tori Murden McClure.  Belittle me if you must, but read this book.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

ASTORIA REVIEWPeter Stark is an adventure and exploration writer.  That’s a fair and fitting description. The knowledge and talent on display in his writing certainly supports it.“Astoria,” is Stark’s riveting look at the trials faced by John Jacob Astor in his bold attempt to set up a fur-trading monopoly in the Pacific Northwest in the early 1800s.  His two-pronged endeavor, one by land and one by sea, ended in failure, but the monumental struggles faced by his representatives will keep the reader both enthralled and horrified.A seagoing party, aboard the ship Tonquin, was to sail around South America and up the west coast of North America to where the Columbia River meets the Pacific Ocean. An overland party would leave the east coast of the United States and follow the trail of Lewis and Clark to the same location where the combined group would establish a fur-trading empire.  It was all funded by Astor’s tremendous wealth, carefully planned, adequately supplied, and strongly supported by Thomas Jefferson who could envision the West Coast of the continent adding valuable territory to the fledgling country.Deleterious conditions plagued the two expeditions.  The sea travelers encountered violent weather, stormy water, a dictatorial captain, sickness, and hunger that decimated the crew.  The cross-country explorers fought their way through cold and snowy conditions as they fended off natives prone to thievery and warfare, suffered from lack of food and water, struggled over steep terrain and wild rivers, following a leader who was weak in decision-making and people skills.Even after the two depleted and demoralized crews met, the lack of organization, deplorable weather, and backbreaking work continued to weaken them.  In the end the colony, known as Astoria, collapsed under the strain.  The crews scattered as the members struggled to survive.Stark writes this history with the eye of a fiction writer.  He melds intense research and innumerable facts into a readable story that supplants the usual aridity of historical details.  We learn about catabolism, where a person’s body eats its own fat and tissue to survive; scurvy, a debilitating illness brought on by a vitamin deficiency; and post-traumatic stress syndrome that brings madness and suicidal behavior.  Although Astor always maintained that his plan was solid and his men were weak, the author clearly describes conditions that no person could be expected to endure.Of particular note are the footnotes (full of meaningful information), helpful maps, an insightful afterword, and a wealth of research notes.  A complete index is also helpful.This is a book of feelings; the reader suffers the icy winds and inexorable rain, the physical exertion, the bodily deterioration.  The author totally immerses his audience into an atmosphere of mesmerizing misery.  Don’t miss it.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE INVENTION OF WINGS REVIEWSue Monk Kidd is a remarkable writer with insight, a talent for storytelling, and the ability to create characters that resonate with the reader.  “The Invention of Wings” is a vivid novel that engages the reader in a historical period that has been dealt with many times but seldom with such jarring intensity and compassion.Sarah Grimke, the daughter of a wealthy landowner and holder of many slaves in Charleston, is given a 10-year old black girl for her eleventh birthday to act as her handmaid.  Kidd’s novel, based on actual people and events, traces their lives in parallel stories over the next thirty-five years as Sarah struggles with her aversion to slavery and Handful, as the slave is known, battles the cruelty of the institution with its demands, punishments, and family disruptions.  Their relationship is perplexing with its periods of defiance, love, misunderstanding, and futile efforts at merging two cultures.Kidd presents each experience using chapters that alternate between Sarah and Handful as the years progress.  Sarah, along with her sister, Angelina, grows to be a force in abolition and women’s rights while Handful emulates her mother’s pugnacious behavior as she uses guile in her abolition efforts, stealing if necessary, to confuse and muddle tradition.  Through the years, although separated by distance, their mutual dedication to disrupting the practice of slavery continues, Sarah to great notoriety and Handful to personal pain, disfigurement, and adversity.It is a moving story of two women and their common fight against oppression, although different approaches are used in their individual battles.  The author does a splendid job of outlining each adventure and the different challenges that each woman faces.The characterizations are beautifully drawn.  The dialogue sparkles.  The period descriptions are historically correct and appropriate for the times.  Kidd is careful to explain in her Author’s Note that the Grimke sisters were authentic and the first female abolition advocates as well as among the earliest feminist activists.  Their struggles and motivations, as well as Sarah’s inner voice and actual life, are the author’s interpretations based on her research.  Handful is a fictional character Kidd devised to add a slave’s voice and life to the story so both worlds could be presented.  Handful is a wonderfully created character with spunk, determination, and a sassy spirit that longs for freedom.This is not a Civil War book.  In fact the events begin some sixty years earlier.  It is a time when the institution of slavery was deeply imbedded in the South and radical attempts at abolition were deeply resented but not taken very seriously.  It is very illuminating to this reader who is more familiar with the time surrounding the war.  Read it.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE GLASS PALACE REVIEWIndian writer Amitav Ghosh is uniquely qualified to take his readers on a historical journey through the exotic lands of India, Burma (now known as Myanmar), and Malaya.  Ghosh, born in Calcutta, spent his childhood in Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and India and studied in Delhi, Oxford, and Alexandria.  The cities of Calcutta, Mandalay, Rangoon, and Singapore that invoke flights of fancy in both literature and music play a major part in his remarkable novel, “The Glass Palace.”Ghosh is caught up in the politics and nationalism of India and its surrounding countries and it shows in his writing.  He asserts that colonialism has had ruinous effects on underpopulated countries by removing natural resources.  In Burma’s case it is the oil, timber, and ivory.  In “Palace” he is particularly harsh on the presence of Great Britain.  This disturbs some critics, although Ghosh is factual in his reporting and his complaints are well documented.Nevertheless, Ghosh writes with a beautiful and descriptive style that is captivating.  His scenic sketches are mesmerizing.  His characterizations are immaculate; there’s not a single character in “Palace” that doesn’t strike the right chord with the reader.  The book is a lengthy read but I never lost interest in his story.The basic storyline involves a young Burmese orphan, Rajkumar, who, at eleven, possesses the acumen and drive to rise to be a wealthy rubber tree plantation owner, highly respected by both family and community.  Some one hundred years of familial relationships and national turmoil are reported covering a vast geographical area.  Wars are fought.  There are complicated alliances across cultures and countries. Rebellions develop and are crushed. Personal relationships ebb and flow.  Fortunes are earned and then slip away in the clutches of war and colonialism.Through it all, the reader is treated to thoughtful and accurate writing with historical detail being carefully drawn.  The splendor of the Burmese kingdom is destroyed by the unceremonial removal of the royal family, an astute move by the British to both humiliate and remove the King from public memory.  Burma’s valuable natural resources were then easily plundered and the gentle life became chaotic.The invasion by Japan causes further disruption and war scenes containing both benevolence and cruelty are vividly depicted.  When the war ends relationships are re-established and shattered families are reunited.Although the book is filled with tragedy, war, dislocation, and death, I never viewed it as a tragedy.  It was an eventful look at the vagaries of life as experienced by this family.  I thoroughly enjoyed it.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

THE LIGHT IN THE RUINS REVIEWChris Bohjalian has written an intriguing novel about a period in history that has often been overlooked.  In “The Light in the Ruins” he takes us to Italy at a time when Nazi Germany was currying favor with its hesitant ally.  Neither country was enamored with the other and relationships were tense and cautious.  It was a contentious and eventful time that has been only lightly explored.In 1943 the prominent Rosati family of Tuscany was confident their grand villa would protect them and garner favor from the greedy German forces that were gradually intruding on Italy and its citizens. Theft of national treasures and needed crops was commonplace.  Despite early benevolence extended to the interlopers, confrontations eventually occur, the villa and its ancient tombs are decimated, and the Rosatis fall to disfavor with both the Germans and their own Italian countrymen.Jumping forward to 1955, the story picks up with the brutal slayings and heinous dismemberments of Rosati family members by an unknown assailant.  Serafina Bettini, a Florence police investigator, who still suffers from horrendous burns received during the war, is assigned to the gruesome case.  She promptly finds herself immersed in family disorder and unpleasant memories as she pursues the serial killer who is determined to slay the entire clan.  Serafina discovers she has a personal relationship with the maniacal murderer.Bohjalian knows how to tell a story that’s full of historical and well-researched detail that doesn’t dull down the narrative.  The reader can fully appreciate how history can embellish the storyline and bring realism to the action.  His characterizations, while numerous, are clearly defined.In my opinion, there were several characters that could have been eliminated in favor of a shorter and less tedious read, but many authors like the sound of their own words and have no intention of being pithy.  That said, “The Light” remains a great book by an equally great writer.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

TIBETAN CROSS REVIEWI am always totally exhausted after reading a Mike Bond novel.  “Tibetan Cross” is no exception.  The frenetic action, convoluted character interactions, deep meanderings of the mind, and heavily flavored scenic descriptions are almost too much to handle.Bond’s encyclopedic knowledge of the exotic places to which he takes us is overwhelming.  Throw in his familiarity with local politics, governmental peculiarities, attitudes towards hostilities and the use of weapons, and the makings of fine fiction are in place.  All Bond has to do is assemble the information that churns in his brain and another book is born.  His biography sums it all up.  His novels “depict the terror and fury of battle and the intense joy of love, the beauty of the natural world, and the nature of the universe and its many meanings for human life.”Bond has never met an adjective he doesn’t love.  Scratch a few from his novels and his stories would be much shorter and easier to read.  But, setting that foible aside, the reader is treated to intricate plots, splendid settings, characters that resonate, and nonstop action.In “Tibetan Cross” a Himalayan climber gets involved in backpack nuclear weapons and is chased all over Asia, North Africa, Europe and the United States, along with a beautiful woman he happens to pick up (and who can apparently suffer through his never ending unkempt and smelly semblance), by the CIA and other assorted nefarious agencies.  Extermination is, of course, the intent.  Bond, as always, pulls the fragmented story together into a sort of resolution at the end.IF you like action, exotic places, and tough guys always on the run, Mike Bond can provide great entertainment.  Be prepared, however, for an out of breath and sometimes-quizzical adventure.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

TEXAS VIGILANTE REVIEWBill Crider has penned a rather traditional western, "Texas Vigilante," full of revenge, cowards, stalwarts, and strong women.  I was somewhat taken aback by the cover, a cowgirl in Ray-Ban aviator sunglasses, not the typical face I'd expect from the 1880s, but I was better pleased by what I read.The sequel to another novel, "Outrage at Blanco," heroine Ellie Train sets out to bring justice to a band of brutal killers, a skill she learned after she was raped and left for dead in "Outrage."  She is relentless, unafraid, and focused as she seeks retribution once again.Crider is a skilled writer, leaning towards both westerns and crime novels.  He's won many awards and best book nominations for his some 75 novels, and if thrilling western action is to your liking, this effort will be appreciated.  The action is non-stop and realistically presented; the dialogue is crisp and well written.  The characterizations are skillfully prepared with the bad guys being bad and the good guys believable and likeable.There is no need to review the story, it's been told many times. The book's appeal is in the writer's skill.  I had some minor discomfort with the seemingly never-ending bad choices made by the protagonists, but the story is carried through this parade of situations, even if some seem contrived.  This is a minor complaint, not enough to squelch my enthusiasm for the book.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

LUSTED REVIEWI expected an interesting book about a young girl’s adventures as a violist in a big time symphony orchestra, the Boston Symphony, no less. Instead I got a male domination story about a despicable egomaniac, a nave round heels, and horrendous writing that made my teeth ache. Who are these reviewers that awarded 4 and 5 stars?“I’m going to tie you down and assault you with this astounding vibrator while I whack your bottom.  Say, yes sir.”“Yes, sir,” she said, as she vaulted into his bed.I’ll be going now.  My work here is done.Schuyler T WallaceAuthor of TIN LIZARD TALES

I've given Pejoy biscuit sticks threestars because I didn't particularly enjoy them, but my husband thought they were fabulous. They are very fudgey and I am sure I will be buying them in the future, just not for myself. I much prefer the hazelnut variety. However, I found that dipping these in peanut butter makes a really nice treat.

It's hard to judge a product when the criteria for its use are not met. I got Fiproguard Plus three weeks ago and the dog was pest-free. He is still pest-free. All I can say is that this product is easy to apply, the dog cooperated, and there has been no sign of infestation. Should this continue throughout the summer, I will be elated.

Even if I didn't sew or had grandchildren, I would want this book. While the pattern pieces allow for a world of creativity and expression, just looking at the photos of the finished products is entertaining. My nine-year-old granddaughter alleges an interest in learning how to sew, and I think SEW DOLLED UP provides projects that are easy enough for beginners but enjoyable for adults, especially those with mountains of fabric scraps.

In a world where simple niceties are often abandoned or neglected, author Steve Antony reminds us that if you want to be treated nicely, you need to be a nice person. Antony's book, PLEASE, MR. PANDA, reminds young children of the benefits of being polite, specifically the importance of magic words (please and thank you).The book also illustrates the power words can give. It would be swell if one could read it to a child once and the child became socially aware, however, adults reading to children need to use their words to reenforce Mr. Panda's lesson (raising children offers many opportunities).Young children should enjoy the bold black and white animal illustrations as well as the mystery of Mr. Panda's not-too-perplexing mind changes.  PLEASE, MR. PANDA supports socialization without preaching and provides the basis of teaching moments.

I DO love it! I hadn't realized that there are so many full-length episodes of television programs on You Tube, and I've been watching more on my smart phone every night than I do on my television, pc, and tablets put together. Although I was already familiar with You Tube, I'm finding so much on it since I started using the app.

Excellent fruit chips, but I would like to be able to get more of the strawberry/banana variety, and less apples or pears. I like the taste and texture, but find the Asian Pears to taste more like Asian nothing than pears. Otherwise, these make a great, lo-cal snack, and the small bags travel well.
This is a disappointing ap because ti sems that the majority of the videos are two- and three-minute trailers, rather than full length episodes of Discovery programs. It's worth what I paid for it.

These shoes are nu-buck, which I knew when I ordered them. They're cute but not as cute as they would be if they were made of suede or leather. I like them, but I don't think they are going to last all that long.

I don't actually know what's in an oat bag you'd give to a horse, but I imagine it is about as tasty as this Special K Hot Cereal. It is no competition for oatmeal; it's just sort of mushy and bland. It's not that there's not enough nuts and cranberries, it's just that they don't work for me.

These are better than okay, but not quite as good as I anticipated. Maybe I've outgrown my taste for macadamias because these Glazed Mauna Loa nuts were more of a disappointment, and not something I imagine craving in the future.
If you love toffee and you love hazlenuts, you need to try these Roasted Hazelnut Toffees.They are out of this world! I know I'll be buying more--they are addicting. Very chewy and full of nuts.
Okay, but not great. I prefer freeze-dried fruit chips to these, which I wouldn't purchase again. I gave most of these away.

I love these shoes! I was looking for something in an oxford and these are super-comfortable. They go well with jeans or dresses/skirts with tights. They are the most comfortable shoes I own, and probably the most comfortable I've ever owned. These are the first shoes for which I didn't need to add a heel insert to avoid them digging into the area below my ankles and my heels.

I bought these slippers because I was tired of slippers that fell off my feet. Well...guess what. Only one of them keeps falling off. That doesn't make them very useful, unless I'm in the mood to limp around in one slipper. They would be very comfortable and I thought the elasticized fit would keep them on my feet, but I was wrong.
This nicely made, good quality, preppy style dress was a success with my granddaughter at Christmas. It looks good and the price was fantastic.
This is adorable. I bought it for my granddaughter's birthday and her eyes lit up when she opened her present. A cute outfit at a great price! Perfect for FROZEN fans.
I would like this item if it worked, but it doesn't so I don't.

While the OXO Good Grips Can Opener is a useful tool--it does the job easily--it does not compare to the OXO Good Grips Smooth Edge Can Opener, which costs about twice as much but seems to be a higher quality, well designed can opener (we have two). This OXO Good Grips Can Opener also works well, but does not offer the same clean cut and is on a par with similarly priced can openers, certainly worlds better than something you can get for a dollar, but it doesn't seem that it is made as well as our many other OXO products. As far as the color...meh. It's blue, but not an especially attractive blue, more of a retro fifties blue. It's bright and cheery to look at, but I prefer functionality over color. Long story short: it's okay, not fabulous.

Okay...this is a little weird, but I write notes on my laptop, and when I say "write notes," I am talking about "physically on the computer," not with software. I am fully aware that the cover of the laptop was not designed to be a writing surface, but it's convenient and it works for me. I use dry erase markers and I am quite pleased with the perfomance of the Quartet EnduraGlide Dry Erase markers. I like the colors (there are five and the dozen pack is an assortment), the ink dries quickly, and I have no problems wiping the ink off the PC. I also get satisfying results using them on a white board. Although I haven't used them on household appliances yet, I am relatively certain I will have similar, satisfying outcomes. Highly recommended.

I was a bit iffy about getting this set for my youngest granddaughter, but am glad that I went ahead and ordered it. The T.S. Shure ArchiQuest Wooden Farm Blocks set is very well made and it successfully entertains my granddaughter, which is why I got it. The included book is actually a board book, not a flimsy 8-pager that will fall apart after a few readings. I have no complaints about the toy, but the storage box, oddly enough, does not include a cover, which cuts down on the practicality and portability of T.S. Shure ArchiQuest Wooden Farm Blocks. The box is simply a wooden box with no compartments and no lid to keep the pieces from straying when the toy is moved around. I expected that it would have a clear plastic cover similar to other sets from T.S. Shure. Luckily, the box is deep enough for me to be able to throw all the pieces in without having to arrange them, but it isn't stackable (unless it's the top piece in the pile). Although I like this product, I am not too sure that I would buy sets with different themes because of the storage problem.

The odd thing about me thinking this is the greatest song ever recorded is that I don't watch Walking Dead. I love Bad Lip Reading, though, and when I saw the Carl Poppa video I was hoping I could get a copy for my playlist. Of course, as a song it doesn't make sense since it's just words and phrases that fit the actors' lip movements. However it has added a new dimension to my vocabulary--now, instead of calling people **#*@&%**, I say, "You're a shrinky dink." And to those who don't "get" my love of this song, I say, "You cannot handle the flow, son."

It's probably not fair of me to review a product that I am totally addicted to, but I have always loved these satellite wafers, although I'd be happier if they contained fewer candy beads. I've been buying these for more years than I care to mention, and was thrilled when I found that I could get them from Amazon. I have to say that most people I've shared them with don't find them as appealing as I do, even going so far as to say they have no taste (huh!), but my solution is to forgive the tastebud-dead idiots and stop sharing. It works for me.

Capers are yet another item I can never find in the grocery store, because different chains classify them differently. Will they be in the veggie aisle? How about with spices? Specialty foods? Oh, I know--get them from Amazon. I used them in mediterranean cooking, and like this brand, which I had never used before. I can't say that there is a huge difference between different brands of capers, but I am happy with these.

I was 900 miles from home when I first tried Burt's Bees Honey throat drops, and it was love at first dose. Unfortunately, when I came home, my dogs finished off the bag. I was happy to find them on Amazon. These are so much better than honey-lemon drops, and I had just about given up on finding honey drops without lemon. They are throat-soothing and work well for coughs resulting from post-nasal drip.

I liked these, but not as much as the ones I used to get at the candy store, and that are sold in multi-packs during the summer. There is something about the marshmallow--maybe it's softer or there's more of it, but these aren't exactly what I wanted. Nevertheless, as a big fan of sugar-coated sugar, I somehow managed to eat all of them. They ARE good, they just weren't what I wanted.

Artichoke hearts are one of those things that I forget when I'm grocery shopping, yet I use them a lot in cooking, so it only makes sense to buy them by the dozen jars from Amazon. I'd never used the Vigo brand before, but the jar size and the price were right, so I thought I'd experiment. Boy, am I glad I did! These are really delicious, either straight from the jar or in salads and cooked dishes. One of the main differences I've found in artichoke heart brands is the seasoning, and some brands overdo the spices; these are just right. I will buy again.

Nope. One of the things I really want in a printer is one that does not tear through ink cartridges so quickly that three or four cartridge changes cost more than the printer itself. I realize that the cartridges are the money makers, not the printers, but gee whiz, I'd be happy to pay more for a printer that didn't just zip through the ink. Obviously what this is leading up to is that this is a prodigal printer: it very generously applies ink to the page, actually quite a bit more than is needed. That may be why it seems the print cartridges empty so quickly, but my impression is that the cartridges do not hold as much ink as those for other printers I have used. The print quality is no better than my HP printers, another disappointment. Another problem, and this is definitely my fault, is that the printer is much bigger than I expected. Since I wanted it specifically for my tablets and cell phone, I somehow expected it would be smaller. I realize that is a strange expectation, but I don't have room for a printer this large. I forgot to check the dimensions of the printer before I ordered it, and wanted something much more compact. Although this printer has lots of bells and whistles, it doesn't offer the basics I need. The amount of ink it uses, in itself, is enough to keep me from buying this Pixma.

I didn't get this peeler so that I could review it and serve humanity by offering my opinion. Nope. I got it because I misplaced yet another peeler and kept forgetting to replace it. Well, I'm glad I kept forgetting because the closest store to me does not carry OXO products (or anything else that works well), and this peeler is, indeed, superior to others I have used, especially those on the lower end of the price spectrum. While it does a superior job of peeling, equally important is that it is comfortable in the hand, unlike those skinny peelers sold at grocery stores. I've been using OXO products for a number of years, and found that they are both useful and durable, and the Good Grips serrated peeler is no exception.

Here is a cable that is perfect for stowing in a purse or jacket pocket; I got it because I like to have a cable when traveling and it is much better than carrying a standard cable in my handbag--it doesn't get all tangled up. I keep it in the zip-lock bag it shipped in, and it's there when I need it. I haven't found any fault with it; it does exactly what it's supposed to do. One caveat: you MUST follow directions. There is only one direction for using this cable: "Always pull both ends at the same time." It is  printed on the back of the case, so you can't miss it, unless you are me, and then you will pull one cable at a time, the cable gets all screwy, and you think "this is the WORST thing I ever got from Amazon." No, it is not the worst; it's great which you will discover when you follow the direction. Lesson learned.

Have you ever been in a hotel in which the electrical outlets aren't close enough to the bed to allow you to recharge and use your tablet/phone at the same time, while reclining? This cable is the solution. Up to this point, I've been traveling with power strips and extension cords because the standard cable supplied by device manufacturers and those found a la carte in a variety of stores are not long enough, even when an outlet is located behind the night table. Yes, I know, "first world problem," but a problem nonetheless. I am thrilled with the length of this cable, and happy with the quality which is quite a few notches up from standard cables. The fact that it's a bright orange that I can easily locate is another plus. These cables come in a variety of colors, and I plan to order several for the various devices we first-worlders find ourselves saddled with.

When our cat died, we immediately ordered this memorial for her, and I am so glad we did. It is a high quality item, but even more impressive was the communication, sensitivity, and sympathy we received from GraphicRocks. Since we usually have a half dozen or so cats and dogs, inevitably we will need to purchase memorials in the future and plan to continue doing business with GraphicRocks, who impressed us with the quality of their product, rapid delivery, and thoughtfulness.

Gag reels provide humor that may not be found in a film, but with SHARKNADO, the gag reel is totally unnecessary. Sharknado is so hilarious, it can't be topped (although I am looking forward to viewing Sharknado Two [or To or Too or 2]) by additional silliness. Watch the film for laughs, watch the gag reel for a break from reality.

Wow! Somebody makes her prom dress out of duct tape and the next thing you know, duct tape is the hottest, trendiest craft medium around! My biggest apprehension was that instead of a "pop of bubble gum" the tape might smell more like a bubble gum bombardment, sickeningly sweet and artificial. Well, I guess all bubble gum smells artificial since bubble gum doesn't actually grow in gardens or forests. Whatever. The point is that this Duck Tape smells amazingly like the bubble gum of my youth, not one of the many fruity flavors now available. It is also more pliable than those sticks of bubble gum that came with trading cards. I do wonder if whatever makes it smell so good should keep me from ripping the tape with my teeth, though. Although I thought this product would be okay for kids, who else would need it or spend the extra $$$ just for the scent and color, I think it would be great as a gift-wrapping accent. I also wonder how long the scent lasts once the package is open and the tape is applied.

Wow! You think you know your cats and then they throw you a curve ball of yarn. The cat population at our home varies; there have been as many as four, right now there are two. Trying to find a cat food they would all eat, we settled on DeliCat, which was amazingly successful in appealing to all our cats. Last weekend, we took a short trip, and left the cats home with a huge portion of DeliCat and a large bowl of 9 Lives Lean and Tasty Dry Cat Food. Much to my surprise, when we got home we found that our little darlings had devoured the 9 Lives! I had expected they would turn their noses up at it because it's "lean," and, like our kids, anything that hints to be in any way healthful is to be avoided at all costs (including starvation). Maybe it's because the individual pieces are smaller (and aren't so much "work"), maybe it's because Morris is their idol, or maybe it's because our cats are contrarians--we don't know why, but we do know that the cats seem to like this stuff. Who knows? Maybe it's as "tasty" as 9 Lives claims. It doesn't really matter--if they'll eat it, we'll buy it.

Different grandmothers have different styles of grandparenting. For example, my grandmother used to be sure to put us to bed VERY early, and she chased my brother around the house with a broom (probably the one she arrived on). Her idea of interacting with children was to eat with them, tell them when to bathe and go to bed, and administer discipline as needed. I only met my other grandmother once, when I was 4; she lived on the west coast and apparently did not have a burning desire to spend time with her east coast family. On the other hand, I like to have toys and art projects around for my grandkids, and I enjoy assisting and interacting with them. Since we have four dogs, the ALEX Toys - Craft, Color a Dog House Children's Kit, seemed like a good project that I could work on with my two granddaughters (ages 6 and 9). Rather than allowing them to fight over who was going to do what, I assembled the dog house, and they decorated it. What an easy project! The coloring kept them entertained, and they felt like they were creating something that would actually be used. Our dogs aren't too keen on doghouses, so this one will probably end up being a cat house. We have always had good experiences with Alex toys, and this one is no exception. I would suggest letting the kids decorate the house BEFORE assembling, if possible.

I already had a travel pillow similar to the Classic Brands U-Shape Memory Foam Travel Pillow and there is a tremendous difference between them. The Classic Brands U-Shape Memory Foam Travel Pillow is much firmer and does an excellent job of supporting my head while I sleep in the car. It's a very nice color and I appreciate the carry-strap because I never to have enough hands. But...the first time I tried this pillow, I was not in the car. I was sitting on my couch in my living room. Usually when I watch television, I end up with a stiff neck and, often, an accompanying headache. I found that if I used this travel pillow while watching a film, I avoid that problem. So, it turns out that I will be using it at home as well as when we travel. I was surprised to learn that this pillow costs less than my old travel pillow; when I checked the price after trying it out, I expected it to be at least twice as expensive.

My husband has assembled a few of these hobbyist helicopters, but never one with a camera. The first thing we learned assembling the Dromida Kodo UAV Quad RTF with Camera was that it is not a toy. Although Amazon includes it with "Toys and Games," it is not for the inexperienced. Among the problems encountered:1. Incomplete and unclear instructions.2. Impossible for a beginner to fly.3. Stick that controls speed of blades is not gradient. It's all or none, therefore  difficult to control.4. User must be familiar with about a half dozen different types of software  in order to convert the video to something you can watch.5. Blade guards impossible to install.Advanced hobbyists who are familiar with the necessary video software might enjoy the Dromida Kodo UAV Quad RTF with Camera, but it is definitely not for beginners. It may be impossible for intermediates as well.
