I now know that there is a vast backlist, including Ms. James' highly rated FBI/US Attorney Series, that I can't wait to sit down and explore!Source: Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

If you love your romances short, cute, sweet, and full of laughs, then The Bet may be a good bet for your next listen. Having previously listened to several books in Ms. Van Dyken’s Eagle Elite series (mafia New Adult), I have to admit that I was expecting something a little different (deeper and more emotionally angst ridden). Nonetheless, in the right frame of mind, The Bet comes off as the classic tale of what happens when two brothers fall in love with the girl next door, except here, it’s riddled with tons of jokes, puns, and crazy laugh-out-loud, off the wall scenarios. As for the narration, with the caveat that it was somewhat difficult to distinguish the two brothers who are the main characters in this story, Tanya Eby otherwise delivers a decent performance.For the full review see AudioGals.

This fifth book in the Seven series once again proves that you can always count on the fab writer/narrator duo of Dannika Dark and Nicole Poole to deliver a solid paranormal romance. While I have to admit that Wheeler, with his dark, brooding personality is not my favorite Weston brother, Three Hours nonetheless delivers a believable, heart warming romance with a good dose of suspense and action, which are the classic hallmarks of the Seven Series. Additionally, like each of the four books that came before this one, Three Hours also contains threads of originality that render the romance fresh and is sure to keep listeners on their toes. In this case, be prepared for a hero who enjoys a little bit of submission and an elegant heroine whose animal wields an inordinate amount of power that is both feared and desperately sought to be enslaved by many familiar with her breed.Please note that this series must be read in order for maximum enjoyment as there is a larger story arc concerning the shifter world that evolves successively over each book. Additionally, although each book features one primary couple, and the unfolding of their love story, the prior couples continue to evolve and play influential roles in the later books. Both the hero and the heroine have been previously introduced in prior books--Wheeler being one of the Weston brothers and Naya being the exotic dancer, best friend of Lexi (the heroine from Seven Years).Notwithstanding that both Wheeler and Naya share the common trait of being self-reliant and extremely independent--a trait no doubt derived from their mutual attempts to keep their own dangerous secrets hidden--they still nonetheless always seem to fight like "cats and dogs" whenever they have had the misfortune of crossing paths in the past.But everything changes when Naya comes to Austin, the Weston Pack's leader and Wheeler's brother, for protection and help to find a missing exotic dancer from the club she works at and Austin assigns Wheeler the role of acting as Naya's bodyguard. Forced to spend time together they soon acquire a deep respect for one another and eventually become unable to mask their mutual attraction. It isn't long before they are divulging to each other secrets that they have not shared with any one else, and are longing to bring their physical chemistry to its natural fruition. However, when Naya's secrets and Wheeler's secrets converge, they soon will find each other in the cross hairs of an extremely dangerous plot; and they will be forced to decide between their love for one another and their own lives.Nicole Poole as always delivers a great performance in Three Hours. I find it remarkable that with so many different characters involved in the Seven Series, she is nonetheless able to impart each one with his or her own unique sound. Additionally, Ms. Poole's characterizations have remained remarkably consistent across the five books in the series thus far, causing you to feel like you are settling into a new story with old familiar characters that you have come to know and love in the prior Seven Series books.From the Indian to the Spanish accents, and the old to the young, Ms. Dark does a fantastic job of conveying each character's unique traits via her delivery of their dialogue. Naya, for example, sounds just like the exotic dancer, diva you would expect her to be, but nonetheless very powerful all in the same. Whereas, Wheeler sounds like the glum, social outcast he has portrayed himself to be in the prior books. I love that in Three Hours we finally come to know what deep dark secrets Wheeler has been hiding--and which when you learn them--ultimately redeem him as an honorable, loyal man. Interestingly, Ms. Poole's performance is so magical that you almost feel like you can hear the difference in his dialogue from the beginning as compared to the end when he generally becomes a more likable hero.All in all, I greatly enjoyed Three Hours. The Seven Series has come to be one of my favorite paranormal romance series of all time, and I can't wait to continue the adventure with what promises to be one of the most epic love stories of all: Denver and Maizy's story! Stay tuned for this next installment in the Seven Series, titled Two Minutes and which is scheduled to be released later this year (August 2015).Source: Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

I couldn't stop reading this captivating best friends turned lovers romance. Fans of love stories that involve emotional healing--in this case on both the hero's and heroine's part--will not want to miss Searching For Beautiful. This story tore me apart and gave me courage to renew my hope in love all at different points. The thought that people with past demons would settle for something less than true happiness, due to their own insecurities and past misfortunes, and that others would prey on such weaknesses, is heart wrenching. Gen's and Wolfe's story will make you angry and want to fight for these poor souls, all the while giving you faith that every person, no matter how damaged, has their own unique soulmate who can heal and provide them with true happiness. If you are "searching for" a "beautiful" love story, then look no further!As this is the third book in the Searching For Series, I feel that it is important to note that this story can nonetheless be read as a standalone. In that regard, I will point out that while there is definitely some overlap of the secondary characters who were involved in the prior books, the love story between the primary couple in Searching for Beautiful is fully contained in this book.Genevieve MacKenzie, a medical resident, is about to experience what's supposed to be one of the happiest days of her life--her wedding day--and yet all she feels is great anxiety. Her fiance, who is also the Chief Surgeon at her hospital, and thereby also her boss, should be the perfect man for her HEA. Somehow, however, what used to be a dream come true has become quite the nightmare the closer they get to their big day. Manipulative and controlling, Dr. David Riscetti seems more concerned about turning her into his trophy wife than in truly making her happy.Gen seizes the opportunity and chooses to go with her gut when she attempts to flee the inevitable disaster by climbing out the church window rather than walking down the aisle. Little could she have expected that the one man who would catch her fall would be none other than her one-time former best friend, Wolfe. Having become somewhat alienated from Wolfe since her engagement to David, Gen is surprised to find just how at ease she quickly becomes when Wolfe enables her escape and actually takes it upon himself to bring some joy back into Gen's life in this time of need. Imagine their surprise when after a short respite together they both realize that their feelings for one another have evolved making their once strictly platonic relationship a near certain impossibility. But, could they ever risk losing their most important relationship, their unique friendship, just to indulge their more base needs? Moreover, Gen is not the only one with past tragedies. Given their mutually damaged pasts--and failure to provide full disclosure--could they ever hope to find a HEA when all their secrets are out in the open?What an intriguing story. Although of late I have read a lot of best friends to lovers stories, I was pleased to find that the art of this beautiful romance lies in the poignant way that Jennifer Probst tells this story. Ms. Probst draws you in and maintains your attention to the very end. Now I can't wait for the release of the next volume in the Searching For Series, Waiting for Always, which is scheduled to be release at the end of this month (June 2015).Source: Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

Wow, Glimmer is a scorcher in the heat department, which I was expecting based on the blurb, but what totally caught me off guard, and perhaps I loved the most, was the unexpected intensity of the suspense of this well developed read. Reminding me of a cross between E.L. James' Fifty Shades of Grey and Karen Robards' Dr. Charlotte Stone Series, Glimmer has a little bit of something for nearly every type of romance reader. Glimmer, however, does end in a cliffhanger, so if you want to know the full story, you will need to commit to reading Glow, book 2 in the Glimmer and Glow Series, which is scheduled to be released in December of 2015.Alice Reed never dreamed that she, a student at a run of the mill business school, would be recruited to participate in the world renowned, summer program at Camp Durand.  Given that an internship at Camp Durand could lead to an executive position at Durand, Inc., one of the US's top fortune 200 companies, the nation's top elite MBA students typically fight it out to fill the precious few spots.As soon as Alice arrives, she realizes just how different she is from the typical candidate, which only causes her to further wonder why Dylan Fall, Durand's CEO, would have taken a chance on her.  It doesn't take long, however, for Alice to feel the passionate chemistry that unites them, confirming her unique assets.  Rather than fight it, Alice dives head first into the intense and erotic world that Dylan insists on introducing Alice to.However, after a short while, it becomes clear that Dylan has been less than truthful with her, leaving her to question just what deep dark secrets Dylan is hiding and just what demons from the past Alice may need to battle if she is truly determined to try and seek a rightful place in Dylan's future.However, just when you think you have the plot figured out, think again, because there is much more depth to this story than just your typical erotic, controlling billionaire with past issues.  I loved the intensity of the interactions between Dylan and Alice, but also enjoyed sleuthing the clues that Beth Kery sprinkled throughout the story.  Pay close attention because these little nuggets ultimately lead up to the reveal of one wallop of a secret which will completely change the playing field.I, for one, can't wait to continue Dylan's and Alice's story in Glow!  I'm sure more secrets, and lots of boundary pushing erotic episodes, await!Source:  Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

What an emotional journey! I started and ended Confess in tears. Without a doubt, this is one of the most creative, thought provoking, romantic listens I have had the good fortune of listening to in a long time. If you are a Colleen Hoover fan, then you are already familiar with her talented writing in the New Adult and Young Adult romance sub-genres. What I find the most fascinating about Ms. Hoover’s stories is that even though they all tend to fall somewhere between those two sub-genres, they still nonetheless all have their own sense of originality. It is this lack of a typical mold that keeps Ms. Hoover’s stories so engrossing and her ability to capture human nature (both the good and the bad) that makes you connect with her characters so profoundly.See the full review at AudioGals.Source: Audiobook borrowed from my local library.

Chasing Me is the continuation of James' and Quinn's story from Beyond Me, with some interesting changes. They have moved to Chicago together, and James has now left behind the comforts of his rich lifestyle to pursue his interest in art in an effort to become a man worthy of Quinn's love. Perhaps that is the aspect that I loved the most about this story. The fact that James' goes through a remarkable maturing process and its all driven by his love for Quinn.Quinn is also advancing in her career objectives. However, all of these positive changes do not come without a price. Like in the real world, Chasing Me highlights the difficulties of attempting to nurture true love while at the same time dealing with life's realities. As a result, James' and Quinn's love for one another will be challenged by insecurities and fears like never before. Will their commitment to one another be strong to survive in the end?What a real, poignant and touching story. Interestingly, while I had not been expecting a sequel to Beyond Me, I think Chasing Me does a great job of further developing James' and Quinn's story. If you enjoyed Beyond Me, then you definitely will not want to miss Chasing Me.Source: Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

ShutterGirl is unlike any other movie star romance I've read, proving once again that CD Reiss is a master at writing original, poignant and heart stirring romances. Among the many facets that make this a fantastic read is the successful juxtaposition of two such completely different viewpoints--the A-list movie star and the paparazzi who stalks him--and the fact that Ms. Reiss still manages to find a way for their perspectives to converge and unify in the end.Laine Cartwright thought she had finally moved on and forgot the boy who so captivated her all those many years ago.  A boy, who although he should never have been accessible to a girl like her, a foster kid from the wrong side of the tracks, nonetheless interrupted his routine to let her in his world once.The day he left, she threw herself in a pit of danger, just to feel something real again. Somehow she managed to dig herself out of that hole, and has resurrected herself as her own force within Hollywood circles.  Today, Laine is one of the elite paparazzi, who can always be counted on to click and preserve  America's royalty--movie stars and other A-listers who travel in their circles--for common consumption.Interestingly enough, Michael Greydon has also reinvented himself.  Today, he has followed in his father's footsteps, and is on the sure path to super movie star stardom.  Laine should know, as she has watched him rise through the lens of her camera every step of the way.They have both graced the streets of Hollywood at opposite ends of the spectrum, but never in this showbiz dance, have they directly acknowledged each other in the nearly 10 years since they last walked away from each other.  Then one heated night their worlds collide again reminding them of what they once knew but the reality of their diametrically opposed worlds forced them to walk away from.  Will an even more defined divide--that which separates the movie stars from the paparazzi--be enough to keep them separate this time for good, when the only certainty they have ever experienced is that nothing ever feels as "real" as when they are together?What an amazing story!  Both the various interconnected layers and the way Ms. Reiss so artfully puts it all together were fantastic.  So completely different from her prior books, and yet so similarly insightful of human nature and the basic needs that we all share no matter how dissimilar we may appear.I can't wait to read more of Ms. Reiss' unique romances!Source: Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

Having recently fallen in love with another shifter romance series, I took one look at the blurb for Dark Instincts and just knew I had to listen to it. What particularly called my attention was the idea of two dominant shifters–enforcers for different packs–finding their happiness together. Often times, it’s the hero who is the primary or stronger alpha or dom in PNR books, so Dark Instincts was like a breath of fresh air. In addition, I also really enjoyed the suspense, humor and group dynamics between the extended members of the two packs (the Phoenix and Mercury Packs). Further rounding out this fabulous listen was the talented narration by Jill Redfield.As this is the fourth book in the Phoenix Pack Series it is worth noting that this series, like most paranormal romances, is intended to be read in order. In that regard, as this was my first and only listen of this series, it was definitely clear that a number of the characters had been presented in prior books and had continued to evolve over the series. This made listening to the beginning of this story a little difficult to follow, but I was able to eventually catch on. Additionally the immediate conflict, from a suspense perspective, and the primary romance, were fully resolved within Dark Instincts, so this title could still be read or listened to as a standalone.It isn’t easy being a dominant female shifter in the Mercury pack, particularly given that her brother, Nick, is the alpha wolf leader of the pack. Nonetheless Roni Axton will not be deterred in showing her true personality. As the Mercury Pack’s enforcer, moreover, she is able to use her true nature to help her pack.Marcus Fuller, the enforcer of the Phoenix Pack, has a well earned reputation with the ladies. However, the type of females he usually attracts are nothing like Roni. So imagine Roni’s surprise when a mutual enemy brings their packs together and she soon finds that apprehending/seeking revenge on the bad guys is not the only goal Marcus has set his sights on.The stronger Marcus comes on, the more Roni tries to divert his attention. But strangely enough, Roni soon finds that the one place she finds herself wanting to submit is when she is intimately involved with Marcus. As the two navigate the personal, and pack politics, to determine if a HEA could possibly be in their future; the immediate threat–a jackal pack intent on victimizing members of both the Phoenix and Mercury Packs to further their own demented agenda–becomes even more targeted and personal. Soon the fate of their destinies becomes dependent not just on the taming of their own true natures, but also on winning one of the most dangerous games they have ever been engaged in.This was my first experience with Jill Redfield, and I absolutely loved her performance. Excelling in all the key markers I look for in a great narrator, I now know that I have found a new go to narrator. Not only does Ms. Redfield do a good job of producing authentic male and female voices, but she also provides nuanced distinctions, befitting of the particular character’s personality, to distinguish among the characters of the same gender. Ms. Redfield also conveys the particular emotion or mood of the scene by appropriately varying the speed, and/or, tone of her dialogue.Perhaps my favorite part of Ms. Redfield’s performance was her characterization of Roni. I loved how you could glean Roni’s dominant nature from the authoritative intonation of Roni’s voice. Additionally, you could hear Roni’s angst as she pondered whether any sort of a future could possibly be in her future with such a possessive male like Marcus.If you enjoy shifter romances, with equal parts action/suspense and romance/passion, then you definitely will not want to miss The Phoenix Pack series. I, for one, now can’t wait to go back and explore some of the prior titles in this series.Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

Wow, this series just keeps getting steamier and steamier! I also love how the suspense aspect of this read is really starting to take a crucial role in the unfolding of the story. I can't wait to continue on to part 4 to see how Derek and Frankie navigate the multiple obstacles that seem to continue to get in the way of their undeniable hot chemistry filled bond.Please note that this is part 3 of a 5 part serial that must be read in order. This review may therefore contain spoilers for the prior parts. If you have not yet started this series, see my review of the first part.Part 3 pretty much picks up where part 2 leaves off. Misunderstandings continue to abound and get in the way of what Frankie and Derek both want, irrespective of the fact that both have multiple reasons why a relationship with each other will never work.Further complicating matters are the hidden motivations and agendas of Reed, Frankie's ex-boyfriend, and Hayden, Derek's sister. Derek's competition and plotting against his father is also taking it's toll. Moreover, Frankie receives potentially career altering news, but it may come with a price.Can Derek and Frankie possibly find a way to have each other and everything else they want? I can't wait to read part 4 to continue to uncover the true extent of the hidden agendas and true motivations and to see if Derek and Frankie will get their HEA.Source: Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

Capture is a fitting, albeit different styled, conclusion to the Elements of Chemistry Series. With a slower overall feel, and definitely a lower heat level in general in the passion department, this story is more focused on character development.  Like in life, however, at different stages in our lives, we are primed for different priorities. Capture does a good job of exploring this evolution.Please note that this series must be read in order. Accordingly, this review contains spoilers for the previous parts. If you have not yet had the pleasure of starting this series, please see my review for Attraction.Capture picks up several months after the cliffhanger break-up in Heat. Both Kaitlyn and Martin have moved on and are now trying to be together again, but in a different way:  as friends; and not just any friends, but friends that share an apartment together.  As you can imagine, when the chemistry is right, sometimes no matter what you label the mixture, it can’t help but show its right composition.  However, miscommunications abound further complicating this potion.  Will Kaitlyn and Martin, eventually figure out that you can’t keep two opposites that attract near one another without leading to the inevitable?  Or will life continue to interfere with what otherwise would be chemistry perfection?All in all, I enjoyed this sweet, funny and somewhat quirky romance.  And now that it is over, I can’t wait to delve into some more of Ms. Penny Reid’s unique breed of romantic comedies!Source:  Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

Being a believer that total honesty is always the best policy, I absolutely loved the moral of this story. Moreover, Helena Hunting had me in stitches with the completely unexpected and yet hilarious things that would come out of the heroine's mouth, never mind her thoughts. If you love heroines that are bold and brash and love to say what comes to their mind, hot sexy athlete heroes, who have a reputation for being uncatchable, and lots of hot, unadulterated passion and laughs when they join forces, then you will love Pucked!Violet Hall knows all about playboy hockey players. Not only is her step-brother, Buck, one of the NHL's most well known man sluts, but her step father is also a scout and coach for one of the best minor league teams. Having been burned by a hockey player before, Violet avoids hockey players like a VD plague.Alex Waters, the team captain of Buck's NHL team has one of the worst reputations, when it comes to player status. A reputation that is no doubt well earned by his rock hard body and to die for looks which have won him plenty of endorsements. The fact that one such endorsement is the subject of Violet's fantasies, when she takes care of business, well that is neither here nor there.When Violet gets to know Alex in person, however, she is shocked and rather intrigued to find that Alex is not your stereotypical dumb jock. No, Alex not only knows his literature, but is quite the gentleman and, most unexpectedly of all, is not just satisfied with a one and done intense physical encounter--at least when it comes to Violet.When it becomes clear, that Alex is interested in more than just Violet's body, and that he is not a man to take "no" for an answer, Violet is left with one hell of a quandary: Believe the hype or give in to what she is really craving but fears will end in another world of hurt. However, dating a very public figure has its own quirks and soon Alex and Violet find that they are not the only factors in their relationship. Instead the media can be a very meddlesome third wheel. Can a HEA possibly be waiting for them at the end of the game?What a funny, sweet romance with a great lesson to seal the whole package together! Some of the phrases that Violet coins are absolutely hilarious and so creative! In fact, I'm not sure I will ever look at the initials "MC" ever the same again! This is one quirky heroine who loves to let it all hang out, and I for one loved every minute of it!Source: Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

Romantic suspense lovers, who also like a little extra heat in the passion department, will not want to miss Escaping Reality. This steamy little read had me constantly guessing throughout, and the story has just started. While we get a small glimpse at just what danger the heroine may be fleeing from in Escaping from Reality, the huge cliffhanger at the end, makes it clear that we have only scratched the surface, and moreover it is not just the heroine, but also the hero who is hiding secrets. I can't wait to learn more about "The Secret Life of Amy Bensen" and Liam Stone in Book 2, Infinite Possibilities!"Amy" has been running since she was eighteen. Most recently, she got complacent in her hiding while living in New York, and made the mistake of attracting the attention of her past ghosts by getting a publicly prominent job at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.Fleeing with just the clothes on her back, and the new identity her handler has concocted and communicated to her via the contents of a large yellow envelope, Amy boards a plane to Denver to assume her new life. It is on this flight that she meets Liam Stone.Amy knows better than to let anyone in to her life, for their own safety as well as hers, and yet she can't help but get caught up in the safety net of Liam's dominant aura. Although she knows she should say "no", Amy inexplicably finds herself lured into a passionate night which she originally intends to be a one night stand.Liam Stone is a brilliant architect who has made billions pursuing his passion. Notwithstanding his overwhelming success in the business arena, however, socially he is publicly known as a recluse. Amy catches Liam's eye, however, and he immediately notes her overwhelming need to control her fear. Enraptured both by what he sees, and what he perceives Amy is hiding and he is determined to unravel, Liam makes it his mission to conquer Amy. Part of that goal involves allowing her to "escape her reality" by submitting to him in intense erotic episodes that allow her to forget, at least momentarily, the dark secrets she is running from; and the other is to peel back the layers until he exposes the "raw and honest" truth.I loved both the mystery and mind engaging suspense of Escaping Reality. Frankly I have pondered Amy's potential plight both during the read, and over the couple of days since I finished the book, and I still haven't been able to definitively sleuth out her precise predicament, though I do have a number of theories. Additionally, as a fan of dominant heroes, Liam Stone is exactly the type of protective alpha hero that I love to encounter in my reads, and those reality escaping passionate encounters were definitely off the charts in the heat department! I can't wait to read Infinite Possibilities! My mind is already running through all of the probable circumstances that could possibly explain both that astounding cliffhanger and Amy's past!Source: Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

What an interesting read that brings together a number of my loves and wraps it all up together in a completely unique packaging! Mixing some of my favorite sub-genres, paranormal/UF, contemporary YA/New Adult romance and Mafia like romantic suspense, Cold Burn of Magic is sure to appeal to a wide audience as it has a little something for everyone! What a fantastic beginning to a new series that is sure to be another hit for Jennifer Estep!Lila Merriweather was forced to learn how to survive early in life. Having lost her mother (a former bodyguard) at a young age, she has tried her best with the help of her mother's friend, a pawn shop owner, to avoid foster homes. Earning her way by stealing and completing odd jobs that her mother's friend assigns to her, and living in the basement of a library that she can only visit after it closes at night, has taught her a lot about making ends meet in the magical world she lives in which is ruled by a few powerful Families of varying magical strengths. Above all costs, the one rule that she has learned is essential she follow, is avoid the Families and never let them know her true magical talents, one of which would nearly certainly be stolen from her if she ever let it be discovered.Everything, however, changes when Lila inadvertently gets involved in an assassination/kidnapping attempt against the son of the head of the Sinclair family, the second most powerful Family. With only a split second to determine her fate, and not really recognizing Devon as a member of the Sinclair Family, Lila throws all caution aside and saves Devon exposing her extraordinary fighting skills.As no good deed goes unpunished, it is this act of selflessness, which, for better or for worse, opens up a whole new world to her. While this puts her square in the sites of Devon Sinclair, a young man who is poised to become the head of the Sinclair Family, and who makes her feel things she has never felt before, it also may just mean that her destiny to live and die like her mother, at the hands of a Family feud, may also be sealed.I loved both the suspense/action-packed angle and magic filled nature of this young adult read. As I typically only read romance titles, I feel compelled to mention that although Cold Burn of Magic is not labeled a romance title, it does have a satisfying, rather subdued, element of romance. In particularly, it really felt to me like Ms. Estep was teeing up this romance aspect to play a more prominent role in upcoming books. I can't wait to continue the Black Blade Series with Dark Heart of Magic which is scheduled to be released in October 2015!Source: Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

4.5 "Revolutionary Beginnings" Stars for the story and 3.5 Stars for the narration!If you love well developed, historical romances with a BDSM element, in this case primarily disciplinary and erotic spankings, and are looking for a sensual, quick listen; then Humbled may just be the right contender for your next listen. The heat factor on this naughty little listen is off the charts, and the cleverly crafted plot, which could easily have truly taken place during this time period, provides for a captivating and entertaining story.Set during the time period of the French Revolution, Humbled gives us a glance at what life may have been like for both the aristocrats and peasants at around that time. Our hero and heroine meet as children when the heroine, Corrine, a young aristocrat, saves the hero, a peasant named Jean-Claude, from the guillotine.Having been sentenced to die for the theft of a pig that he wasn't even fortunate enough to catch, Jean-Claude would nearly certainly have died that day had it not been for the courage of Corrine to stand up and take blame for his offense instead. Many years later, during the midst of the French Revolution, Jean-Claude has still not forgotten that incredible act of kindness on Corrine's behalf, and determines to return the favor by saving her from near certain death at the hands of an angry mob that is intent on storming her mansion.Corrine instantly recognizes Jean-Claude and allows him to lead her to safety. Determined to see her safe for the long haul, Jean-Claude insists that Corrine flee France. Soon they agree that Corrine will board a ship to New Orleans where she can assume a new life. Unwilling to allow possible harm to an unescorted young female, Jean-Claude also comes along.During this long journey, the couple slowly become aware of their mutual attraction, even as they struggle to acclimate to a new world where their class differences no longer matter. In that regard, Jean-Claude begins showing his dominant side, for both pleasure and disciplinary effect. As their passionate feelings become undeniable, the couple is left struggling with the possible threat that they may still be in danger, never mind have no way of supporting themselves in the New World. Will Corrine and Jean-Claude find their HEA in America? Could a HEA ever possibly take place between two individuals of such different classes?Having previously read a couple of Renee Rose's books, I was familiar with her unique brand of spanking romances, so I knew what to expect from an erotic perspective. Well, I'm pleased to report that not only does Ms. Rose deliver on this front, but I also very much enjoyed the French Revolution history, and particular attention to the difficulties of class imbalances at the time, as well as the underlying love story that was built on the backbone of the impressive and selfless protective nature of both the heroine and the alpha hero.Faith Alowyn Alden renders a fantastic performance in Humbled. In fact, I would have easily given Ms. Alden a 5-star rating based on her performance alone. Not only does she have a beautiful, mesmerizing voice, but she produced unique, distinguishable and personality appropriate intonations for each one of the many cast members, making it incredibly easy to know who was talking without needing to rely on dialogue tags. Ms. Alden also does a great job of conveying the particular mood of a scene in her narratives and imbues her voice with just the right amount of emotion to act out the dialogue between the characters.Unfortunately, however, there were some issues with the production and editing of the audiobook that caused me to lower the overall score. Namely, there was a hollow, almost echo like, sound throughout the entire recording. It almost sounded like the book had been produced in a large auditorium or cave. Another effect of the production--that in my experience is atypical--was that I could hear a light amount of static in the background, almost as if it was recorded during a light rain. There were also a few instances of clicks, and the like, that I would have expected to have been filtered out in the editing process. It is worth noting that notwithstanding these technical issues, after a while of listening, I was able to eventually tune them out. Nonetheless I did feel that it was necessary to point out these matters, as they are not something you would normally expect in a commercially produced title.All in all, I thought Ms. Rose imbued Humbled with just the right amount of balance between the development of a satisfying historical plot, an enticing romance and an erotically charged love story. Further enhancing this story was Ms. Alden's talented reading which, subject to the noted caveats, makes this a good choice to pick in audiobook format.Source: Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

What an enjoyable witty, romantic comedy that explores the age old conundrum of what to do when you fall in love with your best friend.  I loved both the hero and heroine, and Kristen Callihan had me laughing throughout this charming, engaging romance.  This was my first experience with Ms. Callihan, but it definitely will not be my last.  Now I can't wait to go backwards and read The Hook Up, Book 1 in the Game On Series, to experience Anna's and Drew's story!  And the great news, particularly for those who have already had the pleasure of both books in this series, is that Book 3,  The Game Plan, is planned for release later this year in the Fall!Gray Grayson is a player, both on and off the field.  As the star tight-end for his college, Gray is expected to potentially go number 1 in the NFL draft.  His moves when it comes to women are also well known, as he is famously known for the one and done maneuver.Gray doesn't befriend women, so the last thing he expects is to become "attached" to his potential sports agent's daughter--Ivy Mackenzie-- via text, no less.  All because he did the right thing and let his buddy, Drew, who was suffering from a broken leg, borrow his automatic transmission car, leaving him--courtesy of his potential future agent--with Ivy's, very feminine and tiny pink car to ride around in.  As no good deed ever goes unpunished, it doesn't take very long for Ivy to start summoning threats and implementing rules for Gray to follow when using said pinkalicious car.Ivy, in turn, is busy learning her mother's trade, baking, overseas.  Moreover, she is not the type to fall for the players, particularly any such player that may potentially become a client of her father's.  Nonetheless, she surprisingly finds herself craving Gray's texts.Then when Ivy returns to her father's home for a short stint before her planned departure back to London to run one of her mother's bakeries, Gray's and Ivy's carefully crafted plans for their future all become a jumbled quandary as they are left to sort out just what the nature of their "friendship" truly is all about.What a fantastic, touching, new adult read that is sure to appeal to anyone who has ever explored the age old question:  can a boy and girl truly have a strictly platonic relationship.  I can't wait to read more of Ms. Callihan's clever, entertaining romances!Source:  Review copy provided in exchange for an honest review.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, we received this JTX-1 trailer/stroller combo for review. We don't bike and so we have only used it with our 3yo for some summer/fall jogging. This is written based on our three months of experience from August to  October.The stroller comes well-packed inside and the box was intact when it arrived. This assured us quite a bit more in comparison to a traditional stroller we ordered at the same time. That one just came with dents and punctures in the box due to a lack of internal padding.The assembling is very simple out of the box, but we didn't realize that there is no car seat adapter before we ordered. This is not exactly Allen's problem but we thought we should point this out.The screen cover has the usual nylon smell in the first week, but it goes away quickly. The zipper is smooth, but it seems to have a small clearance to the side and "catches" the fabric quite easily.In actual use for jogging, we lock the front wheel straight and rely on tipping the front off the ground for turning. The large rear wheels and the suspension both make the ride more comfortable when going over small bumps. So far, our kid has not complained.We never jog in the dark with our kid, but we appreciate that the rear wheels have reflectors on it.The harness straps are not as padded as we would like. In the summer (we live in the northeast) this is really a problem because putting more clothes on our kid is not a solution. In the fall, we deal with it with a thicker sweater.We are quite happy with the light weight of the stroller. Our kid is slightly over 30 pounds. Our concern is not the pushing, but the stopping due to momentum. This year we feel that we are still in control. Next summer we expect our kid to be 40 pounds and we are not sure if we will still be mentally comfortable with the momentum. We will come back to revise the review if this proves to be a real concern.Overall, as a jogging system we are very happy with this JTX-1. It is now living in our garage and we look forward to this coming Spring to use it again. Cheers!

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, we have received a Graco Fast Action Fold Duo LX Click Connect stroller for review. At the time of this writing we have a 3 and a 1.5 year old, each with their own stroller. Packing both stroller into minivan is easy, but we need both of us to be present if we want to use both strollers together. We thought if we have this duo stroller then we can do this with just one of us. There are a lot of positive design features like independent recline and canopy, but we are not going to summarize them in this review since you can just read it in the item's description. Instead, let us write about our experience in actual use.The box came a bit damaged (Amazon shipped it bare: there is no protection whatsoever) and that made us a bit worried at first. Fortunately, the stroller itself is fine and most importantly all the parts stayed inside. Assembling takes less than 10 minutes, and we are really to roll. :)The first thing we realized is how wide this really is, or rather, how much we underestimated its width from the pictures, which are all taken at an angle. To be sure, it goes through doors with about an inch of space on each side left, but our side walk have trees and in one case it just oh so barely squeezes through with a rear wheel of the stroller rubbing on the metal fence of our neighbor. We are quite concerned that it will damage the wheel. Be ware if you are buying this. The rear wheels are about 32 inches apart and are single wheels (not doubles).The second problem is the weight distribution. As mentioned our kids are just 1.5 years apart, which realistically is very close to the smallest gap possible. Still, we can feel that there is an uneven weight distribution when turning. Prior to this, we have tried a front-and-back design when visiting our sis-in-law. We thought we didn't like that design since it is very long and makes for an awkward turn and also higher center of gravity (since the rear seat sits up high). Now that we have tried this side-by-side design, we actually start to prefer the front-and-back design...The third problem is quite obvious but also unavoidable. Two kids plus the car seats plus the stroller is a lot of weight. The spec says that this Duo model can hold two kids of 50 pound each, but we are not so sure about such usage. As a comparison, airline checkin luggage max out at 50 pound also. Honestly, we do not look forward to using this when my older gets to 4 next year.The final problem is actually something we did not anticipate. With two (single) strollers, we can stack them when we get into the minivan and leave the other side of the floor for grocery. This is not so feasible with this duo model.Overall, we feel that this is a great duo stroller and Graco did a great job putting in all the right features. If we want a side-by-side duo stroller, this would be our choice and we highly recommend it. This easily earns a 5/5 in our book. (As you would have observed, all the problems we ended up having is precisely because we do not want a side-by-side duo stroller. We feel it would be unfair to take any point off because of our personal preference.)

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received this 4-piece decorating kit for review. The four pieces include the silicon squeezer and three tips (circle and two star-like patterns). Usage is super easy: you spoon enough frosting into the silicon body, screw on your chosen tip, and squeeze to pipe. True to the OXO reputation, this is a high quality item. The plastic screw top seems durable, and the silicon body has thick walls. I don't expect any problem in the long run. I especially appreciate the flat bottom of the silicon body. This makes it possible to rest the bottle on the table in-between piping.If I have to nit pick, it would be the design of this kit makes it not so suitable to do smaller batches. The body holds 4oz. If you only put in say 1oz of frosting, then you have to squeeze very hardly during piping. I also find the silicon body a little bit harder to clean than my silicon piping bag, which is perfect in every department (perhaps except a higher price).

I previously had a similar tension rod of another brand over the shower for hanging hand-washed laundry items, all of which are pretty light. The rubber on the old one finally lost its holding power this fall and I replaced it with this Maytex EZ Up tension rod, courtesy of the Amazon Vine program. As tension rods go, this is pretty standard operation procedure once you figure out how to lock it after extending the middle portion. My trick is to overshoot the length by a fraction of an inch and then push the rod into its position. (The method of increasing tension while the rod is already in its intended place never works for me---it resulted in too little force.) The plastic ends on this rod seem ok in quality, and I have no doubt that it would probably work for over a year. However, I don't know why but I can see rust spots (more precisely rust-colored water drops that eventually dried on the bottom of the rod) sets in after just a month. I believe this is from condensation during showers. Since I use the rod to hang laundry, I am not sure I will keep this because I am afraid there may be rust drips ruining the clothes. To be fair, there was never any mention of "stainless" in the product description and I am indeed not using it for shower curtain, which is what this product primarily targets. However, even if it is just my shower curtain, I would not like to see the rust spots. 2/5.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Black & Decker EHC3002B Glass Bowl Chopper, Black” for review. The major components inside the box are the motorized chopper itself and two 4-cup glass bowls with lids. There are also the chopping blade and a splatter guard.This is actually pretty genius design: the chopper fits over the splatter guard, which in turn fits on top of the included storage glass bowls. (Although the bowls have Black+Decker imprints, I tested it with 4-cup bowls from a “Py” brand and it works equally well.)In practice, you would put the ingredients in after you rest the blade into the bowls, then continue with the splatter guard and the chopper motor. There are two buttons: low and high, with one and two very small protruding dots on the buttons itself that are barely sufficient for my fingers to tell.The manual includes a chopping guide (which really can be summarized as “use high always, unless you want to make a spread”). It also contains a number of recipes: Caramel Apple Dip, Cream Cheese Icing, Blue Cheese Dressing, Rotisserie Chicken Salad, Fresh Tomato Salsa, and Spinach Artichoke Dip.Honestly my housemate and I have not tried anything other than the salsa (which was the primary reason we decided to get this). In this regard this B&D chopper performs brilliantly. The reason is because there are very few things to wash: you see, the blade goes into the bowl itself, and once the chopping is done, there is NO need for any salsa transfer. The unused portion can be stored inside the glass container with the included lids. We especially appreciate the glass bowls: with plastic you often get left-over odors, but with glass there is no such problem.Overall, we are very impressed with this B&D chopper. I wouldn't go so far to say that we don't know how we would have lived without it, but I would say that this really has increased our frequency of making salsa at home. Highly recommended if you chop a lot of things.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “iDevices IGR0009 iGrill2 Bluetooth Thermometer” for review. Inside the box are the iGrill2 itself, two AA batteries that can support the iGrill2 for 20 hours, 2 “Pro meat probes”, 2 probe wraps (for coiling the wire), 2 probe color tags to tell the probes apart, a magnetic holder for the iGrill2, an optional magnetic disc in case you want to stick the holder on a non-magnetic surface, and a brief instruction sheet. It comes with one year of warranty.In short, the iGrill2 is a grill thermometer that can support 4 probes at maximum. There is not much user interface in the iGrill2 itself: it only has an on/off button, a cycle button to go through the probe temperatures, and when there is an alert it has a very tiny beeper that really you should not rely on hearing, especially not outdoor. The actual UI is on a phone app (as of this writing they support both iOS and Android).The meat probes seem accurate in my experience over this holiday for briskets and birds. The smoked brisket presented a power challenge since one of our recipes last 18 hours even before resting. The iGrill2 ran out of power at the end. (No big deal, but I think next time we will really try to use fresh batteries and try again.)I have compared them with my trusted ThermaPen and the readings are rarely ever more than 4F away from each other. This is the most important benchmark and iGrill2 scores high on this. I also appreciate that the iGrill2 probes seem to be quite consistent across each other. For example, the two probes that are shipped to me detects the room temperature at a max of 1F off from each other. This is very good quality control.The probe wraps help keep the probe wires neat in storage. They also snap into a stack vertically: you can stack the probe wraps on top of each other by pushing the protrusion at the top to the groove at the bottom. I consider this a major upgrade from one of my previous grill thermometers without a wire management system: when I store that one the probe wire is always a mess in the drawer. Clearly the iGrill2 is great for neat freaks.The magnetic holder is also nicely designed to hold the iGrill2 at about 20 degrees off. You can snap the iGrill2 into the holder in two ways that are 180 degree rotations of each other. If you are mounting the holder on a vertical surface, you can have the iGrill2 tilt up 20 degrees from the bottom so you can see it better from the top. If you are placing it horizontally, then you can have the iGrill2 tilt up 20 degrees from the back so you can see it better from the front. The bonus magnetic disc is also a very thoughtful touch. In my case I stick the disc on the stone surface in my kitchen so that the holder will stay in place when used with the oven.Of course, the most important component that is not in the box but absolutely necessary for the daily operation is the app itself. I use an Android phone, and since this is the iGrill2 I installed the iDevice Connect app, which is about 24MB as of this writing. (Confusingly iDevices also have an app that is called iGrill, but that only supports iGrill1.)The app is pretty sophisticated. Besides displaying the temperatures of the probes, the app designer has put in a lot of thoughts. Upon the insertion of a probe, it will guide you through setting up the probe. You will tell it the color of the probe you have just inserted, and it will present you with an extensive menu of common food items and their recommended temperature at a particular “done-ness”. Hit the start button and you are good to go.There are actually two types of alerts: peak (beep with a temperature is reached) and range (beep when temperature is outside a hi, lo range). Whenever there is an alert the phone will show a notification and the iGrill2 will also emit a tiny beep. It can show the temperature of each probe on its own graph, just like what you see in the stock market. Finally, it can also let you set up your own custom alerts.The app has some quirks as of this writing. First, I really hate the way their non-committing changes. Say you go into set up a temperature alert. After you pick a temperature, you need to be careful to use the Save button on the top to commit the change. If you use the Back button, you lose the setting. No modern app does this any more: all changes should be saved at Back. Then, the color scheme is pretty odd. At the temperature alert screen, the bottom shows the two types Peak and Range. Guess what, when you are in the Peak mode the text “Peak” is in grey and the text “Range” is in bright white! (And vice versa.) I sometimes get confused because of this. Finally, the menu at the bottom does not swipe in. Instead, you are supposed to click on it and a menu will slide up. I hope iDevices will fix these quirks.Compared to all my previous grill thermometers, be it the wire type or the ThermaPen, I find iGrill2 to be superior. The number one weakness of the ThermaPen is that you need to open the grill/oven door to insert the probe. With the iGrill2, this is no longer a problem. The Bluetooth range is adequate and I get at least 50 feet. My deck is outside the kitchen, and I have no trouble monitoring the grill through the glass windows. However, the signal drops when I am in the living room, which is separated from the deck through the kitchen and a stone wall. The iGrill2's price is steep, but honestly if the probes don't give up then this is actually a great buy! (I will come back to update this review if the probes die.)P.S. The app also allows you connect to other iGrill2 users through the “Globe” feature, which I did not use since I don't do this social network thing.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Altra Furniture Galaxy TV Stand with Mount for TVs up to 50-Inch, Walnut Finish” for review.I live in a city apartment, and space is at a premium. Before this I have been putting my 43-inch TV on top of a IKEA media center using the TV's integrated stand. There is nothing wrong with my existing setup, but I figure I can give this Altra a try.The out-of-the-box experience is pretty good. The package is heavy, and when UPS came the box was slightly damaged. It worries me quite a bit since there is wood inside. Fortunately, the content inside the box is well-padded and there is no damage. There are about a dozen items in the box, mostly the composite wood panels, the glass “in-the-air” panel, the metal TV frame, and a whole bunch of screws to put them together.The actual assembling takes 25 minutes for me. I know I can probably do it faster, but I was taking caution because I want to make sure it does not wobble since the last thing I want is to see my TV crushing onto my Xbone... I am glad that the patience paid-off, and once the center column is assembled, it neatly mounts onto the bottom plate without difficulty. The middle glass shelf, however, is a bit more work. In my stand the glass has a tiny bit of give in one of the slots in the center column. It's so small that a penny won't fit (I think even half the thickness of a penny won't fit). I ended up cutting a piece of small plastic from the milk jug and it fixes the problem satisfactorily.The actual assembled stand is larger than I thought, but this is mostly due to the stand's foot that extends to the front to make sure the stand does not tip forward. I don't have any wall space for the stand to lean on, and therefore I rearranged the living room so that this stands at a corner, offsetting it at 45 degrees. It works ok for stability since the two sides of the TV is what prevents the stand from tipping backward.For the asking price I think this is a pretty good deal. The wood finish looks real enough and does not seem to scratch, and the glass panel seems sturdy (modulo the fitting problem I described above). While it offers about a feet of height adjustability of the TV, it does not allow vertical tilt. I ended up mounting the TV at its minimal height, which is ok but still a bit high for my taste. I guess I will get used to it.The two shelves (if you call the foot a shelf) are open to the air and so is the center column. As a result, dust does collect on them. (My previous media center have glass doors on the front to keep the dust out). This can be a real problem if you are OCD about it.Overall this is a very minimalistic TV stand. The TV mount is pretty sturdy, and I like the fact that the cables are all hidden except where they exit the bottom of the stand. It's not premium by any standard, but I do find it comparable to IKEA items. If you are renting or if you want to mount your TV higher but do not want to drill your wall, I can recommend this.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Tile for iOS - For Finding Anything and Everything (Retail Packaging)” for review.This is essentially a weather-sealed bluetooth transponder that has a battery life of one year. You pair it with your phone, register your email address with Tile's website, and the app will activate the Tile (otherwise it seems to just turn off after a few minute---yes, I did try to pair it with an Android device just for fun). Every couple minutes the app will try to scan for all the tiles it can see around your phone  (about 100 feet radius), and report the location of these tiles to the server. If one of these tiles is yours, you can also see its location in the app.I know quite a few friends who backed this, though I myself didn't. It is an interesting concept, but it seems to suffer from the classic problem of bootstrapping. But since this review is about the product and not the business idea, I will stick with my experience with the product and the service *as of today* (it may dramatically improve in a few months once more people sign up).The most major pro of Tile over its competitors is its weather-sealing. Being water-resistant (though not water-proof) is good since you never know when you will splash some liquid on it. But that also effectively make the battery inside each Tile non-replaceable. A built-in expiry day of one year? I mean, even if you are getting the 12-pack, that's still 15 bucks per year per tile to be thrown away. (And if you get the 12-pack each year you are throwing 180 bucks away.) And to conserve battery, the beeper is not very loud---certainly not loud enough for a restaurant.The cons list is, unfortunately, quite a bit longer.First, their app is a phone-battery eater. Before installing this app I can almost cruise through a second work day if I forget to charge the phone the night before. This app made this impossible: every night the battery is almost dead when I go to bed. While I think they can tune the frequency of scanning, their sales literature made it clear that it cannot be too infrequent: the app is designed to scan for other tiles periodically to support the lost-n-found feature.Putting the environment issue aside, I still find the location function lacking, though this is really not the Tile's fault. Tile does not have any GPS real-time tracking location. Instead, it relies on the phones that see it to report the location. The problem is that most phones are just not very good at its location. At the moment my phone thinks I am sitting on the street outside, 12-floor down.The form factor is also not very pleasing. It measures 1.5 inch on both length and width and 3/16 in thickness. I have seen sales picture of sticking a Tile to a violin or putting it inside a wallet. I am not sure about you, but I don't think it can comfortably fit in my wallet. (I tried, and it stretches the leather.) Seriously, the last couple times I lost something in a restaurant/bar, the thing I lost is actually the phone itself... but at this thickness, there is no way I will do it.Overall, I like the concept of keeping track of things. I am just not sure Bluetooth LE is the solution to that. And even if it is, I find Tile's implementation as of today to be a bit premature. This is definitely an early-adopter technology.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Saris The Boss Single Bike Storage, White” for review. This is an interesting item that I didn't know I had a need for, but after using it for a month now I wonder why I didn't notice I had a need for it. :)I bike to work everyday when the weather is dry, and usually when I get into the office I just put the bike on the wall. Over time, the handle has rubbed some rubber onto the wall where I usually rest my bike. My office manager didn't seem to mind it.At least that's what I thought.The Saris is a very simple device. Think of it as a flat stand with a vertical fork that can hold the rear axis of the bike (the product photo is very illustrative here). The fork has some rubber/silicone coating to prevent scratching, and there is absolutely no adjustment other than the a slide lock that locks the fork in its place (when it is shipped the fork is bent towards the plate to minimize the package size).The entire device is not that heavy, and so it surprised me a bit that in practice it is very effective in holding my bike. The fork is easy to use, and so far I have zero trouble with it.For all these, and the fact that this is very affordable, I am giving this Saris a five star.Let me end with my office manager. He walked by one afternoon after I started using this Saris, and he said “oh, I always wished that you would install a kick-stand on your bike; this one is quite nice, where did you get it?” That evening he had the custodian clean the rubber marks off the wall using glue-gone. Oops. :)

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a "Jolie Sustainable Luxury Candle, vanille" for review. This is in essence a vanilla soy wax candle.This is my introduction to soy wax candle. Compared to some other normal scented candles, I notice that there is less smoke during burning and there is also less smell from the wax itself. These are very good characteristics to have since they translate to more smell from the vanilla oil.However, I have to agree with many other reviewers that this is one expensive candle if I have to buy it by myself. 6oz really is not that big at all, and making things worse is that the vanilla smell in this candle is very faint to my nose. This means it is less effective at scenting a room than I would like.The bottom-line is I honestly think you have to be looking for a luxury to like this candle. Yes, the 40 hour claim is at the right ballpark so long as you remember to trim the wick, and the candle is very high-quality in its components (from wax to wick to the glass). But if you are looking for a high price-performance ratio, you may be quite disappointed. Sorry folks.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Vornado SRTH Small Room Tower Heater, White” for review.This heater is really small. At barely a feet tall and six inches wide, I initially have some doubt on its capability to keep my room warm. At the top of the tower is a 4-hour timer button and a power knob that allows me to select among power off, fan-only, low, and high. This Vornado also features a (by-now standard) safety shut-off when tipped.Vornado's sales literature claims that this heater uses their V-Flow heat circulation technology. Compared to the more traditional space heater design that uses a fan to blow forward, you can imagine that in this Vornado the fan is blowing towards multiple grilles in many different directions in an attempt to disperses the hot air into a wider span. This is similar to how air conditioning works in a passenger car.I use this in my office, which is about 100 sq ft. Despite the sales claim, I have to report that in practice this Vornado makes very little difference in heating when compared to my existing heat fan made by Holmes. They both heat up the office at the same speed at the same power consumption. Notice that I am not using the space heater underneath my desk to keep my feet warm. Instead, I am trying to keep the office a few degrees higher than the building's heat default. Therefore, I did not need to use the oscillation on the Holmes since the fan is not directly blowing hot air towards my legs, which is what many of my colleagues do. However, notice that this Vornado will also be relatively ineffective in this application since the heat is not so focused.So how do I justify my 4/5 rating? It turns out that if you care about noise, then this Vornado is in fact quite a bit quieter than my Holmes heat fan. The consistent problem with my Holmes is that it makes a very audible difference in sound when it switches on and off when regulated by the thermostat. This Vornado, on the other hand, makes a constant noise that eventually becomes a white noise. However, of course if you care about noise you would use a silent heater such as an oil heater. An oil heater is slow to warm up, though these days many of them come with a timer that allows you to turn it on in advance.Overall, I think this is a fine small room heater that gets the job done, but I didn't feel any magic with the V-Flow. Since the 4 hour timer is rather inflexible, I am taking a star off. 4/5.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “TP-LINK TL-WA854RE N300 Universal Wireless Range Extender, Wall Plug, Plug&Play, Smart Signal Indicator Light” for review. I had high hopes for this range extender since I have a fitting application for it. However, it turned out to be quite a frustrating experience to set it up the way it is intended to work...The wireless signal from our cable modem in the living room has always left us wanting in the bedroom. In theory, this range extender is the perfect solution if we plug it in the dinette, which is situated right in-between the living room and the bedroom.The out-of-the-box experience is quite nice. I'd say that these days most vendors have adopted (or “copied”) from Apple well enough that the device feels exquisite. There is a nicely folded manual, a drive cd (that I don't care for), and the repeater itself.The manual is very clear: there are two methods to set this up. Method one is WDS, which is supposedly easier, but we cannot use it since we don't want to mess with the cable modem. Instead, we use method two: boot the repeater, associate a computer with a temporary access point exposed by the repeater, and then configure it to repeat the signal from the cable modem.We are able to associate with the temporary access point with no problem (the default login credential is printed on the manual). Then we made the first mistake: the default setting is to have the range extender use the same wireless network name as the cable modem. To be sure, it works, but it turns out one of our smartphones gets confused by the presence of two wireless networks each with the same name and the same password. It gets so confused that the wifi driver on the phone keeps crashing. We figure that we should change the wireless network name. To be fair I am not taking any points off due to this: after all it's our own phone that has problem.Resetting the range extender is easy: just hold a pin-sized button for 10 seconds and it will reset and reboot. The second time we tell the range extender to expose a wireless network under a different name. In other words, the uplink for the range extender runs in the same network as the cable modem, and it itself presents another wireless network. We reconfigured all our phones, tablets, and laptops to use this newer network, and everything worked flawlessly.At least for a while.We made the second mistake by following the manual's suggestion to relocate the range extender. You see, the manual suggested us to set up the repeater somewhere close to the cable modem, and then unplug it to relocate to the designated location (which is the dinette for us). However, after relocation, the range extender cannot join the cable modem's network reliably. The repeater will hang a few seconds after booting up. We had to unplug and plug it in 5 times for it to finally latch on the network.So we thought this must be a firmware problem and we went to the TP-Link's firmware download page. Sure enough TP-Link is already aware of the problem. On 8/27/2014 they have released a new firmware version that “Fixed a BUG that device sometimes may not connect to the main router after relocation/reboot.” However, we did not dare to install this firmware since it is for hardware revision “'TL-WA854RE(EU) V1” and the review unit we received is “US v1.1”. Duh!In the end, we spent over an hour to figure all these out: pick a different network name, and do not try to relocate it. I hope I have provided you with some entertainment. :PDuring the setup time my housemate and I were both quite astonished: both of us have computer science degrees, and so while it was frustrating we knew how to move forward since we wanted to write this review. However, if we are consumers who paid for this, we would have definitely returned it half an hour into the game. I hope TP-Link would release a firmware for the US hardware version and flash it on as soon as possible. Otherwise, I predict Amazon will have a lot of “warehouse deals” (returned goods) on this model.We are giving it a 4/5 since it actually works as advertised... except it does require a lot more fiddling than we would expect.

I have tried all four popular speakerphones in the $100 range you can find on Amazon: Philips WeCall, Logitech P710e, Jabra SPEAK 510, and Plantronics Calisto 620. If you are ok with using the WeCall over USB, you should buy it *now*---it has no competition!Inside the box there is the WeCall, a USB-to-microUSB cable, a travel case, and a very thin manual. You really don't need the manual since everything is very intuitive. The WeCall has four buttons on top: Answer/Hangup, Mic Mute (just mic, not the speaker), Volume Up, and Volume Down. On the bottom there is a slide button for Power, a push button to initiate Bluetooth pairing, and a slide bottom to choose between USB and Bluetooth. The form factor is a square spanning about 4.25 inch in each direction, and it barely breaks an inch at its thickest point, which is at the center since the top is dome-shaped.The Philips WeCall excels in what it is supposed to do, namely as a speakerphone. For now, let's forget about Bluetooth and focus on using it over USB.The speaker is good quality. At its highest volume it can easily fill a 20-feet-by-20-feet room. The voice is clear with no distortion. There can be no complaint.Philips's magic is in the microphone part: WeCall boosts 4 microphones and this allows Philips to pick up my voice at a moderate distance while performing noise cancellation. (Plantronics has 2, and Logitech and Jabra both have 1). I know in principle some digital signal processing can help and this is what the other manufacturers will tell you. But this is my experience in the same room: At 1 feet all these speakerphones equally clear. But at 3 feet, only the Plantronics and the Philips are usable, and the Logitech is ok if you are facing the front direction. At 6-12feet, only the Philips can pick up clearly. The Philips WeCall is truly amazing when you have more than 2 people in the room.(At over 12 feet, I have positive experience only on a PolyCom. We do not have budget for the Internet (IP) version of PolyCom. But who uses landline these days? Plus, it is not portable.)So why are some of the reviewers not so happy with the WeCall? I believe that's because they are using the WeCall over Bluetooth. In this mode, I have yet to meet a speakerphone that performs satisfactorily. The WeCall still performs better than the other three, but I notice a sharp quality degrade once I am more than three feet away. (Note that for the experiment I have the WeCall communicate with my MacBook Pro at exactly the same location as it was when I was using USB. Also, I have tried plugging the WeCall into a power source under the theory that maybe in the Bluetooth mode it needs to conserve battery. Still, no change.)Our entire office is very happy with the WeCall and it has really enabled us to turn any room into a conference room. In fact, I bought one for my home, and my collaborators from remote sites also bought the WeCall given their positive experience when teleconferencing with us.Bottom line is: this is a solid 5/5 and I recommend it without hesitation. It is perfect if you are ok with using it over USB, and it still beats the competition in Bluetooth mode.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Paderno World Cuisine 4-Blade Spiralizer” for review. Like many reviewers, I have purchased the 3-blade version before and so I guess this is why Amazon thinks I should check out this upgraded 4-blade version.A spiralizer is a very specialized kitchen device in that it can do only one thing: essentially you use a rotating handle to push food towards a mounted blade, and on the other side comes out the sliced food. I primarily use it to cut zucchini and cucumber strands for salad. For this I use the “spaghetti” blade, where the strands have a diameter that is roughly that of a cooked spaghetti. There is also a fancy blade that can cut a potato into spiral accordion, although I honestly have not ever done it.In this upgraded version, you get a new “angle hair” blade that cuts very thin strands. I tried very hard to appreciate this new capability. However, given my typical use for zucchini and cucumber, I don't really think I need this new blade since this new blade is not so suitable to cut these softer veggies. It makes perfect sense if you think about it: softer veggies have trouble going through the smaller holes without getting squashed.The construction on this new 4-blade version is every bit as good as the old version. The white plastic is very sturdy, and the blades appear to be equally sharp on my copy. Now this is only 2 months in and so I cannot comment on long-term sharpness. If it significantly deteriorates later, I will surely come back to update the review.In the end, I know you will be asking if the 3-blade is a better value. For my usage, the two are indeed the same and so the lower asking price of the 3-blade seems tempting.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Dirt Devil SD40050 Dash Bagless Canister” for advance review. This is the sixth vacuum cleaner I have reviewed for Amazon though this is the first canister in the six and also the second in my life.Frankly, I am not a fan of canister since I live in a colder climate (western Pennsylvania) and even fancy canister vacs struggle on carpets. The reason is just laws of physics: on an upright the weight helps you push on the carpet a bit more, and on a canister you have to do the pushing.This Dirt Devil is not a fancy canister, but it is very capable if you have extremely thin carpet (like our office) or hardwood (like my kitchen). The vac has an easy to use foot pedal on the brush to choose between these two settings. I have tried it on both surfaces and unsurprisingly it works much better on the hardwood floor.This Dirt Devil have two major selling points. First, it is bagless with a HEPA filter. This works well in practice. My previous canister is a Miele that retails for over six times the asking price of this Dirt Devil, but that one is bagged. So while the Miele wins in its raw suction power hands down, the Miele does require frequent bag replacement to keep its advantage. In this regard, I actually prefer this Dirt Devil: no bags means the suction remains high regardless of bag fill, and you don't have to keep buying bags (and honestly the Miele bags are not cheap). The only required maintenance on this Dirt Devil is to wash the HEPA filter periodically.The second selling point is that it can be fitted with a so-called “Vac+Dust Floor Tool with Swipe”, at least according to Amazon's webpage and the user manual. However, the vac that got shipped to me does NOT have the Swipe head, and so I cannot review this feature.While this is a good bag-less vac, it certainly is in the entry-level. The reason is the included accessories. There there is basically one “3-in-1 tool” that can be fitted on the hose. The tool can be clumsily converted among three modes: crevice, bristle brush, and lint brush. Given the price point, I find this a fair level of quality.All things considered, I find this vac to be a nice introduction to bag-less vacuum cleaners. If you have thin office-style carpet (no loft) or hardwood, and if you are looking for a bag-less vac, this Dirt Devil gets my recommendation. Just make sure you leave plenty of room for storing it: the hose does not compress well and it occupies considerable space in the closet.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Kyocera CFP26BK Ceramic Nonstick Fry Pan, 10-Inch” for review.I have not been using non-stick pans for almost 10 years out of potential health issues with the non-stick coating. In the last few years I have been hearing about all these ceramic pans in the stores. However, since I am quite happy with the non-stick performance of my seasoned carbon-steel fry pan, I never bothered to check them out. Well, until this pan shows up on my Vine list...Upon arrival I immediately noticed the high-quality construction of the pan. The pan seems sturdy and it has survived Amazon's no-padding shipping. The handle is super nice: it is 100% smooth and does not have any sharp edges to dig into your hand. The bottom of the pan is essentially smooth, so you need not worry about scratching in case you are using a glasstop (I myself use gas).Kyocera is well known for their ceramics and I have been using their ceramic knives for over 10 years. According to the packaging, this pan uses a proprietary ceramic non-stick coating known as Kyo Glaze and it is supposed to be oven safe up to 400F and also comes with a one-year warranty. The glaze is said to be metal-utensil safe and it is free of PTFE and PFOA.Of course, the real test is in actual cooking. After having used it for over a month, I find myself using this pan more often than I thought. The handle shape is really nice and the handle is mostly cool to touch. Food releases very well, though it also suffers from a lack of caramelization just like other non-stick pans. I tried using a metal spatula inside when I fry a fish fillet (which is a struggle since this pan is 10 inch only) and the glaze does seem to hold up. The cleaning is a snap, or I should say a swipe---there is really nothing to clean other than swiping a soaped sponge over and rinse. In the last month, I have tried cooking pan cakes, fish fillets, eggs, and also a risotto. Nothing sticked.So what's not to like about this pan? Very little. If I really need to pick on it would be on heat distribution. The bottom of the pan seems to have special embedding to help heat distribution, but still it is very thin and it is very obvious on a gas stove. For example, the center of a pancake is often quite a bit more browned than the edges. My cast iron pan is perfect for this. I am also not so hot on the lack of caramelization---I really like my fish fillet to have a crispy crust and this barely makes it. Finally, at 10 inch this pan is a tad small, though it is less of a problem because the side is relatively straight.Overall, I am quite impressed with this Kyocera pan. If this pan ends up wearing out, I will be quite happy to replace it with an equivalent 12 inch. (That is assuming that no new health issues come out with ceramics.)P.S. I also did a magnetic test: yes, magnets stick to the bottom and so you should be able to use this on an inductive stove.
