Courtesy of the Amazon Vine Program, I have received an “OXO Good Grips POP Cereal and Snack Dispensing Canister” for review. This series comes in three sizes 2.5Qt, 3.4Qt, and 4.5Qt and I am reviewing the medium size here.At its most basic, this is an air-tight canister with a pop lid: you push on one side of the lid and the other side pops up. The air-tightness comes from the silicone gaskets on the lid and around the pop up. OXO lists two other major features, namely a smooth-pour spout and a contoured grip.To put this canister to test, I fill it up with my favorite breakfast cereal, which happens to be the good old corn flakes. There are quite a few things to like. First, the contoured grip really helps gripping the canister. Second, the air-tightness indeed seems to work ok: In the past, I would notice the flakes getting softer as the week progresses due to moisture absorption. (I did not used to put the opened bag into a container.) However, now that I have this canister, I just empty the bag into the canister in a batch and the problem seems to have gone away. Yay!Over my use, I am not sure the smooth-pour sprout really makes any difference though. The truth is I never have any problem pouring out my cereal. In fact, given the size of the opening, I will be surprised if this can make any difference.Overall, we all know that OXO makes good items and this is no exception. The plastic is BPA-free, and the construction seems high quality and durable. The lid is asymmetric, and therefore you always put it on in the correct orientation so that the grip and the sprout are on opposite side. The pop out part of the lid is also detachable for thorough cleaning, although honestly I won't bother doing that. Now OXO did not list if the item is dish-washer safe, and so I have to assume that the gaskets are better washed manually.Other than the what I consider to be slightly high asking price, there is really nothing to fault. OXO easily earns 5/5 here.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received an “Ambient Weather BC-2000 Intelligent Battery Charger for AA/AAA Rechargeable Batteries” for review. I guess Amazon picked me to review this charger because I have just purchased a PowerEx MH-C9000 Wizardone Charger a few years ago. :)First, let me describe the BC-2000 briefly. Inside the box you have the charger itself, a small 12V-1A power supply unit, and a short but quite detailed manual (argh... the tiny font size). The charger can charge both AA and AAA out of the box, and also bigger batteries like C and D if you buy a converter. (And just to be sure, there is no rechargeable batteries included, which, to me, is a good thing).To a MH-C9000 veteran, this BC-2000 gives a similar feel, but it is less sophisticated and also arguably (due to being less sophisticated) easier to operate in a normal day-to-day operation---to charge a batch of batteries. The standard operation procedure is this: you push in 1 to 4 batteries with no more than 6 seconds delay in-between each, then up the current from 200mA to your desired current by pushing the Current button, then the charger will start charging each battery intelligently (won't overcharge) and independently (neighboring batteries does not affect each other's charging). This compares favorably on my MH-C9000, which requires you to push an Enter button for each battery. (However, see below.)As the manual stated, if you are charging 1 or 2 batteries, you want to place them on slots 1 and 4 (the outermost). This will allow you to select up to 1400mA. If you put them in the middle two slots, then you can select up to 1000mA only. When charging 3 batteries, put them in slots 1 through 3 but only slot 1 can be at 1400mA (the other two will be at 1000mA). When charging 4 batteries, every slot is limited to 1000mA. If you think this is way too complicated and perhaps somewhat restricting, it's  because it is true... Indeed, the MH-C9000 does not have this restriction and it can in fact go to 2000mA on each slot (that is one of the reasons why the power supply unit on the MH-C9000 is rated at 12V-2A).Of course, there are other functions on the BC-2000. Besides charging, it can perform discharge to measure battery capacity. There is also a refresh mode that charges and discharges a battery repeatedly to refresh/break into an old battery. (And if we limit the number of cycles to one, it's called test mode on the BC-2000.) Finally, there is also a quick test mode which discharges a battery for about 10 seconds and measures its internal resistance. (A high resistance means you should replace the battery.)Overall, I really like the BC-2000's simplicity in its most frequent usage mode of charging. I think of it as a slightly fancier version of a high-quality charger that often comes in a bundle with rechargeable batteries (such as the Sanyo NC-MQR02N that are often bundled with Sanyo Eneloop rechargeable batteries). The fanciness is because you get to choose the charging current and also perform other functions like cycling. The MH-C9000 is about 50 – 70 % more expensive, and the only difference is the interface and the ability to charge at a higher current (but you rarely want to do that... usually you charge at half the battery rating... so for a 2000mAh battery you charge at around 1000mAh, and some people even recommend slightly lower). So between the BC-2000 and the MH-C9000, there is really very little reason to go with the latter. I happened to picked MH-C9000 since there was a good deal due to Amazon's dynamic pricing, but for my usage I can totally go with the BC-2000 just as well.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a "PowerCube Extended USB, Electric Outlet Adapter 5ft Extension Cord Power Strip with 4 outlets, Dual USB Port and Resettable Fuse PC-4400-USEUPC" for review. Inside the easy-to-open box is the power strip itself, a brief manual printed at the back of the cardboard packaging, two stickers, and a plastic mount.The power strip itself is heavy-duty. You can tell it is serious stuff by the thickness of the 5-feet cable to the wall. It is rated at 125V and 15A. There is a fuse and from their website it is rated at 16A.There are two innovations in the cube-shaped strip. First, the four sockets are on the four sides of the cube. This means it can easily accommodate four "power bricks" adaptors with no worry to block so long as the brick is within 2.5 inch thick. The designer further reduces the chance of blocking by orienting the sockets differently: two of the opposing sockets is aligned in the up-down direction and the other two opposing sockets is aligned in the left-right direction. Very clever.The second innovation is in the two integrated USB charging ports. Being USB, the two ports are rated at 5V. The output is listed as 2.1A, and it is not clear from the literature nor the packaging whether this is a combined 2.1A across the two ports, or 2.1A per port. (One iPad can use 2.4A, but I don't have two iPads to test concurrent charging.)The plastic mount can be snapped on one of the sockets in a snap-and-twist motion. The idea is that you mount the plastic mount underneath a table top using either the two supplied stickers or by screws (screws not supplied). Once done you can easily snap a power cube underneath your table. I did not test this since I use a glass table top. The stickers also look flimsy... no sure it can hold the weight anyway.Overall, I am quite impressed with the design of this power cube. Although it sports only four sockets (there is another version that does not have USB ports and instead has an extra socket), I like the overall aesthetics of it. It also comes with two years of warranty. I have contacted the vendor to check if the USB ports are rated at 2.1A each or combined. (If it is combined, I will come back to update.)UPDATE: I communicated with the designing firm and they confirmed that it's 2.1A COMBINED. Be ware of the implication. For example, charging one iPad alone will consume all the available power. I am taking a star off since this is really a missed opportunity. I'd rather seeing the cube goes a bit more expensive and support at least 3.5A. (One phone plus one iPad doesn't seem much these days...)

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “K'nex Hyperspeed Hangtime Roller Coaster Building Set” for review. The set comes well-packaged in the shipping box (it's huge, and it matters given how UPS/Fedex treats packages), and inside the set are a large number of pieces, (620 to be exact), and you need to provide 3 'C' size batteries (it's the one size bigger than 'AA'). I have not purchased such batteries for almost 10 years now, but they are well-stocked at retailers and are easy to find.We tested this with our neighbors 10-year-old, who is very much into Lego but has never heard of K'nex before. He has extensive experience Lego sets with large number of pieces, and so 620 is a 'medium size' for him.School has started at this time of the year, and so it took him 2 evenings to finish building, though it is obvious that by the end of the first evening it's mostly done. In total, he built it without adult intervention in under 3 hours. (I think he takes it as a challenge to build it as quickly as possible. This is not intended.) The set looks impressive in size, and the inversion makes the roller coaster quite a bit more fun to look at. The fact tha K'nex is not 100% rigid actually makes the coaster more interesting to look at: when the car moves around the whole set jiggles a little bit, especially at the electric 'launch' at the base.The kid's impression to the K'nex was good and here are a few comments. First, while the color coding makes it easy to build, the end result is a bit less attractive visually (to him anyway). (Constrast this with Lego, where the same piece can come in different colors.) Second, the instruction is very clear and easy to follow, and there is actually a second set of downloadable instructions for another coaster. He likes that this is not a “one tricky pony”. (And since this is his introduction to K'nex, he doesn't have any spare set to invent another build yet. I imagine this is possible, just like Lego.) His mom appreciates the toy, but commented that it takes up a lot of space in the living room and so it's not obvious that they will keep it there for long. After all it is a display item: once you have built it, there is nothing else other than an infinite loop. Indeed, a week later when we visit again the kid is no longer paying attention to it. (This is not unique to K'nex; many kids these days cannot stay on one toy for too long.)Overall, this is a good introduction to K'nex. If you have the space, it can even be an attractive display. However, we feel that to get the most out of K'nex you need to invest in the system, and in this regard we feel that K'nex is a bit specialized (in this regard we have to agree that Lego is a lot more versatile).

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Francois et Mimi Large Stainless Steel Double Wall French Coffee Press,50oz” and a “Francois et Mimi Brushed Finish Stainless Steel Double Wall French Coffee Press,34oz” for review. Since the two items are similar except for the look and capacity, I am writing this one review for both. I will specifically comment on each of them after I get through their common points.Francois et Mimi is a new brand to me. As French sounding as the brand is, the coffee presses are both made in China. (I don't want to start any argument here, but I state this as an FYI.) These are the first fully-metal french press I have ever used. I am compelled to review these due to a simple and obvious reason: since they are made of metal only, they cannot break, at least not easily. In practice I did manage to drop one of them into the sink by accident (or rather, lack of caffeine right after waking up), and sure enough nothing broke. Great!Another reason for the metal design is that these pots are supposed to be insulated by double walls and so they retain heat. This is where you need to set your expectation right. The heat-retention effect is very noticeable to be sure, but it is not in the same league as Thermos (or lately, Rubbermaid) and so you should not expect these to double as an insulated carafe. (In fact, there is a tiny opening next to the spout and hot air can still escape.)But how well does the idea of heat-retention work for coffee? Well, I am sorry to report that I don't get the design at all. You see, brewing coffee with french press has a problem: if you don't empty the pot after pressing you risk over-extraction. I just don't see any use where I will want to press the coffee in the pot and leave the coffee in. In other words, for my daily use there won't be any hot coffee to be left in the pot to keep warm! I didn't realize this until I have slightly ruined my first pot. Oh well... And unlike the newest breed of french presses that try to compress the pressed grind into a pallet to prevent over-extraction (at least in theory), these Francois et Mimi are the old-school design where the grind is still loose. Definite a high risk.The smaller of the two (34oz) is matte and it actually looks quite nice in person. The large one is mirror-finished and, like all other items of such finish, it is a fingerprint magnet. Other than these two factors, the two are virtually identical.Honestly, with my preference of not over-extracting coffee I really don't see much use of this design. However, the construction and material is top-notch. I am conflicted but I think a 4/5 rating is reasonable. Sorry.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a "Verilux VT10WW1 HappyLight Liberty Natural Spectrum Lamp, 5K Energy" for review. Inside the box is a simple one-piece box lamp and a brief manual.[EDIT] The 5K refers to the intensity of light (5000 LUX). (Previously, I thought it was the color temperature.) The color of the bulb is in fact also very close to 5K, which is similar to broad daylight. It's much more "blue"/"cooler" than the typical yellow light from an incandescent bulb, and skin tone look fantastic in this light. Since it mimics daylight, it is also believed (and with some scientific evidence) that this helps to improve mood.While I am not qualified to verify the science, I can speak of my experience as a user. It's summer here in the Northern hemisphere and therefore there is no lack of sunshine during the day. But I am in the computer industry which happens to involve a lot of night time. For this, I want to know how well this Verilux mimics daylight. The answer: Verilux does it very well. In the past month I have used it in the evening while I am still in the office and I can attest that its light does keep me alert for quite a bit longer than I initially think such a small light can. The trick, it seems, is the angle. This Verilux lamp happens to be a small box sitting on the desk. At the recommended usage distance (about 24 inch from the face), it's in fact very bright. It also has a very effective lens that can diffuse the light evenly and there is almost no hot spot in terms of light. (But in terms of temperature, the lamp does run quite hot. I cannot keep my hand touching the top of the lamp for more than a few seconds.)The manual has clear instruction that you should not stare at the lamp. Instead, you should place it in the peripheral vision. For me, it is still too bright and my eyes don't like it (perhaps I will like it more in the winter?). Instead, at the moment I have it light up the wall behind my monitor and I think it still works fantastic since it helps to reduce the contrast between the screen and the wall behind it.Inside the box lamp is a 26W CFL in the spiral form. It's changeable and the electric connection is called GU24, which is not Verilux-specific. (As of this writing I know Home Depot has GU24 bulbs and they are even rated at 5K color temperature, but they are lower wattage and are dimmer.) In any case, you can order replacement from Verilux directly. The manual has an order form, and it is 14.95 for each bulb and 6.95 for the shipping.Overall, I have to say I like this lamp for that it does to me, but I also understand that the effect of light therapy can be very different on different bodies. Fortunately, the price is not that steep and if you have a medical need for light therapy I can definitely recommend this product.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a "D-Link Systems Wi-Fi AC750 Portable Router and Charger (DIR-510L)" for review. What an interesting device! At the size of about an iPhone5  (though longer and thicker), this device packs a feature-rich wireless router AND a 4000mAh rechargeable battery. Very neat.Inside the box you will find the device itself, a brief manual, and a 100-240V wall-to-micro-USB 2A charger. The charger unfortunately is not the sideway type and therefore it can take up multiple wall sockets.The device is full of ports and controls on its four sides. At the south side there is a micro-USB socket for charging the device itself and an Ethernet socket. On the east side there are two USB (apparently USB2.0 according to my testing) ports, rated at 0.5A and 1A. On the north side sits the WPS button and a three-way slide switch (charger, off, on). Finally, on the west side we have a pin-sized factory reset button just in case you have misconfigured the device.The charger function needs no explanation. It works, but 4000mAh is not exactly a lot by today's standard. At best I can say it serves its purpose. However, the wireless router feature of this device is very interesting. There are three modes this router can operate in, depending on its uplink.1. Ethernet. Nothing special: you are sharing the ethernet connection to wireless devices associated with this router. Any wireless router does this.2. USB. This is fun. D-Link's firmware supports a number of USB 3G/4G/LTE modems. That means you can split that 3G/4G/LTE uplink among your devices. A few years ago a device like this can cost several hundred bucks. I don't have a USB modem, and therefore I cannot test this. D-Link says "For a list of compatible 3G/4G USB adapters, check your local D-Link website." But I cannot find that list.3. 802.11 hotspot. This is why I am in love with this device. Essentially it acts as a wireless client to another wireless network, and thus allowing you to split the wireless uplink to your other wireless devices. My team travels a lot and truth be told we often need to work in the same hotel room. This is where this device shines: we pay for one hotel room internet access, and the entire team is online! I can see that this device will pay for itself in just a few trips!The device's firmware also features a DLNA server that allows you to share any file stored in a USB thumb drive or even a low-power harddrive (we use the 1A port---it works). This can be super convenient so long as you have the right software clients. You can upload files through their sharepoint HTTP on port 8181, and we share (download) media from the device using VLC. Everything works flawlessly. (The only thing I can wish is to have a SAMBA server to make things more convenient. :P)Overall, I am very impressed with this device. The packaging is top-notch; the built is great; and it boasts a very rich feature set. What's not to love? 5/5.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Lexar High-Performance microSDHC 633x 32GB UHS-I Flash Memory Card LSDMI32GBBNL633R” for review. In the package is a 32GB Class 10 microSD card and a cute USB adaptor.As with all storage devices these days, the performance stated by the vendor is just an estimate and for some devices there can be different read and write times. To figure this out, I have done a small test using 4 ISO files totaling 2841 MB in size.Here are the read and write timings as measured on my Retina 13” Late 2013 MacBook Pro, which features USB3 and PCI-e SSD. Note that *each* is performed right after a cold boot to minimize cache effect:Read from Lexar, as in `time cat * > /dev/null`:real 0m31.731suser 0m9.813ssys 0m1.247s(This is about 89.6MB/s.)Write to Lexar, as in `cp * /Volume/NO\ NAME/`:real 0m31.537suser 0m0.010ssys 0m0.678s(This is about 90.2MB/s.)As you can see, the read and write performance is very close to Lexar's spec of 95MB/s. Based on this performance, I am giving this a 5/5

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Rubbermaid Shaker Bottle, 20-Ounce, Black” for review. In summary it's a BPA-free hard plastic (Tritan) bottle with a five-sided paddle ball for mixing. As you can see from the picture, it has both black and lime green accent, though the tritan plastic is dark grey and so I think black is an apt description.Prior to this I have never used a shaker bottle before. It's principle is really simple: you put the paddle ball into the bottle together with whatever you want to mix, and as you shake the paddle ball will stir the mixture for you to speed up mixing. In practice, my primary application is protein shakes, and I can assure you that it really is a lot faster than just shaking alone. As a result, this has become part of my gym packing routine.The bottle has several nice features. First, there is a rubble handle that makes it easy to clip onto a carabiner. Second, the cover has rubberized side and so twisting it off is easy. Third, the (small) cap on the cover twists in very tightly and this prevents leak from shaking. Furthermore, you cannot lose the cap since it is attached to the cover over a pivot. Finally, the entire bottle is dishwasher safe.Overall, I really think this bottle is very practical for everyday use. I am giving this a five star based on this.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Tweezerman G.E.A.R. Essential Grooming Kit” for review. Inside the neat small package is a pouch, a nail file, a nail clipper, a pointed tweezer, and a pair of facial hair scissors.My overall impression of this kit is that everything is above average, but all can use some improvements.The pouch, as many reviewers have noted, is large enough but have too much opening when closed. In practice, the nail clipper can easily fall out of the opening in travel.The nail file is quite good but in the one month of testing, I already feel that the file is has reduced efficiency. No, that's not because my mails are that strong. Instead, it has to do with the pattern: when the nail pieces start accumulating in the grooves, you are effectively “un-sharpening” the file. The pattern Tweezerman used happens to make accumulation easier than the other files I have used. (However, it is still very effective, so long as you remember to clean the file regularly.)The clipper is typical Tweezerman quality, which is good. The problem is it's not competitive: no file built-in, and no nail catcher. These are standard these days. (If you can, get a nail clipper by the Japanese brand Muji. It's the standard I judge every nail clipper that comes my way.)The tweezer is the pointed variant, so you should be careful about the point when handling. Fortunately the pouch has a special slot for it so that the point can be properly stored. The points on my pair match up perfectly. Kudos.The pair of scissors is actually a re-branded Inox. It's as good as any other pair of Inox scissors I have come across. Be careful not to use it to cut anything hard. I ruined a pair before by trying to cut a small fragment of nail away. (The metal on the Inox is softer, I don't know why.)Overall, I would say this is a nice starter kit. But I cannot give this a perfect score. So 4/5.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Miele RX1 Scout” for review. Previously, I have been called a “Roomba-holdout” in the office: I work in the high-tech industry and I am the only person in the team who doesn't have a robotic vacuum yet. Instead, I happily take out my Dyson and more recently my LG Kompressor every weekend and enjoy the experience of pushing it around by myself. I know this sounds strange, but I really enjoy doing vacuum cleaning and that's one of the few household work items that my gf approves me to do without her supervision. :PI won't go into detail about what this Scout is. Amazon's website and many other reviewers do a wonderful job explaining what it is. Instead, I want to talk about my experience of using it.The out-of-the-box experience is very good. Everything is neatly packaged. The manual is clear: attach the brushes, let it charge first, and setup the remote and clock. Done. The only potential negative here is the gf's comment that this is made in Korea (Miele is a German brand). I honestly have no problem with where this is made so long as it is high-quality.Once done with charging, you essentially push the Auto button to select the mode and then the Play button to go. At this moment the “fun” begins. We have a cat that would chase after anything with the slightest movement. Naturally, the Scout moves, and so she gives chase. Unfortunately this interferes with the Scout because it is a machine and it doesn't understand that the cat is not a piece of furniture. So, we ended up locking the cat in the bedroom for the Scout to finish the living room. First problem.Then we get to the reason why I have been a holdout: these machines are, urr, machines and you really have to work with it and cope with its limits. I claim that I still do a fair bit of work to let the Scout work its way. I have to clean up all the obstacles on the floor or else it may get stuck or keep pushing things around. The cat toy that looks like a tiny pillow? No way, the Scout will try to run over it or keep pushing it around. In practice this generates the same amount of work for me in terms of moving things around. It's just that instead of me doing it one piece at a time, I have to do it all at once before I start the Scout. Second problem.The Scout is supposed to have a good vision algorithm that trumps all Roomba: instead of literally bumping into a furniture and uses the physical feedback (at which point your chair's leg can already been scratched), it uses a camera to try to not run into anything. However, just as some other reviewers have pointed out, the machine vision algorithm in the Scout can really use some improvement: in my case not only it cannot see the cat toys, it also could not see the cloth window shade and would run into the glass window behind it. Miele did provide us with a short magnetic strip that can act as a barrier, but it is too short for the entire sliding window in the living room. We decided that it's ok for it to bump into the glass anyway and let it go. Then the Scout decided to not touch the strip of carpet in front of the AV system. Maybe that was due to the magnetic field of the AV? Third problem. (In any case, I guess maybe later firmware updates will improve the performance.)The dust bin is generous but understandably doesn't compare with any old-school vacuum. I realize that Scout owners probably would let it run everyday and so it is not a real problem. However, if that means  I have to arrange the room everyday (think the cat toys), then no thank you. In our case we manage to fill the bin after an hour. (The battery is supposed to be able to last for two hours, btw.) It's not a big deal, but just remember that this is not a real “week-ender”. Fourth problem (for me anyway).Overall, I would say that if you are looking for a robotic vacuum and can cope with its limit, this Miele may be worth checking out given its extensive feature set (the remote control mode is super fun for the cat). In fact, my gf commented that she would definitely go with the Miele since she has discussed this extensively with her friends who own Roombas and every one of her friends thinks the Miele is more desirable. The reason I said “may” is because at the time of this writing there is no asking price yet and so it is difficult for me to comment on how I see its value.To end this review, while I appreciate this Miele a lot, logically I will continue to be a Roomba-holdout for the longest time to come. :) I justify my four-star rating due to two competing factors: this is premium design, but it is not without its flaw in the machine vision department. Given the potentially high asking price and the uncertainty of future firmware upgrades, giving this a 5/5 would be difficult. I hope Miele would appreciate my honest feedback. Sorry.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Kensington Proximo Key FOB Bluetooth Tracker for iPhone 5S/5C/5/4S and Samsung Galaxy S3/S4” for review. On paper this is a great concept: a key fob that keeps a bluetooth connection to your phone and a corresponding app on the phone. Once the bluetooth connection drops or degrades to a certain level, you get alerted. The app also has a feature to allow you to page the fob, and vice versa. So, what's not to love?Unfortunately, as many reviewers have indicated, there are two everyday issues that keep me from warming up to this Kensington key fob. First, the “panic button” on the fob is too prone to be pressed. That means in practice your phone panics all the time. On the first day of trying, I think I triggered it at least five times. It's that embarrassing... you sit down, the pocket presses the keys onto the fob, and alarm it goes. Second, the app has trouble staying alive on the phone, which means you can find the fob using the app (since you are using the app and so it is alive), but you can rarely find the phone using the fob (since you are not using the app, which can get suspended by the phone's O/S). Fortunately, haha, in the modern times I tend to lose my keys more often than my phone, and so this is not too big of a problem. However, if it's the other way around for you, I would not recommend this.Overall, I think this is a reasonably-good concept but with a lackluster execution. The price is not low either. Sorry, Kensington, I can only give this three stars at best.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a “Fugoo Tough Bluetooth Wireless Speaker” for review. In the past I have encountered a number of bluetoth wireless speakers, including a Bose SoundLink Mini, a Jam Party HMDX, and a Pure Jongo S3. Instead of purely focusing on describing the features of this Fugoo, I will try to draw a comparison.First, here is what the Fugoo is. The model I reviewed is the Tough edition, meaning that it comes in a sturdy metal/rubber casing that Fugoo says is virtually indestructible. The casing is sturdy but also makes the speaker heavy. The spec claims to be snowproof, sandproof, and also waterproof at 3 feet for up to 30 minutes. I did try to use the speaker during a shower with water pouring on top. It works. This is the first Bluetooth speaker I have taken a bath with. Ha.The control is extremely simple.  On the top there are two volume buttons and a “shift button”. If you shift+volume, you skip tracks. The shift button also acts a clicker for play and pause.On one side is the power button and the bluetooth pairing button. It seems it can only pair with one device. This is common among speakers I have tried except for the Bose where you can pair with 6 devices. One feature (annoying or not is up to you) is that the speaker can announce its status---at startup it says “Powering On, Device Connected”, and at a press of the power button after it started it will announce the power level like “battery is about half full”. It will also say “Powering off”  at power off. I have yet to figure out how turn the first and last announcements off.On the other side is a min usb slot for charging (no, it does not appear to be an USB speaker), and an audio jack for connected playback.The audio playback quality is very good, thanks to its 6(!)-speaker design. It's hard to see through the Tough casing, but they are there if you shine light through the mesh. I am thrilled at the sound quality. It is every bit as good as the Bose and the Pure, both of which blows the Jam Party away. However, as I have indicated in my review on the Jam Party, for an outdoor speaker the audio quality does not matter too much. (This is the reason why I think the Jam Party is a reasonable buy for outdoor picnics, though it is definitely not waterproof.)Unfortunately, thus Fugoo seems to have a battery drain similar to the Bose. Perhaps these speakers don't really turn off completely. I discovered this by turning it off (the speaker announces “Powering off”, so there can be no ambiguity on what I should expect) and leave it for a week. When I come back, there is no power left. The Jam Party and the Pure do not have this problem.One key thing that distinguishes this Fugoo bluetooth speaker from the rest of the pack is that it is in fact NOT just a speaker. I don't know why the marketing material says it's a speaker when it's really a speakphone! Indeed, it has a fully working microphone built-in. You can hold a conversation with it and I have tested it on Skype. It works flawlessly and the audio quality is as good as any other microphone I have tried if I am close enough. (In this use case the quality bottleneck is usually the audio compression deployed by Skype.) However, perhaps due to the sturdy casing, the audio quality drops once I am at about 3 feet away. For this reason I would not use it on my desk to hold teleconference. And just like any other microphone I have tried, it's mono and using it will also forces OS X to change the playback to the mono as well. (If you select stereo playback, it disconnects the microphone.)Inside the box, which is extremely difficult to open, is the speaker itself, a 2.1A USB charger (allowing charging to be fast), a usb cable, and an 3.5mm audio cable. The cables are tangle-resistant and very high quality. Great stuff. There is no manual other than a very simple leaflet. Interesting there is no hex key included to allow me to remove the casing. (I imagine if I buy another casing it will come with it?)Overall, I am very impressed with both the build and the audio quality of this Fugoo. For anyone who has an active lifestyle that involves sand and water, I would highly recommend it. The asking price is a little bit high, but then, you are really getting top-quality components. (I am only aware of one other water-proof bluetooth speaker. But I have not tried it so I cannot draw a comparison.)

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Rayovac PS73-4BT6 7-Hour Power Back Up for iPhones, Android, and Micro-USB Mobile Phones for review. Inside the box is the charger, a USB-to-microUSB cable, a USB-to-iPhone (old 30-pin standard, not lightning) cable, and four AA non-rechargable batteries. I don't have an iDevice so I have used the USB-to-microUSB cable only.The charger is very simple: it essentially is a battery case where you can put four AA batteries in serial (that's about 6V), and then it down-regulates the voltage to USB (5V). There is no on/off switch. You plug a USB cable into the charger's USB socket and it turns on; unplug and it turns off. There are two problems with the operation if I have to nitpick. 1. The charger turns on even if you have not connected a device on the other side. 2. When it turns on, there are three green LED on the charger to tell you how much juice your AA batteries have, and they are super bright Combining 1 and 2 means that you can potentially drain your AA batteries unintentionally.In actual usage, the amount of power it carries depends on your AA batteries. I have previously purchased an Energizer 3AA-to-USB charger B0093GIME8, and since that is a 3AA design, the running time is lower than this 4AA design. However, this also means the Energizer is more compact. A very reasonable tradeoff.The charger's construction feels a bit, urr, low-quality and the battery cover wobbles a bit more than I wish. I have not seen this grade of plastic in electronics for a long time. To give you a rough idea, I think all the TV remote controls I have handled in the last 10 years have a higher quality plastic than this. However, let me stress that this is enough to get the job done.Overall, if you are looking for a good 4AA-to-USB charger, this is a solid choice in terms of its one-and-only one feature.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Rayovac Indestructible 3 AAA Flashlight for review. This is a very solid LED flashlight, taking 3AAA batteries (included). The operation is very simple: there is a tail button---click once is high, once more is low, and once more is off. The metal construction is top-notch: Rayovac claims that you get drop it at 30 feet. I have not actually drop it from that height onto a hard surfaced, but repeated droppings onto carpet from standing height (about 4-5 feet) do seem to do no damage to the flashlight at all. In other words, if you are a domestic user, I think this is really almost indestructible in the house. The flash light is water-resistant but not water-proof, so don't go diving/snorkeling with it. :) Overall, this is a very solid (pun intended) offering from Rayovac. I have no hesitation recommending it to domestic applications.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine Program, I have received a white AKG K323 XS In-Ear Headphones with In-Line remote control and microphone for review. My overall impression of this AKG is that it is a solid offering for what it *is*, but the asking price is a tad high for my taste.Spec: At 12.85 gram (0.45 oz), this is a very light IEH (in-ear headphone; a perhaps more common name for this is IEM where M stands for “monitor”, except I am very sure no one agrees that this AKG is monitor-grade worthy). The spec claims to support 20Hz-20kHz, but of course this is essentially saying “typical human hearing range”.Components: In the plastic case there is the headphone itself, and it comes with four sets of tips (XS, S, M, L) and a small cloth pouch. I use the XS because my ears are small and you need get a good sealing for this AKG to sound right. There are also some paper documents in the package, but they are not the manual; instead they state the warranty (one year), the typical warning (don't listen too loudly), and the environmental/recycle information. The operating instruction is printed on the packaging, and it pictorially says press the middle button on the inline control to start/ stop music or take/ hangup calls. If your software supports it, you can also press the button twice to go to the next track (most Android music players support this). And if your software also supports it, you can press the button three times in a quick succession to go to the previous track. I have yet to encounter a music player that supports this but I have heard of such. (Yes, it's much less elegant than the method on Apple iDevices, but I heard there is a patent issue for other platforms to implement it...)Sound: This AKG sounds ok on day 1, but if you are willing to give it two weeks (about 14-20 hours) for “break-in”, then it does sound smoother. Another thing that new IEH users need to get accustomed to: if you don't obtain a tight seal, the sound is bad; but if you do, not only do you get to suppress the environmental sound well, you also get base. At the fifty buck price point, I have not heard any IEH that can be considered to be much better. So you do get what you pay for, if you want the benefit of in-ear, i.e., lower environmental noise.Usability: However, you do not necessarily want in-ears, especially if you are on the move (walking between home and office in my example). There are two reasons. First is unfixable and is a definite cons for almost all IEH/IEMs I have tried: microphonics, meaning the ability for the cable to transmit noise to your ear as it rubs over your clothes. This AKG is downright horrible in this department. I can hear every rub. Second is fixable: it really needs a clip to clip the cable to the shirt. Amazingly AKG decided not to give us a clip. Fortunately, there are a lot of aftermarket offerings and my dollar-store solution worked well. And if you clip the cable, the microphonics reduces too. AKG should really ship a clip in the future.Phone calls: The microphone on the inline control picks up the sound very well, just like every other phone-grade microphone I have used. No complaint here.Durability: Unfortunately the jack is damaged in 2 weeks. I have uploaded a photo showing you the problem. This is fixed using super-glue.Overall: If I can I will give 4.5 stars due to the small flaws. But I am rounding up since the flaws are either fixable (clip) or applicable to all similar in-ear designs (microphonics).

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a T-fal FV4495 Ultraglide Easycord Steam Iron with Ceramic Scratch Resistant Nonstick Soleplate for review. It is rated at 1725 watt, which is in the same ball park as most domestic full-size irons I have tried.I will give you the bottomline first. I am not sure if I have received a faulty unit, or if the design is problematic, but my copy drips quite a bit. I am taking a star off due to this.T-fal can make very good iron. My first iron right before college graduation (needed one for interview clothes) was T-fal and the smooth ceramic plate was what won me over. I am happy to report that this T-fal FV4495 also sports a smooth ceramic plate, and it feels every bit as smooth as any good iron I have used, including top-of-the-line Rowentas and Electroluxs. (I bought a Rowenta DW9080 two years ago. See my review there.)I don't have the number of steam holes. Some other brands like Rowenta like to advertise that they have 400 holes. However, in use, this feels every bit as powerful as my Rowenta in its steam generation capability.The water tank on this T-fal is big. It easily lets me iron an entire week of office clothes. No complaint here either. It uses tap water and has a decent de-calc system. (I never needed to de-calc more than once a year since I live in a soft-water city.)The cord is sufficiently long, at around 12 feet. It's quite typical in a full-sized iron. The iron also heats up respectful quick. There is a safety timer that turns off the iron after about 10 minutes. So all is well in the electricity department.The one thing that makes me take two stars off is that my copy drips way more than the other irons I have tried. I am not sure if it is my technique or a faulty heating system, but I can often see a few drops of water on my shirt before the iron reaches the shirt. In practice, this is not as big a problem as it sounds since you are going to heat the shirt through ironing, thus taking care of the water. However, since the other irons I have tried do not have this problem, I consider this a relative cons and thus take a star off.For its asking price this is a very good iron. I would easily give it five stars if it were not for the dripping.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a 1-qt Oster Mykonos Greek Yogurt Maker for review. Note that there is also a 2-qt version, which addresses my most major complaint to this 1-qt version, namely that it's too small if you are really making greek-style yogurt.I have owned a yogurt maker for many years and a yogurt maker is really just a slightly-heated container. The idea is you first pasteurize the milk, increase the protein content if you want (by adding powdered milk), and then cool it to a suitable temperature and add the starter. Put the mixture into the maker and wait a number of hours (think 8, but it varies) and the heated compartment will keep the bacteria active throughout. The bacteria will digest the lactose, give out acid, which in turn makes the protein curd.This Oster yogurt maker is no different from any other yogurt maker I have tried. Every step up to the waiting part is done manually in your kitchen. The only difference is that this comes with a tons of accessories. First, there are four cute 7oz glass jars with plastic lids. Then it has a 17oz larger plastic container that allows you to make a medium sized batch (obviously 4 * 7 = 28 so you have more capacity if you use the jars instead of this plastic container). Then it comes with a strainer, which is what makes this a greek yogurt maker. (Greek yogurt is essentially strained yogurt).Overall, I have no complaints about the yogurt maker itself. It keeps the temperature well throughout the night. The plastic used in this maker does not have any bad smell (I had one that smells really “plastiky”.) The glass jars are nice, and the recipe book is informative. For these, I will give it five starts.However, I must take a star off if this is supposed to be a greek yogurt maker. The reason is because its designed capacity is just too small. Recall that greek yogurt is strained. For every ounce of “normal” yogurt you make, you get about half an ounce of greek yogurt. So all your effort to pasteurize the milk gives you at most 14oz of greek yogurt at the end. What for?I highly recommend getting at least the 2qt version if you are serious about making yogurt.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Savora Garlic Press for review. Mine came in red. It comes in a very elegant gift box.This garlic press can be decomposed into three parts. The colored part you see in the product photos is plastic, and hence it can come in many colors. The silver handle is inseparable from the plastic part, and it is heavy metal. The silver grille at the bottom of the photos is metal also, and it can be twisted off for cleaning. The transparent cap on the grille is plastic, and it snaps on the grille very tightly and doubles as a container when pressing.The mechanism is a bit hard to describe and I refer you to the product photos for clarification. Essentially you open the metal handle to expose the chamber behind the grille for you to put some garlic pieces in. Then you close the metal handle towards the plastic handle, which will drive a metal plate towards the grille, thus crushing the garlic pieces through the grille into the container cap. Since the grille can be twisted off, cleaning is easy. It is dish-washer safe too, just in case.The design is such that you have a 6-to-1 mechanical advantage. In my very elementary understanding of mechanics, I think of it as the distance travelled by the handle is 6 times larger than the distance travelled by the press. Hence the power from you is “condensed” 6 times, which makes crushing garlic feels easy. (That's essentially what you get from a lever, except that here it is driven by gear.) In practice, it does feel that way. I have never used a garlic press that feels easier.Another ergonomic advantage is that you do not need to hold the press in the air. Instead, you can rest it on the table top with the container cap. This allows the press to be made with heavy metal parts. (And it is indeed quite heavy.)In terms of design this is easily a 10 out of 10. So what's not to like?The construction. See I keep saying “crush” everywhere in this review? The problem is that the press has too much tolerance and the metal plate never quite touch the grille on my copy. This ends up being a big problem in practice: try as I might, this is at best a “garlic masher/ricer” or “garlic crusher” in my kitchen. There is a lot of garlic left between the metal plate and the grille, which spells waste. My other garlic press (from an O brand) has almost zero tolerance and the two pieces of metal meet very tightly. Therefore, every bit of garlic is at least in the grille. There is always some left in the grille in both designs, but that is understandable.It does not help to have the container cap snap so tightly to the grille either. I expect the cap may become looser over use. But the problem is that I will not be using it long enough to find out.I am giving this a 3/5. It has a very good design (5/5), but a poor implementation takes at least two stars off. Sorry.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received an Actiontec 200Mbps Powerline Network Adaptor Kit for review. This essentially is a pair of adaptors that plug into two electric sockets at your home and use the power line between the socket to run network traffic. Then you plug your network devices to the adaptors using the two included ethernet cables (yes, cables are included).My router is on the ground floor and so that's where one of the adaptors go. I have tried a couple of different locations in the house measure the throughput. My home was built in 1960 and so the wires are quite old. The best speed I get, which is from the very same socket, is 80Mbps. This is not bad for an adaptor that is rated at 200Mbps. However, on pretty much any other socket in my home, I get about 30Mbps max. Again, I must stress that these speeds are for my house only. Your experience may be different.Since the whole point of these adaptors are to get a connection that is faster than wireless and yet I already can do better than 30Mbps on wireless, I am a bit disappointed. (Yes, in real life, I would have returned it.) However, since the adaptors work as promised, and they are very easy to set up, I feel that I should still give them a 5/5.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Buffalo MiniStation 500GB USB 3 portable harddrive for review. I have formatted and tested this drive on my MacBook Air, which has USB 3 in its generation. This Buffalo is able to read and write over 100MB/s. Unfortunately, since I use Mac, the Buffalo windows utilities are of little use to me.The drive includes a 1-year warranty. At its asking price, this seems reasonable to me. Since the drive has a good USB 3 transfer speed and has been working well for over a month now, I will give this a 5/5.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a  24" Aquatic Life LED Aquarium Light Fixture for review.In essence, this is a thin (quarter-inch) LED light with a variety of LED and a programmable 3-channel timer. There are 13 6K White LEDs, 14 9K White LEDs, 17 10K White LEDs, 3 Blue LEDs, 7 Red LEDs, and finally 3 Blue "Lunar" LEDs. At maximum output (all LEDs on), this consumes 36W as rated on the power brick (wall-adapter).The 3-channel timer allows you set the on and off time of two day channels and one night channel. Using this, you can create a variety of lighting conditions. The day channels controls the white, red, and blue LEDs. The night channel controls the three lunar blue LED. For me, I had both the day channels start at 7am and off at 10pm, by then it switches to the night channel.Operational-wise, programming the timer is super easy. I was able to follow the instructions in the manual and get it up and running in under 5 minutes.The LEDs run rather hot, which explains why the top of the light is in fact a heat-sink. Since it is winter right now, I do not have any problem. I will come back and update the review if there is any issue during the summer.My review unit did not come with a manual, and it took a little while for me to realize that I have not been mounting this light correctly. The two L clamps on the side are in fact adjustable by loosening and tightening four screws. By sliding the rails, this lighting can fit aquariums that are from 23.5 inch to 26.25 inch. Now it fits snuggly on my 24 inch tank, and all looks good.(I came back to update my review after using it for a month. So far it has been running trouble-free.)

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Belkin QODE Ultimate Keyboard Case for the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3. As typical for reviews like this, I am typing this review on this keyboard.Construction-wise, the metal frame seems sturdy, but the keys are more wobbly that I would like. It is a very compact keyboard case. Once you put the Galaxy into the sleeve, it does feel integrated into one piece. All the ports remain accessible, and the rubber is nonslip. I would give this a 8/10 in terms of construction.Electronically, this keyboard is a bluetooth keyboard. I was able to pair it with a variety of devices without any hassle. Well-done, Belkin.The power on-off mechanism is very clever. Essentially, there are magnets built into the lower rim of the sleeve that is intended to hold the tablet. Once you open the tablet (like as you open the lid of a laptop) and let the magnets engage with the magnets built into the keyboard, the keyboard turns on. There are also multiple magnets on the keyboard and so you can pick your angle. Very clever.So what's not to like? Unfortunately the keyboard layout drives me crazy. At 10.1 inch there will be compromises if the keys are to remain large. However, if you are a touch typist on a computer, then you will be constantly pressing the wrong key when you type punctuations. Look at the , . / ? < > : ; ~ ' “ keys on the product pictures. I am especially annoyed that they move the semicolon.Overall, I'd say that if you want a keyboard for your Galaxy Tab, this is a very good choice. However, be very aware that you may have trouble touch typing. This is especially concerning given the relative high asking price. I am taking a star off due to the layout.

The design of this stopper is very elegant: by tightening the screw, you push together two pieces of metal sandwiching a rubber stopper. As the metal pieces get closer, the rubber gets squeezed along the vertical axis and thus expands (bulges) horizontally, thus sealing the bottle opening. I picked this stopper since this design allows it to fit more bottles.The external polished stainless steel surface screams high-class and the stopper is very hefty. I would have totally loved it...Unfortunately, they cheap out on the screw and the thread on mine has stripped after the third use. Now it becomes a very elegant paper-weight. Avoid!

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a LeapFrog LeapPad2 Kids' Learning Tablet (Custom Edition) for review. Let me first explain what Custom Edition means. This is essentially a LeapPad2 with 10 extra sticker skins and matching pictures on the LeapPad itself.It is tempting to compare this with an iPad mini (7 inch) or any one of the many 5-inch Android tablets. For about seventy dollars you get a 4-AA tablet that has a 5 inch touch screen with 4GB of memory, and you even get front and back cameras, though the cameras are only of average quality. There is no wifi though, and so the cameras are really for recording only. You get extensions through buying more LeapPad games.As many reviewers have pointed out, the LeapPad games are a bit expensive though, and that is in comparison with iPad and Android apps. This complicates the equation, unfortunately. With LeapPad, you may pay less up front; but if you ever need to get more games, you can potentially make it into the iPad mini territory, and at that point you will notice that an iPad mini can do so much more than a LeapPad. Worse, some of the 5-inch Android tablets are not even that expensive---they are in the same range as the LeapPad itself. I think this is the point that what every reviewer must make.However, I would actually argue that LeapPad still makes a lot of sense. First, not having a wifi network is a plus to me. You do not need to worry about what can be done on it. Second, from what I understand, many of the LeapPad titles are LeapPad-exclusive and that alone makes the LeapPad worth considering. LeapPad has been in the market since 1999, and a lot of professional games have already been developed for it. Third, teach them as I may, kids sometimes throw things. In this department the LeapPad wins hands down compared to an iPad mini since it is much more affordable to replace. Unfortunately I have seen Android tablets that have similar weight to a LeapPad and so this argument is weak in that aspect.Overall, I think LeapPad still makes a lot of sense even in the current market. For its intended audience (3-9 years old), I think the availability of high-quality educational games cannot be overlooked. I give this a solid 5/5.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Rowenta DW9081 Steamium Steam Iron for review. I bought a DW9080 two years ago, and I guess that's why Amazon thinks I should review the DW9081. I use my DW9080 every weekend for the dress shirts and pants for work, and so I have very good experience with it. This past month, I have swapped in the DW9081. My focus is on whether there is any improvement in the DW9081 over the DW9080.I will give you the bottomline first: I cannot find any improvement, and at the current price that a DW9080 is selling for, I would totally recommend going with that model instead. (Of course, when you read this the DW9080 stock may have already been depleted.)I am a male office worker and not a sewer, and so my metric for an iron is how much time it takes me to get good results on my work clothes. I avoid starch as much as I can, and as a result I don't really dirt my soleplate much other than lint. I also only use the cotton setting exclusively even though the iron can do the entire range of temperature from nylon all the way up to linen.With that said, I am quite happy with the DW9081 (everything I said here applies to the DW9080). Before I switched to Rowenta I was using a T-Fal that has about 100 holes. The 400-hole feature is basically a gimmick. Honestly if they change it to 100-hole, I would not notice. You need to understand: a 4 times increase in the number of holes is just a 2 times in increase in density. And 100 holes are already aplenty for the steam to hit the shirt evenly, and 400 holes are just great (or an overkill, depending on your perspective).The soleplate is very smooth, and it has a nice tip that makes precision ironing possible.  I especially like the steam trigger on the index finger and that, I believe, is the most distinctive reason why you want a DW9081 over any other iron that does not have this trigger feature. The idea is you first use steam with the trigger to iron the fabric and create a crease, then you release the trigger and dry-iron the crease alone to lock it in. It works wonder once you master this technique.The iron heats up fast, and the water tank is large enough for me to go through all five sets of clothes each weekend. The anti-drip works ok, and I have yet to experience any dripping on my old DW9080, and thus I expect the same on the DW9081. I must mention that while this Rowenta takes tap water (no need to get distillated water), you should definitely empty the water tank after each use. At one point I was lazy and didn't do this, and rust water came out and ruined a shirt~~~ my bad. Fortunately, after using the self-cleaning feature a few times in a row, there is no more rust in my DW9080. And now that I am on the DW9081, I will take extra care to make sure rust does not develop on this one.Overall, I'd say that there is nothing to complain on the DW9081. If you are in the market for a good quality iron, you just cannot go wrong. Price is a bit on the high side (and thus my comment on the DW9080), but I tend to think that you do get what you paid for.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a uComfy Shiatsu Foot Massager for review. I am familiar with electric massagers for the back and neck, but this is the first time I try an electric foot massager. Essentially it provides two foot pockets that are surrounded by machine inflatable air pressure bags on the top and several sets of motorized, rotating “teeth” at the bottom. The machine periodically inflates and deflates the air pressure bags and change the direction of each set of teeth. This is how it massages your feet.The uComfy is a relatively big machine at about 14 inch long, 16 inch wide, and 9 inch tall. It comes with an external power supply like the ones you get from laptops. The two foot pockets are zip-detachable and can be washed for hygiene. There are five buttons on the top surface. From farthest to closest they are heat, vibration down, vibration up, kneading, and power. Right below the power button is a two digit LCD countdown counter (like the digits you see on calculators).The power button is easy to figure out. Once pressed, the machine turns on for 15 minutes with the counter showing the remaining minutes until the last minute at which point it shows the remaining seconds. The heat button toggles a rather mild heat generator. If the heat is on, yellow lamps inside the machine will turn on. I am not sure if there is a separate heat generator, or if the lamp is the heat source. In any case, since it is mid-winter as I am reviewing this, this feature is very welcomed and I can actually detect the difference it makes.The “vibration” buttons do not seem to control vibration. In fact, the machine hardly has any vibration at all. Instead, they control the air pressure, which defaults to level 3 at startup, and can be adjusted between 1 and 5. The machine does not have memory and you have to set the air pressure level every time if you do not like the default level.The kneading button is the almost mysterious. After a lot of experiments, I think there is a set of special “teeth” in the machine that are activated only when the kneading feature is on. (It is on by default.) This is most obvious if you set the air pressure level to 1.Overall, I find this foot massager to be quite comfortable and easy to use. I have been using it every night after bath. It does a reasonable job in hitting every spot on your footbed. I happen to have plantar fasciitis on my right foot, and on some nights it was actually a bit painful, but in a good way. So far it has not helped my situation though.Will I recommend it? Yes. It works as advertised so long as you know what the buttons are for. However, at the moment the asking price is quite high for what this machine does. Honestly, if it breaks down, I would not replace it at this level. I am still going to give it a 5/5 though. (I am tempted to take a star off due to the poor instructions, but really even at its default settings the machine is good enough to be recommendable.)

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Freshware 12-cup silicone muffin pan for review. As a silicone pan, this one is on the thin side: I cannot imagine moving this into a preheated oven when it is loaded with batter. To be sure, I have not seen any such silicone pan for muffins due the large amount of batter involved. However, I can still tell by feel alone that it is thinner than some of my other silicone pans, such as those from the W brand.The manufacturer lists “Heat Tunnel” as a patented design. Honestly, I am not so sure what this feature is since the manual that comes with the pan does not mention this. The only special thing I find is that this pan has a very slight dotted pattern on the bottom surface. Presumably the tunnels around the dots can allow hot air to circulate better. This is especially important for this muffin pan since, again, you need to support it below with a cookie sheet or a jellyroll pan.Of course, the most important metric of a baking pan is the quality of the baked goods. In this regard, this pan delivers: the muffins brown well, and the release is very easy. Unfortunately, even though it has the Heated Tunnel design, it does not seem to outperform my existing W silicone muffin pan. The muffins from either pan are very similar. Also, so far I have yet to find silicone pans better than my existing metal pans from W-S, and this one is also consistent with my experience: metal pans brown baked goods better, and is also very easy to release if used properly.Overall, I am still giving this a 5/5 since it has nothing to fault on as a silicone muffin pan. If you are in the market for one, I would say that Freshware has a pretty solid offering.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Philips Avent BPA-Free Natural Infant Starter Gift Set for review. This set contains three 4-oz bottles, two 9-oz bottles, a pacifier, a formula dispenser, and a bottle brush. Philips Avent is a major trusted brand in infant products, and upon opening the box I can see why: these are very high quality bottles. No rough edges from the plastic molding process, and the plastic is BPA-free. The distinguishing feature of this set over other sets from Philips is the formula dispenser, which is essentially a capped jar with three milk powder compartments. Honestly, it is not clear to me that the formula dispenser is really needed...  we just measure the milk powder and put a portion in each bottle. :) Therefore I think the buying decision should be on whether you need the microwave sterilizer or not. (Compared to Philips Avent BPA Free Natural Essentials Gift Set, this set has an extra 4-oz bottle, but one less pacifier.)Overall, this is a really great gift set for any new parents. I would not hesitate to buy it for any baby shower  list.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Philips Avent BPA-Free Natural Essentials Gift Set for review. This set contains a microwave sterilizer, two 4-oz bottles, two 9-oz bottles, two pacifiers, and a bottle brush. Philips Avent is a major trusted brand in infant products, and upon opening the box I can see why: these are very high quality bottles. No rough edges from the plastic molding process, and the plastic is BPA-free. This is a really great gift set for any new parents. The distinguishing feature of this set over other sets from Philips is the microwave sterilizer. There are pros and cons to this. Yes, you can use the sterilizer to avoid the dishwasher or the traditional method of boiling on the stove. In theory you can even use this during travel (think hotel room). In practice, however, notice that the sterilizer is not small and so bringing it on trips is a commitment (but worthy in my opinion). But if you do not plan to use it for traveling, then it is one extra item to take up space. Any new parents know about the explosion of infant-related items, and this is one item that you may be able to do without... :)

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Levana Oma+ Clip-On Portable Baby Movement Monitor for review. First of all, I think this should be clear: not every newborn needs to be monitored this intensively, but it certainly doesn't seem to hurt to do so. But if you know you need one for your baby, then be assured that this is a superb design.As a movement monitor, this device clips onto a diaper and senses breathing by proxy of abdominal movement. If there is no movement in 15 seconds, it vibrates a bit to nudge the baby to cause some movement in response. And if there is no movement in 20 seconds, it sounds an alarm. The alarm is loud enough to be heard in the next room, but I would not count on it on a different floor.The design is well thought out. It's wireless, so there is no cable to worry about tangling. The clip is secure. I would say that if you are in the case of needing a moment monitor, this is a very good choice.

Courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, I have received a Corsair Vengeance 2100 Wireless Dolby 7.1 Gaming Headset (V2100) for review. Prior to this, I have been using a Sound Blaster EVO Entertainment Headset with Bluetooth Mobile Wireless (EVO) as my gaming headset. In what follows, I will draw a few contrasts between these two headsets from the perspective of a Mac casual gamer (~1 hours a day).The V2100 is a 2.4GHz wireless circumaural headset with a pair of 50mm drivers. Inside the box is a USB wireless transceiver that must be used in order to use the headset. This is in stark contrast from the EVO, which can be used in USB, bluetooth, and also analog (3.5mm) mode. The selling point of the V2100 over EVO would be that it can do Dolby 7.1 wirelessly. Unfortunately, as Corsair made clear on the packaging and also on their website, Dolby 7.1 works only on Windows (version XP to 8)---there is no Mac driver yet. Therefore, for this review I have only been able to use the headset in stereo mode. It's a bit disappointing in this regard, and I can only hope that Corsair releases a Mac driver one day.Fortunately, the V2100 is already very impressive even as a stereo headset, thanks to its 50mm drivers. In terms of audio quality, the V2100 has a discernible advantage over the EVO, which is 40mm, but the improvement is moderate only (a typical diminish of return phenomenon in headsets past the 100 dollar mark). For gaming, both the EVO and the V2100 are more than adequate. Explosions have enough oomph, and dialogue is clear and separable from background music. But here is the bonus if you get the V2100: I am currently happily enjoying the V2100 as my primary wireless headset for music at home as well. Indeed I have been pleasantly surprised by the good overall sound quality of the V2100, given it is wireless. It gets close enough to my wired headphones in the two-hundred dollar range that I am willing to give up some quality for the sake of being wireless.Speaking of the wireless connection, it's very robust. I live in an apartment complex and there is a lot of wireless interference due to wifi and whatnot. Corsair quoted 40 feet in range, and I can confirm that it does work for me. For gaming applications, this range should be very adequate. Corsair also included an 5-feet USB extension cable in case you use the V2100 on a desktop so that you can improve reception by better antenna placement, and an 5-feet micro-USB cable for charging. (Yes, the headset can be used while charging.)Playback is only half of the story for a gaming headset. The other half is recording. In this area, the V2100 is also very competitive. On the left ear cup is a broom with a unidirectional noise-canceling microphone. In actual gameplay and also Skype, my friends all reported very good recording quality. The broom also has a trick: it has a mechanical mute trigger. Push the broom up (retract towards the headset) and the recording stops; pull it back down and the recording resumes. I cannot overstate how convenient this is.Battery life is quoted at 10 hours, and in my experience it is accurate. With the very first charging I logged at least 8 hours of gameplay. Charging is also very fast. 2-3 hours was all I need on a 2.1 amp charger (the ones we use for iPads; if you use smaller-amp chargers the time will rise).If I really have to pick on the V2100, it would be heat. Being circumaural means each ear cup surrounds the ear completely. Depending on your personal taste, it can get uncomfortably hot---especially when you are already all psyched up due to gameplay. I must stress that, however, this is to be expected. There is no easy fix. Having said that, I should remark that the V2100 is very comfortable in other areas: the ear cups are well cushioned, as is the head band. It's not obvious in the pictures, but the cups can rotate in the vertical axis and therefore you can be sure of getting an even pressure (if it does not rotate, then the pressure to the front and to the back of the ear can be different and this can cause discomfort).Another aspect that I wish Corsair would improve on is the volume control, which is a scroll wheel on the left ear cup. That wheel just lacks precision on Mac---it seems impossible to use the wheel to adjust the volume by one notch (one unit of volume with respect to F11 and F12, the standard Mac volume key).Overall, I am very impressed with the V2100. Yes, I know what some people may think since I have received it for free. But no, it is something that I will replace with my own money if I happen to lose it and I will definitely pick it over the EVO. Plus, the fact that I put in the effort to write a long review (when a shorter one would suffice). I really believe that the price/performance ratio the V2100 is high enough to warrant a 5-star review.

I have shoulder pain due to overuse early on in my life, and on some days it is bad enough that I have to take a pain killer. I happened to have other issues that prevent me from taking most of the NSAIDs, and so acetaminophen has been my go-to pill before I see this on the Amazon Vine program (which, for full disclosure, sent me the bottle to review). On average, I need acetaminophen 7 to 10 days a month.I am glad that I learned about this Curcumin Phytosome supplement on Vine. In my actual use, I feel that taking one pill after dinner is an almost sure way to eliminate any pain the next morning. Since I have started the routine a month ago, I have only needed to use acetaminophen twice.So why do I say it's almost as effective as acetaminophen only? Well, it just doesn't last as long because in my experience I have to take it the night before and by late afternoon I can feel my shoulder pain. Unfortunately, if I take the pill at breakfast, it won't kick in until later in the afternoon. This is in contrast with acetaminophen, which takes about 30 minutes so I am all ready when I get to office. This is why I actually take one pill at dinner and one pill at breakfast. (60 pills = 1 bottle = 1 month for me). At present, this seems to be working really well.Upon researching it on the internet, I learned that curcumin phytosome is a form of turmeric that is more readily absorbed by our body (this is called “bioavailability”). In fact there is a patent pending on it, which is why even though the bottle is branded and distributed as Jarrows Formulas, you still see the Meriva label on it. This is critical when you shop around because you know that every vendor who uses Meriva's compound gives you effectively the same thing.

This is a collection of a bunch of uncensored grindhouse trailers from the '70s and early '80s, and they're great. Many forgotten gems, the full versions of which don't exist on DVD anywhere, and the transfers really are quite good. Plenty of nudity on display. Really a lot of fun, as long as you understand what you're getting into ahead of time and can appreciate it for what it is.Host Nikki Leigh (apparently a Playboy Playmate) is present but doesn't take too much screen time or talk so much that it becomes annoying. And of course she spends the entirety in her underwear, which is a plus. It would have been a bigger plus had she taken them off.The only negative that I could see is that some of the trailers already are out there on other collections.

It's a classic, and this Blu-ray version looks phenomenal, but just on its own merits it probably would earn three stars. It's a little unevenly paced and slow-starting. Director indicated that he cut out all of the full-frontal nudity and I think that that was a mistake for a movie called "Frankenhooker."It does have its moments. The (spoiler alert) exploding hookers, and mutant creatures made out of odds-and-ends body parts, are funny in their absurdity. Patty Mullen is amazing in her role as the female lead, especially considering that she had so little acting experience. And there are a few hot women here who show a little skin.What elevates this to four stars are the aforementioned beautiful transfer, the impressive DVD authoring and the several extras: a few behind-the-scenes featurettes and a director's commentary. (The SFX designer also is on the commentary track, but in name only since director Frank Henenlotter insisted on shouting over him for the duration.)If you're a fan of these old B movies from the late '80s and early '90s, you really can't go wrong with buying this one.

It's really hard to know how to rate Bill Zebub's stuff that I've seen, which admittedly hasn't been too much. But this one is really tough.Firstly, this is two full-length features, one "Science-Less Fiction" and the other "Indie Director." Most of the same cast members are in both.Young fanboys who think that they're edgy will watch "Science-Less Fiction" for the absurd level of racist shock value. Zebub tries to act like all of this was very self-aware and tongue-in-cheek, but I'm not so sure--it seems to come with far too much ease. I'm a white guy and definitely no screaming liberal idiot, but a lot of the dialogue was tough for me to stomach. Most of the production values are pretty terrible and overall, the movie doesn't make a lot of sense. Something about racist aliens dressed as clowns invading the Earth?? He's trying to make some political statements here but I had trouble cutting through the insanity to figure out what all of them are. So, points off for all of this.The other merits of Zebub's films though are near-constant gratuitous nudity of his (mostly) very attractive female starlets. His women almost always are all-natural, too, which is a huge plus in my book. There are three here who are pretty scorching hot and aren't afraid to be exploited a bit because of it. On these merits, this movie is pretty great.Zebub also is pretty faithful about providing behind-the-scenes material, so there's a featurette included with cast interviews and that's interesting. Plus for this.The included second feature "Indie Director" actually is better than the main feature, I think. It has all of the requisite nudity (with some incredibly hot women), but the humor--most of it from Zebub as an actor, a lot of it ad-libbed--hits far more often than it misses, unlike "Science-Less Fiction." It's about a director's trials and tribulations as he attempts to get movies produced and distributed. Overall I actually found it to be lighthearted and fun. It is loaded down with exposition, though, so the average viewer probably won't enjoy it so much. Just look for the naked women and it will be worth it.

I've seen many, many bad movies in my life, but it's not mere hype to say that this is, indeed, the worst movie that I've ever seen--minus the one and ONLY one redeeming factor, and that's the female nudity (which is abundant). The only thing about it is that most of the girls appear to have been hired out of your local trailer park. In other words they aren't too attractive...and God knows that they can't act. But then again, neither can anybody else in this ridiculous thing.Of course it's not as if they had anything to work with in the script. The writing actually is worse than the acting. The line "Thanks for the crystal meth!" occurs MORE THAN ONCE in the film. And the "plot" sort of meanders around; something about vampires and drugs. To be honest I'm not sure exactly how the movie ended because I watched the last 30 minutes at 32x speed, but it's not nearly as bloody as the title suggests.But even worse than the acting OR the writing are the production values and editing. Holy moley. I've seen cheaply-made movies before but this one pretty clearly was shot on a consumer-grade videocamera, with all of the audio from the on-board mic, and maybe one keylight. Then they edited the thing together in an afternoon and didn't pay close attention to silly little things like logic.How this ever made it all the way to mass distribution, I will never know.

Mostly cute and fun, but in parts annoying. Totally agree with another reviewer who says that John Cross doesn't ever shut up and thinks that he's hilarious--he tends to be the worst thing about his own productions. Raw explicit nudity abounds and most of the women (Berlin, Jenaveve Jolie, the incomparable Jamie Lynn and to a lesser extent Penny Flame and Zoe Britton) are hot. I kind of like how it was set up as a kind of TV show rather than the old Hot Body "contest" formula--this is one of the newest Hot Body DVD productions even though it is from 2004.Overall a very nice pickup.
These are great and exactly what I needed...except that I got only five and not six. I saw at least one other reviewer who did not receive six, so quality-control might be a problem here.
