I received the watch 1 week ago: Amazon's packaging was very professional. The Tag box is as handsome as the watch. Everything included was high quality.The watch is exactly what I wanted and is described well in pictures and features table..The watch is relatively thin at 10mm compared to other watches with more features that are 13mm to 15mm thick. The diameter at 39mm is a good fit for most wrists as it does not appear large or oversized in any way.Rubber wrist band is very good quality. Forms readily to my wrist. The band does require trimming to your size. There are no instructions in the manual, but it is not difficult to figure out.Sapphire crystal is very hard. Very difficult to scratch. According to Wikipedia the only thing that can scratch it is a diamond.The watch does have some weight to it, but the rubber band distributes the weight well. As I move my arm during the day, the watch stays upright at the top of my wrist even though I still have the band a little loose.Trimming the band: you have to cut the band to size. The backside of the band has grooves. The spacing of the grooves are relatively small and you should cut along a groove. Be careful when you get close to your size because one grove makes a surprising difference. The upside is the watch band will fit perfectly.The overall look of the watch is very handsome. I does not look flashy at all.Beautifully crafted watch at a very good price. Would not hesitate to buy it or another expensive watch from Amazon again.Note:Ships from and sold by Amazon.com6 week update: The watch is very accurate. It has kept time to 1 second compared with 2 radio updated clocks. It has become even more comfortable as the rubber wrist band forms to your wrist(takes only a few days). At 6weeks now, the longer I have this watch the more I like it. It is very high quality, excellent workmanship. Absolutely no buyer's remorse. ha ha9 month update 11-25-12 watch keeps time perfectly. High quality piece. Love it.

I was pleasantly surprised at the overall good quality of everything in this package.a)The drive enclosure is well made and fits the 2.5" (laptop) drive perfectly. Power switch is a good feature, so you can turn off power before moving/disconecting drive.b) Includes screws and screwdriver to attach to drive to holder.c) Well made USB cable. Requires to 2 USB ports. The 2nd port is for extra power. One of the USB plugs has a pass through so you only need one open port on your pc.d) Comes with a very nice padded case for drive holder only. Would have been nice to add a place for the cables as well. The case has a magnetic closure. Magnets will erase  magnetic media like harddrives but probably is ok since the case covers are metal(steel) which will shield the drive. The magnet is not powerful either.e) The product box is very good quality and is great for storing drive and cables between uses. Everything fits inside easilyf) Using the drive the 1st time was easy. Windows 7 recognized the drive and installed drivers automatically.g) The case becomes warm after backing up entire system (30min). About 30min to backup 40gig.. Not bad for USB 2.0. Back up did not slow down my system at all, so I could continue my work.h)Includes mini CD with instructions and drivers for older versions of windows and Mac's.There are other drive holders on Amazon for about $8 on up. I paid extra thinking overall quality would be better. Regular price on this is $17.99 free shipping with Amazon prime.Very happy with this purchase. Thank you to all of the other reviewers who help me make a good decision.Note:Sold by LLYtech and Fulfilled by Amazon

I tried Tufoil many years ago after reading about it in popular mechanics. Then, my Nissan pick-up was making loud valve tappet rattling noise ONLY in the morning for a few seconds. I put some tufoil in it and by the 3rd day the morning rattling was gone. Never came back.Next vehicle was a Toyota pick-up turbo 5 spd manual... The 1st gear was very tight. Many times at a stop light I had to put it in reverse to roll it slightly to get it into 1st gear. I knew Tufoil would help but it was a pain to get to the manual transmission oil filler hole, but I eventually did it. It took about a month to see some improvemnet, but it did gradually get better until it was very easy shifting.I have put this in new cars after the break-in and ran them years until I sold them private party. Always got top dollar partly because the engine sounded so good. I am still using it.I just bought an Infinity G25 and added it after the break-in was complete (6,000 miles) I put in my lawn mower and air compressor. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. (Note: I am an Electronic engineer not easily sold on this kind of thing)

This is a GREAT funnel for what it is desinged to do. ADD FUEL ADDITIVES to your gas tank. No drips or spills on the side of your car. (LOOK at the picture) For other applications, maybe a larger or different style funnel is better. Price SHIPPED TO YOUR DOOR tax free is VERY GOOD. ($3.36)(The list price $23.88 probably should be $3.88) :)I like it and would buy it again.

I've been shopping for a fire (security) safe for months now and until now couldn't find one that had relatively good reviews and at a reasonably price.We've all read the other reviews and I agree and confirm most everything. It arrived in perfect condition by UPS. Paint finish is quite good and has a thin oily residue. The interior was clean, and the caulking around plastic interior and steel case was applied well. The shelf is thin and sags readily with any weight (My documents will be on this shelf.) The plastic combo dial works well and has loud clicks. Numbers are easy to see in low light. The key lock is nice for extra security should someone learn your combo. Exterior hinge? Not the best idea. The door inside has a pocket that fits a small frame pistol such as a 380.To in icrease weight: On the bottom of the safe I put about 20 boxes of 40cal ammo. In addition I will keep 5 handguns and some valuables. This adds at least 50lbs+. Now it's VERY difficult to move.I have no illusions that these safes will protect valuables from a determined thief. Safes actually would be one of the first things a thief would want because valuables are normally concentrated there. My safe will be a DECOY and have documents, passports and a few handguns. Other valuables (emergency cash, gold, expensive coins) will be stashed elsewhere inconspicuously out of sight.Hope this helps you.Note: Once the safe is opened it can be locked and unlocked with the key only as long as the combo dial isn't turned. You need to turn the combo dial to relock it completely.Note 2-27-13 (1 year): I use Eva-dry Renewable E-333 Wireless Mini Dehumidifer to keep the safe dry for a year now. The safe must be reasonably well sealed, One of these keeps my save very dry at < 40% relative humudity.I am quite happy with the purchase. Thanks to all of you that reviewed this and other safes.Note:Ships from and sold by Amazon.com

This shirt is made from lightweight quality material perfect for warm to hot weather. Construction quality and detail is excellent. The fit is just a little large, but just enough for breathing room when it's hot outside. I now both have gray and navy. Both good colors. Fine (small)wrinkles out of the dryer, but if you fold it carefully the wrinkles are gone the next day.Great shirt for the price ~$15

Great shirt for cool weather, Not thick but still warm. Soft inside and out. Comes out of the dryer wrinkle free. Well made with quality material. I have the navy and love it. Wish they had the colors heather and gray also. Good value for the price.

This hoodie is well made with quality material. It is surprisingly warm to. The inside is very soft. The metal zipper used to stick but I found small black threads where it was stcking. After removing the threads no more sticking. (the thread are very hard to see, so I can understand how they were missed during manufacturing. I've washed it several times now and comes out of the dryer wrinkle free. Little or no fading yet.

I really like this knife! Cost me almost 70 bucks from Amazon. It feels like a big steak knife more than an outdoor knife... this isn't necessarily bad though. It is the small brother of the Camp Knife. It comes with an extra set of coyote brown scales and a very nice desert colored cordura sheath. The first thing that strikes me is the light feel and smallish size. Speced at .4lbs including the sheath I believe. The blade is thinner than the .165" thick handle tang and has a thin tapering flat grind which is clipped almost the full length of the blade. Thumb jimping was placed in the perfect spot for my hand. After removing the scales I found 2 large cutouts between the bolt holes. Seems like this was needed for balance and weight reduction which is good but I don't classify this as full tang as the advertising states. It's a great medium/light duty outdoor knife. The blade, especially the thin tip has a delicate feel to it.The handle scales were very smartly designed and feel excellent in every hand hold position including being choked up on the choil. They are not totally slick and provide okay grip IMHO.  The brown scales really make this knife pop! Very handsome. The edge came crazy sharp out of the box... be careful! The grind is perfectly done also. No flaws. The blade coating is nicely done and should hold up as good as any. The sheath is well made with lots of extras including mounting options. There are lots of straps, loops, snaps and even eyelets for leg tie or a handle retention cord. The velcro pouch is noisy but very effective.The BK 15 makes a great camp knife and could handle light fire making and bushcraft tasks but you need to be mindful of the laws of physics when putting this thin blade to task. Recommended!I will update after a few more months of use.Update: 30 May 2013After typical use (no abuse) as a camp/outdoor knife I still like it. The look, feel, comfort and cutting ability are all above average. Love using it choked up on the choil. It is not as efficient shaving and feathersticking as a pure scandi grind but is excellent for a flat ground blade. The coating holds up very well but you can feel the resistance when cutting chunks of wood bigger than shavings. After some use the coating does begin to smooth out a bit. I only batoned small pieces of wood... nothing bigger than 2". It chops small jobs just fine... the sharp holding edge is to thank for this as the knife is very light. No rust even after a rainy overnighter. Still recommended!Please comment and join the great discussions concerning this knife!

Who would've thunk that a dishwasher utensil basket could change your life. For years I struggled to keep the old Maytag basket together with tie straps and wire but my fork kept finding its way through the bottom no matter what I did. Having to fish it out of the bottom of the machine frightened my fork and hurt my back. Maytag would gladly sell me a replacement but I felt getting a loan for this item would be silly... very expensive for another piece of junk. So, as usual, I turned to Amazon for help and they delivered... literally!This basket fits anywhere because it splits in half and can be hung on any available rail. I keep one half by the sink to load dirty silverware while my clean stuff waits for my selection from inside the washer. It seems durable and well made. Both halves have simple, sturdy covers that remove easily and the inside dividers are flow through for improved washing/scrubbing action. What a great idea at a great price! Now my fork rests comfortably and securely in place while being showered with warm, lathery water then awaits my return to select it once again.Recommended!!

For the money I like this knife. It seems that Taylor Brands has made some changes in the steel they use and sheath design. This particular knife used to be 440c and now it is shown to be 7Cr17 according to S&W catalogs. 7Cr17 is a Chinese 440a. My knife has no steel designation on it but has some 440c characteristics. Since it has the new style sheath it must be the 440a which is fine with me. The older sheath was heavier because of a larger hard plastic insert, metal fasteners and D ring. The newer sheath is much lighter but comes with a better pouch and molle system. I have several S&W knives with both sheath designs and I like them both for different applications. I was hoping to receive the old style with this knife.The knife and sheath arrived new and in serviceable condition. It has a sturdy feel due to the full length tang and well attached butt cap, handle and guard... nothing is loose. I do want to note that the guard is not fastened to the tang in any way but held tight by the pressure of the handle pushing it against the blade. The aluminum butt cap is firmly attached to the tang by an aluminum pin which holds it all together. The rat tang is cut at a 90 degree angle where it goes through the guard. You begin to get the picture here. This is a solid knife but if abused too much the tang can snap off at the guard... this is the weakest point.The tanto blade is a strong design with plenty of steel at the tip. There is a slight swedge at the front end of the spine but not enough to make it delicate. The grind starts at just over 50% of the width of the blade which adds to the edge strength and gives you a nice strong flat at the spine which is ideal if you need to fasten it to your bench sharpener. The grind is flat with a secondary bevel of about 25 degrees (could be more) at the cutting edge... strong, strong edge! It came utility sharp and responded well to my Lansky ceramic rod for a smooth paper cutting edge... no problem here. The sandpaper like blade coating sticks well but will wear with use. Stainless doesn't usually need to be coated but the extra protection doesn't hurt. Some question this but the main reason for the coating is to be in sync with the tactical design. The coating can be removed easily with any number of products from your hardware store.This knife was designed for tactical purposes and is a copy cat of many other famous fighting knives. If carried for this reason and medium utility use, it should last a lifetime. Some like to use it for outdoor/bushcraft activities and will chop with or baton this knife... take caution and remember the weak spot I mentioned earlier!! I would recommend light batoning and chopping only... use common sense here! You can not overcome the law of physics! I would not hammer nails or anything very hard with the aluminum butt cap/pommel. Tent pegs... yes. Why? Well, it's aluminum. You see, the purpose of this pommel design is for tactical grip. Something to keep your hand from slipping off the end when pulling the knife out of what ever you stuck it in... tanto points are made for stabbing/penetrating. The pommel can also be used as a nonlethal striker. The handle is grippy and simply designed to accommodate different tactical grips such as the reverse grip. If you have large hands you may find the grip a bit small though. There is a decent sized unsharpened part of the knife after the guard (ricasso) that you can choke up on for utility use. You will have to reach your thumb over or around the guard to rest it on the blade spine. The upper guard could be ground off to make this grip easier.The new style sheath holds the knife fine enough and has a velcro belt loop system so you don't have to remove your belt. They added a small diamond sharpener in the pouch... it works. Here is a tip if your guard or butt cap ever loosen up over time. Take some 6 pound mono-filament, color of your choice, and wedge it in between guard and rubber handle and start wrapping until tight then tie ends together. Seal the gap with black nail polish or anything else black that will do the job... be creative. I have done this to many knives... problem solved! Good luck and enjoy!

I picked this up from Amazon when it was down to 34 bucks. Then I watched it go down to about 28 bucks... a steal in this price range. 50 bucks may be a bit much for this selection though. Anyway, I like what I got! I've had it for a few months and have been batoning wood for the fire. It has held up like a champ. The hard zytel handles did loosen up from the impacts and I had to apply Loctite... problem solved. Grip is fairly comfy but I think I would have preferred a softer Kraton or hard rubber. I did slip a ranger band over the handle grips which solved this problem. Oh, the steel is one solid piece when the scales are removed... a true full tang! The 1070 steel came crazy sharp and will dull after a while but touch up is a snap with a ceramic rod. The blade coating is extremely durable and without a scratch after propelling it through hardwood logs 40-50 times or so, including knots... impressive! While stuck in the knots I could see a bend in the blade but it always came out unscathed. This is a tough knife but not a behemoth so proper caution is needed during hard use... any knife can break when taken past its limits. Don't worry, mine is still intact and I didn't mind testing it for you! The Full flat grind is very nice but is a bit thin towards the edge so it should be handled accordingly.The sheath is fine and holds the knife. It's typical light weight nylon with plastic insert. The survival gadgets are better than nothing and work okay. Not high quality of course but nice for the money. In all this is an acceptable knife and with proper use and care should last a lifetime or more. Recommended!Update 13 March 2014:No problems with this knife after much hard use. I like it so much I ordered another one!

Not only does this machine effortlessly clean my teeth but the invigorating vibrations are at the perfect frequency to jump start my brain in the morning. This thing is a masseuse for the mouth... amazing. I've tried many expensive teeth cleaners over the years and this beats them all, hands down. $5 each and one simple AAA battery - are you kidding me! No more shelling out big bucks for gizmos that don't work and charge $15 for a new brush head! This is the tool we've all been waiting for. From the bottom of my heart, thank you Colgate! FINALLY, all is right in the world of teeth cleaning!And by the way - when the bristles are tired and you need a new one, don't throw the old one away. Put it to work cleaning the household nooks and crannies or put it in the tool box for other odd cleaning jobs. It's the gift that keeps on giving!

The knife is 5.75" in total length, 2.5" blade, 2.25" cutting edge. Other than the extra inch being advertised here it is a fine three finger knife! The build quality is excellent and came razor sharp. The G10 scales and white liners look very nice. This full tang knife is 1/8" thick and comes with a big lanyard hole. The sheath is okay... nothing special but it does the job. Looks much better than the price may indicate. I would recommend it!

I really like this knife. It looks like something my grandpa used to pull out of his pocket 40 years ago. Simple, nostalgic and useful. The quality is very good. The blade fits tight between the brass liners and opens and closes with a snap... no blade play. The grind is fine and it came utility sharp. The celluloid handle material was first developed in the mid 1800's if you can believe that. It's a softer, flammable plastic material that replaced the use of real ivory and was used to make hair clips, buttons, pens, dolls and of course... knife handles. The softer plastic provides better grip than the newer thermoplastics which is a plus for me. I love the yellow color. This sturdy pocket knife should last a lifetime. I guess grandpa knew a thing or two! If you're old like me you'll know what I'm talking about.Why spend 500% more for other similar name brands when this will do the job just fine. I'm gonna get some more!

Hi, I'm Paul and I'm a knife addict. Sometimes I find myself walking the cold, dark streets trying to score a cheap piece of steel but no more. Now Amazon is my supplier and they deliver! For free! All kidding aside this knife rocks  better than grandma's chair! It's comfortable in the hand, flys opens with a slight flick of the thumb stud, locks up solid, came razor sharp, has no blade play, is perfectly centered when closed and blade retention is solid... no accidental openings here! It seems to be a 420HC steel and takes a wicked edge very easily when needed. The liner lock works perfectly and the pocket clip does its job. Rubber scale insert and thumb jimping provide nice grip. Blade coating is durable. Great beater or starter knife for anyone! Very high value.  This is a no brainer. Watchya waitin' fur... getya one!

Just received the cara cara 2 today and I'm "eggstatic" about it! I haven't used it yet but after a byrds eye view I feel like the rooster that got in the hen house. Got it on sale for 15 bucks free delivery... just can't beat it at that price. Not downy comfy soft in the hand but don't tar and feather Spyderco for that. I mean come on... you get a FFG blade, bronze washers and 4 position pocket clip for such a low price. The bi-directional FRN scales supply an eagle claw like grip and thumb jimping transforms your hand into a talon. The action is easy and as smooth as the inside of an eggshell. Lock up is good. Blade retention when nested is very secure. Anyone can proudly strut their tail feathers over this one because it will certainly impress any chick.  Don't get plucked by another brand. Why not spread your wings with this high flyer. Did I mention that this knife is as light as a... okay, you know what I'm gonna say here. So why get your wings clipped by another brand when "The Byrd is the Word"! Don't forget to tweet your friends about it! I'll update this review after I've had it outside the nest for a while and share it with the flock.Update 1 Feb 2013: I like this knife more now than when I first got it. This blade is large, lightweight and maintains a solid feel. After use I just stroke a few times on my Lansky ceramic rod which brings it right back to factory sharpness. Love the forward choil to choke up on for fine work. At first I didn't like the look of the comet shaped thumb hole but it works great and I don't think about it anymore. Still no blade play and I love the loud snap when the lock back engages after opening. I keep it clean so staining/corrosion has not been a problem. It truly is the Wind Beneath my Wings!

I'm very impressed with this knife. Beautiful, elegant and fluid lines. Very easy and quick in and out of the pocket. Jimped Flipper deploys the blade effortlessly without flicking the wrist and locks up solid. The blade rides between a bronze and nylon washer with two ball bearings to provide a smooth pivot. Good retention when closed. Came very sharp, comfortable in the hand and not too heavy but still feels sturdy. The blue steel pocket clip and skeletonized liners are very attractive. The black and blue micarta is good looking and although the finish is smooth it still provides some grip... good enough for emergency tactical use along with the guard provided by the flipper. Another 1/4" of jimping further up the blade would add to the grip. The pocket clip is perfect and holds well without tearing your pants apart. A real winner from Mr. McGinnis... Great Design!

3:23 MinsThis little gem is a great utility knife that can skin, bushcraft and campcraft. The hollow grind, drop point blade is 3.5" long with a 3.25" cutting edge. ** WARNING ** It came razor sharp out of the box! The plastic handle has rubber inlays which makes it extremely grippy and comfy.But the real cool feature is the one handed release, roller locking plastic sheath. The spring mounted roller rides up the ricasso and locks into the finger grove when fully inserted. It will not accidentally come out! A push on the edge of the sheath with your thumb pops it loose with just one hand.The sheath has a nice horizontal drain hole which can accommodate a lanyard for a neck knife hang. One handed release also allows for belt, pack or boot mount.The knife and sheath weigh next to nothing and the cost isn't far behind. I highly recommend this knife!

Got this on sale for 8 bucks and am very pleased. The rubber handle is the first thing you notice after removing it from the nifty box... this thing is grippy, grippy, grippy and very comfy. Mine is colored a deep forest green and looks nice. Lanyard hole with brass liner included! It is very light certainly not much more than 5 ounces.The steel is advertised as 400 series and seems to be some type of 440, could be A, B or C but I haven't done the research yet. The blade is an upswept drop point with a nice flat spine that maintains it's thickness almost to the point. The grain is very fine and almost looks like another stainless I have with vanadium in it. **WARNING** the edge is danger sharp and cuts paper with ease right out of the box! The grind is a slightly hollow half grind with a slight secondary bevel... great for skinning, fish cleaning and bushcraft. It's 1/8" thick (thicker than a standard Mora) so it takes an easy edge but thick enough for moderate tough duty. The blade is 4.25" long with a 3.75" cutting edge and 1.2" wide. The handle is 4.75" long for a 9" total length not 9.5" as advertised here. It has a thumb depression instead of jimping which is fine and you can choke up on the ricasso by placing your index finger forward of the handle. My magnet sticks to the handle all the way around so it's a full length tang... even past the lanyard hole.I think the sheath is fine. The braided nylon has a cool look to it and is well stitched. It has a solid plastic insert that extends to the bottom with drain holes. The brass insert at the bottom is secure and could be hung as a neck knife... the knife will not fall out after the brass snap is secured. The best feature is that the knife can be inserted either way so if you're a lefty this set up will work for you!Hey, this is a smart buy for the budget minded who need a versatile knife... I recommend it!

This is a nifty little tool with excellent size and weight. Not a heavy, hard use item like the larger, more expensive popular brand of multitools but certainly comparable to some of the basic swiss selections. Complete with grippy scales and orange accents like the rest of the BG line up. It rides comfortably in any pocket and the blade and tools open and close easily while maintaining a solid feel. The knife came paper cutting sharp right out of the package! I can't see how the blade can possibly catch on the liner as another reviewer mentioned... it's just not possible unless the tool has been damaged in some way. The liner is completely covered and inside the grip on my tool. This sturdy pocket tool is a great value at 10 bucks and comes with the obligatory survival guide. Another good selection from Gerber and BG.Update 11 Aug 2012:This tool is still solid even after some hard use. Everything stays tight even after loosening some stuck screws. The blade is easy to maintain and takes a razor edge. I find myself using it more than my slick plastic handled swiss tool as the grips on this knife make it more comfortable and sure. Others have complained that the tools are hard to open... they are tougher to get out than a swiss tool but it's really not that difficult. I have noticed that it gets easier the more I use it. Not sure if this is due to breaking it in or just getting used to it... but it does get easier! The best part is, once open, it is very very sturdy. This is what I want in a tool. Well worth the money!

WOW! What a little powerhouse. Finally a light that comes on the low setting before high. Here's how it works: The first full switch depression is low, the next full depression is off, the next is high and then off again. A few seconds after the light is off it always comes on in the low mode. The neat thing is that once it is on you can switch back and forth from high to low with only a half switch depression... this is really cool. Unfortunately you can't turn the light on with a half depression when it is off... you know, like a tactical momentary switch.The build quality is impeccable along with the pocket clip, key chain ring and lanyard. The housing is solid and feels like a fine instrument of light. The spot is nice and white with good, even spill light. No dark spots or goofy looking rings with this tool. I found it at a local discount store for 13 bucks... I thought that was a steal. Highly recommended!

The LED flashlight is very bright and of surprising quality. Nice even spot with good spill light and no dark spots or rings. Even if the light craps out it's still not a bad deal for 24 AA alkalines. Got mine from a local discount store for 10 bucks.

The LED flashlight is very bright and of surprising quality. Nice even spot with good spill light and no dark spots or rings. Even if the light craps out it's still not a bad deal for 24 AA alkalines. Got mine from a local discount store for 10 bucks.

You can save some weight with the plastic shovels but there is something to be said about steel. When it comes to clearing roots and rocks at your camp site this little gem can help. You can put an edge on one side and rid your tent spot of those nagging tree roots that will keep you awake all night. The fact that it folds and can slip into your back pocket is kinda neat and convenient. I got mine at walmart for 4 bucks. Highly recommended!

Great Buy! I use this mug for backpacking with my alcahol stove, its large size makes it ideal for  making hot drinks or backpacking meals! A perfect product! Although I did buy mine at my local grocery store for just $2.59 in the mexican food section.

4:33 MinsThis is the Best of the BG offerings. Most retailers sell it for 30 bucks which is a bit much but when I found it on sale for 19 bucks my cat like reflexes took over. This knife is no toy. Its very sturdy with no blade play and has a good solid feel... I was pleasantly surprised with how tuff this thing realy is. It will make a great back up to your fixed blade survival selection. The handle is fantastic and very grippy even when wet. The rubberized grip absorbs impact and sticks to your hand. It fits VERY nicely in the hand and feels like an extension of it. With a dual thumb stud it opens easily, locks into place with a confident "SNAP" of the lock back and securely closes for safety. You will not feel "under knifed" with this thing.The thick but not too heavy high carbon steel blade is half serrated and comes very sharp. Love Gerbers serrations... great for cutting rope, cordage and strapping. Lots of so called knife experts reject Gerber's steel but I find it tough, dependable and easy to sharpen. The serrations cut paper better than the straight edge portion... they are danger sharp!I like the orange accents on this type of knife... makes it easier to find in a hurry which makes sense since that's what it's for. The nylon sheath is excellent. Don't forget to melt any frayed ends with your lighter... this will help it to last longer and look great. Even comes with survival instructions that seem to be printed on moisture resistant paper. A fine knife... good job Bear and Gerber.

3:23 MinsThis little gem is a great utility knife that can skin, bushcraft and campcraft. The hollow grind, drop point blade is 3.5" long with a 3.25" cutting edge. ** WARNING ** It came razor sharp out of the box! The plastic handle has rubber inlays which makes it extremely grippy and comfy.But the real cool feature is the one handed release, roller locking plastic sheath. The spring mounted roller rides up the ricasso and locks into the finger grove when fully inserted. It will not accidentally come out! A push on the edge of the sheath with your thumb pops it loose with just one hand.The sheath has a nice horizontal drain hole which can accommodate a lanyard for a neck knife hang. One handed release also allows for belt, pack or boot mount.The knife and sheath weigh next to nothing and the cost isn't far behind. I highly recommend this knife!

Got this light last week and I like it so far. It winds easily and makes a cool whirling noise to keep the bears away while hiking in the mountains!I know the first review wasn't favorable but here's the trick to these self powered lights. These small rechargeable batteries are designed to keep a charge on them. If you buy one that's been on the shelf for a long while without being charged the batteries can loose their capacity to hold a charge. They are charged from the factory so the best time to purchase them is after a power outage when the stores have replenished the shelves... you will have a better chance of getting a "factory fresh" unit. Not foolproof but the odds of getting a longer lasting light are better. Don't buy them from the clearance rack! I've seen several youtube reviewers complaining of this also. Once you do buy the light be sure to crank it for a few minutes each month and never shelf it dead. Keeping it charged will extend the capacity of the batteries for a much longer time. Don't overcharge though, lithium Ion batteries could be damaged.Now back to the Light. It has 3 modes... off, on and flash. When on, the 3 main white LED's throw light ahead. Press the switch again and the 3 white LED's along with the 2 red lensed side markers flash. This is great for signaling. The rated 7.7 lumens won't blind anyone but it's enough light in an emergency. It has a 2032, 35mAh battery and one minute of winding is supposed to power the 3 LED's for 15 minutes. This info is from the Dorcy website which differs here. I wound it for about 5 minutes and it lasted for about an hour initially. This time should actually increase as the batteries are exercised more. The rubber knob on the sturdy crank handle locks into the light body and a lanyard can be attached to hang it. The shape of the light, crome crest above the lense and hazard type marker surrounding the switch gives it a weird retro look but that's okay. The yellow color makes sense and the ruber side grips work great.I hope this review helps everyone. Happy Lighting!Update 10/23/11:The light no longer works. Press the switch and the LED'S blink crazy and won't stay on! I took it back to the store for a refund. Gotta keep it honest!

Should be called "The Forever Light" because that's how long the batteries last. I've used this flashlight around the house for about 2 years and it is as bright as day 1 using the original carbon zincs, not alkalines. Now, it's not the brightest flashlight in the world but it throws a sufficient beam to light your home, path or trail. The 3 LED's are low power and sip amperage from the 6 AA's keeping the heat down and preserving battery life. The beam has a moderately clean spot with plenty of spill light to brighten any room. It only opens at the head to replace the batteries and is sealed with an o-ring for water resistance... this is good. I love the gel grips. They feel great and mine have stayed clean and serviceable without peeling off. It has been very durable and if it ever gives up the ghost I wouldn't hesitate to buy it again! I recommend it. Oh yeah... got mine at walmart for 8 bucks.Update Feb 2013:Yup... after more than 3 years on the same batts still bright as day 1 !!

Nothing fancy here but certainly has its place among other sharpeners. The ceramic seems to be a fine grain and enough strokes will hone an edge very near hair shaving sharp. That's pretty good if you're in the field. I think it would compliment a coarser diamond rod or stone to keep you in cutting form. It sports a large and small curved edge for serrations, two flat edges and a hook or scribe sharpening groove.The rubber base has angled edges to rest it on a table for proper sharpening angle but this procedure is not fool proof. I pulled the bottom rubber base off as I like to free hand and this allows for a longer stroke. It was only lightly glued and can be easily reinstalled. The beaded chain allows for field or keychain carry. Not a bad addition to my knife sharpening tool belt!

Big black Buck beauty bundled with the same quality as the original Nighthawk plus a few extras, minus some metal! That's right, there are 3 holes where beautiful, thick, strong steel used to be. The center oval can be used to turn O2 bottle valves and the rounds to bend thick wire or other items... Buck calls them utility notches. They also serve to lighten the blade. Okay, this is nice but I'd rather have the steel. The "holes", all black handle and new molle type sheath give it that tactical flair so many knife enthusiasts crave these days.Bucks 420HC steel continues to be magical and gives very little to complain about. It still boasts their famous heat treat. The grip is excellent for those bloody encounters after a successful hunt. The new sheath design is awesome. Quality nylon, molle strap on the back, storage pouch on the front, leg tie... it's all good and can be modified to fit your style in many different ways. It's a collaboration with Tops' Mike Fuller and would do well hanging from anyones belt. Use it for hunting, camping, bushcraft and even as a survival tool.

I think this is a great little tool very useful for those small jobs that pop up throughout the day. Easy to carry and deploy tools. The nail nicks actually work well for a change. It even looks cool. The knife comes nicely sharpened and I like that tension can be adjusted by the torque fasteners on the handles.Common sense dictates that this tool is not for large jobs... it is designed to be small and lightweight and should be used accordingly. The pliers work just fine within their limits. Remember, this is marketed as part of Bear's survival series and not designed for hard, continuous use but good to have in an emergency situation. The small size makes it easy to carry and available for use. For this reason I give it 4 stars. Good job on this one Gerber!

I think this is a great little tool very useful for those small jobs that pop up throughout the day. Easy to carry and deploy tools. The nail nicks actually work well for a change. It even looks cool. The knife comes nicely sharpened and I like that tension can be adjusted by the torque fasteners on the handles.Common sense dictates that this tool is not for large jobs... it is designed to be small and lightweight and should be used accordingly. For this reason I give it 5 stars. Oh yeah, the blade and file are marked to alleviate guessing... this is smart! Good job on this one Gerber!
Please stand.Classic, Beautiful, Elegant, Timeless, Durable, Functional, Reliable, Legendary, Iconic, Brilliant... just Brilliant. All Hale the Buck 110.You may be seated.

I'm very pleased with the look and quality. Yes, it's chinese 440c steel but looks like it was hammer forged over an anvil by a crafty, early period knifesmith. The chip flint blade finish, inlayed scrolling and Colt emblem really bring this knife to life. The full tang clip point blade is 5/32" thick, 1" wide, 4 5/8" long and has a 4 1/4" cutting edge. The knife is 9" long from end to end. It has good heft to it and is very comfortable to work with in different grips. No thumb jimping which is fine with me. The grind is slightly hollow but strong. The handle pins are polished and there is a sizeable lanyard hole lined with a brass roll pin.You could skin with this knife just fine but bushcraft seems to be a better fit. The edge needed some touch up and I reduced the steepness of the secondary bevel to improve its cutting ability and ease of sharpening. The sheath is very good quality, holds the knife tight and smells like cowboy leather. A great knife to carry into the woods!

Another High Value Winner from S&W. I got this knife for two reasons: 1. I'm cheap 2. It cost 12 bucks 3. It looked like it could be a comfy bushcraft type knife... okay, that's three reasons. Anyhow, I was right. The blade is thick at 5/32" and has a nice traditional drop point. The 420C doesn't seem to be the highest quality steel but should work wood with no problem. It is stamped "Hammer Forged". I can't imagine what this is supposed to mean... maybe a stretch of terminology to describe the manufacturing process and an attempt to conjure up images of the crafty old knife maker working red hot steel by hammer and anvil?It has a steep, flat grind and secondary beveled edge that wasn't very clean and sharp so it required a bit of a touch up. The edge is now more in line with the grind and looks smooth and polished... really cleaned up well. A shallow edge will improve cutting and ease of sharpening. It's 9.5" long with a 4.5" blade and 4" cuting edge. The rubber handle is removeable and reveals a full tang which is the same thickness as the blade but not as wide... it's cut down a bit with a rounded, not 90 degree angle. This is good for strength. The handle slips off the tang easily and should be shimmed before reinstalling and tightening the fasteners. I'm also thinking of adding sealant to keep moisture from entering at the ricasso and fasteners. This will give it a more solid feel.The rubber handle is extremely comfortable in my hand and you can choke up on the front choil for close work. It feels like you could work it all day without discomfort. The rubber really grabs the hand... it won't slip even when wet. The sheath is surprisingly good. It's actually plastic that is covered with balistic nylon and has a second plastic liner where the knife slips in. It's held closed with 4 solid rivets. This stiff sheath grips the knife handle even before being secured by the velcro retaining strap... it doesn't move at all. Nice S&W Bullseye logo is sewn on. A Winner at this price!

We still have our original Ginsu set from the 80's which includes this slicer. I Think it has sliced 1,798,326 slices of bread, 965,231 slices of tomatoe and 3,569,212 slices of celery. It still looks like new, is sharp and gets plenty of use. Who would have thunk that this gimmicky, inexpensive knife was for real back then?... I didn't.

My son just got this on sale for 50 bucks to add to our bush cooking capabilities. It is fast, convenient and amazing! The flux ring keeps the heat focused on the bottom of the cup while the cozy and rubber like lid keeps it in the cup. It's almost magical how your water heats so quickly but the cozy and lid stay cool. This system is light weight, simple and sips fuel from the canister. Measuring increments inside cup also. A steal at this price!

I have 3 sets of these bags, one set as low as 20 bucks on sale. For the money they are outstanding. The stuff sack style allows you to pack them tight then flip the cover over and buckle it down. They are spacious! Great for cummuting and touring.Here are the specs from Nashbar:WEIGHT:  1302gCARGO CAPACITY:  2,350 cubic inchesCARGO VOLUME:  2,350 cubic inchesDIMENSIONS:  14 x 14.5 x 5.5"NUMBER OF POCKETS:  3MATERIAL:  Nylon corduraI have had these bags for 3 years and have logged thousands of miles with them on my bike... I have had no problems. The cordura nylon is strong and the zippers are easy to use. The gray stripes you see are reflective and light up like a beacon at night. There is a compression strap that wraps around the middle to keep contents secure. The deep side pockets have dual zippers and are very roomy. I put camping gear like tent pegs, shovel, guy outs and such in one, personal/hygiene items in another, bike tools and parts in another and the last carries need to get quick items like hat, gloves, camera, phone etc. Now, remember, I'm just talking about the side pockets fitting all this gear... there are still 4 bags to fill but I think you get the idea of the room these bags have.They ride very securely on my bike. Two rubber coated hooks, velco strap and attached bungee do the job. If you attach them properly they will not bounce off or hit your spokes. A plastic panel which lines the back of the bag provides some stability. My only complaint about these bags are the odd covers. They are elastisized around the edge and unless the bag is fully packed they won't cover the bag so well. They do the job but a full, wide cover that descends the sides of the bag would be better. There is a zippered pocket along the top of the cover but if the bags are packed full and the cover is stretched over the top this pocket is not very useable.The bags are not waterproof but highly resistant. You can place sensitive items in plastic bags or line an entire bag with a large waterproof bag... I've done both. I also sprayed the bags with water repellent which prevents the material from soaking up water weight.Okay, these are not $300 Ortliebs and certainly aren't as well made. If you're planning a remote, extended trip to a far away land I would suggest a more bullet proof set but if you're looking for serviceable and inexpensive bags to get you started and then some, you can't loose with the Nashbar ATB's. I would certainly buy them again!Check out the pics I attached...

Under 4 bucks at Walmart by "Outdoor Products". Packaged in a box in the camp gear section. Can't beat it. It digs. It's compact. It folds. It has a nifty nylon case. It's tough. It's not as light as some of the plastic models but worth the weight while clearing your tent spot of rocks and roots. Comfortably rides in your back pocket. Definitely a tool to have in your inventory. Get yourself one!

4:48 MinsThis knife isn't a great buy because it's a great knife, but a great knife because it's a great buy. Come on, you get an almost 4", 440c blade with finger flipper, lanyard holes,ferro rod striker (the jimping at the end of the liners), tactical features, comfortable handle, cool blade paint and deep carry pocket clip for 7 change delivered.The drop point blade is fairly thick and menacing with a nice even grind and edge. The flipper acts as a finger choil if needed. The liners protrude past the end of the scales and house the laynyard hole. It's also nifty that the edges of these protruding liners are jimped for use as a ferro rod striker. You would think this folder cost 50 bucks after listening to some of the complaints in other reviews. At this price I'm willing to sharpen the blade and tighten a screw or two... what's the big deal? Of course it's not going to be a zero defect knife at this price.By the way, mine was extremely sharp out of the box and my screws haven't budged. My blade does not lock tightly into the handle as others have stated and can come loose but at this price I'll live with it or fix it if possible. Blade centering when closed is off a bit but this doesn't effect the use of the knife at all. For The Money, This Knife Rocks! I would recommend it to anybody and I'm going to buy a few more.

I've had my eye on this knife for more than a year now and noticed a drop in price... and then another drop, $33.50 with free shipping and it was just a reflex at that point. After I bought it I watched it go down to $29 here on Amazon... THIS IS CRAZY!!! Getting 1/4" thick, 1095 steel blade at this price is absolutely SICK! If you're looking for a Tough, Beefy, Heavy Workhorse of a knife... Look no further. An Incredible buy at this price! I'm not a prophet but I predict this knife will be one of the most popular survival knives in a year or so. I bet they will fly off the shelf once everyone catches on and gets over the overseas production thing.After I opened the box and pulled the plastic off I was in love. My next observation was that it seemed smaller in person than it did on the video reviews I've been watching - it just has a larger look on screen than in real life. This is a meaningless observation but thought I'd share it. The next thing I took note of was the removable handle. Most all of the Amazon reviews and video reviews lead me to believe the handle was a soft rubber... it is not soft rubber or at least mine isn't. It is a hard, kraton material that seems to be very durable and is quite comfortable. It's not perfectly flush with the tang but I feel no discomfort and have no concerns with this. It's a large handle and provides several different grips. You can choke up by placing your index finger on the choil which provides excellent control for close up work. My hands are small and can grip it behind the index finger groove for better chopping leverage. The contoured shape fills the hand and the flared end keeps it there. The raised circle pattern provides excellent grip and looks pretty cool.This knife is so thick and heavy for its length it feels like a club in the hand and makes you think it's indestructible. Makes that other "Ultimate" Knife look like a toy. After ogling for a while I inspected it more closely and found it to be very well made. The steel is finely and evenly shaped. The edge is precise and sharpened right down to the choil. The flat grind is only slightly beveled to form the edge giving it better cutting power than some of the more deeply beveled blades that are out there. The dark gray blade coating is tough and very handsome. It prevents corrosion, glare and reflection. The modest thumb ramp has large knobby jimping and works well but not so outrageous that it interferes with batoning or other camp/survival tasks. If you have to choose one knife this one can do it all!The nylon sheath is fine. It holds the knife securely with plastic insert and the handle retention strap length is adjustable thanks to velcro... it still secures with a snap. It has a removable front pouch that can attach to your belt separately. There is a velcro strap and snap on the back of the sheath that can be used on a molle system. Velcro belt loop allows removal of sheath without having to take your belt off. There are lots of ways to modify and upgrade this sheath with a little bit of planning. I added an extra retention strap by burning 2 holes through the belt loop with a torched nail and adding paracord with a spring loaded cord lock. Quick, run... buy this knife!!Update July 2012:Still lovin' this knife. It retains its edge and the blade coating holds up well. I chopped a 6" fallen tree in half very quickly and batoned many a big log into smaller logs for the camp fire. I have no complaints with this knife and highly recommend it! It is starting to catch on!

I caught the all black knife on sale for $12. I can honestly say, you won't get more knife for so little money anywhere. It's not only inexpensive but full of excellent features and usefulness. It's called a sportsmans knife but has a definite tactical edge to it also. The intermediate blade size is pefect for many uses such as camp, bushcraft, survival and tactical. Not excellent at all but can do it all.This kinfe is heavy for it's size, about 9oz, so ultralight backpackers beware - But I like that, it feels like a tool in the hand. Most of the weight is in the wonderful, full tang handle - I like that to. Lots of knives are skeletonized or have minimized tangs to save weight but not this knife, it's ready for some abuse. The more than 5" edged blade has a dropped clip point and a very slight hollow grind with 1.5" of deep serrations that are more suitable to cutting wood than cord, strapping or wire. The tang is about 5/32" thick and extends this thickness 1 3/4" beyond the handle. The blade came very sharp and takes an edge easily when needed.I love the handle. The removeable scales are rubber coated aluminum with smooth beveled edges making it very comfortable and grippy even when wet. The tang protrudes past the scales providing a tactical pommel with lanyard hole. The Ricasso has an upper and lower quillon that act as a thumb ramp and guard. I like the lower quillon which prevents your hand from sliding forward on the blade but not the upper quillon. Yes, it provides a thumb ramp for tactical purposes but I much prefer it to be flat which is better for camp/survival tasks like batoning. This is the only thing I don't like about this knife but it's a small issue and doesn't subtract from this great deal. There is thumb jimping which crosses the scales and also on the thumb ramp itself. The same style of jimping exists in the palm area and there is fine jimping on the lower quillon to help prevent your index finger from slipping.This knife is suitable for spear making. With handles removed you can lash it to a stick with cordage. You can also create a new handle with paracord for a different look and feel.The cordura nylon sheath holds the knife just fine but is nothing to write home to Mom about. Overall, a fantastic knife for the price! I definitely recommend it.

I caught this knife on sale for $12. I can honestly say, you won't get more knife for so little money anywhere. It's not only inexpensive but full of excellent features and usefulness. It's called a sportsmans knife but has a definite tactical edge to it also. The intermediate blade size is pefect for many uses such as camp, bushcraft, survival and tactical. Not excellent at all but can do it all.This kinfe is heavy for it's size, about 9oz, so ultralight backpackers beware... but I like that, it feels like a tool in the hand. The more than 5" edged blade has a dropped clip point and a very slight hollow grind with 1.5" of deep serrations that are more suitable to cutting wood than cord, strapping or wire. The tang is about 5/32" thick and extends this thickness 1 3/4" beyond the handle. The blade wasn't real sharp but I like the slight angle and it takes an edge easily.I love the handle. The removeable scales are rubber coated aluminum with smooth beveled edges making it very comfortable and grippy even when wet. The tang protrudes past the scales providing a tactical pommel with lanyard hole. The Ricasso has an upper and lower quillon that act as a thumb ramp and guard. I like the lower quillon which prevents your hand from sliding forward on the blade but not the upper quillon. Yes, it provides a thumb ramp for tactical purposes but I much prefer it to be flat which is better for camp/survival tasks like batoning. This is the only thing I don't like about this knife but it's a small issue and doesn't subtract from this great deal. There is thumb jimping which crosses the scales and also on the thumb ramp itself. The same style of jimping exists in the palm area and there is fine jimping on the lower quillon to help prevent your index finger from slipping.This knife is suitable for spear making. With handles removed you can lash it to a stick with cordage. You can also create a new handle with paracord for a different look and feel.The cordura nylon sheath holds the knife just fine but is nothing to write home to Mom about. Overall, a fantastic knife for the price! I definitely recommend it.

One of the smoothest opening, inexpensive folding knives I own! This knife came well oiled and the blade flys open with a slight flick of the right handed thumb stud. Love the blade shape and geometry. The blade has a nice belly with straight grind that hollows out a bit as it reaches the recurve towards the handle. This thing came very, very sharp with a nice clean straight edge which extends all the way to the handle - no wasted blunt stainless here... it all cuts! The back of the blade provides a slight thumb ramp with comfortable and effective jimping that is perfectly set between the aluminum handles, providing a sure grip. The blade has reach at 3.25" and folds into a 4.25" handle - that's a lot of blade in a small package at just over 3oz and 7.5" extended.The zytel inserts over the army green handles look great and are vey grippy. The liner lock works well and has no jimping which won't tear up your index finger. There is also a slight cut out of the left handle for easy release of the liner lock. This is a smartly designed little knife! The black pocket clip is strong stainless and does not provide a deep pocket carry but with such a small and light blade this is okay. It does not block access to the pivot stud so it can be tightened if necessary. S&W even thought of a lanyard hole. Its light weight and long blade length make this a great EDC. Well worth 10 bucks.

I like everything about this knife. It's a perfect camp/utility knife and very well designed. The first thing you notice is how comfortable it feels in the hand... seems like you can work with it forever. The rubber scales peel back from the edges a bit and will wear with hard use. They cover a wonderful, full tang which gives you confidence when tackling the big jobs! I've seen some knives covered with a cord handle after the rubber deteriorated. The thick drop point blade makes short work of common camp tasks. It remains fairly thick, even to the tip. It batons, notches and shaves wood with ease. Nicely placed lanyard hole if you need it and may be used for tactical purposes.The blade steel is typically Gerber and adequate - not super hard like 1095 high carbon but tough enough at this price. I love the subdued, bead blasted Gerber finish. My son did manage to damage the serrations a bit but they still do their job. The sheath is just a sheath and holds the knife effectively, that's about it.This knife is a good, solid performer and no one would be dissapointed with it at this price. I wish Gerber would make a bigger 6" blade version - that would be awesome!

This is the tool we've all been waiting for. No frills at all - that's why I like it so much. Just a lot of blade and simple wooden scales held tight with three brass pins... simplicity at it's best! Flat knife back to baton with and a full tang you can see all around the handle. I'm getting excited just thinking about it.The knife itself is 13" from end to end. I think the 14.25" designation is while it's docked in the sheath. The blade is 8.5" from handle to tip and the cutting edge is 7.5". This thing is a meat cleaver on steroids. The 1075 high carbon, black powder coat steel (older version) is 3/16" thick at the tang and slightly tapers as it reaches the tip. It's full flat grind with a convex edge. El Salvador is stamped on one side and Condor, the other.My sheath is thick, supple, brown leather and retains the knife securely without a strap. The belt loop is attached with a single fastener so the sheath will pivot on your belt. The single piece of leather is simply folded over, stitched and riveted at both ends. It is embossed with the Condor logo. There is no drain hole but one can be poked through. I was thinking about just cutting the tip of the sheath off since there's about an inch and a half extra length after the knife is tucked in but I always hate to change the originality of something unless absolutely necessary.I took it to the back yard and laid into some logs. Oh my... sweet, sweet chopper! It seems to beg for more and it's so easy to oblige. The powder coat held up well but will soon yield after continued use as all coatings do. The Hudson Bay really brings out the inner primeval man - no rubber, plastic, micarta or mechanical fasteners here. I am Grizzly Adams... at the low, low price of $33!Update 24 July 2013: The knife broke about 3 inches from the tip while batoning/splitting Bartlett pear tree for the fire. I contacted Condor through their website and sent the knife in for replacement. It was shipped from El Salvador Monday and received today... Wednesday. It is brand new in the box including another sheath. This replacement has the new blade finish, better edge grind and improved handle. My old knife was simply painted black and the new has a rustic, chip flint style finish... very cool. The old edge was a convexed V grind which was okay. The new edge is not convex and is closer to a true V grind... very nice and sharp. The handle is much smoother and more rounded for a better grip. Overall fit and finish is improved. The knife weighs 15.4oz. Sheath weighs 5.2oz. I am well pleased with this new knife and the service received from Condor!I will keep my rating at 5 because one broken knife during hard use does not mean they are all bad... it can happen to any knife. Also, Condor made it right immediately! I thought this would be good for everyone to know!

I'm pleasantly surprised with this folder. This is a good sized knife and not too heavy thanks to the aluminum handle. The handle has a textured finish and rounded edges which provides a comfortable grip. The lock back is very strong and gives the user a good sense of security. Because of this it doesn't flip open readily with the thumb studs so don't plan on looking like a knife fighter with this one. The blade is larger than it looks, almost 4" from handle to tip and just under 3.5" of cutting edge. It has a slight hollow grind. It says "First Production Run" on the opposite side of the blade and "China - 05" inside a circled Schrade emblem. I got the gray one from another supplier for less than 8 bucks delivered. The pocket clip is solid as a rock. I may get the black one also. Another good job by Taylor Brands!

S&W knocked this one out of the Park! Got this for 13 bucks and quite frankly it's worth every penny. The handle edges are beveled which provide enough comfort but rounding them off would have been better. The handle has a deep belly which feels a bit awkward and calls for a glove if used for longer tasks. No movement in the blade when deployed and the action is very smooth. The blade has a slight hollow grind and the serrations are toothy and should be better on wood than cord or strapping. No seperate liner lock here - it's actually the handle itself (frame lock) that springs over to securely lock the blade open. I like this feature - simple and rock solid. The pocket clip is strong but I wish it provided for a deeper carry. The finish is fine and it feels like a sturdy tool in the hand. A bit big for EDC unless you have your heavy jeans on so I plan on using it as a second bush knife. I'm very pleased and it will make a nice addition to my collection. Good job on this one Taylor Brands!

This knife was well thought out and has some real good features but a few minor flaws. I think the good outweighs the bad. At first I was a bit dissappointed and wanted to give it 3 stars but the more I handled it the more I liked it. I bought it because I wanted decent serrated blade length without a lot of weight for EDC - this knife fit the bill which brings me to my next point. As an EDC, a strong, deep riding pocket clip is needed - Gerber nailed it here. I also like the fact that it has features suited for tactical and utility use. This makes it a good all around folding blade and adds value as an EDC.The finger flipper works great after excercising it a bit and the pocket clip acts as a finger hold while opening it this way. After the blade locks open the flipper takes its role as a hand guard. The EVO rests firm in the hand and provides a confident, comfortable grip. Love the black color and titanium coating. The blade was relatively sharp but not razor sharp. The serrations are subtle and should be good to cut cord, strapping and wire. There is slight jimping on the blade back but the handle edge extends beyond the blade minimizing the effectiveness of the jimping. Control is good enough nonetheless. The thumb studs work but I prefer the flipper. There is no play in the blade when extended. You can attach a lanyard to the bottom handle stay without the blade interfering.The tip of the blade on mine was not finished correctly which gives the appearance of a slight bend. A bit more sharpening on one side will correct this so it's not a big deal. When I flip it open sharply the liner lock overshoots the butt of the Blade and jams in the locked position. This requires excessive force, sometimes with two hands, to release the lock before closing. I don't think there is anything I can do to correct this defect but I'll give it a few more days of use before I decide on a course of action.I got it at Dick's for thirty bucks including a Gerber Clutch multi-tool so it was a fair deal. This is a good solid performer that will work well for many uses. I like it more now than when I started writing this review!

I'm always looking for inexpensive, bright and long lasting lights and finally decided to pick this one up and see what its got. Purchased it at Target for 15 bucks... if it's no good I can take it back.What caught my interest is 60 lumens of light lasting for 48 hours. This would be exceptional if true. The package also says 72 hours on low at 18 lumens. It has a strobe function which blinks slowly at high power if you hold the switch down from any setting. The red LED is, well... a red LED - I don't use those much. The sequence of light is low, high, red then off. The orange face is brilliant on high and while flashing which can be used as an emergency beacon. This is a good safety/survival feature. The whole case glows when the light is on and glows red when that LED is selected.It's still a sunny day outside but I can tell that this sucker is powerful. From inside a dark room the spot looks tight, bright and white. The switch is of good quality, easy to find with the right hand and has a nice positive action when depressed. The aluminum battery compartment cover screw works fine and is received by aluminum threads nestled in the case side. There is a rubber gasket but it doesn't provide a guaranteed seal - maybe a bit resistant but not water proof.The overall quality of the plastic case and lens is adequate but certainly not unbreakable. I would rate Energizer headlights a bit better in build quality. The tilt mechanism works fine with 4 different settings. I'm okay with the color as it would be easy to find inside your pack or drawer. I'll update this review after a few days of use.Next day update: Well, I guess 60 lumens for 48 hours isn't gonna happen. I thought it sounded to good to be true. I turned the light on high at 9pm and it provided full brightness for about two hours before I could notice a significant reduction in brightness. After 3 hours it was about as bright as it initially was on the low setting. When I awoke at 630am it was still shinning at about the same dim brightness. So that's 9.5 hours so far. This light obviously has no output regulation. We'll see what happens tonight.Next day update: Left it on again for 9 hours and it's still putting out light but no where near the original 3 hours of 60 Lumens. It is now very dim - about as bright as a 10 lumen light. I may keep it though because I like the strobe and the initial 2 hours of very bright spot light. Buyer beware on this one!

Update May 2014: This headlamp has been upgraded since I purchased the single button model and wrote this review several years ago. This newer version has 2 buttons, more power, a low and strobe mode. I like it better than the original. Enjoy this review of he original version!I own several Energizer headlights and while they may not be known for their sexiness they sure are dependable. They all continue to work, and better than advertised at that! This 1 watt model is big but produces big light also. If you're a runner this one will bounce on your head so choose another model (new model has less bounce). This one serves me best at home and I carry the smaller, 7 LED model into the bush with me.The on switch is excellent. It sits right at the top of the light and responds with a solid "Snap" when depressed - no guessing here. Press once and the main 1 watt center beam comes on, again and the two red LED's take their turn, again and the two white floods come on line, one more time and the unit is off. I would prefer the sequence to be red, flood, then spot - less power to higher power,  but this isn't a big deal to me.The light output is excellent as I find on all Energizers. The packaging says the spot will shine for 5 hours and this Amazon description says 11 hours. Mine has lasted well past 5 hours but not sure if I made 11 - this is good operating time for 50 lumens either way. The beam is white and bright with little distortion. The white floods seem to shine forever on a set of bats and is the setting I use the most - good spill light here and plenty for normal use. I don't use the red lights much but they are nice to have. They provide a good flood effect and yeah, they last longer than forever and will protect your night vision.The light body is absolutely rock solid - I wouldn't say bullet proof but I take care of my equipment so I won't find out. The tilt mechanism is strong with a positive action and has 6 settings - the most I've seen for this type of tilt assembly. The battery case is easy to access and is complete with rubber seal for water resistance. The lens cover encapsulates all LED's and is sealed in place for a clean look. Nice foam padding rests on your forehead and the strap is wide, adjustable and comfortable.Like I said, this light isn't the sexiest, brightest, smallest or lightest, but for the money, dependability and functionality it is a smart buy. I'm sure I'll have this fine tool for many years to come!Tip if you wear eyeglasses:Any headlight will cause some annoying glare with glasses on so I recommend wearing a ball cap under the headlight or apply some electrical tape to the bottom of the unit. Any type of glare shield you can fashion will solve this problem.

Not only does this machine effortlessly clean my teeth but the invigorating vibrations are at the perfect frequency to jump start my brain in the morning. This thing is a masseuse for the mouth... amazing. I've tried many expensive teeth cleaners over the years and this beats them all, hands down. $5 each and one simple AAA battery - are you kidding me! No more shelling out big bucks for gizmos that don't work and charge $15 for a new brush head! This is the tool we've all been waiting for. From the bottom of my heart, thank you Colgate! Finally! Finally!... all is right in the world of teeth cleaning.And by the way - when the bristles are tired and you need a new one, don't throw the old one away. Put it to work cleaning the houshold nooks and crannies or put it in the tool box for other odd cleaning jobs. It's the gift that keeps on giving!

The packaging says this headlamp will provide 80 hours of light on high setting... NOT EVEN CLOSE! After about 5 minutes the light housing becomes very warm and after 20 minutes is extremely warm. I guess this is where all the power is going - HEAT not LIGHT. After 1.5 hours it was very dim on high and at 2 hours was just a faint glow - even the heat was gone. Mine would still shut off though. I thought Princeton products were quality but now I know. I just got it yesterday so I'll try returning it to the store. It's a shame because it is a very light, small and easy unit to use. Would be a great design if it worked. I'll stick with my energizers.Update: 4/4/11Dick's took it back and were unaware of the issues with it.Update 6/6/12: New packaging has been changed to read 2hrs on high. The packaging I bought it in said 80hrs on high. Not sure if PT upgraded the light at all.

I just received the SW970 which is identical to the 960 and 980 except for blade features. The 980 has more of a clip point with false edge and the backbone is straight - there is no depression towards the upper guard/thumb ramp like the 960 and 970. The 980 is more of a bowie design and the 960 is a drop point with a spear point look. This 970 has a more of an upswept clip point with false edge and is more suited to skinning. $[...] including shipping from Thompson Tools through Amazon.It seems like it's a full length tang and the pommel is attached to the end, secured with a roll pin which forms the lanyard hole - this is good. The stainless pommel does wiggle and click a bit but it's aesthetic only and finishes the handle off nicely. You may be able to thump lightly on plastic tent pegs or someone's noggin but certainly not drive nails. The blade is also loose inside the handle but just a bit. This should not affect performance and the handle has no way of coming off.I've seen this blade advertised as 440c steel on other sites but it doesn't say this on the knife, packaging or paperwork. The 2009 S&W online catalogue says it's "stainless steel" and weighs 6.5 oz. It has a nice satin finish. The knife is sturdy, about 5/32" thick blade, 11" total length, 6 1/4" blade length, 5 3/8" cutting edge. It came sharp enough to work but not crazy, razor sharp. It feels great in the hand and is ever so slightly handle heavy, although I wish the handle was a bit larger. The handle material is harder than rubber, sturdy and provides a decent grip - not as grippy as rubber though. Other web sites say the handle is kraton - S&W catalogue calls it composite.The thumb ramp could be a bit more subdued and may get in the way of some camp/hunt tasks but helps with blade control nonetheless. You can choke up on the blade by placing your thumb around the thumb ramp and resting it on the back of the blade while your index finger rests in front of the bottom guard on the flat choil area. "Smith & Wesson" is stamped on the blade and molded into both sides of the handle along with the logo - this looks cool. "SW970" is stamped on the other side of the blade. The edge is a tapered 3/4 hollow grind and is designed to cut and skin but seems solid enough to split small wood for the fire with some light batoning... the 970 is not made to be pounded on. Some light chopping is possible but it's definitely not an axe and shouldn't be used as one. The grind on the 970 is a bit thinner than the 980 which makes it a better cutter.The sheath is standard S&W black leather with embossed logo which I love - well made and makes me feel like a cowboy. Even the strap snap wears the logo. I know about getting leather wet and sheathing your knife in it but hey, I just like leather. Great carry for backpacking and certainly menacing enough for self defense if needed.I used this knife for some light batoning and other woodwork and as I suspected it worked fine. The blade is strong but I wouldn't baton much bigger than 3". I notched and skinned the bark of a few branches also. It has good control for a longer blade with a skimpy handle. The edge dulled quickly but is easy to touch up. Well worth the money!

Of the many flashlights I own this has been one of the best. The biggest reason is the price... got it on clearance at Target for $18. That's a lot of light output for the money! It is solid and well made but certainly not indestructable. I don't abuse it too much or submerge it in water as it is not advertised as a hardened, waterproof item. It is protected by flimsy, misplaced o-rings which warned me of this. So don't soak this thing or hammer with it. Nice lanyard hole on the end cap!If you need or like a strong "spot" light this one will fit the bill. This is its main function. There is a bit of spill light available but only because of the shear brightness it puts out, not by design. Not sure how accurate other reviewers are with comments on Lumen output and I'm not a Lumen measuring expert but this sucker is Brilliant! The spot is Tight, White and Bright! I have a few more lights rated at over 100 lumens and the Dorcy is the brightest. Great for nightwatchman, rent a cops, mall security, outdoorsman etc. Not for serious life and death use such as military, tactical, firefighting, mining, diving etc. You should always seek out proper equipment if engaging in these type of activities.I love the fact that this light uses inexpensive, easy to find AAA's. This is a great and convenient feature for this type of light - thanks Dorcy! And your light will shine bright for well more than 10 hours! The polycarbonate lens will scratch but there are many products available to polish it up if needed. All in all a great product if cared for properly. I'm glad I have one.

I’m a 34 year-old woman who has always struggled with motivation. I would have it in fits and starts (usually at the beginning of the year), but I could never maintain it over a long period of time to actually effect any positive change. I would make resolutions that would backfire. I would force myself to do something and then never do it again. Exercise had always eluded me. When I got my hands on Mini Habits, I was, of course, incredulous. My friend gave it to me and told me that it helped her get her life on track. After avoiding it for months, I decided to give it a try. I started even smaller than Stephen Guise did. I did 1 jumping jack per day for a week. I realized how easy it was and I bumped it up to 10, then 20, then 100, then 1000. Now I’ve got an entire workout regimen that I stick to consistently and I have Mini Habits to thank for that.Of course, I also have 27 Quick Life Transformation Tips to thank, as well. Written by Alvin Huang and Greg Frost, this book is filled with universally practical insights for improving your life. Mini Habits helped bolster by persistence, but 27 Quick Life Transformation Tips has helped improve just about every other area of my life. The book is separated into 27 chapters and each chapter provides a different step-by-step guide to improving your life. For instance, one chapter talks about how to utilize your 401 to get the most out of your retirement. Another talks about the health risks of detoxing and how to do it right. There are countless valuable nuggets of truth, and the writing is straightforward and witty.I would say that these two books have helped me get out of my rut. There’s a never-ending cycle of trying to get motivated, getting motivated briefly, and falling back on your laurels. These books have helped me break that cycle. I am more motivated, healthy, and driven than ever before and I’m so glad I came across these books.

Nice enough antenna, works well enough.  I bought this on a whim, for an interior bedroom in my apartment. Another OUTSTANDING XEN-TAN product!  There is a reason film and TV studio pro's trust this brand.Forget about streaky, "oompa-loompa" looks- this will not occur. I am a guy, with fair skin.
