I was given a free copy of this book in order to read it and give my honest review.First, may I ask: If I were to travel to Paris, would the man of my dreams somehow approach me, and we'd be in blissful love forever?? Most of these books about Paris really want us to believe it is true. This may be little, if no, exception.First, this family of four lost their oldest and only son in a car accident. The mom is attempting to pull herself out of a deep depression. Sbe asks her newly "independent" daughter to go to Paris for about 3 days; then meet up with the father to go on vacaton when his plane touches down. she mentions that her son had been Paris before. Tell us about that.The whole reason she dragged her daughter to Paris was to spend quality time together, just the two of them. Also she found a letter behind a painting that she wanted to investigate to learn the history of why this man loved this young woman, but he knew they could never be together.It was a book about Paris. We can't say no to that. Otherwise the period parts of the book were very slow going, but necessary for the plot. i desperately wanted to read the book when I saw the title. I read up on the history of Montmartre and the artists who passrd through there over the decades. Yes, I enjoyed this book. But not enough to read it again, unfortunately. I DO, however, recommend anyone who loves Paris to try it. There are rarely any "touristy" locations mentioned. This plot could have been in Phoenix if written for that setting.

I kept coming back to this top everyday for almost a week.  It put me in a trance every time.  It is so incredibly enchanting on the screen.  However,  it looks and even feels so much better in person.  It makes me feel like a princess.  I absolutely  LOVE it!!!!!!

I would have loved to have received my Goodreads Giveaway book so that I could read it and give my honest review. Unfortunately, the one responsible for the giveaway has not sent me a copy, nor has anyone answered my inquiry when I wrote them.This is happening more and more. If someone, I don't care who they may be, tells people that they are a "giveaway winner", then honor that! It really hurts potential readers to be neglected so. They tell two friends, who tell two more friends each. Soon, no one will want to purchase a book from someone who renigs on their promises.He can keep his "free" book, and leave it sit with all of his other nonselling books. Hoard them all. You lost one potential reader and a big fan of your show. Shouldn't he have a publicity departnent to handle book giveaways, so that "WINNERS" who have been notified that they are WILL ACTUALLY RECEIVE THEIR COPY? Is this the way you do business, seriously? HIGH KICK FOR YOU! "Wheeeeeeeee!!!!"

Unlike "The Paris Architect", which was written from a reluctant French Resistance agent's perspective,  this book was written from the perspective of two sisters: one who actively joined the resistance  and the other who had very little conscious  choice in the matter.  Both books had very frightening moments in them which involved sadistic,  psychopathic German officers in them. Both books talked about what life was like for occupied France and her people during the German occupation during WWII. Each of these books are wonderful works of art,  meant to take us back to a very dismal time in our world's history,  least we forget.The main thing I took away from this book is that no matter how you choose,  and what justification you tell yourself why you chose that,  your actions: all of them,  whether for good intentions  or to just survive the best you can,  have consequences.  Unless it's in hindsight,  we really have no idea of the outcome at the time that our choice is made.  Did we do the moral thing?  Were we right on snitching on our friends?  Whatever the result,  it is for the decider to live with for the rest of their lives.  We do not get off scot-free from our consciences, no matter how hard we try.That this book talks about the kind of atrocities  and torture like no other that really makes me feel a fraction of the terror that entire villages went through speaks volumes. This isn't some Disney,  watered version of the past.  This book makes sure you know just what it was really like to live and fear the German occupation  in its next door neighbor's home.  A true gift of art to keep for generations to come.  I hope this becomes required reading  in English Literature  classes throughout  the United States.  This offers a vivid account of how cruel and inhumane war actually is.

It seemed more like sensationalism than any real work of nonfiction.  Don't get me wrong... I am just as curious of the goings on of celebrities, now and in the past, as the next person. Parts of this book had some very juicy gossip in them. Coco Chanel was indeed one of them. Then, too, you have a ridiculously garish batch of stories about Earnest Hemingway pretending to take on the German army around Paris.I do love stories about hoteliers who have grown up there, when their parents had worked there before them.  You know that if anyone would have some important knowledge, they would (if only you could get them to talk).  With high level German occupiers in your midst,  it is better to turn a blind eye and keep your head down with your mouth shut. I may have learned a thing or two, but at what cost?The German officers and their "new friends" ate high off the hog and drank to excess while the average Parisian was forced to go hungry for lack of food. The American journalists seemed to be better off befriending these Germans, and partaking in all of the festivities, than to care for their own boys dying on the shores of Normandy.  For them, the ONLY destination is to get to the swankiest hotel, ever, before their colleagues do.  And,  that was the Hotel Ritz on The Place Vendome.

I love this book. I love Commissaire Georges Dupin most of all. He was transferred from Paris because he tended to not play well with others in the police station. Hey, getting older has its irritations. Then, right at breakfast, he gets a call to investigate a murder that took place in a little village next to the sea just as tourist season was about to begin. The man who was supposed to be heading it up was on vacation, himself. This didn't sit too well with Dupin any more than interrupting his morning coffee.He heads the fifteen or so miles to the little seaside village of Pont-Aven, on the coast of Breton, to find out why and who brutally stabbed the 91 year old, third generation hotel owner to death. Dupin doesn't seem to have time to babysit his investigative team. So he gives them very mundane tasks, while he interrogates those closest to the beloved staple of the small community, Pierre-Louis Pennec. When not engaged directly with police proceedure, he takes zen-like strolls along the riverbank that leads out to sea, or enjoys the meals only the French can prepare so well.While all this sounds so pleasant, one tends to wonder if this case will ever get solved. The book is tempting its readers to come visit the quaint artisan village and to learn of its unique history, kind of like it is trying to divert your attention away from the main storyline. This is another reason I love this book. All of the clever little diversions away from the grizzle in the meat of a police investigation keeps the reader sidetracked long enough to get near the end. All in all, it is akin to taking a working vacation to someplace pleasant one would enjoy more if work wasn't a part of it. I didn't have to put too much effort into remembering which person was which. I could go with Dupin's flow (I am as much of a stay-to-myself-person also). I believe I understand his foibles much more than other readers who are less impatient with the pace of life that Dupin seems to lead. He takes the time to smell what roses he does come across.I was given a copy of this book in order to read it and give an honest review of it.

I was looking to buy a folio cover for my Kindle Fire HD 7. Then, I happened upon this Poetic case. It may be a fraction of the cost of those "show off" brands, but it is the greatest case! It makes the colors so much more vivid, and really reduces glare. The screen protector is built in. There are covers for when you aren't charging and stuff. It is easy to grip and hold. And, it is even water resistant, in case you ever accidently splash some water on it, trying to get the lid off of your water bottle. The case colors are fun, without looking like you took your toddler's by mistake. The pros outweigh the cons (if you can even spot a con). I would like to order a few more colors to switch it up a bit when I want to. The warranty is unbeatable, too!!!!!!

Thank you to NetGalley for giving me a free copy to read and give my honest review.I don't know if becoming madly passionate to want to read about a sick, twisted, kind of "Saw" scenario makes me a bit psycho or not. But the very moment I read the quick premise of the book, I absolutely knew I NEEDED to find out what was going on and why. And from the very beginning, this book is so enthralling, I had the insatiable desire to read it all the way through without stopping for anything.  How does a couple getting soaked in the rain end up as survival of the most heinous?I loved Helen Grace, lead detective on a series of "games", which pits two people against each other, starvation, doing the right thing vs. looking out for #1. What I didn't like about her character was how quick she accused her closest coworkers of conspiracy or assisting the "killer". And, is one truly THE murderer or just someone who makes other people slowly lose their minds and become the killer, themselves? It wasn't like one was "holding a gun to their head" and forcing them to choose. We all have some free will.But, this is where the book REALLY gets psychologically interesting: who is actually the most fortunate of the two hostages? The one who gets put out of their misery (not of their choosing) or the one who decides to save their own hide by killing the other person? The answer just may surprise you, the reader. You may think this is a clear case of the reader getting clues to solve the case before the "coppers". This brilliant author, M.J. Arlidge is way too clever to allow it to be that easy.He loves to throw curve balls at you to try to hit you in the head. He wants you to place yourself in the picture and to ask yourself just how far would you go to stay alive. Also, was your choice the right one? If you had to do it all over again, would you do it differently? This is a very good form of entertainment with a very special bonus: You will never see your friends, family, or even coworkers in the same way ever again. This will not disappoint!

At first, I couldn't understand where this story was leading. Hence the four rating. Then, all at once, I am enthralled. I could not put the book down to save my skin. This Henry character is somewhat confused about his conundrum whether to tell the truth or lie. He does some incredibly bad things that he fears will land him in jail. However, it seems to me that strange circumstances tend to happen at the right time. This very enthusiastic and passionate detective tries to trip Henry up so that he can get some sort of truth out of Henry. But this supposed womanizing drifter in the beginning slowly becomes smarter and clever as the story goes on.I loved this book after it grabbed me and pulled me in. Why I feel this way is the quirky characters. The writing is brilliantly thought out. What a grand imagination to come up with a full story filled with illusions around every bend. The things that happen all around Henry are unforeseen by me, the reader. They hit me so unexpectedly, it felt like I had the wind knocked out of me. I really want to keep the suspense for you to find out on your own. It is too good a story for anyone to give it away. Does the detective ever solve his mystery? Whatever becomes of Henry? Those were the questions that kept me guessing and needing to find out to the very end. I have never read such an out of this world type of book before. I don't know of any author who used a main character to take us on an exciting roller coaster ride like this one. The narration made the book. I want to read so much more from Sascha Arango. I am still energized by this story and the people in it.I am one of the Goodreads First Reads giveaway winners. I received a copy of this book to read and give my honest review.

I came into this book thinking "not another girl leaves boyfriend for trip to Paris. Girl meets Frenchman, then girl develops feelings for him. Boyfriend tries to bring girl home. Girl stays in France with new man. Chick lit overkill." Am I ever so glad that I couldn't have been further from the truth (well, most of it anyway). I didn't find out that it was inspired by an actual discovery until the very end. Astonishing!To me, this book is a multifaceted gem. Cat Jordan discovers that she has inherited an apartment that has been locked up ever since 1940. Another claimant, Loic de Florian, teams up with Cat to solve a mystery of why she inherited it and not the owner's family, who were shocked to just now learn of it. He eventually gives up; however Cat's willingness to persevere pays off in the long run."Paris Time Capsule" fascinated me most with it's intonations. The apartment is the tangible time capsule, clearly. It had been untouched for over a half of a century. Loic takes Cat on an informational treasure hunt, for clues to his grandmother's youth, in very old buildings in very quaint villages is another. The most important one for me is what it was like to endure the loss of one's freedom, home, and possibly life once the Germans invaded France and took possession of Paris. Ms. Carey brought those hopeless days of WWII to life like no other. I was mesmerized to the very end.Thank you, Netgalley for giving me a free copy of this book to read and give an honest review.

This is Blair Howard's third book in the "A Novel of the American Civil War" series. No two books are ever alike. This book is no exception. I used to read Louis L'amour's westerns. Never in those has there been a chase like this one. It keeps you on your toes. There is always something around the next corner to keep you glued to the pages.The book starts with a gang of 23 rouge confederate soldiers,  including their demonic "commanding officer" , Lieutenant Jesse Quintana. This motley gang ravages a small frontier town, Echo, on the Kansas prairie. From there, they are on the run for Mexico.Word gets out to O'Sullivan ("The Mule Soldiers") that he was to report to Colonel Richard at Fort Scott, Kansas. He was given orders "to track down and arrest, or kill, this band of renegades". Along with Sergeant Major Coffin, nearly right out of military school Lieutenant Warwick, a scout, and 14 troops, O'Sullivan is out on the quest of his life.One word of caution. This book is full of gore, very detailed. It may not be suited for children or sensitive people. However, Mr. Blair is making this as real as possible. There are some equally humorous parts, too. I love the level of detail in this book. It, as a whole, is extraordinary. Like his previous Civil War novels, you will feel like you are literally in the book. It is so good, you will be begging for more.Mr. Blair Howard gave me a free copy of this book to read and give my honest review.
I have been looking to buy a dutch oven. I found this wonderful cookbook on Amazon. This book has some extremely good and simple recipes that even busy Moms like me can fix every day of the week!

This is the ONLY brand I will EVER buy again. Their description above says it all. The syrup is SO sticky.....that tells you it is real syrup. The taste (I am a 49 year old bubble gum flavor CONNOISSEUR...It HAS to taste like real bubble gum) is PHENOMENAL!!! It is the real deal to me. The person who wrote that it did not taste like bubble gum must be like me. I wanted it to be  an overpoweringly strong bubble gum taste. I must have used the pump 6 times. One is barely going to do it for bubble gum connoisseurs. But one squirt in coffee, and .I put one pump in milk (it is to DIE for) is more than plenty for everyone. You just taste it and add more if you are so inclined. I tried other ""syrups" that were watery and tasted bad. This is the syrup you want to buy. It is authentic and real bubble gum taste and smell.....the flavor lingers in the glass when I go to wash it. HEAVENLY!

This tasted like something I could not describe except Industrial fluids.with a touch of green apple if you use your imagination. I did follow the instructions to a tee. I wanted BUBBLE GUM SYRUP. I don't know what is in the watery stuff, but there is NO bubble gum taste at all. It is absolutely horrendous.
