Whatever was in that bottle was as thin as water itself, but tasted terrible.  Syrup is sticky and if there is a flavor in it, you would taste it. This tasted like something I could not describe except Industrial fluids.

I absolutely love Mrs. Lesage's writing style! For me, it is the mix of sarcasm (just like mine, that makes my daughter yell "shut up! You always embarrass me." - it is SO MUCH FUN!) and humor. She always comes up with the coolest things to write about. It is as if we are sitting outside of a small coffee shop visiting, and Vicki says "Let me tell you about the DAY I had!"I will let you in on just a couple topics she writes about. One - the Facechat she has with her Mom across the lake (isn't England the "pond" from America?).  Her son is telling Grandma all about his favorite topic "caca vroom vroom" otherwise known (but not yet to Grandma) the garbage truck. It is not only the cutest thing. Grandma doles out advice to her daughter about....... well, read the book! Do you honestly expect me to spoil it for you? While you are reading, find out why Mommy gets nervous that Grandma may find out the French word for "seal". That one made me roar, laughing so loud.Two - 10 things to compare living in Paris with going to the dentist (or something about the dentist). Now, instead of a second topic I love, there are actually TEN of them in one chapter alone. I could almost say "You had to be there". However, I have never been to Paris. I did go to the dentist (too many times as a kid).  You will find the comparisons spot on if not funny. Ah, but you WILL find them funny. Just like her others, this book will not disappoint! Make sure to tell all your friends, so you can all laugh together.I was given a free copy of this book to read and give an honest review.
This won't even install on my Kindle HD 7 at all.  I read the summary before I bought it. Why is it being sold on the Kindle app store if it is not Kindle compatible? What history eraser app is?

Thank you Velvet Morning Press Books and Reading Deals for allowing me a free copy of this book to read and give my honest review.I really began to love these four strangers who all have something to do with someone on the Rue des Martyrs. The book begins with four different storylines that begin to weave in and out of each other seamlessly. As each story unfolds, one can't help but see the flaws of the main characters soften just a bit. By the end, I wanted "the happily ever after" for all of them.The mystery of who these people are and in which way they are connected to each other is absolutely phenomenal. It keeps the reader constantly on their toes and wanting to stay invested in finding out the outcome of the book. For this reason, I believe any reader worth their salt would enjoy this good read.

I love the way it is constructed and the feel. The look is really authentic: a wow factor.  I just bought an  Irulu android tablet. The only thing that I don't appreciate is that the cutouts on the (top if you look at it this way, or the right side of the tablet) don't match up quite well enough. This is a new, slim Irulu, so it is not the fault of the manufacturer of this product. It doesn't have a lot of unnecessary flaps. It closes like a book. It opens and the cover can be folded to make a stand.  I LOVE THIS ONE.

I used to buy these at a beautiful bakery. When they closed, I could never find any place that sold them (at least 30+ years now). I would search "butter" cookies, but they weren't it. Here is a whole, beautiful cookbook on JUST spritz cookies. Now I can make them myself. If you haven't had the pleasure to taste spritz cookies, they are somewhat small, buttery tasting, and the moment you bite into one, they are like a cloud, real nice and light. I never knew there are so many flavors! I recommend these for anyone who would like to serve the best tasting, light,don't-have-to-say-I'm-watching-my-weight to their friends and loved ones any time you want a decadent desert or to go with coffee.

I love Greece, and the pictures. However, some of them were muted like something that Andy Worhal would make. It was not so much about the dog, but the Greek culture, food, and plenty of friends. I would recommend this book more for older readers, than I would as a picture book.

The title is not a dog lover who hates cats. It is, however, true things that cats do to make you tear your hair out at times. Each page has a different kitten on it and  the page explains one or more things cats do: I think it is a reality check for people who think kittens are adorable....get one....and six months later, you want to drive them onto a dirt country road and let it fend for itself, get attacked or run over......or the worst: starving to death. Kittens turn into cats. They are God's precious love bug  I love this book! Any cat lover will relate to a few or many things cats love to do that will test your mettle. But, we love them enough to never let them go. And, the last page is something us cat people really do need you to know......it is all about love, pure love..

I am a devoted Hay House reader. When I saw this beautiful cover and then read that it helps people grieve, I had to read this book. I believe, as Dr. Turndorf does, that if you are open to signs, you notice things. However, this Dr. stated that her husband would visit her in full apparition nearly all the time. She also said that she'd send him to her friends' homes to deliver messages to them. Has ANYONE ever had experiences like that, EVER? Even the Long Island Medium, I believe, said that she has never seen full bodied apparitions. And the friends weren't the least bit concerned that he was standing right there without first knocking or something?She falls in love with a "married" man twice her age. She breaks up a marriage, and brags about his "smell (not scent, his smell.....even whiffing his armpits. I did not need to visualize that). She tells how her parents, mostly her over-opinionated mom (which of us don't have one?), would disapprove of her marriage and had been abusive to her when she was young. Is her beloved Jean a daddy fetish or was she seeking a daddy when she found him? Again, it is nothing that should concern me. But, she wrote the book.For being a t.v. Dr. who gives out advice, isn't she just a bit out there? One minute she is in hysterics, and the next she feels the "rapture" of the most intense love she's ever felt. But, then it is as if she is throwing a tantrum with hysterics, again. Yes, like she said, we all grieve differently. But, as a professional, couldn't she try to keep it together at least somewhat?What broke my complete reading connection with this book was the younger man who set up his massage equipment for her. Then in front of a large window, she jumps up completely nude (where a neighbor or anyone walking by could see her). The masseuse guy had to see her full frontal, and then the clincher. He goes into a trance and talks to her like her husband would. Then, it was as if her husband just jumped into this man's body to keep talking to her: in the buff on a massage table. And, when the encounter was over, she walked the masseuse upstairs to "find out where the strange music was coming from."  Why wasn't he concerned about blacking out or that someone else was talking through him? I am sorry, but this book sounds insane or made up. Honestly.I know about the afterlife, and how very much energy is needed for them to come through, if that. He is there in person as much as the Rat Pack was in Vegas in the 50's. There is something so sad and pathetic to think people who are of sound mind would believe her OR finish this book. If she came up with grieving therapy, I don't want to know about hers. I could not force myself to be curious enough to read something I would have no business needing to know about. I'm good.**I was given a copy of this book for free to read and give my honest review.

I was so excited to try this brand. I think that little green star with "50 pcs" drew me in. Great marketing!!!! My cat absolutely loves the Chenille Kraft 1 inch glitter balls to play with. Before you say they are harmful to cats: I bought individual ones at a pet store, compared them to the Chenille, AND THEY WERE IDENTICAL IN EVERY WAY.  These are absolutely gorgeous, and they make you want to stare at them all day. The colors are in the fabric, also. They feel more durable (hard) than the others. However, the very same with the SIX  2 inch Creativity Street Glitter Poms (they advertise 16). I opened both bags right in front of my cat, and she just walked away. There must be some chemical smell they can smell that repulsed them. Has anyone else bought these for their cat? Is there any way to wash the smell out? She goes bonkers with the other poms, and can't wait for me to open them, then she takes and thinks she is hiding them from me. She won't go near these. They would beautify any craft real well. I am thinking of buying Styrofoam balls and glue these on for festive decorations. I will buy more for projects like these. I love the bright colors. But, these were intended for my kitty, and I let her down.

Wait a moment. I received six, not 16! They were very brilliant in color, but they seemed mashed. I took them out of the wrapping, and days later, they were still like that...not round. I bought these for my cat, who loves me to "flick" the balls, and she brings it back. She took one look at them and walked away. I have them in the box they came in. I thought she'd like a larger size. They are absolutely gorgeous in color...and not just on the tinsel like most others. You will love them for crafting. I'm not sure why my cat didn't even at least look them over. Has any other cat parent tried these yet?

I heard James Patterson was a brilliant writer. I saw the sandy beach, then thought "Honemoon = exotic location". Boy, was I wrong. I really don't know why he even named it that. Why not FEM FATAL or  THE POTION.....or better yet REWRITE THE BOOK, AND MAKE SOME SENSE OUT OF THE WHOLE THING. Start with a basic outline and stick with an original them throughout.I really like the first 1/3 of the book. That Nora was a clever, naughty girl. But then the P__N_S did the writing. Not erotica; just this one guy's description of her, and the other way around. It was overkill how gorgeous they all were.The book began to make one think even the writers were getting sick of writing the book. There was nothing about a honeymoon nor a beach. I doubt the author's even thought out the plot line to follow.  This man  (character in the book) who was supposed to be on a non-police stake out ends up going gaga for her, also. And she just happens to want HIM in bed?Then comes the decline. One could slide down that hill. The rest of the story seemed to me like the last third of the book was just thrown together to get it over with.For being a James Patterson book (this was my first read), it sure doesn't represent his brand very well. But, I did like his commercial for "Private Vegas" and bought the audio book. Last time I checked, Beverly Hills was NOT IN VEGAS! What is up with this author, anyway?

Pardon me. I wrote a lot on my Kindle and it froze up and I lost everything.  This book is sort of a call to arms to get people thinking and openly talking about sexual abuse, molestation, and incest.  Mr and Mrs Miller, in 1978, decided that they wanted to join other international ministries through their denomination. They chose to go to Novatia, Africa after hearing great things about that country. One of those things was "the dedication of the scores of missionaries who had worked there for a quarter of a century" (p. 27). All the missionaries around that area felt as if they were all brothers and sisters in the church.One day, Dee went to see a missionary co-worker's visuals or her presentation. The husband was the only one home.She knew and trusted the couple for many years. Yet, intuition told her she should not be there. He then tried to sexualy assault her. She ran around the kitchen table and then seen a monster who molested others before; and that he may kill her to keep quiet. She finally made up her mind to find other victims so they could band together and have him removed from Africa.  But, she knew that more needed to be done to get him the help he needs before he could molest one more woman or girl.She wrote her story to alert us to the epidemic of pediphiles, rapists, incest and sexual predators. She tried nearly everything to get the local committee to listen to her. Friends she trusted no longer wanted to talk to her. The men were.blaming her for trying to cause trouble. She wrote letters to the home office, to the local leaders, and her husband even got involved in the whole mess. Men have their "good ole boys club" and they stick together. The wives dutifully keep their mouths shut, even when they know what happened and is continuing to happen in secret.The purpose of her book was to tell victims that they are not alone; and they must speak up. Also a denomination is not alone when it comes to sexual victims and their perpetrators AND those problems MUST not be ignored or hidden. (Forward  p. vi). Girls and women are afraid to tell anyone. First there is guilt, self-blame, denial, and fear of what others are going to think of them. Boys keep it all bottled up inside and keep telling themselves things such as "I am a rotten kid" constantly. Some of them grow up to do the same thing as their molesters.It chronicles the lives and struggles the Millers have to face in attempting to bring up the "unmentionable"  to try to get more victims to tell what happened to them so that the denomination's home office will punish or relieve the man. Little did they know what they were in for. Dee also wants all of us to take a stand and fight this "epidemic" of sexual violence against women and children. You don't have to protest and get on tv. All it takes is in this book.  Why I like it is because something happened to me, also. No one wanted to believe me; and most said it was my fault. This silence cannot continue to go on... take baby steps until you are strong enough to do more. But, read this book so that you know you are not alone.****I was given a copy of this book to read and give my honest review from GoodReads Giveaways, Dee Ann Miller, and Prescott Press.

I am a novice reviewer when it comes to book reviews. I am always looking for advice on what to put in, etc.When I saw the title of this book, and the description mentioned reviews, I wanted to read this for advice. Mr. Foster also touched on what is and is not allowed in a review. And, he helped me better understand what readers want out of a good and helpful review.I am really glad that he told authors how to deal with negative reviews. It is MY personal belief that if there is a number rating system,that a reviewer can rate the book honestly; and it is their right to explain why it was not for them and why they rated it 1, 2 or 3 without fear of retaliation.I had a very bad experience with a disgruntled author just lately. I gave a 1. Then I wrote that the "foods you love" cookbook was mostly seafood recipes which was not for me but, people who do will love it. This author wrote a nasty comment that his/her book deserved a high rating because I said that it is a good cookbook for seafood lovers. Two "others" wrote nearly identical reviews within minutes of the author's. I was supposed to be intimidated. That author acted like a schoolyard bully instead of a working professional. Shouldn't they be held up to the same standards as others?I look to read books that I would like. I don't give out 1-3 very often, because I have good intuition about great reads. The book above had a title that was not represented in the pages. That was not my fault. There was no mention of seafood in the description, either. I was relieved to read advice to authors who get their feelings hurt if someone gives constructive criticism. That should be on Amazon's list of no no's also. Authors and their friends should be prohibited from bullying because a reviewer, any reviewer rates 1-5, indicative of their own like or not, with honest, polite, constructive advice.As a book lover and trying to help others like me (I read reviews before I buy, also), I try to review the book as soon as I can while everything is still fresh in my mind. I do review ALL BOOKS that anyone gives me to read and review. I may have several ahead of that one.Please take Mr but please don't send emails every other day "reminding" me, please. Like Mr. Foster explained, not everyone will be willing to give a positive review, if any at all. I absolutely gained a lot of information as a reviewer. I recommend this to any writer or reviewer who want to improve their writing.

I chose this book by intuition; and am I ever glad I did. I had a deja vu experience 1/4 into the book, I could have sworn I have read it before a very long time ago. However, the story is broken up into different times in the life of Jack McGuire and people close to him. These are not "flashbacks", and they don't confuse the reader. They add to the book (like pieces of a puzzle)..... so he is a child with a brother on a farm in Nebraska and they both get the flying bug from a neighbor. Jack goes to flight school and meets his best war buddy, Don. After the war, Jack is still on the island where he was stationed. A lovely lady comes for a few days, and Jack can't get her out of his mind...... but the chapters are broken up into different times of his life: to make the story so much more interesting that a straight, linear storyline. The book continues to get better and better to the very end. Heikki Hietala (from Finland), with the help of others, researched what it was like for REAL WWII veterans who shared their recollections. It took 12 years for him to write his first novel. He hit this one completely out of the park! I took forever reading it. Then I knew why....I loved the plot, the characters, the intrigue, and wanted to know what was going to happen next. I wanted to experience every little nuance, the ambiance of the island in the South Pacific, where the pilots had to constantly have dogfights with the Japanese planes in the air. Who wouldn't come back to base. It is so "human", if I may use that word. It is not a stale book. He has given tons of thought to put into his words. They flow so well. It transports you directly into Jack's world as it really would have happened. There is no macho, over the top characters or unbelievable action adventure. It doesn't need it. Real life is enough. The main theme of the story is that the only real thing you get out of life is memories, so make as many of them as you can. Nothing else matters as much as those. *NetGalley and Fingerpress Publishers gave me a copy of this book to read and give my honest review.

Cat Stevens' Izitso was first released in April 1977 on A & M Records here in the States. It was his first album after Numbers which wasn't the big seller that his previous albums on A & M had been. Cat teamed up to work on Izitso with co-producer David Kershenbaum. The album being recorded in several different locations, a wide variety of backing musicians such as Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section and even jazz legend Chick Corea pops up on here. The album brings in synthesizers which are generally used to create a lush contemporary sound although he does experiment with them as well here and there. It's the strongest overall batch of songs that Cat's turned in on a single album since Teaser and the Firecat in my opinion. The remastering on the 2000 version is great.

In early 1994, King Crimson reformed the 1980's lineup while adding Trey Gunn and Pat Mastelotto who'd worked with Robert Fripp and David Sylvian. They began working on material at Applehead Studios in Woodstock, New York which led to the VROOOM ep which in turn led to The VROOOM sessions cd in the Collector's Club. It's now compiled here as Maximum VROOOM. The new lineup would begin touring Argentina at the end of September before going into Peter Gabriel's Real World Studios in Bath in late October.  B'Boom Live in Argentina would document some of those shows and is included as Hi-Res stereo on the dvd and blu ray while outtakes from Real World show up as JurassiKc THRAK and EPK THRAK.  THRAK was first released in April 1995 (actually it's the 2002 remaster featured along with the 2015 re-imagining) with the Double Trio lineup beginning it's tour on May 1st spending most of the next two years touring the UK, US and several shows in Mexico.The THRAK box contains three "best of" sets of the band's multi night runs in London (Kcensington THRAK), New York (New YorKc THRAK which is pretty much the On Broadway Collector's Club release) from 1995 and Mexico (AzteKc THRAK) in 1996 mixed from the multi track tapes. The box also features a previously unreleased video of a show at the Warfield in San Francisco although the first couple of numbers are missing. The Deja VROOOM video is also here remastered along with a new feature called Tony's Road Movies. ATTAKcATHRAK is a new and improved version of THRAKaTTaK. Bite Size THRAK includes the single edits along with 4 songs from the Nashville Sessions in 1997 which marked the end of the Double Trio lineup. The box is loaded with the usual ton of extras (big book, posters and so on). There are also High Res rips of all the stuff spread out over the dvds and blu rays. The only drawback for me here is that this is the first KC box to not include a full performance on disc. I probably would've included all of the Mexico shows on cd here as there still not currently available in their entirety on DGM Live.

Yes' fourth album Fragile was first released in the UK in November 1971 and January 1972 in the US. If you're reading this then you already know that this is one of the best albums ever recorded. To me, previous cd editions all fell a little short of the original album's sound. The one that worked the best for me was the MoFi version but even that felt a little off. I think Steven Wilson has really nailed it here and the sound is fantastic. The Blu Ray audio also includes the new mix in stereo and surround sound, the original mix, a needle drop from the first pressing as well as the 2002 dvd-a mix. This release is also loaded with bonus tracks of early versions, single edits as well as a nice reproduction of the original booklet, archive photos and liner notes from Sid Smith.

The new Elements box is a lot like the old one in that it's mostly made up of stuff that has appeared in the box sets, 40th Anniversary Editions and Mr. Stormy's Monday Selections. Whereas the first one sort of focused a bit more on the 1969 to 1974 era, this one focuses a bit more on the Adrian era as well as including a couple of things from the current lineup. The set opens up with the Wind Excerpt and an instrumental version of Epitaph. It's the one on the first album with the vocal track removed. Cat Food is actually a nice instrumental studio run through with the players working the song out. Bolero is the version from Frame By Frame that has Gordon Haskell's bass parts replaced by Tony Levin. From Islands, we get a studio orchestra run through of an instrumental Islands and A Peacemaking Stint Unrolls. Larks' II is on USA and The Road to Red while Fracture is from The Road to Red.Next up is the guitar extract from One More Red Nightmare which leads directly into the Live at the Orpheum version. The first disc is rounded out with the 12" dance mix of Elephant Talk, an instrumental take of the unfinished song Absent Lovers from Beat and a nice instrumental that would become part of Sleepless and Larks' III from the Three of a Perfect Pair album. The second disc relies largely on THRAK, The ProjeKcts, The Power to Believe and the new lineup with a few other things mixed in. It's also nice to have a couple of more songs from 2004 and 2008 on cd. There's a nice flow to the set and it works well as a compilation. It's a nice addition to any Crimheads collection.

"The Grateful Dead are putting out an 80 disc box set, yeah 80 disc! No info on what Grateful Dead song it will be." - Conan O'Brien 06-02-15For $700.00, there are some criticisms that I want to get out of the way up front. The sleeves that hold the cds aren't so good. They're thin and they look like they could end up scratching the discs. It's hard to get the cds out without leaving fingerprints. They are not digi packs with holders in them. They're the kind that you actually have to slide the cds out. I would've preferred them dropping the scroll in favor of better sleeves that actually hold the cds. Some of the disc splits aren't great as well. On the 1981 show, the disc split is between Sailor/Saint and the Caution jam that flows out of it instead of at the beginning of Drums or between Drums/Space. The '88 and '95 shows could've fit on two discs without any fades between Drums and Space.  Not all the shows are upgrades to what currently circulates. 10-27-79 actually sounds poor compared to the last remaster from a couple of years ago that circulates for free on certain torrent sites which is pitch/speed corrected.On the plus side, shows like 11-10-67, 09-24-72, 10-03-76 (although it's a bit edited because the drums is missing from the sbd so there's an additional edit to try and make it seemless), 10-12-84 and 10-26-89 have never sounded better than they do to me here. 11-10-67 and 10-26-89 are mixed from professionally recorded multi tracks. The box is great looking and the show selection is also very good too. Granted, you can always wonder why they picked x show over y show but that's always the case in the situation where you can only pick one show from each year. Am I happy to have it? Yes. Would I be willing to purchase another box costing this much or more? No. I feel that it's successful in some ways but I'm not entirely won over either. For $700.00, each show should be the definitive version of each show but unfortunately, that isn't always the case here.

Cirkus was first released around the Summer of 1999 and is a compilation of Fripp's picks from the live material that had been released up to that point in time. The first disc focuses on the band's more recent era including a bit of the ProjeKcts while the second disc focuses on the earlier era. The songs are edited in such a way as to flow in and out of each other or begin as soon as the other one ends. The main problem is that, on the first disc, in particular, all the song choices are given to the band's heaviest songs while omitting songs like Matte Kudasai, Discipline and Exiles. It makes the release sound a little one dimensional and even a bit fatiguing in spots. Great versions of great songs but a little more variation would've made it even better.

Highlights was first released in late 1993 and marks the third Yes compilation in three years. 1991 gave us the cool box set Yesyears and 1992 gave us the best of two cd set Yesstory. This is basically the 2 and a 1/2 hour Yesstory edited down to about an hour on one disc. The only song here that isn't on Yesstory is Leave It. Given the fact that the band's back catalog was also getting ready to be re-released in remastered editions in 1994, this did feel like the label was sticking it to the fans. To be fair, this collection does seem more geared to the causal listener than the rabid fan. This was the release that you tended to see at places like Copperfield's, Barnes & Noble or other non record stores in the mall in the pre-Starbucks era.

Classic Yes was put together by Chris Squire (RIP Fishy) and first released in time for Christmas of 1981. It was a single album along with a 45 rpm single. The main album consists of songs from the albums: The Yes Album, Fragile, Close to the Edge and Going For the One. The single was two unreleased live performances of I've Seen All Good People and Roundabout which were holdovers from the previous year's Yesshows which was also released in time for Christmas. They also now appear on the expanded and remastered version of Yesshows. The total time for the disc with both the album and single make the disc run about an hour which isn't bad at all for the days of vinyl.As far as single disc compilations go, this is one of the best ones on the market as far as I'm concerned. It's not as career spanning as say the single disc Highlights: The Very Best Of Yes but it hangs together better. Remember that the earlier stuff had also already been covered on Yesterdays which is the other great single disc collection. This one is more focused on the band's Progressive era and even has some of Roger Dean's best artwork. This is also one of the only official Yes comps to include live versions of a couple of songs which I really like. At the time when this was first released, Yes was broken up so there was an air of finality about this album at least for me. I have the other cd releases of this but recently I was a buck or two short on free shipping so I ordered the newest release of it on Rhino Flashback and it's still the 1994 remaster that's being used.

Yesstory was first released in 1992 and is a slimmed down "greatest hits" highlights release of the Yesyears box eliminating pretty much all of the rarities. This compilation runs from the band's first album all the up to and including Big Generator covering the band's Atlantic/Atco era in the order they were released. The majority of the material here is from the band's "Classic Era" from 1969 through 1978. Owner Of A Lonely Heart and Rhythm Of Love are the only songs representing the '80's as nothing from Drama is included.The set itself is put together very well for the most part and runs about 2 and a 1/2 hours. The release opens with the rare stereo version of Something's Coming as well as some of the band's longer songs Close To The Edge and Ritual as well as Roundabout, I've Seen All Good People, Starship Trooper, Heart Of The Sunrise, Time And A Word, Yours Is No Disgrace and Wonderous Stories. The only drawback, at least for me, is that no live songs make the cut. Still, this is a good overview of the band and certainly better than next year's Highlights: The Best Of Yes. Mine's the old factory pressed cd set so I have no idea about the cd-r version that Amazon is now selling.

This is a pretty good performance from near the end of the band's Three Album Tour although Close To The Edge is omitted from this release. I'm not sure if it was actually played that night as there were a few shows on that tour that were slimmed down due to time constraints. The performances here are pretty good although they feel a little "draggy" in spots to me. This was the first tour to feature the song A Venture and it's played well here. Perhaps because they were nearing the end of a tour, the band sounds a little tired compared to some of the other performances I've heard from this tour. For me, it's actually songs like Turn of the Century that turn out the best here.

I really don't have a burning scalp but this works well and gives my hair a bit of a refreshed look. I don't know that I would've bought this on my own but now that I've tried it. I might pick it up from time to time.

Belkin is a great company that makes low priced accessories for computers and mp 3 players. The quality is always good and it does the job well. The privacy screen works great at blocking out the view from the sides and angles so others can't see everything that your doing. Like all the other Belkin products that I own, it does the job well.

I still remember when this was first released around Thanksgiving '91. I was in Tower Records, saw that King Crimson had a box set and ran to the check stand without even looking to see what was on it. The box was a pretty good collection at the time including things like the single version of Cat Food/Groon which had previously only been available on A Young Person's Guide which never made it to cd in the U.S.. There was some legal stuff that had gone on with Gordon Haskell so Cadence And Cascade has a new vocal track recorded by Adrian Belew (this is still currently the only place that you can find this version) and Bolero with Tony Levin on bass (now an extra on 40th Anniversary of Lizard). The King Crimson Barber Shop makes it's first appearance here and on top of this, we get a whole disc of previously unreleased live stuff.The drawback about this set, for me are the edits that are used instead of the whole songs. It isn't too bad on the first disc (the improv after Moonchild is edited out and the first couple of seconds of cymbals on Sailor's Tale) but the second disc suffers much more. About half of Fracture is edited out and about two third's of Starless. Starless ends after the vocal section and Larks' Tongues in Aspic Part I is abridged as well. All the discs here run under the maximum playing time even by 1991 standards. Had this been laid out a bit differently, we could've avoided a couple of the edits. I would've like to have seen the live stuff mixed into the discs into their proper eras in the set among the rest of the music. For example, the live stuff from the first Crim after the In the Court songs and so on. The booklet and family tree are nice but everything from here minus Adrian's Cadence are available elsewhere.

After The Present was released in late Summer of 1983, Decca was bought out by Polygram Records. The band began to shop around for a new producer and settled on Tony Visconti. The first album of new material on the new label would be The Other Side of Life released in April 1986 which is the first disc in this set. The album finds the band shedding it's more orchestral flavor for the more contemporary sound of drum machines and sequencers. This would also be the first album that founding member Ray Thomas wouldn't get a single song in 20+ years of recording. The album boasted the big hits Your Wildest Dreams and The Other Side of Life. Other standouts for me are Running Out of Love, Slings and Arrows and It May Be a Fire. This was the first digital recording that the band did and had never been remastered until now. The remastering is a major improvement. As an added bonus we get single edits as well as live versions that were b sides which have never made a cd appearance until now.The second disc in the set is a previously unreleased performance from July 8th, 1986 The Blossom Music Centre in Cleveland, Ohio on The Other Side of Life tour. The disc is fairly full and there are a couple of other songs from this show that are the live single b sides bonus songs on The Other Side of Life. If you add all the songs up from this show, you get about 85 minutes from the two hour concert. If you want to put them in performance order, it should be: Gemini Dream, The Voice, Rock 'N' Roll Over You, Tuesday Afternoon, Your Wildest Dreams, Isn't Life Strange, The Story In Your Eyes, It May Be A Fire, Veteran Cosmic Rocker, The Other Side Of Life, I'm Just A Singer, Nights In White Satin, Legend Of A Mind and Question. It was also one of the first tours where the band brought along additional musicians. I've had this box since it was first released a few months ago and this is a performance that I keep going back to.The remaster of Sur la Mer kicks off the third disc which features the hits I Know You're Out There Somewhere as well as No More Lies and Vintage Wine. It was first released in early Summer 1988. Unfortunately, for me, I find this album less successful overall than The Other Side of Life although some really seem to like this one so your mileage may vary. Ray doesn't appear on the album at all, and the imput from both Graeme and Patrick is less as well. The album feels even more awash in harsh digital sampling sounds. The bonus songs are the single edits of I Know You're Out There Somewhere, No More Lies, Al Fin Voy A Encontrarte (which is I Know You're Out There Somewhere in Spanish) as well as the re-recordings of Question and Isn't Life Strange that appeared on The Moody Blues Greatest Hits. This box also includes a blue colored vinyl single of Al Fin Voy A Encontrarte.The next disc features Keys of the Kingdom which was first released in June 1991. Patrick Moraz had become dissatisfied with his role in the band. He was unhappy that the band kept passing on his songs and he felt that the music was becoming too simplistic. The whole thing ended in a law suit. The band also went through a number of producers during the album's making. Drummer Graeme Edge only appears on three songs while the rest of the sessions are handled by session drummer Andy Duncan or a drum machine. On the plus side, Ray Thomas makes his first appearance since The Present eight years earlier. While the album isn't entirely successful either, it does have a number of good songs like: Say It With Love, Bless the Wings, Is This Heaven?, Lean on Me (Tonight), Hope and Prey and Celtic Sonet. The song Highway should've been included on the original release but is here as one of the bonus songs. There's also a US promo edit of Bless the Wings as well as a few songs recorded for BBC Radio One.The final two discs and the two dvds are given to the band's A Night at Red Rocks with the Colorado Symphony Orchestra release which was recorded September 9th, 1992 in Colorado. This was recorded during the era where the band was doing shows with symphony orchestras and people seem split on it. I happen to like it but for some others, it can be a bit much.

I love this era, as do many other King Crimson fans but I do think this box could have been done slightly better. Shows like 4-9-73 Olympia in Paris, 6-16-73 Community Theatre in Berkeley and 6-23-73 Richards Club in Atlanta aren't included even though Doctor Diamond appears on the Audio Curios disc. All three of these shows are available as official downloads from DGMLive and I've had them for years. They also didn't bother to include the unedited version of The Night Watch from 10-23-73 The Apollo in Glasgow even though it's available on the download version of the concert. I already have the entire concert downloaded but it would've been nice to include both the edited and unedited version here on disc. The 3-30-74 Elzer Hof in Mainz show ends with a jam of Easy Money -> Fracture-> Larks' II but the soundboard cuts early into Fracture. In the past, they've always grafted the audience on to the soundboard to make it complete and it still would've fit all on one disc but unfortunately, they didn't do that this time. This means that if you want to hear the entire show, you have to switch between two different discs and deal with overlap. The audience portion is here but on the Audio Curios disc. All in all, a mostly perfect release but just a little short of a five star review. I've had this since it was released a few months ago and these flaws still bug me.

Like others, I was hoping for a longer release, There were a lot of great songs that were played on the tour that didn't make this release like Larks' Tongues in Aspic Part I, Pictures of a City and even A Scarcity of Miracles. Still, what made the release is generally very good and the sound quality is a good as it gets but it does make me wish we had more. One More Red Nightmare made it's first ever live appearance during this tour and it's a real knockout. Other standouts are The Letters, Sailor's Tale and Starless. This is definitely a must have if you're a King Crimson fan.

This Tourbox is better than the 2008 40th Anniversary Tourbox which was better than the The Power to Believe Tourbox. I still feel that they could've given us more especially considering the price. I would've like to have seen this actually expanded to three discs. Still, what is here is pretty good. If you've bought the newest remasters, Collector's Club releases, box sets and kept up with Mr. Stormy's Monday Selections then there really isn't much here that you don't already have. However, this set still packs a nice punch. I've had it since it was first released and I find myself listening to it fairly often even though I pretty much already have everything elsewhere.

I actually ended up really liking this book. There's been so much written on the Grateful Dead in the last 20 or so years that I've pretty much stopped keeping up. We've had books written from the merchandising perspective and we've even had books written by Dead Heads on what it feels like to be a Dead Head. That's not to say that there hasn't been some excellent books written on the band but there's also been a lot that feel written just to "cash in" on the band's popularity. Bill's book is actually quite interesting and provides a fresh perspective on his life and times with the band. Bill was always more of the quiet one and never really seemed to do as many interviews as the rest of the guys so it's really cool to read his perspective on things. If you're a fan, then this is a must read.

In February 1974, The Grateful Dead played three shows at Winterland on the weekend of Friday 22nd to Sunday the 24th. The band was working on songs that would end up on their next studio album From The Mars Hotel which would be released on June 27th. Several of these songs as well as It Must Have Been the Roses make their first appearances during this run. The Saturday show would mark the last appearance Here Comes Sunshine until December 1992. These shows would also a more practical purpose: to raise money to help Keith and Donna buy their own home. Donna had their first kid in December and the money from this run helped them buy a house.The first set opens with U.S. Blues, a song that had first been introduced the previous year in a different arrangement as Wave That Flag before dropping out of the set lists in April. U.S. Blues debuted on Friday night. The rest of the first set is given to extremely well played standards at the time before giving way to a massive set ending Playing In The Band. The second set opens with a ripping Cumberland Blues, a jammed out Weather Report into a cool Row Jimmy with great versions of new songs It Must Have Been the Roses and Ship Of Fools. The second set includes a massive 45 minute Dark Star->Morning Dew while the encore is the first It's All Over Now, Baby Blue since September 1972.
My wife wanted these and so I picked them up for her. She's very happy and says that they look even better in person than they do here on Amazon.

The problem with this collection is that it tries to shove too much into 2 cds as a retrospective. Yes generally recorded long songs and with 19 studio albums, there's just no way to do it decently. The band also has several great live albums but none of it is used here. So, what we get here are a few songs that are edits. It would have been nice if they'd just used other songs if they couldn't have fit the whole songs on here or as the 3rd disc is rehearsals of acoustic Yes stuff and it's fairly short. It would have been better to stick this stuff at the end of the 3rd disc and stretch out the stuff on the first couple of discs which wouldn't have ended in edited versions. They would've also been able to stick a couple more songs on the set and make it more filling.

The cover artwork is a patch of album covers like This Is The Moody Blues and Utopia Anthology. I like all the songs here but it really does seem like an unnecessary collection even back in the late '90's. There's nothing particularly rare while songs like And You & I, Siberian Khatru and Owner of a Lonely Heart have already appeared on numerous other collections. If you interested in a small concise collection, you're better off with the 2 cd set Wonderous Stories: The Best of Yes

This is a budget priced release made up of Moody Bluegrass (2004) and Two Much Love (2011) on Bunny Rae Records and distributed by Red River Entertainment. I think that both of the original releases might still be available individually as I saw them not that long ago still being sold somewhere. The packaging for this two cd version is really cheap. The songs are generally well done and the second disc Two Much Love has Justin, John, Graeme and Mike guesting on different songs. There are a few spots where it turns into sort of generic bluegrass. A few big names turn up here including Peter Rowan. In fact, the version of It's Cold Outside Of Your Heart would appear on Justin's Spirits album which was being recorded around the time that this was. If you like the Moodies and like bluegrass, it's a cool listen.

Monday, October 23, 1978 found Utopia turning up at the Electric Ballroom in Milwaukee for an electrifying performance. This release comes from a cassette of an FM broadcast probably a generation or two removed from the master. Each disc is around the 45 minute mark. Still, the sound quality is quite good considering that. The set list is also typical for the era. There are a few typical flaws with on the fly live recordings of this nature such as the mike on the piano not being switched on for It Wouldn't Have Made Any Difference. The performance is quite energetic and this release is a treasure.

I received this as a birthday present back in July '13. I'd already spent a bunch on the pre-order for the big box version of Timeless Flight so a friend picked this up for me. The album starts off with the song In Your Blue Eyes and you just know it's going to be good when it starts off like this. The album has a more down to earth feel than View From the Hill and, I think, it benefits as a result. Part of that more than likely comes from that part of the album was recorded around the sessions that Justin did for the Moody Bluegrass Two Much Love in 2011. That has since re-released with both volumes as a 2 cd set with different artwork. If fact, the remake of It's Cold Outside Of Your Heart here first appeared there. All in all, a near perfect release.

The cd soundtrack to the blu ray/dvd release. This was recorded on the tour for Justin's Spirits of the Western Sky tour last year and features Justin with Mike Dawes on second guitar, keyboardist/vocalists Alan Hewitt and Julie Ragins. Both Alan and Julie are currently with The Moodies as well. The sound is a bit stripped down and works quite well as a result. There are quite a few standouts such as the medley of It's Up To You/Lovely To See You, The Land Of Make Believe, The Western Sky, New Horizons, One Day Someday and It's Cold Outside Of Your Heart. This is a really good performance and I really like the stripped down feel. I just hope Justin follows this up with a sequel doing other songs that don't appear here.

This release is from a show recorded on Friday December 12, 1969 at a place that was briefly called the Thelma which little is known about. It was located on the Sunset Strip near the Whiskey. I knew someone up until about 8 months ago who caught the band quite a few times between 1966 and 1972 in the area and he couldn't remember the place (hey Gary H. if you read this). This was the third show in a three night stand with Steve Stills showing up at the first show on the 10th. Various parts of these shows have shown up in trading circles for decades. Even odder is that while some of the songs on the audience versions match the soundboard versions, others do not.As for this show itself, the first 45 minutes were missing from the vault for many years although a passable version turned up in trader's circles a few years back. The show opens with a grooving Cold, Rain and Snow and a rocking Me And My Uncle. Both Easy Wind and Next Time You See Me are taken at a slow pace with Pig and Jerry singing harmony on Next Time. There are great early versions of newer songs like Black Peter, Dire Wolf, High Time, Casey Jones and the newish combo of China Cat Sunflower>I Know You Rider mixed in with older songs like He Was A Friend Of Mine. The show is brought to a screeching finale with a massive jam of Alligator>Caution>Feedback>We Bid You Goodnight. If you were fortunate enough to get the bonus disc subscription, then you have massive versions of Dark Star>Saint Stephen>The Eleven>Cumberland Blues and That's It For The Other One>Cosmic Charlie. If you missed that, head over to a torrent site and download the circulating copy of that show!

Built To Last was first released on Halloween of 1989. To be honest, looking back it was pretty clear that there were going to be problems from the start. The wonderful Stanley Mouse cover art was rejected for this cover. The band also recorded most of the album in isolation from each other. The original recording sessions began at Marin Vets just as they had for their last album "In The Dark". Jerry and John Cutler were producing again. They quickly decided that the same approach wouldn't work and the recording sessions began getting moved around to various studios. The album was finally finished just a couple of hours before it was to be turned in. Unlike some, I like most of the songs but the problem for me here, as with Shakedown Street and Go To Heaven, is not the songs themselves but in the actual production. Jerry referred to it as "confined space" but to me it sounds more like "confined void". Despite this being a high end recording, the overall mix is actually very hollow and synthetic sounding.The opening Foolish Heart is actually a very good song but it fades out before the beautiful closing jam which was usually great in concert. Just A Little Light is actually one of, if not, my favorite Brent songs. Unfortunately, here it doesn't have the cool synth introduction or the nice extra little jam near the end that the live versions have. Built To Last is another great song but here it's played so slow that it's plodding. Blow Away was a really good song until they decided to rearrange it in an over the top manner in typical late '80's style. Victim Or The Crime is actually one of the two songs that benefits from the albums production style. Musically, the song always had a Twilight Zone feel to it and that actually pays off here. I guess that there are some Dead Heads who didn't/don't like this song but I do. We Can Run is okay but once again, the keyboard isn't used starting instead with a very brief Jerry intro. The lyrics also sound a bit heavy handed as if they're trying to shove them into the song. Standing On The Moon is a Jerry ballad and it comes across very well here and is the only song to use an acoustic instrument (aside from drums) in the mix. Jerry's acoustic guitar give the album a very earthy feel missing elsewhere in the album. Bob's Picasso Moon is a nice rocking song and it's given a decent treatment here. I'm not a fan of I Will Take You Home and it's actually my least favorite Dead song. Some people find it sweet but it's just too much for me. Your mileage will vary. All in all, the album sounds very much like it was recorded in 1989 for 1989. It manages to capture a lot of what I didn't like about the late '80's production style.This expanded cd version includes three extra live songs: Blow Away (which is from the show that would later be released as Crimson White & Indigo), an okay Foolish Heart (which was recorded during the run that would later be released as Downhill From Here although Foolish Heart isn't on Downhill), and the song California Earthquake which was played twice on the Fall tour after the San Francisco Earthquake of 1989.

Friday, November 17th 1972 found the Dead playing what would be their only show in Wichita, Kansas at the Century II Convention Hall. This show has circulated for years in less than stellar sound quality but here we FINALLY get it in all of it's remastered and uncut glory. The sound quality is even better than I thought it would be and the performance is a real barn burner.Everything in the first set has that extra little kick to it and pretty much everything is a standout performance. I would be remiss if I didn't at least mention Sugaree, Me And My Uncle, Tennessee Jed, Black-Throated Wind, Bird Song, Jack Straw, Box Of Rain, Don't Ease Me In and China Cat->Rider.  The second set features great versions of Cumberland Blues, He's Gone and a massive jam of Truckin'->The Other One->Brokedown Palace. To top it all off, there's even a nice bit of filler on here from November 15th at the Oklahoma Music Hall that includes a 30 minute Playing In The Band and Wharf Rat, among others.

The Veterans Hall in Sebastopol is a small, lovely place to see a show. It's next to Forestville and the Russian River. The place is beautiful and surrounded by trees and hills. Did anyone else attend the Dead Dances there in the '90's? Kathleen, are you out there? On Wednesday, March 22, 1978 both Robert Hunter's band Comfort and the Jerry Garcia Band played a show there. The band at the time consisted of Jerry, John Kahn, Keith & Donna Godchaux, Maria Muldaur and Buzz Buchanan. There's also a guest appearance by future member Ozzie Ahlers (who was playing in Comfort at the time) who would replace Keith & Donna in the JGB. The band came rolling back into the Bay Area after a tour supporting the new Cats Under The Stars album.The first set features a well played set of standards for the JGB at the time with the standouts, for me, being Catfish John, A Simple Twist of Fate and The Night They Drove Old Dixie Down. The second set is even better featuring a great Mission In The Rain as well as the then new original Cats songs' Cats Under The Stars, Gomorrah and Love In The Afternoon. Mystery Train and Midnight Moonlight are excellent as well although the tape does run out before the end of Midnight Moonlight. Another great release and one of the better ones in the series although maybe next time, we can get a Reuben And Cherise and Rhapsody In Red.

Like most of the other reviewers here, I'm a massive Yes fan having bought all the albums in several different formats ranging from Vinyl to remastered Imports. I've spent massive amounts on solo albums and side projects as well as box sets and compilation releases. I grew up with albums like The Yes Album and Fragile.  I can usually find stuff that I really like on even the less successful albums like Union and Open Your Eyes. I even LOVED their last album Fly From Here so I know that they still have it in them. However, Heaven & Earth is the first Yes album where nothing really stands out and everything is just pretty much forgettable. I've given it multiple listens and everything just sounds flat and uninspired to me. The band sounds incredibly sluggish throughout the album.It's hard for me to "Believe Again" when it sounds like the band have lost the belief themselves. I read an interview with Steve Howe a few months ago and the impression I get is that this album was put together very quickly. Perhaps more time should have been spent on writing and recording this album. The album is produced by Roy Thomas Baker who was a really famous producer in the '70's for mostly producing "bubble gum" pop/rock. To me, the album sounds like a bland Yes cover band with actual members of Yes on it.

Steve Howe's third solo album, Turbulence, was recorded in 1989 and released in 1991 on Relativity Records. It an album of instrumentals generally recorded with a trio of musicians featuring Bill Bruford playing on most of the album. The album is about 38 minutes and all the songs are very good. Songs like Corkscrew have even turned up in Steve's solo spots in Yes shows. The album is more upbeat that some of Steve's later solo albums and the songs generally move with a fast pace. The album tends to bypass Steve's more country and bluegrass stuff in favor of mostly all rocking songs. The album doesn't quite have the range of some of his other albums as a result. If you like Steve's more rocking stuff, you'll like this.

Jon's second solo album, Song Of Seven, was first released on Atlantic Records in November 1980. I picked up my first copy around Christmas time in a Woolworth's. I still remember sitting at the soda fountain and drinking an old fashioned coke while I checked out the back cover. This was Jon's first solo album after leaving Yes the year before. In fact, several of the songs were written as possible Yes songs. I actually think that the majority of the album is actually quite strong although some of my Yes friends at the time didn't seem to care too much for it. Looking at some of the other reviews here I can see that there are some who feel the same. Still, I like it and the Wounded Bird cd that I've had for a few years sounds real good to me.

Steve Howe's Quantum Guitar was first released in April 1998 on Resurgence and clocks in at about 60 minutes. I first picked this up a while back and this has become one of my "go to" Steve Howe albums. The album begins with a cool cover of Walk Don't Run and pretty much features one stand out song after another. There's also a great cover of Sleep Walk on here. The album is pretty much one great song after another. This used to be fairly common but it looks like it might becoming a bit rarer so you may want to pick this up for a good price while you can.

At the end of 1980, Yes was disbanded with Chris Squire putting together the retrospective albums Yesshows and Classic Yes early the next year. Both Chris and Alan White began working on projects together and even released the single Run with the Fox in December 1981 while Steve Howe went on to join Asia. South African guitarist/keyboardist/vocalist solo artist Trevor Rabin, who had released several solo albums, was looking to join a band. At one point, he even auditioned for Asia and it was during this time that he met Chris and Alan. The three of them began a group that was to be called Cinema after the title of a side long song that they had worked up for the project in 1982. Former Yes member Trevor Horn was brought in to produce. During the recording sessions, they decided that they needed a full time keyboardist for the band. It was during this point that both Chris and Trevor discovered that they had another mutual friend in original Yes keyboardist Tony Kaye. As the recording sessions were nearing completion, former Yes singer Jon Anderson, was brought in to help with the singing duties and Yes ended up being reborn. The song Cinema would end up in a very edited form on the record while the album ended up being named after it's original catalog number 90125.90125 was first released in November 1983 and marked a massive departure from the band's more progressive sound into a early 1980's pop sound which put off some older fans. To be honest, management's idea of having the band sporting Member's Only jackets and hiring Cyndi Lauper's hairdresser for Chris didn't help didn't help older fans impressions. I've seen interviews with the band members' later claim that they felt embarrassed by it. Even the artwork was of it's time and a shift away from the Roger Dean era artwork. The album would become a massive hit for the band and bring in scores of new fans. Songs Owner of a Lonely Heart, Hold On, Leave It and It Can Happen were all over the radio and MTV at the time. While I generally prefer the band's more progressive stuff, there's no denying that this is a very good early 1980's pop record. In fact, it's one of the best mainstream records of the early 1980's.

Marathon was first released in September 1979 and is produced by Keith Olsen, David De Vore and Santana. The album features new members Alex Ligertwood taking Greg Walker's spot on vocals while Alan Pasqua takes over for Chris Rhyne on keyboards. The album takes on a late '70's pop feel with a bit of Earth Wind & Fire. As a result, the album is a bit hit and miss but does include the good songs such as Marathon, the classic Aqua Marine, You Know That I Love You, All I Ever Wanted and Stay (Beside Me). Bumped up from 3 stars to 4 for Aqua Marine.

Festival was first released in January 1977 and is produced by David Rubinson who had produced the band's last album, Amigos. The majority of Festival is quite strong and starts out with a cool run of Carnaval/Let The Children Play/Jugando. Leon Patillo returns and takes the vocal spot handled on Amigos by Greg Walker. Gaylord Birch takes over on the drums from Leon "Ndugu" Chancler. There are also quite a few other standouts like Revelations and The River. The album also features guest appearances from Maxine and Julia Waters. Overall, a really good album that's not to be missed.

Santana's Shango was first released in early August 1982 with Bill Szymczyk as it's main producer. The album also marks a brief return of Gregg Rolie who had left Journey not too long before. Good songs, for me, are The Nile, Nueva York, Oxun, Let Me Inside, Warrior and Shango. The main problem with Shango is that the good songs don't really standout. Even Santana's weaker albums usually manage to pack a couple of classics on them. Shango seems to be the exception to the rule although The Nile is very close.

Inner Secrets was recorded in the Summer of 1978 and released that Fall. Tom Coster wasn't in the band although he does co produce this with Carlos. New members include: Chris Solberg, Chris Rhyne who took over keyboards from Tom and Armando Peraza. Santana had been heading back to a more mainstream sound since the end of his Jazz era which ended with Borboletta. At the time that Inner Secrets was released, AOR Rock, Funk and Disco were what was in fashion. The band downplays it's Latin and African roots for a more mainstream radio friendly sound. That's not to say that this album doesn't have it's moments. In fact, I like about half the album. Not their strongest album but it does have some good stuff. By the way, the Japan import has the original version of One Chain while the domestic copies have the "Dance Mix".

The late 1980's were an odd time for Santana. They weren't selling real well and the newer, more modern sounding pop albums weren't selling well with older fans. Both Blues for Salvador and Viva Santana did well by comparison and there was even a reunion tour featuring the early members that went over well as did the tour with Wayne Shorter. The band had been getting hard pressed by the label for quite a while to have a hit song. Spirits Dancing In The Flesh was released in June 1990 and is produced by Carlos Santana, Vernon Reid, Chester Thompson, Jim Gaines. The production style used here reminds me of Quincy Jones a bit. The band itself is back down to a six piece with new members Walfredo Reyes, Jr. and Benny Rietveld. The album features quite a few guests including a church choir on the title track. Like the last couple of albums by the band, this has some really good songs but it sounds a bit over produced for my taste. This is also the third Santana album in a row to feature a Curtis Mayfield cover. The album would be the last for Columbia Records.

Carlos' third solo album was released in the Summer of 1980 features people like Herbie Hancock and Wayne Shorter joining Carlos. The album was released as a short two record set clocking in at about sixty minutes. As you might've guessed, the album has a very jazzy feel. While the band Santana was drifting towards a more pop sound, Carlos was using his solo albums during this time to explore in a more diverse direction. All the songs here are great and I love the jazz feel. The album is full of life and spirit unlike a couple of the Santana band albums of the mid 1980's.

This was released on the heels of the 10th anniversary of the Dicks Picks series and we were getting ready to hit 30. This was originally released around Christmas time with Grateful Dead - The Closing of Winterland Closing of Winterland: December 31 1978 which made it a rather expensive Christmas having to buy gifts for an ex AND myself, laughs. I had 5-19-77 on tape for decades and had 5-21-77 for almost as long. The first show was the second show of a two night stand at the Fox in Atlanta, GA and the other being from Lakeland Civic Center in Lakeland, FL which is the night before Dick's Picks, Vol. 3: Sportatorium, Pembroke Pines, FL, 5/22/77.5-19-77 (Thursday):The first set gets off the a rousing start with a ripping Promised Land before giving way to a killer Sugaree->El Paso. Peggy-O is a pretty number and it's played very sweetly here. Looks Like Rain finds Bob and Donna in good voice backed by some thoughtful playing from the band. Row Jimmy is a song I'm always happy to here and this one doesn't dissappoint. Passenger find Bob and Donna upping the energy with a rocker. Not to be outdone, Jerry returns the play with a soaring solo in Loser. The Dancin' In The Streets would melt the floor at Studio 54.The second set opens with a rip the roof off Samson And Delilah. Ramble On Rose sounds like a Gypsy caravan and Estimated Prophet is a dark monster. The jam of Terrapin Station->Playing In The Band->Uncle's John's Band->Drums->the Wheel->China Doll->Playing In The Band is quite inspired.5-21-77 (Saturday):The first set opens with a great Bertha and is followed by an equally good Me And My Uncle. They Love Each Other is sweet and Cassidy soars. Jack A Roe is done in it's early arrangement and it's one of the better ones to boot. Jack Straw is wonderful. Tennessee Jed is a blast while New Minglewood Blues is it's usual rocker self. Row Jimmy is a repeat from the last show and this version is just as good. Next up, another repeat with Passenger which is more powerful than a steam locomotive. The first set ends with an explosive Scarlet Begonias->Fire On The Mountain.The second set starts with another powerful Samson And Delilah and is followed by a standout Brown-Eyed Women. The second set jam of Estimated Prophet->He's Gone->Drums->The Other One->Comes A Time->Saint Stephen->Not Fade Away->saint Stephen->One More Saturday Night is wonderful and something every "head" should hear. the US Blues encore is missing due to time limits on the cd. There is also a bunch of hidden filler on this release and that comes from 10-11-77 more of which would later turn up on Road Trips Volume 1 No. 2 w/ bonus disc

This two cd set is a compilation of music played across four different nights at the Fillmore West in San Francisco. The band was still called the Santana Blues Band that year and featured: Carlos Santana, Gregg Rolie, David Brown, Marcus Malone and Bob Livingston. Marcus Malone was the guy who was discovered mostly homeless last December by KRON in the Bay Area last December. They contacted Carlos' people and Carlos showed up promising to help his old friend out. Both Bob and Marcus would be gone by the time the band began recording it's first album the following year replaced by Michael Shrieve, Michael Carabello and José "Chepito" Areas.The band still sounds a little embryonic at times and the jams would become more confident by the time that they played Woodstock in about eight months time. Still, what is here is very good for the most part and shows the band early on. Several of the songs here would turn up on the band's first album: Jingo, Persuasion, Treat and Soul Sacrifice. The others were mostly part of the band's standard set lists back then.

The Essential Santana was first released back in October 2002 before Sony owned Arista/BMG so nothing from Supernatural on was used. Santana was on Polydor/Universal in the early 1990's so none of that was used either. The original release was pretty well packed although disc two still had room for an extra song. In 2010, after Sony had acquired the rights to Arista/BMG and had access to Polydor/Universal, they put out Essential 3.0 in a digipack with an extra disc. While the extra disc does include some nice live stuff, it's also only around a half an hour and misses later stuff. It also doesn't include anything from Woodstock, Lotus or even Scared Fire.In 2011, Sony released yet another version of Essential Santana with a more recent picture of Santana on the cover and back to two cds. Unfortunately, this version drops a lot of the 1980's and 1990's stuff while over representing the Arista/BMG stuff. Really, two versions of The Game Of Love while other songs and albums are completely bypassed. Overall and for the amount you get, the original 2002 feels like the most thought out for what you get as the bonus disc on 3.0 is short and feels rather thrown together rather than carefully put together. Still, 3.0 can be found for about the price of the original release. If you're going to pick one, go with 3.0 as long as you can get it for the price of the original.
