I know it should not be a big deal to take it to a jeweler's, but I did find it a bit of a hassle and inconvenient - plus, not every place of business will take care of pieces of jewelry if you didn't purchase it there.

"Free Men" has an engaging, interesting storyline. Three men, at a time when it might seem unlikely or odd for these three who look so vastly different on the outside to be in any way associated with one another, travel at some length together. They've been accused of committing a crime, and an investigator (or tracker) who is as curious about human behavior as he is about justice, is on their trail.There is something additional, something beyond the interesting storyline. I liked the way the story was told and unfolded (each of the three men, the investigator and another person, briefly, all take turns sharing their stories). The reader is with the characters in the present, but also with each of them in the past as the men share their histories and what paths they trod upon that might have led to the path they all found themselves on together. The men's voices and stories are all very personal, often thoughtful and reflective and show that the men have magnetic personalities with depth to them. Their stories are colorful and full of action. The men also ask really good questions - if not of themselves, then in discussions with one another. For example, which would you choose - to have a cruel family (or to have a big, loving family and lose every single one of them), or to be alone and lonely? Different men choose different answers and it's interesting to see why and to think about your own life and which answer you might believe to be true.I'm glad I invested time in this book and would recommend it to anyone because it's got something for everyone, from the fast-paced story and plenty of action, to the endless big and little questions life throws at us all.

"The Searcher" is an engaging read that has a fast-paced, well-developed plot, a decent-sized cast of enigmatic characters that are still easy to follow, get to know and remember as you're reading, and enough suspense to keep you turning the pages.I liked the various mysteries within the story - Is there hidden treasure tied to the town of Redemption? Who is Solomon Creed, why does he appear in Redemption in the middle of the chaos of a plane crash and fire, and why is he trying to save a man who's already dead (and what does the "I" burned into his flesh mean)? Did cartel leader Papa Tio's son die in the plane crash near Redemption, and if so, was it an accident or something more sinister? What is Papa Tio planning in retaliation? Are the mayor and police chief of Redemption involved somehow with Papa Tio - or the plane crash?I enjoyed the different perspectives in the story - the chapters are very brief and easy to read - and the stories or voices change between Solomon, the founder of the town/church of Redemption, the police chief and/or mayor, and Papa Tio and those around him. The action and suspense are nonstop and just enough answers offered at just the right time to bring the completed picture into focus, albeit with maybe a few pieces missing or cast in shadow.

"An Inheritance of Ashes," told in 16-year-old Hallie's voice and seen through her eyes (both the "now" and the "then," when she was 6 and 8), is a good, solid story that mainly explores what it means - for Hallie, for her older sister Marthe, for hired-man and veteran Heron, for Hallie's neighbors and friends Tyler, Nat, Ada, and for Hallie's brother-in-law, Thom, lost during the war - to be heroes in various circumstances in life and death. I really liked how this theme unwound - the author painted the scenes, atmosphere, characters, Twisted Things, all with patience, depth and experiences anyone can relate to at some point. Although the war is part of the story, I wouldn't say it's even the biggest piece of it - it's more about family (the good, the bad and the ugly) and friends. It's about enemies and some secrets they carry that can reach even an opponent's heart. It's about belief and betrayal, misunderstandings, and the consequences. It's also about the pains and joys of growing up, the ties that bind, what it means to stay and fight or make amends instead of walk away and sulk. The easy connection between Tyler and Hallie made me smile at times - their "spite or pride" question was a pretty good one that I might ask myself in the future.I would suggest taking your time and committing yourself to this book, because the payoffs for reading it aren't in just one place. I didn't think the story or the action was slow at all, but some might get impatient with the time spent getting to know the characters and their stories - the author doesn't skimp on delving into who people are (and their histories). Something is always happening, but I recognize that what I find interesting or exciting may not work for others - I was a bit enthralled just with meeting Ada in her "laboratory" with the Twisted Things contained in glass jars. There are definitely *big* action /fight /revelation /WHAT?! scenes that occur in the last half of the book, so if you can just keep reading, you should find something to spark your interest before the story ends.

What I liked most about "Inuyashiki 1" was how well emotions were portrayed. It's amazing to see the depth and details in this story unfold. That, combined with carefully, almost lovingly created art, expresses with finesse what's happening. Words like "contempt" (seems to be what Inuyashiki's family feels for him; I hope that's not true deep down, but he's definitely not appreciated), "soul-searching," "defeated and lonely," "complete bafflement," "hope and affection" (I love the selfless action and the wonderful canine companion) come to mind as just a few of the emotions that are not just seen - they're felt. The story is well-told and not an easy one - while some solutions are offered, there are many questions left for the reader to ponder until next time.

"Girl Waits with Gun" is one of those rare books that isn't just good or great; it was a completely engaging adventure that I hated had to end. With many books, I expect there to be some part that is a bit dry or dull or the story loses its shine or appeal briefly - I may like or enjoy the book overall, but have to fight off the temptation to skim the parts where I find my mind wandering. There were no such dull, or even ordinary, parts to this book - even a so-called tedious day in the lives of the Misses Kopp sprang to intriguing life on the pages. The 1914 atmosphere drew me in and the voices and personalities of Constance, Norma, Fleurette and their family members living and dead, Sheriff Heath and his men, and seemingly untouchable silk dyer/villain Henry Kaufmann, his henchmen and their mission to cause as much fear, destruction and loss to people as possible, all captivated me and kept me involved in the story without interruption.I found the story itself - of a rich and drunk man intent on harm simply because he can get away with it - and how one woman in her mid-30s who's happy to be unmarried at a time when women are expected to be dependent and docile, stands up for herself and vows to fight back with her brains as well as her brawn, to be compelling. But there's much more to the story that enhances and enriches the reading experience, and I enjoyed every moment of it.

If readers want more of a performance or theatrical review, this biography of Maggie Smith's is very thorough in covering Maggie's work. In fact, the book is mostly about Maggie's acting career: Details and more details about the play or movie or other professional work, including other actors and their comments, and delving into particular scenes and how they are acted. I found it to be quite dull - the author expresses that Maggie has a personality, but it isn't brought to life here, though there were glimpses (Maggie's early relationship with her mother and a general picture of her childhood is presented in a more personal, sympathetic way, and I loved learning what books Maggie read and enjoyed as a child, and the fact that she sat in the bathtub with her blue jeans on).The book felt more like a technical study of Maggie's professional world and works, and less like a personal portrait of Maggie as a whole person - it lacked warmth and personality.

"Wolf by Wolf" offers a little something for anyone who loves a fresh, imaginative piece of art that doesn't skimp on delving into the thoughts and emotions of a girl who used to be a victim but who now strives to be a heroine who effects change in the world.The book is split between "now" (1956 Germania and other locales the young motorcycle racers happen to be) and "then" (1944, when Yael is 6 and is the victim of Nazi experimentation). The shifts between the two time frames is well done - there is no confusion or difficulty in understanding which time frame you're in (or why) - the "now" is devoted to the race; the "then" is devoted to giving the reader an idea of what Yael has been through that has brought her to the point and mission of the race - the identities of the wolves that are inked on Yael's arm are also explored in the "then" time frame and how each inspired or interacted with Yael.There's a lot to this book, but I don't want to ruin any of the surprises - and there are quite a few twists and turns and the unexpected. Experiencing those surprises for yourself is half the fun, so I will just touch on a few of my favorite concepts that are explored and be done - compassion (who proves to show it is one of those pleasant surprises) despite the abundance of cruelty, competition and a sometimes brutal struggle just to survive) and perseverance. (When you're filled with words of criticism from someone you loved, you're still carrying a load of self-doubt and it seems obvious you're beaten, how do you keep going?)

"Jade Dragon Mountain" was enjoyable from the beginning through to the end. There were no dull, sleep-inducing portions where I was tempted to skim quickly; this was a story to take my time with and savor it slowly.Li Du proved to be a thoughtful character who wasn't overly confident or flashy, yet had a quiet, consistent intelligence he didn't always show everyone. Li Du also had a good imagination and patience to ferret out the clues he needed to solve not only the mystery of who killed the Jesuit astronomer Brother Pieter (whom he has met, had a lively conversation with and might have become good friends with had he not been murdered) and why, but other smaller mysteries within the story. Li Du is clever and knowledgeable but humble, kind, able to listen, and interestingly enough, bold when he needs to be. Getting to know Li Du and his story, along with the people he meets through the story, is satisfying and told with just the right degree of suspense and well-planned timing. Other positives include learning a bit about Chinese politics and culture. The location of Dayan is expressed with flair, grace and a vivid style.

My ears are sensitive, and some earrings just irritate my skin and make my earlobes so itchy and red that I can't wear them. These earrings are not only attractive and classy-looking, but they don't bother my ears at all. They're light-weight and I forget I'm wearing them. I also love the fact that the earrings come with two backs - the typical metal back and the softer, plastic back which I prefer. I love these earrings and am happy I tried them.

It's difficult for me, as a teacher, to try and stay healthy when I'm surrounded by so many children who are sick and swapping their colds and flus with anyone close to them. I like these Purell sanitizing wipes because they don't seem as harsh as the brand I usually use - my hands aren't nearly as dry or cracked after using them. I also like the fact that the scent is very mild - I've cleaned desks before students arrive to class, and many children complain about the strong odor when I use another brand of wipes. So far, none have noticed the Purell wipes' smell.While these wipes are strong, easy to use and quite nice for quick, regular use in small jobs - wiping crumbs off desks after snacks - they don't seem as good to use for the big jobs. The wipes are not as damp as others I've used, so it takes more wipes when cleaning larger areas.

"Ghettoside: A True Story of Murder in America" has a special kind of power because although it does have plenty of statistics and news reports through history; results of research and studies; and day-by-day logs of who was murdered that resemble the long lists of who begat who in the Bible; the book also gives an in-depth and personal look at the hearts, minds and lives of people on both sides of the violence. The life of murdered black teen Bryant Tennelle, the gentle son of a successful homicide detective, is presented with care and compassion so that he becomes more than a statistic: he becomes a living, breathing, valuable human being. Detective John Skaggs, devoted and exceptional at his job, but not without his flaws, is white and constantly proving - through actions rather than words - to grieving black families that no, it's not "just another black man" to him, and yes, he cares about justice for these murdered men. Skaggs' goal is to make black lives expensive, not so cheap they're barely noticed.The reader also spends a good deal of time with Bryant's father, Wally Tennelle, and the rest of Wally's family, as they work, play, and finally deal with the horror and tragedy of Bryant's murder. Several police officers have a voice as they explain their workloads and what it's like to work the streets where murder is a daily event. Witnesses add more pieces to the story - their fears, failings, as well as the story of one special female witness who helps Detective Skaggs move forward with an important stalled case. Everyone involved with either fighting crime or seeking justice tells pieces of a story that tries to understand, explain and explore possible solutions to the long-existing problem of blacks killing other blacks. This book is interesting, engaging and enlightening.

I tried at first to read several letters' worth of lessons (thoughts? ideas? a plan for a daily devotion? - each letter includes some of each). But this really didn't work for me, because each letter demands more time and thought than a quick read-through. I found I would miss too much if I read more than 2 letters at a time, so that is what I settled in for. Lisa Nichols Hickman introduces each letter with a pair of words (but often, more ideas for words are included within the short, 5-6 page chapters), and shares a personal story of why these words mean something to her, how it impacted her Christian life (and her thoughts, and her prayers) and what she's learned. There is a lot of imagery, a lot of repetition (which normally I wouldn't care for - here, though, it felt like meditation, which was important to building a better memory of the key points) and quite a bit of encouragement - to think, consider, find some way to action. One of my favorites was imagination/icicles, because I could relate (several of them are relatable, but some make you smile more than others) and also because I've never considered prayer concerning imagination. I also enjoyed the quotes at the beginning of each chapter/letter ... the one for imagination/icicles was "Logic will get you from A to Z; imagination will get you everywhere." - Albert Einstein.

"Migratory Animals" had several ideas and characters I found interesting and thought-provoking, but there were also long explanatory passages (to explain science or how art was made) which I understood needed to be included in some form, but they were so dull, rambling and long-winded that I lost my involvement in the story at times and found my mind wandering.Flannery has been away in Nigeria, where she's fallen in love and made a home. So when out of monetary and scientific necessity she finds herself back in Texas, a good part of her mind and heart stay behind in Nigeria. Flan's most important goal is getting back to Nigeria as quickly as possible - even when she discovers her little sister, Molly, has Huntington's Disease, which her mother had - and died an awful death from - years before.Flan is in a quandary - when is it OK to live her own life - or is it never OK because family connections (and responsibilities) don't really end (or shouldn't ... should they)? She wrestles with guilt, dread, fear, love for her sister and friends, and a drive to do the most effective work to most help those she's left behind in Nigeria.Meanwhile, Molly struggles with past family secrets as well as the need to face her diagnosis. Then she discovers she's got a secret of her own, and finds a helping hand in Alyce, Flannery's best friend who carries a heavy burden of depression and is struggling just to survive day to day.The chapters - and story - are told from different characters' points of view. Their stories merge into one big tapestry, which is somewhat beautiful but also has some flaws and unfinished parts. Overall, it was an OK story - I enjoyed parts of it but I struggled to get through some parts too, and I won't remember it a month from now.

Although this attractive sheet set didn't fit my queen mattress perfectly, it was close enough. I was happy that the fitted sheet stayed on the mattress all night - I hate it when they slip off. Of course the flannel sheets were warm - but they were also softer and much more comfortable than I thought they would be. They seemed to encourage sleep even when I wasn't particularly sleepy.

One of the things I really liked about "A Backpack, a Bear and Eight Crates of Vodka" is its balance. It's not just about the bad times or experiences. It's also about the funny, victorious, hopeful and compassionate moments. I was completely taken in by the relationship between Lev and his older sister, Lina - the clever way the two teased one another and "got even" for tricks played was full of humor and good cheer. On the other hand, I was just as riveted by Lev's family's terrifying ordeal at the border when they were trying to exit the USSR (vicious people were in control of whether his family would be locked up instead of permitted to leave the country).The people Lev and his family meet are just as compelling as Lev and his family. The reader meets various people from charitable organizations who are committed and make a huge difference in the lives of these Jewish refugees. The way Lev introduces them and tells their stories (with warmth and affection) sparks the reader to feel deeply and appreciate these people as if we knew them ourselves. From Binder, who gladly opens up his hotel to help house and feed the refugees on their journey, to Eva, who gives away free clothing - there's a clear, unhurried picture of each person or group of people who helped along the way and their stories/kindnesses.There is the big picture in this memoir, but also little details (Lev learning the alphabet; Lina getting a job; Lev's dad working for free just to get a good recommendation to take to the U.S. with them) and everyday life that brings Lev, his family, people who threaten and cause problems as well as those who care and help, to vivid life. You can't help but read on; the story pulls you in and you find you'd rather stay in it than put the book down to do other things you must do (like work).

Just to look at it, other than a simple design, this Charmin Basic doesn't look like much. While it does look like there's more paper on the roll, it isn't as thick, being single-ply, as the Charmin Ultra (soft or strong varieties). I was not impressed and didn't expect much. I thought I'd have to use twice as much.I was glad to be surprised, then. Despite it looking flimsy or thin, this Charmin is as strong and absorbent - without losing its softness and without having to use more - as other kinds I've tried. I was satisfied - despite being more expensive than some, it will last longer, which makes it more competitive with less expensive brands that have smaller rolls and less quality.If you like Charmin but want to save a little money, this is worth a try.

I wanted to like this book. But I had to force myself to finish it, and even after a solid ending that gives closure, I am not satisfied or happy to have read it.It's not about liking or disliking the characters - it's more that they all lacked color (or spark?). It's not about a dull or snail-paced plot, either (Leila and the people she meets along the way all move rather quickly and don't sit still on the pages).The main problem was I struggled to find any connection to or emotion for any of the characters. None of them felt genuine enough, were interesting enough, or maybe they lacked depth. Most of their behavior, conversations, actions and problems seemed either too typical (including stereotypical) of what others have done (I did actively search for originality; there were a few glimmers here and there but not enough) or a bit dumb (as in ridiculous, over the top, difficult to believe - and not enjoyable to read). I could understand the reason for Leila's journey and had a mild interest in her reaching her goals, but while I tried, I couldn't feel much for any of the characters. While I found a few pages here and there where there was an interesting concept, idea or something happened that made me feel something other than boredom, overall I didn't get much of value from this book.

I was engaged and interested in the beginning of "Take Me With You." The conversations felt natural and genuine; I believed what the characters said and their behavior began to express their personalities. But then I began to lose interest and the story lost a lot of its magic. I liked Seth, the 12-year-old, but once August begins his summer excursion with him and his little brother, Henry, Seth's conversation sometimes becomes unnatural (it didn't sound like a 12-year-old speaking) and repetitive. When Seth kept saying certain emotional things over and over again it seemed like the words' only purpose was to evoke pity or sympathy - they didn't add anything to the story nor move the plot forward. The children and their situation naturally demand readers' concern and sympathy - I can't comprehend how anyone with a heart wouldn't feel deeply for these children (and August), so the repetition only succeeded in distracting and distancing me from the story.I know it's petty, but the overuse of the sigh (the title should be, "Take Me With You, and Sigh Every Step of the Way") made me a little crazy, also. Is there truly no other way to describe a character's reaction to a frustrating or difficult situation?Despite being annoyed, I did stick with this book and read all of it. I admit to being a fan of Henry, the younger brother, who at 7 would go long periods of time without speaking at all. It was very satisfying when he takes a stand and speaks up for himself. I also understood the value of several other issues (how do you know when you're an alcoholic? how do you make a difference in a child's life when you're not a blood relative and the adult doesn't want you around? how do you stage an intervention, and what do you do if it doesn't work?) that were discussed rather well: I particularly liked what was said in one of the AA meetings, about if one goes around with a pillow trying to break others' falls, it might not be the great thing one thinks it is. Issues are handled with compassion and a strong dose of reality: It was nice to see how someone might deal with a problem that persists.

Jacob Underwood has been transformed because of a motorcycle accident. He cannot identify, understand or experience human feelings and believes he is dead (he has Cotard’s Syndrome).Other than the crazy and different - yet disturbingly believable - world Jacob exists within, Jacob himself is fascinating. He tells his story, including his current job as an enforcer, and his history - and what has happened to make him the way he is. Despite Jacob's lack of ability to experience or understand emotions, he has a compelling and mystifyingly magnetic personality. He often uses colors to describe things (from smells, to pain, to the physical nearness of someone). He has style, intelligence and pizzazz - his thoughts, methods, odd habits (he can't stand to eat or drink any food and consumes a nutrient drink only because he has to), rules to survive (tell people he doesn't like to be touched; he must wash his Shell every day), surprising reaction to dogs - all of these pieces of Jacob make him appealing. From beginning of the story to the end, his Spark shines with a curious, inviting brightness.I enjoyed the overall story of Jacob: his job, the mystery of the missing target he’s assigned to track and some confusing events he encounters which are related to his job, as well as the advanced technology of his world, the politics and society he’s moving through. But the best part of the book was getting to know Jacob and watching his Spark catch fire, and hoping that despite the odds, he’d manage to survive long enough to solve some personal and professional problems and be better for it despite his insistence that the words “good, evil, right and wrong” have no meaning and are irrelevant.

"Close Your Eyes, Hold Hands" deserves an extra star for the moment when 16-year-old Emily lets the reader in on a little secret: Most Emily Dickinson poems can be read (or sung, rather) to the theme song of Gilligan's Island. I couldn't help but try it (and it's true)! Emily (who calls herself Abby for awhile) is a wonderfully intense little firecracker and her personality really sparks the story along - some parts, like setting the poems to music, were fun, unique and made me smile. Other parts of Emily's story - such as how she went to school drunk one day, getting into trouble to send a message to her often-drunk parents what it was like to live with people who drank too much and got into embarrassing situations - show Emily's sass, determination and strength.I loved this book for the way it shines a light on human nature and how some people still manage to find ways to survive despite major catastrophes, people's hatred, abuse and fear, and to find reasons to live and care about others. A terrible tragedy has occurred and her parents are being blamed - and Emily finds herself alone and on the run. She meets a wide variety of people along the way - some friendly, some scary, some bullies, some who need help, and one who behaves cruelly in the beginning but who grows up a bit, changes, and offers Emily inspiration instead of reasons to fear and dread.I could identify with Emily's guilt and criticism of herself - she feels she's disappointed everyone and made too many stupid mistakes and poor choices. But her courage in the face of everything falling apart around her really is uplifting. Emily is genuine, has depth and doesn't behave predictably or even rationally at times - her story, retold in journal-style, is somewhat messy (which makes sense, considering what she goes through) and not well organized (and it's not supposed to be). It all somehow works and adds an element of reality to the story. When Emily explains the history of the phrase "Close your eyes, hold hands," it opens yet another avenue of thought for the reader while tying an extra meaning to Emily's story.I very much liked the thoughtfulness of the story, which was somewhat disguised and hidden like pirate's treasure within a "quasi-Looney Tune" teenage girl's disorganized, somewhat messy and sometimes highly emotional (understandably - it never feels over the top, though) retelling of her story of survival.

This is the kind of book that has the capacity to do for its readers what it's done for its characters: Inspire hope to overcome and to change your situation; unleash the potential to be kind to a complete stranger; spark action to connect with others and help improve others' lives if at all possible.At times Ellen's story felt a bit over-the-top (Temerity, while I really do love her spunky, can-do attitude, is a bit too perfect even though she does need to ask for help "seeing" certain things). Plenty is going on - gang and drug activity, a few murderers and thieves on the loose, a few situations with babies and their uncertain futures, invisible Ellen's brand-new friendship with Temerity - and Ellen's horrific childhood flashbacks where she somehow survived unimaginable abuse. It's not that I don't like all the action, but there's so much going on that a woman accustomed to being social would struggle; Ellen, who's been invisible all her life, is all of a sudden taking on some major problems with just a few squawks here and there. Temerity plays a major role in supporting Ellen and encouraging her to live courageously, but it happens too quickly for me to find it very believable.My favorite part of "Invisible Ellen" was seeing Ellen's intelligence blossom as she snuck around and made things happen behind the scenes - without being seen by anyone. I also enjoyed Temerity's boldness in helping others (because when you think of others, you tend to forget to think so much about your own problems) - her conversation with Janelle when she was "shopping for a rug" and seeking a disabled discount was clever, witty and brought out the personalities of both women.Overall, the book is well worth reading: I've felt invisible many times before and wanted to be invisible in many situations, too - as I'm sure many people have - so, many people will relate to Ellen and want to see her succeed. Also, Ellen's story is a reminder that if things are bad in your life, they can get better. Who knows who's out there who might speak or act kindly toward you and inspire you to pass that kindness on? Who knows whose lives you might touch or maybe change for the better? Who knows how many friends are waiting for you to find them and how your life could be made richer for brainstorming with these new friends ways to help others? The possibilities are endless.

"The Book of Unknown Americans" does an exceptional job of speaking to the heart of its readers. The personal, honest and engaging voices the characters use to describe their thoughts, beliefs, things they've seen or experienced - and the language used to paint a scene the reader is able to step into and watch  (sometimes with breath held) what happens next, caught my attention early in the book and kept me captivated. Many scenes described were everyday scenes some Americans may take for granted because they're so ordinary. But to a family that's never been to America, knows no one, and has hurried to the U.S. due to a life-or-death emergency and has had no time to learn English - the act of buying groceries can be a scary if not traumatic experience. These scenes made me think what I might do if I were in their shoes. If I HAD to go to a foreign country to save a loved one, would I go? How would I feel if people who lived in that country were rude, impatient, or outright hostile for no reason I could see?The vibrant characters behave in ways I could understand: They had heart, spirit, hope - and a link to who I am and what I want in life, too. The unknown Americans are shown to be people with goals common to my own who are deserving of being known, of being shown respect, compassion and common courtesy.I will remember this thought-provoking, meaningful story about a family that comes to the U.S. for help, hope and healing - and the people the family members meet during their stay in Delaware - for a long time. The many voices telling their stories added a satisfying dimension which gave me a glimpse into various lives and experiences and left echoes in my mind even after they'd finished speaking and someone else had begun to speak.

Spunky P.I. Fina Ludlow makes a shining second appearance (after Loyalty) in a mystery about cryobanks and the families they help create. Identity refers to not only a single mom's quest to discover the identity of her daughter's father, but also to Fina's quest to find the identity of a murderer (who killed a sperm donor, and why?), and Fina's mission to help friend Risa discover the identity of the woman who claims to be her aunt. There is also thought given to what makes up a person's identity - family? friends? illness? wealth?One of the things I liked about "Identity" is the abundance of action on more than one level (there's more than one case Fina tackles, but there aren't so many the reader is confused about what's happening). There's action regarding Fina helping her family, her friends, and clients she doesn't particularly like. There's also action and progress made for Fina personally - she has to face and deal with her older brother, Rand, (Rand has committed a horrendous crime against his daughter, Haley, and Fina discovers this crime and does everything in her power to protect Haley - all of which is explained in the first book, "Loyalty,") and his threat to make a triumphant return to the family business. Fina also has to define her feelings when cop Cristian becomes involved with a woman who could prove to be someone special. Massage therapist Milloy is present in this second adventure, and I love the guy but wanted a bit more depth or connection between him and Fina: I missed hearing a bit more of his wit and his thoughts. He's present, yet muted (Cristian, however, does have a good voice in "Identity").The mystery. the characters, the pieces of story - were all interesting and well presented at a good pace. Fina's magnetically drawn on the page and she lights up every avenue of the story with her spark and zippy personality. (Maybe not zippy. What's the right word? She's fun, loves a good verbal sparring; yet she's thoughtful and caring, as well). I'm addicted to Fina's cases and know I'll be back for any future adventures.

This oatmeal isn't bad. I can eat it. But I wouldn't choose it. It's easy to make. But it's blah - the apples and the almonds are the best parts, occasionally adding a bit of flavor and a crunch I liked. Otherwise, I found the oatmeal bland. I tried adding a bit of sweetened creamer and was surprised when it didn't help - I've tried this before and the creamer brings out the flavor of the oatmeal. This time, all I tasted was creamer.

There is very little in this carefully crafted, suspenseful mystery that doesn't have a surprise attached to it. Alex is complex. Just when you think she is one thing (for example, a victim), you discover she is also something else (can't give it away!) ... I suspected there was even more to Alex and there were reasons for certain things she's doing, but as the layers of her life and personality are peeled back, what I learn is never exactly what I expect (I was able to guess a few little pieces because Camille, the police commandant leading the investigation, and his team gave me hints and clues).The personalities, even of the most unlikable characters imaginable, are riveting - in horror films there are sometimes moments when the squeamish (me) want to hide eyes and/or look away - but in this novel there is none of that. There is just no unsticking those eyes that are glued to the pages. I couldn't help but read on and on, sometimes a bit impatiently, but always being rewarded all the way. The action is nonstop; I was impressed that the characters were as lively and believable as they were considering how much was going on. But the pacing is precise and the explanations are very thorough and clear - the writing is tight and electric and I was much too involved - and jolted - to get lost. I really loved it.

This book is a collectible work of art; I really enjoyed it as it's not just a half-hearted or hurried story or even stories of the people within its pages. "Lovers at the Chameleon Club, Paris 1932" is full of life, love, heart and questions: When and how are heroes and villains created?This is not an easy read, but by that I don't mean it's confusing or dull. It's multi-layered, and has a depth that I liked wandering around in, and that I found interesting, but it demands the reader's attention and time. Also, there are multiple stories and points of view. All stories relate in some way to Lou Villars, whose story is being told from all angles - through a photographer's lens (and his life), through a writer and teacher's words and through several people whose lives intersected with Lou's. We see who Lou was, as a child and through her life, and any golden nuggets of good as well as the destruction she had a hand in, during the time of Hitler's rise to power. The decision is left with the reader as to who Lou really was - if she was human and had some scrap of love or kindness in her or only a monster without heart or soul - and if she should be shown compassion or only contempt.What I liked most was getting to see different sides to one story, and the use of art to paint one perspective. What one person sees or experiences may not be how another person in the same place at the same time sees or experiences something. Sometimes, two different people tell similar or complementary stories, one filling in the gaps left by another. The ending is intriguing because what one chronicler of Lou's story writes is called into question by another person in a way that leaves some questions but still manages to end the story gracefully and satisfactorily. I actually kind of liked having some intrigue at the end because it lets the reader continue to think, question and decide for him- or herself what to believe about Lou, her story and the rest of the cast of people who lived during that difficult time.

Within the first few chapters, I was drawn into this story - the language and style of writing, the characters, the plot. I thought, "This resonates; I am really going to love this."But as the story progressed, while I liked it, I didn't love it throughout the rest of the book as much as I did at the very beginning. The ending has some of the magic the beginning offered, and I remembered what had initially drawn me into the story. But I didn't feel the magic, the total immersion, throughout the entire story. There were times I didn't want to keep reading; I was bored, annoyed, or just disappointed by anything from too much silliness which took away from some of the beauty of the story, or characters who ended up being shallow, or shells of the people who, I thought at first meeting them, had depth and unique style. At times I felt as deceived as Irene (who was made for George) says she is.The story is good - sweet even - and the characters are quirky and likable. It's a love story on more than one level - it's not all fairy tale, either, as some hearts connect and others don't: Not everyone gets a happy ending, and that was fine. But the deeper meanings and lovely, lyrical thoughts and insights are limited (the dreaming and the connections the characters shared there was the best and most fascinating part of the whole story). And that's what bugged me most. Overall: A nice story with glimpses of greatness which ultimately doesn't live up to its potential.

I was a little worried about trying these Tide pods because I have a front-end washing machine and I have some delicate blouses that need to be washed on the hand-wash cycle - I was afraid the pods might stain or even ruin my delicates. So, I tried the pods first on a hot-water load of towels. No problems at all, and I liked the cleaner, brighter and fresher smelling clothes, so I held my breath and tried the pods with every load of laundry, including the delicates. I was relieved, and very happy, when I had no problems at all. Hot water or cold, heavy-duty washing or shortened cycle hand-wash, the Tide pods did a great job on them all.This package is perfect because it's complete and takes care of every stage of the laundry. I also loved the Downy chips and found that it's fun to experiment with how many pieces to use. With my delicates, I only used a few. With my sheets, I used enough to cover the bottom of the lid you pour the chips into, and it was enough to noticeably improve the laundry's scent without being overpowering. I really like the whole bundle - the Bounce dryer sheets make a pleasant ending to the whole laundry chore, which feels more satisfying to complete knowing you're using high-quality products which really work to make your clothes cleaner and fresher..

I picked up "Gutenberg's Apprentice" because as a booklover, and having watched countless times in amazement as a modern press pumps out daily newspapers, I am fascinated with the printing process and how books and other printed materials are created. Although bits and pieces of this story - which chronicles the first press and the many trials and challenges faced - are indeed interesting - occasionally fantastic (and somewhat mind-boggling), overall, the story lacks depth in its relationships and personalities of the characters.It's not that I didn't like the characters (the master, Gutenberg: the inventor of the press and whose ideas gave spark to future undertakings; his apprentice, Peter, whose adopted father, Fust, is financing the press; and the growing team of people who poured themselves into the press's first major work: those who drew, carved and made the letters, mixed the ink, managed the press, hung the paper to dry, etc.) Not liking the characters is not it at all. I just felt disconnected too much of the time, and wanted to see a bit more depth to their personalities. Sometimes the writing is so formal (technical? history-bookish?) that it moves the characters off to a distance, and chills the fiery personalities we get glimpses of, but not much more. There is the occasional look into a character's life, usually Peter's, which offered that rare glimpse of emotion and personality. But apart from a lot of bickering, there are only a few tender moments or positive connections.The book tries to detail too many historical occurrences at the time of the press's first major work. The politics, religion (and superstitions), financial hardships - and the occasional 35-year jump-ahead where Peter related the story to an abbot who is writing down his story - all feel relevant and integral to the story, but none of these influencing factors felt relayed in a satisfying way. Some were focused on too intently (and in quite a dry manner); others were not delved into deeply enough. None made the characters more personal or life-like.

The story unfolds at a perfect pace, exploring how Laurel gradually comes to face, and then find a way to live with, losing her big sister, May, who she admired and wanted to be like. Laurel tackles many other challenges that come her way. Just a few include: starting high school where she doesn't know anyone; writing letters to famous dead people for an English assignment; learning who she wants to be and how to begin growing into that person; and discovering that NOT talking about things is hurting her, not helping her - but how can she talk about what happened the night May died, and who can she trust?Some of the things I loved about the book are its vivid imagery, lyrical language and pieces of poems and good, sometimes magical memories Laurel shares from her childhood that express a depth to Laurel's feelings and experiences. Laurel - and the dead people she writes to (and her boyfriend, parents and friends) - really come alive and shine; you can really get a clear picture of how they think and feel. I also felt the revealing of Laurel's secret (part of what happens - and why it happened - the night May dies) was not only well expressed, but it unfolds at a perfect pace - the reader sees a glimpse here, a hint there, and then we can see the whole picture. Sky, Laurel's boyfriend, has his own interesting story to tell and the connection between Laurel and Sky deepens as more of his story is revealed. It's captivating to see how Sky and his story twines with Laurel, her story, struggle and personality.The story is just plain good for the heart and soul. It has the potential to touch people's hearts, whether they're happy or sad, and to offer thought-provoking ideas for dealing with life's challenges which we all must face at some point.

When I picked up "The Life List," I expected a fun, pleasant read, but I didn't expect to feel quite so much. I thought it might be a little lighter than it was: Not that Brett's story is bleak or depressing, exactly, but what she goes through after her mom dies is very realistic and genuinely felt and expressed. I did laugh - there were a lot of funny parts that felt natural, not forced - but I was shocked when I found myself moved to tears by Brett's thoughts, feelings or experiences, because they were so easy for me to understand and relate to. I could think of times in my life, even if I didn't experience exactly what Brett did, that I felt similar things - good, bad, or a struggle. I also admired how as Brett is trying to accomplish things from her life list she wrote as a 14-year-old that some of the results were NOT what I expected. It was refreshing to find so many surprises, (both of success and failure), and so many reasons to keep reading (speedily, almost breathlessly) on.This book isn't a work of fluff or superficiality - it follows through with its goals; it's emotionally compelling; and it's satisfying - in plot, problems and resolutions. I had a very tough time putting this book down - I wanted to know what happened next. I also loved Brett as well as many of the characters (even though Brett's mom has died, she comes alive in Brett's memories and in the notes she leaves behind, so the reader really gets to know her, too). I felt like they were people I wished I could know. I'm glad I read it and enjoyed being on Brett's journey to realizing what she wants and all that she can give, and do, in life.

I usually enjoy fractured or twisted fairy tales or turning a story upside down. And some of the ideas in "Dorothy Must Die" could have been crafted into a fantastic tale. Amy herself isn't an unlikable character, nor are the winged monkeys or the Wicked Witches (though there are a bit too many platitudes and a generally preachy feel that didn't feel genuine). But to take wholesome, good-hearted characters from such a popular, well-loved story and turn them so completely evil with no good reason or explanation made the "villains" flat, one-dimensional, and more than just unlikable. We have Dorothy, the scarecrow, the tin woodman and the lion all suddenly violent, hateful, and power-hungry to the point of ruthlessly and recklessly killing for no reason at all. Dorothy is a petty and annoying whiner who only eats muffin tops, complains over bacon fixed incorrectly, and wants to off the wizard for not giving the tin woodman better relationship advice ... these villains don't just grate on the nerves; they're just plain unbelievable. So very sad; if their story, their abrupt turnabout had been explained with any effort at all, and if these evil characters had been given even a tiny bit of personality or even a glimpse of their familiar good peeking out at odd times, they would have been enigmatic, fabulous villains who would help give Amy and her wicked team more depth, more of a story to roam around in, instead of limiting them to this ridiculous version of Oz that I hated.

"The Garden of Burning Sand" has appealing main and supporting characters: Zoe Fleming, who is an American human rights lawyer working in Africa, a strong, likable team working for the prosecution (from Joseph - a local police officer with tragedy and violence in his past, and a personal illness he must decide to face - to Sarge, who prosecutes in court), a hardworking and sympathetic local doctor and kindly, supportive nuns who look after orphan children in Zambia. Zoe and the prosecution doggedly pursue justice for a teenage girl named Kuyeya with Down syndrome who has been raped.What I most liked in the beginning was hearing Kuyeya's voice (her thoughts) - this was very effective at drawing me in and capturing my interest. If she had been given more of a voice throughout the story, Kuyeya would have been a much stronger character. (The reader comes to affectionately expect the balloon noise she makes, and can appreciate her love for Johnny Cash but this reader wanted to see more of her personality and spirit; Kuyeya offers something vital to the story and her case much later in the story, but it loses a bit of its impact since we no longer hear any of her thoughts or glean any kind of insight into her feelings other than a general feeling of pain and distress.) I sometimes felt that Kuyeya herself is pushed into the background of the story.The mystery of who raped Kuyeya and the development of the villains were well crafted and easy to follow and understand. Zoe's past is well illuminated, as well as her blossoming relationships with several other characters. I cared about and was hoping for more funding and more progress to be made more quickly for both the AIDS and rape victims. My main struggle with this book was while I liked it, I didn't find myself as involved as I had hoped to be. I wanted to like it more, but was a bit frustrated with the countless issues being brought up, left to dangle (not just for a chapter or two, but long lapses) while other issues are introduced while we then return to some problem or danger the prosecution team faces. It felt like too many issues to fully explore (most were touched on superficially), and so I felt little satisfaction from knowing about most of them, even though many are resolved in some way by the end. There were many reasons to celebrate in the story, and much hope and many positive messages tucked within the book. I enjoyed the book but it isn't something that will stand out in my memory.

What makes "Shotgun Lovesongs" so special is the story's emotional impact and its ability to fully engage the reader in the lives of this group of friends. Beth, married to Henry; musician Lee; bull-rider and slightly altered (from a nasty bump on the head while drunk) but still capable Ronny; and seemingly selfish though deep-down really good guy Kip all take a turn telling their stories and how their lives connect with and are changed by their childhood friends. The story has such depth, vivid and genuine personality, open-heartedness and raw honesty to it that it was difficult NOT to like any of the characters. The book is written with a majestic, beautiful and at times haunting language that lingers in your memory and flows so smoothly you cease to realize exactly how quickly the book is slipping away; you're so involved in the story.

"All Our Names" is a deeply felt and thoughtful story about two young men from poor African villages who meet at a university and become like brothers. Bird, so named by his father, but who ends up with several names (Professor, Langston, Dickens and Daniel) says at the very beginning of the story that he's given up the names his parents had given him. Nameless for awhile, the 25-year-old seems to fall under the spell of a strong-spirited, charismatic Isaac, who has fresh ideas for change and a quick fight in the revolution. But when the tension and violence ratchets up several notches, both boys change. Isaac decides to stay in Africa despite the increasing violence and lack of safe places, and he makes plans for his friend to travel to America.Using his friend's name, Bird arrives safely in America, and meets and begins a relationship with Helen, a social worker. The story is told, in alternating chapters, from the point of view of Helen, and from Bird's perspective (but these chapters are entitled "Isaac" even though they're told in Bird's voice - and although it seems confusing, it's not because these chapters are mostly about Isaac and the brotherhood the two men share, and it illuminates Bird's deep appreciation - and perhaps regret at the consequences - for his friend Isaac's gift of the use of his name and a fresh start in America).The story flows easily between the war-torn lives of Isaac and Bird, and Bird's struggling new life living under Isaac's name in America. The images of attacks on villages, refugees seeking safe haven, boys toting guns and engaging soldiers in battle, and beatings both Isaac and Bird endure, are all very vivid and stir a storm of emotion in the reader. Helen's character felt more distant and vague; I didn't dislike her but I didn't feel much of a connection or an understanding of her. She and her relationship with Bird feel more like background to the *real* story of Isaac and Bird - maybe this is intentional and demonstrates Bird's reluctance to allow himself to let go and more fully enjoy his life because he feels his friend Isaac should have been able to enjoy a happier, freer life as well but was denied that."All Our Names" ultimately explores not just friendship or brotherhood and what those ideas mean in the middle of war, but it brings to life hope, freedom and the idea that a life should be lived fully and joyfully because it's the best way to honor a brother's sacrifice.

Yulia, 17, finds herself captured and forced to work for the KGB, along with a handful of other teenagers, all with various gifts (Larissa sees countless possible futures; Masha can remotely view a scene and is working on moving objects with her mind; Valya can change or even erase a person's memories). When Yulia touches someone or something, she can hear that person's thoughts (or with things, she can identify whose things they are). But Yulia 's special abilities aren't so well defined, and she discovers there is much more to learn about herself and what powers she may be able to draw on to defend herself and those she loves.Yulia doesn't want to work for the KGB, but Rostov, the one in charge and controlling things (and people) regardless of what each might want, has captured Yulia's mother, who has been forced to continue her genetic research, and her brother, who needs special care. And Yulia's father disappeared a long time ago. How can she hope to escape the KGB and keep her family safe?The characters and their relationships are well developed and dance to their chosen music throughout the book. Music is part of the tools they use to protect themselves. Who is friend and who is foe is not always clear, and when Yulia discovers part of her past has been scrubbed, she's on a mission of her own to find lost memories and the reason why she was "wiped," Meanwhile, she completes several missions with the other teens for Rostov, all working toward a master plan of eliminating Rostov's opponents and putting Russia on the fast track toward war with the U.S.Sekret grabs your attention and doesn't let go: Just when you think you have some clue as to what's going on, another hidden piece of the puzzle falls in your lap and you're running with Yulia in a different direction.

This selection of short stories told from the perspective of different servicemen doing a variety of different jobs in Iraq and Afghanistan and being affected in all kinds of ways delivers a powerful punch to the reader with its heartfelt and brutal honesty. Although the men serving and telling their stories are different and face all kinds of suffering and damage from what they saw and did, these servicemen have a lot in common, too (No. 1 being their honesty - no one is trying to hide anything; in fact, most of the narrators desperately want to share their stories to either a. have someone understand, b. have someone listen, even if they'll never understand, c. share the burden or d. admit, if not ease, the guilt and shame - shock someone by sharing your secrets into reaffirming how horrible you are). Each narrator is refreshingly genuine and regardless of how filthy the thoughts or language or how shocking their thoughts or deeds, somehow it all works to bring to life the colorful people in this book who for a variety of reasons, go off to defend our country and fight our wars.Many of the narrators share such intimately honest feelings and struggles, and their stories have a stunning depth and pull that won't let go of your attention - or your heart - for even a minute. The narrators open their lives to the reader, offering an up-close and personal look at what each of them went through and the impact each unique experience had on each service member. I could hear, see, smell and feel what the narrators heard, saw, smelled and felt. And I could learn, from what more than one narrator insisted, that despite listening to their stories, I can never truly understand because I'm not any of them; I wasn't there.

Despite a government's lack of preparedness after a horrific accident at Chernobyl, despite promises broken, deadly compromises, a powerful and complete refusal to listen to facts, reason, and plans to save lives, people in Moscow and in the Ukraine show how big their hearts are as they make sacrifices for their family, friends, strangers and their country - even as that country's leaders betray them.The reader is given great privilege in being a part of several families' lives as they unfold in the aftermath of the fire at the nuclear power plant. Most of the characters' lives connect in some way; it was fascinating to connect the dots as one family does something to help another family, who returns the favor to someone the first family knows. "All That is Solid Melts into Air" is about ordinary (but captivating) people surviving (or finding a way to die with dignity and if possible, to die so that another loved one might live) and living their lives the best they can, despite bullying, poverty, political threats and snatching of choice and freedom, and ignorance that is forced by the government. I loved getting to know these people and being a witness to their courage, talent, and their capacity to love and forgive and start over - despite the pain and loss, their story is inspiring.

... until it's gone. At its core, " 'Til the Well Runs Dry" is a love story that spans 22 years. The story is told in three voices: that of Marcia Garcia; her lover, policeman Farouk Karam; and their second-born daughter, Jacqueline.Marcia Garcia is a teenager trying to single-handedly take care of 3-year-old twins who are not well. Her parents and sister are gone, and she sews to make enough money to keep the small family afloat. Then she meets policeman Farouk. Their story is unique - not at all like I thought it would be. Instead of being fireworks and the fairy-tale-like happily ever after, Farouk and Marcia (it's Mar-see-uh) share a turbulent relationship - where superstition and a kind of black magic, secrets left unshared, and trust shattered and not rebuilt - all work against them, despite hearts that truly do seem to beat for and reach out for each other. Marcia, Farouk and their family felt real and believable - and their troubles made their story come alive more. Without giving away too much of the story, let it suffice to say the lingering message I took away from their story is to look around and realize what's priceless in your life and appreciate what you have before it's too late.Hearing Jacqueline's sweet voice explain events in the story proved an effective and wonderful addition to the story. Jackie helped brighten up the story, give it more vibrant color and hope, and underline the goodness of her parents when they make bad decisions.Overall I enjoyed the book. Something is always happening - whether it be the mischief one of Marcia and Farouk's four children has found and immersed him- or herself in; or some danger or threat caused by Farouk's asking a strange witch-like obeah woman for help ensuring Marcia will always love him; or the fresh tragedies and trials for both Farouk (when a murder threatens his job) and for Marcia (when she moves from Trinidad to the United States for a new life). The characters are likable, colorful and very human - I kept wondering if Farouk was good or bad, and hadn't really made up my mind (and maybe Farouk wasn't sure about himself either) until the very end. I didn't care for the ending (it felt abrupt and unfinished), but it's a minor complaint and wouldn't keep me from recommending the book to someone who likes a different kind of love story - raw, real, tragic.
Works well. I just searched the internet for my vacuum's product number and the word "filter" and this is what popped up. The best price was here, and it arrived quickly. Very pleased.
They work, and fit my vacuum. I just searched the internet for the product number of my vacuum and the word "filter", and this is what came up.

Fantastic book. It's a supreme demonstration of problem solving under pressure. Well written and gripping from the first page to the last. If you enjoy thrillers, space exploration, and storytelling without implausible details, you'll enjoy this.

I bought the "Athlete" combination package for two purposes: to stay in shape at home, and to use the smaller of the two bags as a travel exercise implement, along with some water bag liners. It has proven excellent for that purpose.The bags are well constructed, tough material, with comfortable handles, clear included instructions, and are exactly the kind of simple but effective tool I was looking for. Very pleased.

If you're a fan already, buy this album. Dawes has continued their winning trend here. This is more like Stories Don't End than their earlier work, and it's excellent.If you've never heard them, give this album a shot. It's a modern version of what the Steve Miller Band or the Eagles have done. And given how good their albums have been, I hope they have a long career.Highly recommended.

It works as shaving soap, and it's a handy travel size. It leaves a smooth, oily feel on the face prior to shaving and adequately protects against shaving cuts. I did not love the smell, which is relatively powerful, and which lingers for some time after use.Recommended, but the smell may not be for everyone

This is the strongest magnet I've ever held. Amazingly fun to experiment with. Be cautious, the two magnets ship with a plastic bumper holding them apart, and make sure you are ready to pull them quickly and neatly apart when unwrapping. I wasn't, and the magnets slipped from my fingers, smashing into one another, and one of them was chipped by the impact. It still works fine, but I should have been more cautious.Highly recommended.

Valley of Vision is a wonderful book, and every Christian can benefit from these prayers. It has been thoroughly reviewed elsewhere, so I will leave the contents at that.This copy is good, but not perfect. The printing, pages, and binding are wonderful. My only complaint is that it is not true leather binding, but bonded leather, which is a mixture of leather dust and glue. It feels like real leather, but generally tends to be less durable. That said, I am quite pleased with the volume, and when (as I hope) I wear out the cover with time, it can be rebound if necessary, as the remainder of the volume is the best quality.Highly recommended.

If you are ordering this book, I'll assume you know what you're getting in terms of content, so suffice to say the Westminster Confession of Faith is a summary of Reformed, Calvinistic, biblical doctrine.This copy is quite handy, with thick, almost card stock pages, and an imitation leather cover. The imitation leather is the same material called TruTone or DuoTone by different publishers, and has a suede-like feel. I have a Bible covered in the same which has held up quite well for about ten years, so I'm not worried about longevity. The size of this book is on the small side, the same thickness, but just a little wider and a little shorter than the average smartphone, but with decent sized print.This would be perfect if it also included the Shorter catechism as well, but as it stands is a lovely little volume.Highly recommended.
It's steel wool. There isn't much else to say. It worked for my intended purpose.Recommended.
It's steel wool. Competitively priced, and functions as expected. If you need it, this will get the job done.

I bought this just before guests arrived for an extended holiday stay. It shipped quickly, and arrived with clear instructions. It inflated quickly (though the fan is a bit loud) and stayed appropriately inflated while two adults slept on it over the course of a week. They stated that it was quite comfortable, and did not appear to lose any air during the night. I also greatly appreciated the fact that the fan can be run in reverse to powerfully and completely deflate the mattress prior to folding and putting away. Putting it away is also greatly simplified by the included carrying case which works quite well.Highly recommended

Ingeniously simple, these are a great aid to pouring wine without mess. They wash easily, store compactly, are simple and straightforward to use, and they work for the intended purpose. Can't complain, and I'm quite pleased with the purchase.

These are the best razorblades ever. I use them with my Merkur Heavy Duty Double Edge Razor #34C and Taylor of Old Bond Street Sandalwood Shaving Cream and it is the best shave I've ever gotten. Cheaper than a Mach3 too.Highly recommended.

I love books, and have a library of close to a thousand volumes. I swore I wouldn't get an e-reader since they never look like real paper. The Kindle is the exception. It is light, battery life is great, and I can turn down the light until it looks pretty much like paper. It cuts down on weight for traveling, and hold plenty of books. My only complaint is that it is tough to quickly flip through pages back and forth if you're researching something, but for basic reading, it can't be beat.

Tough material, good instructions. My only complaint is that I initially received the wrong size, but I emailed Black Mountain Products about it and they shipped the correct size the next day. Great company, great product.Highly recommended
This works. It's a flat rubber stopper, and appears as well made as these things usually are.If you need this, you'll know, and this is the one you want.
Way easier to pack and travel with given TSA restrictions on liquids. The taste is pretty strongly that of baking soda, with a little cinnamon, but it isn't bad.Recommended
It's cheaper than the brand name stuff, and it works. Leica is a bit crazy with pricing, so something simple like this, it makes sense not to pay five times more to get the "Leica" name on it.

I speak only a little French, but the infectious cheer in this album does not require translation. It is possible to hear the smile on her face while singing. It is a collection of covers of older French songs (with one original composition), the whole produced by Quincy Jones. The gradual transition from small ensemble sound in her earlier album "Zaz" to big band sound feels natural, and like Edith Piaf, to whom she is frequently compared, she handles the transition and material well. Also new in this album is the presence of several duets, with Thomas Dutronc, Charles Aznavour and Nikki Yanofsky. Zaz's voice and style is still present, however, and she has made excellent choices in her collaborators.Some of these songs were written during the occupation of Paris by German forces during WWII, and some of the press surrounding this album has been negative for that reason, saying it minimizes the suffering of the time. My own take is that, with lines like "Plus on réduit son éclairage /Plus on voit briller son courage...Paris sera toujours Paris" (The more you subdue her lights/ The more you see her courage shine...Paris will always be Paris) it demonstrates the refusal of the Parisians to let the hardship keep them down.It is exciting to watch a really talented artist develop her craft like this, and while the sound on this album is not the intimate, minimalist, street singer style that initially drew me to her music, it's still great listening.Highly recommended.

Size and shape are exactly as pictured, but I found this scent to be too sweet, more like "Balsam, Cedar, and Sugar". Your mileage may vary, and that's the risk of buying a scented candle online, I guess.Recommended if you like powerfully sweet smells.

I bought a pair of these as a third year medical student, and wore them almost every day through the next eight years of medical training. That pair finally died, and this is my second. They are absolutely the most comfortable shoes I've ever worn, and a price that works out to less than twenty dollars per year, they are an incredible deal. Walking in them takes a bit of practice to avoid twisting your ankle, but once you do, it's incredible.The advice I got for fit was to buy a half size too large, at least. If you can shove your toes as far forward as they'll go without bending and fit a single finger behind your heel, you have the right size. Any tighter won't breathe as effectively. Looser will slide too much.As with any shoe, your mileage may vary, and fit is a personal thing. But if you work in a field that involves lots of standing or walking, you should give these a shot.Highly recommended.

This is a fantastic boomerang. In my hands it covers a roughly circular path about 40 yards across and returns exactly to the thrower's position, where it hovers and drops. It has a good hover, stays aloft over my head for 1-3 seconds, and the large center opening makes it easy to catch. It takes a bit of effort to learn, and you have to throw it pretty hard, but it I have the space, this is my favorite boomerang.
Just a fun song, happy, upbeat, decent lyrics, and an infectious tune. Give it a listen if you need to smile today.Highly recommended

These are great: firm, intact, well packed anchovies. I have tried the salt-packed, bone-in and skin-on versions as well, and I don't notice much of a difference, except in price. These are about twice as expensive as salt-packed, but the reduced hassle of using these might make that cost worthwhile to you. Regardless, these are cheaper here than buying them in a local store for me.The flavor, if you've never tried anchovies, is savory and buttery, not an overpowering "fish" flavor, especially cooked in sauces. Try them, you might be surprised.Highly recommended

These are the sardines that convinced me sardines were worth eating. The flavor is fantastic, and even if the flavor of the version with the bone in and skin on is slightly better, I prefer these just for ease of eating. Heart healthy, with a fantastic supply of omega-3s, eat a can a day.Highly recommended.

These are exactly what I was looking for after reading Alice Waters' The Art of Simple Food. In that book she recommends these salt-packed anchovies for numerous recipes. And I have to say, after using them I can see why, though I will admit I don't notice a huge difference in flavor between these and the other anchovies I was buying, other than the cost, which works out about half as expensive for this bulk purchase. The hassle of soaking, then deboning these fillets may make the boned version the right choice for your kitchen.The flavor, if you've never tried anchovies at all, is buttery and savory, and not an overpowering "fish" flavor. It's fantastic and I highly recommend you experiment with them at least a few times.Highly recommended.
I love these noodles. Basic penne, I've been using them for years, and now I'm quite pleased to see them in the PrimePantry options, as the price here is half of that at my local grocery store.

This product does not work for bat repelling. I placed one in my small attic close to where the bats were entering and exiting my house, set it to the "bat" setting, and three weeks later they are still up there, clearly not bothered by the sound. I have not tested it for any other creatures, which is why I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and two stars.Not recommended for bat control.

Certainly a timely and topical exploration of the difficulties inherent to intelligence gathering in the modern era. The premise is that intelligence is largely a technological pursuit in this era, and recruiting intelligence assets from a generation raised with open source ideals, which grew up with Napster, bittorrent and Wikileaks, is going to to be extremely difficult.  Furthermore, the conflicting loyalties an agent feels now are in ways very different, and in other ways much the same, that agents felt in the Cold War.I loved the premise, and for about 50% of the book I loved the development. But where this could have been a fantastic exploration of an important idea, the last half of the book felt like it was written by an autopilot going for a happily-ever-after ending. The kind of book that is great to discuss, but in which that discussion is more focused on ideas than characters.Recommended.
